20.caption: Bland spindle cells in myxoid stroma with plexiform capillaries indicate pure myxoid liposarcoma. Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma shows perivascular hypercellularity. High-grade round cell type has minimal adipocytic differentiation.

C, In high-grade “round cell” liposarcoma, adipocytic differentiation can be minimal.

58.caption: Giant cell tumor: A. High-power shows spindled/ovoid cells + multinucleated giant cells, eosinophilic cytoplasm, oval nuclei. B. Low-power: dense cellularity + peripheral ossification. C. Low-power: infarct-type necrosis. D/E. High-power: osteoid foci.
58.original_caption: Microscopic appearance of giant cell tumor. A, High-power view showing sheets of spindled or ovoid cells interspersed with multinucleated giant cells. Both cell populations have eosinophilic cytoplasm and the same fairly regular, oval nuclei with a distinct membrane and one or two small nucleoli. Note large numbers of nuclei in some of the giant cells. B, Low-power view showing dense cellularity and peripheral ossification. C, Low-power view of an area of infarct-type necrosis. D, e, High-power views of small foci of osteoid production within the tumor.

47.caption: Endochondral ossification differs from cartilage tumor permeative growth. A: Enchondroma shows gradual cartilage-to-lamellar bone transformation conforming to lobule shape. B: Chondrosarcoma permeation features single cartilage mass entrapping host bone with abrupt bone-cartilage transition.
47.original_caption: endochondral ossification should not be confused with permeative growth of cartilage tumors. A, endochondral ossification in an enchondroma is a gradual transformation from cartilage to lamellar bone that conforms to the shape of the cartilage lobule. B, permeation of a chondrosarcoma characterized by a single mass of cartilage that entraps host lamellar bone with an abrupt transition between bone and cartilage.

79.caption: Ewing sarcoma: large blue nuclei, amphophilic cytoplasm, some darker condensed nuclei (early apoptosis). Tumor cells vary from clear to amphophilic cytoplasm; round nuclei, fine chromatin, some condensed (apoptosis). Monotonous nuclei, alveolar arrangement, delicate vasculature. Nonapoptotic cells: single, inconspicuous nucleoli; no mitoses, poor cellular demarc
79.original_caption: A, Ewing sarcoma at high magnification demonstrates prominent large blue nuclei with amphophilic cytoplasm. Note that a few nuclei at the periphery appear darker and more condensed; this may be because of early apoptosis. B, Ewing sarcoma. A different high-power field demonstrates tumor cells with clear to amphophilic cytoplasm. A population of cells with round nuclei and finely divided chromatin and a subpopulation of cells with condensed chromatin that may be undergoing apoptosis are present. C, Ewing sarcoma. Another high-power field demonstrates monotonous and uniformly appearing nuclei with solid groupings of viable tumor cells in an alveolar arrangement created by delicate vasculature. D, Ewing sarcoma. A very-high-power photograph demonstrates that in the nonapoptotic tumor cells, nucleoli, when present, are single and not prominent. Note the lack of mitotic activity and poor cellular demarcations.

80.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumors show adipocyte size variation & nuclear atypia. Stromal cell nuclear atypia is diagnostic. Scattered hyperchromatic stromal cells in fibrillary background indicate well-differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma. Inflammatory liposarcoma requires identification of obscured lipogenic areas. Neural-like spindle cell proliferation in fibrous background suggests spindle cell liposarcoma. Multivacuolated
80.original_caption: A, Atypical lipomatous tumors can be recognized on the basis of variation in adipocyte cell size and nuclear atypia. B, Nuclear atypia in stromal cells is a key diagnostic clue in atypical lipomatous tumors. C, The presence of scattered hyperchromatic stromal cell set in fibrillary background and associated with an atypical lipomatous component represents the hallmark of well-differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma. D, In well-differentiated inflammatory liposarcoma, it is important to identify lipogenic areas that can be obscured by the presence of the inflammatory infiltrate. E, The presence of a neural-like spindle cell proliferation set in a fibrous background and associated with an atypical lipomatous component represents the typical morphologic picture of spindle cell liposarcoma. A multivacuolated lipoblast is seen.

81.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumors show adipocyte size variation & nuclear atypia. Stromal cell nuclear atypia is diagnostic. Neural-like spindle cell proliferation in fibrous background suggests spindle cell liposarcoma. Multivacuolated lipoblast
81.original_caption: A, Atypical lipomatous tumors can be recognized on the basis of variation in adipocyte cell size and nuclear atypia. B, Nuclear atypia in stromal cells is a key diagnostic clue in atypical lipomatous tumors. C, The presence of scattered hyperchromatic stromal cell set in fibrillary background and associated with an atypical lipomatous component represents the hallmark of well-differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma. D, In well-differentiated inflammatory liposarcoma, it is important to identify lipogenic areas that can be obscured by the presence of the inflammatory infiltrate. E, The presence of a neural-like spindle cell proliferation set in a fibrous background and associated with an atypical lipomatous component represents the typical morphologic picture of spindle cell liposarcoma. A multivacuolated lipoblast is seen.

87.caption: Clear cell chondrosarcoma has delicate osteoid trabeculae and multinucleated giant cells.
87.original_caption: Clear cell chondrosarcoma typically contains delicate trabeculae of osteoid and multinucleated giant cells.

85.caption: Retroperitoneal leiomyoma with cord-like pattern.
85.original_caption: Cord-like pattern in leiomyoma of the retroperitoneum.

88.caption: Clear cell chondrosarcoma cells have pale/clear cytoplasm, well-defined nuclear membranes, central round/ovoid nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Nuclear atypia usually mild.
88.original_caption: The cells of clear cell chondrosarcoma show ample pale to clear cytoplasm, well-defined nuclear membranes, and centrally placed round to ovoid nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Nuclear atypia is typically not marked.

86.caption: Grade 3 chondrosarcoma shows hypercellularity, pleomorphic chondrocytes with nuclear hyperchromasia, irregular membranes, necrosis. Mitotic activity present, may be rare in grade 3.
86.original_caption: Grade 3 chondrosarcoma demonstrates diffuse hypercellularity, pleomorphic chondrocytes with nuclear hyperchromasia, irregular nuclear membranes, and necrosis. Mitotic activity is present in this case, but mitoses may be rare even in grade 3 tumors.

93.caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma (inflammatory MFH variant). Inflammatory infiltrate predominantly eosinophils.
93.original_caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma with prominent inflammation (inflammatory variant of malignant fibrous histiocytoma). The inflammatory infiltrate consists predominantly of eosinophils.

91.caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma (inflammatory MFH variant). Rare tumor cells obscured by lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.
91.original_caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma with prominent inflammation (inflammatory variant of malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Malignant tumor cells are rare, masked by a prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.

90.caption: Grade 2 chondrosarcoma shows increased cellularity, cytologic atypia (visible nuclear detail). Permeation of viable lamellar bone present.
90.original_caption: Grade 2 chondrosarcoma is visible with increased cellularity and cytologic atypia (note nuclear detail is visible even at intermediate magnification). permeation of viable lamellar bone is also present on the right.

96.caption: Thrombosed, fibrin-filled vessels in pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor.
96.original_caption: thrombosed, fibrin-filled vessels in pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor.

94.caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor, sheet-like pleomorphic cells, rare intranuclear pseudoinclusions, abundant intracytoplasmic hemosiderin.
94.original_caption: pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor, with a sheet-like proliferation of pleomorphic cells with rare intranuclear pseudoinclusions and abundant intracytoplasmic hemosiderin.

92.caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma (giant cell variant). Contains spindle/pleomorphic cells and osteoclast-like giant cells.
92.original_caption: Undifferentiated high-grade pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell variant of malignant fibrous histiocytoma). In addition to spindle and pleomorphic cells, the tumor contains numerous benign-looking osteoclast-like giant cells

95.caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumors show dilated, thrombosed, thick/thin-walled vessels with hemosiderin staining in surrounding cells.
95.original_caption: at low power, pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumors are most notable for large congeries of dilated, thrombosed, thick- and thin-walled blood vessels. Note prominent hemosiderin staining in surrounding cells.

97.caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor (PHAT) periphery shows spindle cell proliferation (early PHAT), surrounding/damaging small vessels, leading to classic PHAT.
97.original_caption: the periphery of pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor (phat) often shows a distinctive spindle cell proliferation, descriptively termed early PHAT. these spindled cells appear to surround and damage small vessels, a phenomenon that likely leads to the development of classic phat over time.

89.caption: Grade 1 chondrosarcoma: mildly ↑cellularity, minimal atypia vs normal cartilage. Morphology overlaps enchondroma.
89.original_caption: Grade 1 chondrosarcoma shows only mildly increased cellularity and minimal atypia compared with normal cartilage. the morphology overlaps substantially with enchondroma.

102.original_caption: Intra-abdominal desmoid tumor. Proliferating myofibroblasts with bland, vesicular nuclei containing one or two small nucleoli.

108.caption: Osteoblastoma with hemorrhagic cystic component.
108.original_caption: Osteoblastoma with large hemorrhagic cystic component.

105.caption: Aggressive osteoblastoma with epithelioid osteoblasts and coarse lace-like bone.
105.original_caption: So-called aggressive osteoblastoma composed of epithelioid osteoblasts associated with coarse lace-like bone.

106.caption: Pseudomalignant osteoblastoma. Osteoblasts and stromal cells show degenerative nuclear atypia.
106.original_caption: Pseudomalignant osteoblastoma. Osteoblasts and some stromal cells demonstrate marked degenerative nuclear atypia.

112.original_caption: A, B, Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath, lobulated and composed of an admixture of osteoclast-type giant cells and mononuclear cells in a collagenous stroma.

110.caption: Xanthoma: foamy histiocytes.
110.original_caption: Xanthoma. The lesion is composed predominantly of foamy histiocytes.

114.caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath with extensive sclerosis.
114.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath showing extensive sclerosis.

115.caption: Pigmented villonodular synovitis. Desmin IHC shows numerous positive cells.
115.original_caption: Pigmented villonodular synovitis. Immunohistochemical stain for desmin shows numerous positive cells.

116.caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath. Hemosiderin deposition in mononuclear cells, peripherally in cytoplasm.
116.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath. Hemosiderin deposition is seen in the mononuclear cells often peripherally in the cytoplasm.

128.original_caption: A, Histologic appearance of central, cellular schwannoma: fascicular growth pattern, only Antoni A, lack of Verocay bodies, and lack of Antoni B, as well as distinctive pericapsular lymphocytic cuffing (B) unlike classic schwannoma. 129.caption: Central cellular schwannoma: fascicular growth, Antoni A only, no Verocay bodies, no Antoni B, pericapsular lymphocytic cuffing. Foam cells mainly in cellular schwannoma.

133.original_caption: Abrupt transition between small blue cell tumor and an island of hyaline cartilage.

134.caption: Hibernoma brown fat cell cytoplasm ranges pale to intensely eosinophilic.
134.original_caption: The cytoplasm of brown fat cells of hibernoma may vary from pale to intensely eosinophilic.

135.caption: Leiomyoma with bland spindled cells, blunt-ended nuclei, cytoplasmic vacuolation.
135.original_caption: Leiomyoma composed of fascicles of bland spindled cells with blunt-ended nuclei and cytoplasmic vacuolation.

137.caption: CD31 immunostaining is sensitive/specific for endothelial cells, aids in diagnosing high-grade angiosarcomas.
137.original_caption: CD31 immunostaining is a relatively sensitive and specific marker for endothelial cells, and is useful in the diagnosis of high-grade angiosarcomas.

138.caption: CD34+ in most angiosarcomas, variable in epithelioid type.
138.original_caption: CD34 immunostaining is positive in most angiosarcomas but may be variable such as in this epithelioid angiosarcoma.

139.caption: Epithelioid angiosarcoma (grade 3) shows sheets of pleomorphic cells with atypical mitoses. Vasoformative pattern may be absent, mimicking other high-grade malignancies.
139.original_caption: Epithelioid angiosarcoma (by definition grade 3) is composed of sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with atypical mitotic figures. A vasoformative growth pattern may not be obvious, raising the differential of other highgrade malignancies.

140.caption: Grade 3 angiosarcoma shows marked cytologic atypia with cells lining vascular spaces.
140.original_caption: Grade 3 angiosarcoma demonstrates more marked cytologic atypia with at least some cells lining vascular spaces.

141.caption: Grade 1 angiosarcoma shows mild cytologic atypia. Mitotic activity may be low.
141.original_caption: Grade 1 angiosarcoma typically shows only mild cytologic atypia. Mitotic activity, though present in this case, may be relatively low.

143.caption: Adult rhabdomyoma. Polygonal tumor cells with eosinophilic-granular cytoplasm.
143.original_caption: Adult rhabdomyoma. Tumor consists of polygonal tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic-to-granular cytoplasm.

142.caption: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor with single nodule of mononuclear cells.
142.original_caption: Some plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumors may consist largely of either fibroblastic or mononuclear elements. This example showed only a single nodule of mononuclear cells.

144.caption: Whole-mount specimen 11-6 shows central cartilage and peripheral bone.
144.original_caption: A whole-mount view of the specimen from 11-6 demonstrating central cartilage and peripheral bone.

145.caption: Plump spindle cells, woven bone spicules, morphologically similar to myositis ossificans; no skeletal muscle fibers.
145.original_caption: Plump spindle cells and spicules of woven bone, morphologically similar to myositis ossificans; however, note the absence of skeletal muscle fibers.

146.caption: Coarse, irregular neoplastic osteoid outlines pleomorphic sarcoma cells in lace-like pattern.
146.original_caption: Coarse, irregular neoplastic osteoid outlines highly pleomorphic sarcoma cells in a typical lace-like manner.

147.caption: Aneurysmal bone cyst: A) Variably sized spaces with fibrous membranes/bone shell. B) Reactive bone/fibrous tissue separates lesion. C) Numerous osteoclast-like giant cells. D) Reactive trabeculae with osteoblasts parallel to membranes. E) Linear immature osteoid parallel to membrane. F) Fibrochondroid stroma with irregular calcification (
147.original_caption: Aneurysmal bone cyst. A, At low power, multiple variably sized spaces are present, traversed by thin fibrous membranes with a peripheral shell of bone. B, The lesion is separated from the surrounding muscle by a layer of reactive bone, which, in turn, is covered by a layer of fibrous tissue. C, At high power, osteoclast-like giant cells are often numerous. D, Reactive bony trabeculae bordered by plump osteoblasts are common and usually arranged parallel to the surface of the membranes. E, Immature osteoid with a linear arrangement is frequent, again organized parallel to the membrane surface, sometimes having a buckled appearance. F, Irregular calcification within stroma that has a fibrochondroid and basophilic blue appearance is frequently seen and considered to be characteristic of aneurysmal bone cyst. G, Calcification of this immature fibrochondroid material may be prominent. H, In solid aneurysmal bone cyst/giant cell reparative granuloma, clusters of osteoclast-like giant cells with hemorrhage are frequently seen within a fibrohistiocytic stroma. Small spaces with osteoclasts are frequent. I, Intermingled trabeculae of reactive bone bordered by plump osteoblasts are evident

154.caption: Aneurysmal bone cyst: A) Variably sized spaces with fibrous membranes/bone shell. B) Reactive bone/fibrous tissue separates lesion. C) Numerous osteoclast-like giant cells. D) Reactive trabeculae with osteoblasts parallel to membranes. E) Immature osteoid parallel to membrane. F) Fibrochondroid stroma with calcification (character
154.original_caption: Aneurysmal bone cyst. A, At low power, multiple variably sized spaces are present, traversed by thin fibrous membranes with a peripheral shell of bone. B, The lesion is separated from the surrounding muscle by a layer of reactive bone, which, in turn, is covered by a layer of fibrous tissue. C, At high power, osteoclast-like giant cells are often numerous. D, Reactive bony trabeculae bordered by plump osteoblasts are common and usually arranged parallel to the surface of the membranes. E, Immature osteoid with a linear arrangement is frequent, again organized parallel to the membrane surface, sometimes having a buckled appearance. F, Irregular calcification within stroma that has a fibrochondroid and basophilic blue appearance is frequently seen and considered to be characteristic of aneurysmal bone cyst. G, Calcification of this immature fibrochondroid material may be prominent. H, In solid aneurysmal bone cyst/giant cell reparative granuloma, clusters of osteoclast-like giant cells with hemorrhage are frequently seen within a fibrohistiocytic stroma. Small spaces with osteoclasts are frequent. I, Intermingled trabeculae of reactive bone bordered by plump osteoblasts are evident

250.caption: Low-power: Ewing sarcoma shows blue nuclei sea, pink areas = necrosis. Medium power: tumor cells permeate Haversian canals. Low power: tumor invades intertrabecular spaces, displaces marrow fat.
250.original_caption: A, At low-power magnification, Ewing sarcoma appears to be a sea of blue nuclei. The pink areas correspond to spontaneous necrosis. B, At medium power, the permeation of preexisting Haversian canals by the tumor cells is easily appreciated. C, At low power, the permeation of intertrabecular spaces with displacement of normal marrow fat demonstrates the local invasive potential of the tumor.

B, At medium power, the permeation of preexisting Haversian canals by the tumor cells is easily appreciated. C, At low power, the permeation of intertrabecular spaces with displacement of normal marrow fat demonstrates the local invasive potential of the tumor.

253.original_caption: Benign fibrous histiocytoma. Storiform arrangement of tumor cells.

257.caption: Clear cell sarcoma shows stronger, more diffuse HMB45 staining (A,C) than S-100 (B,D), opposite to malignant melanoma.
257.original_caption: Helpful to separate clear cell sarcoma from malignant melanoma is that the HMB45 (A, C) is always stronger and more diffuse than the S-100 protein staining (B, D) in clear cell sarcoma, whereas the reverse is true for malignant melanoma.

261.caption: Lobulation is a key low-power feature of lipoblastoma. Myxoid background and plexiform vascular network may overlap with myxoid liposarcoma.
261.original_caption: A, Lobulation is one of the distinctive low-power features of lipoblastoma. B, Myxoid background and plexiform vascular network may cause morphologic overlap with myxoid liposarcoma.

262.caption: Lobulation is a key low-power feature of lipoblastoma. Myxoid background and plexiform vascular network may overlap with myxoid liposarcoma.
262.original_caption: A, Lobulation is one of the distinctive low-power features of lipoblastoma. B, Myxoid background and plexiform vascular network may cause morphologic overlap with myxoid liposarcoma.

263.caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Hypocellular, collagenous tumor with clefting/pseudovascular spaces.
263.original_caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Low-power view shows that the tumor is hypocellular and collagenous with clefting or pseudovascular spaces.

264.caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Bland spindle/stellate cells in collagenous matrix.
264.original_caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. High-power view shows bland spindle and stellate cells embedded in abundant extracellular collagenous matrix.

265.caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone: spindle cells in herringbone pattern.
265.original_caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone. Lesions consist of a cellular population of spindle cells that often assumes a herringbone pattern.

266.caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone. Spindle cells show mild nuclear atypia.
266.original_caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone. The spindle cells usually show mild nuclear atypia.

267.caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone. Low-grade lesions collagenized. Spindle cells show mild nuclear atypia.
267.original_caption: Fibrosarcoma of bone. Some low-grade lesions are heavily collagenized. The spindle cells, however, show some mild nuclear atypia.

268.caption: Malignant fibrous histiocytoma. Pleomorphic spindle cells in storiform pattern.
268.original_caption: Malignant fibrous histiocytoma. Most commonly, lesions show pleomorphic, spindle cells in a storiform pattern.

269.caption: Malignant fibrous histiocytoma. Histiocytic-like pattern with bizarre round cells and pleomorphic nuclei.
269.original_caption: Malignant fibrous histiocytoma. Other lesions show a predominately histiocytic-like pattern with bizarre round cells and highly pleomorphic nuclei.

270.caption: Osteoma with woven and lamellar bone in cortical pattern.
270.original_caption: Osteoma composed of an admixture of woven and lamellar bone deposited in a cortical-type pattern.

271.caption: Bone island with cortical-type bone merging with surrounding trabeculae.
271.original_caption: Bone island composed of cortical-type bone merging with the surrounding bony trabeculae.

272.caption: Osteoid osteoma with woven bone trabeculae lined by osteoblasts, vascular loose connective tissue.
272.original_caption: Osteoid osteoma composed of haphazardly interconnecting trabeculae of woven bone that are lined prominently by osteoblasts. The intervening loose connective tissue is vascular.

273.caption: Osteoblastoma with well-circumscribed margin.
273.original_caption: Osteoblastoma with well-circumscribed margin from the surrounding bone.

274.caption: Osteoblastoma trabeculae rimmed by osteoblasts.
274.original_caption: Interanastomosing trabeculae of osteoblastoma are rimmed by osteoblasts.

275.caption: Ewing sarcoma/PNET: lobular to sheetlike proliferation of uniform small blue round cells.
275.original_caption: ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, showing a vaguely lobular to sheetlike proliferation of uniform small blue round cells.

276.caption: Ewing sarcoma/PNET cells: regular, scant clear/eosinophilic cytoplasm, finely dispersed chromatin, small nucleoli.
276.original_caption: the cells of ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor are typically regular, with small amounts of clear to lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, finely dispersed chromatic, and small nucleoli.

277.caption: Capillary hemangioma with thrombosis and papillary endothelial hyperplasia, a secondary change in vascular tumors.
277.original_caption: Capillary hemangioma with superimposed thrombosis and papillary endothelial hyperplasia. papillary endothelial hyperplasia may occur as a secondary change in any type of vascular tumor.

278.caption: Organized papillary endothelial hyperplasia in hemangioma, sinusoidal pattern.
278.original_caption: Organized papillary endothelial hyperplasia within a hemangioma, creating a sinusoidal pattern.

279.caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia: benign endothelial cell proliferation in organizing thrombus.
279.original_caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia showing a cellular proliferation of benign endothelial cells within an organizing thrombus.

280.caption: High-power view of papillary endothelial hyperplasia. Bland endothelial cytology, no endothelial stratification.
280.original_caption: high-power view of papillary endothelial hyperplasia. Note the bland cytologic features of the endothelial cells and the absence of endothelial cell stratification.

281.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor: hyalinized collagen, cracking artifact, patternless growth.
281.original_caption: Solitary fibrous tumor of soft tissue with hyalinized collagen, cracking artifact, and patternless growth.

282.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor with multinucleated tumor giant cells (giant cell angiofibroma).
282.original_caption: Solitary fibrous tumor with multinucleated tumor giant cells (so-called giant cell angiofibroma).

283.caption: Lipomatous hemangiopericytoma/solitary fibrous tumor with mature fat.
283.original_caption: Lipomatous hemangiopericytoma/solitary fibrous tumor with mature fat.

284.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor (hemangiopericytoma) with branching hyalinized vasculature, surrounded by ovoid-spindled cells.
284.original_caption: Cellular zone in solitary fibrous tumor (hemangiopericytoma) with a prominent branching, hyalinized vasculature, surrounded by bland ovoid-to-spindled cells.

285.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor with hypocellular/collagenized and hypercellular zones, thick-walled vessels.
285.original_caption: Classic solitary fibrous tumor of soft tissues showing alternating hypocellular/collagenized and hypercellular zones, with thick-walled vessels.

286.caption: solitary fibrous tumor/hemangiopericytoma cellular zones show moderately cellular proliferation of short spindled cells in patternless arrangement.
286.original_caption: the more cellular zones of solitary fibrous tumor/hemangiopericytoma typically consist of a moderately cellular proliferation of short spindled cells, arranged in a patternless pattern.

287.caption: GIST with palisading, mimics schwannoma. S-100 IHC negative helps differentiate.
287.original_caption: gastrointestinal stromal tumor (giST) with prominent palisading. Many GISTs exhibit extensive palisading and can mimic schwannoma. Immunohistochemistry for S-100 protein is useful in distinguishing GIST from schwannoma because it fails to exhibit immunoreactivity for S-100 protein.

288.caption: GIST with skeinoid fibers, prominent acellular collagen bundles.
288.original_caption: Skeinoid fibers in gastrointestinal stromal tumor (giST). Some GISts contain acellular collagen bundles known as skeinoid fibers, which are particularly prominent in this unusual example.

290.caption: GIST cytology. FNA smear: hypercellular monomorphic spindle cells, fibrillary cytoplasm, rare mitoses.
290.original_caption: Cytology of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) smear. This smear from an FNA of a gastric lesion consists of a hypercellular proliferation of monomorphic spindle cells with fibrillary cytoplasm and a relative paucity of mitotic figures.

289.caption: KiT(CD117) positive in 95% of GISTs, typically diffuse/strong. Mast cells (right) serve as internal control, adjacent to GISTs and KIT-positive.
289.original_caption: KiT(CD117) staining in gastrointestinal stromal tumor (giST). KIT (CD117) is positive in approximately 95% of GISTs. Most GISTs are diffusely and strongly positive for KIT. Note the isolated mast cells on the right side of the figure. These serve as an excellent internal immunohistochemical control because mast cells are usually found adjacent to most GISTs and are invariably positive for KIT.

291.caption: Juxta-articular/cellular myxomas show small typical myxoma areas with cystic change.
291.original_caption: Careful inspection of juxta-articular myxomas, and other cellular myxomas, will invariably reveal small areas of more typical myxoma, with cystic change.

292.caption: Cutaneous myxoma (angiomyxoma), vascularized myxoid skin/subcutis tumor.
292.original_caption: Cutaneous myxoma (angiomyxoma), a highly vascularized myxoid tumor of the skin and subcutis.

293.caption: Juxta-articular myxomas are more cellular/vascular than other myxomas, may mimic myxoid sarcomas.
293.original_caption: Juxta-articular myxomas are frequently more cellular and vascular than are other myxomas, and may mimic various myxoid sarcomas.

294.caption: Fascicular cellular growth in juxta-articular myxoma.
294.original_caption: Fascicular, cellular growth in juxta-articular myxoma.

295.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma nodule, Kaposi sarcoma-like spindled cells, small capillaries.
295.original_caption: Nodule of kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, showing Kaposi sarcoma  like spindled cells and better formed small capillaries.

296.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma: large infiltrative dermal/subcutaneous mass in young child.
296.original_caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma: a large, infiltrative, dermal and subcutaneous mass in a very young child.

297.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma: stromal fibrosis, crescentic vascular spaces, spindled endothelial proliferation.
297.original_caption: Stromal fibrosis, crescentic vascular spaces, and spindled endothelial proliferation in kaposiform hemangioendothelioma.

298.caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma: tumor cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli.
298.original_caption: tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli in alveolar soft part sarcoma.

299.original_caption: alveolar soft part sarcoma with hemorrhage and prominent nested growth.

300.caption: Malignant solitary fibrous tumor: transition from typical to hypercellular nodules. High-power shows mitotically active, malignant round-to-spindled cells.
300.original_caption: A, Low-power view of a malignant solitary fibrous tumor of soft tissue showing a clear transition from typical solitary fibrous tumor to much more cellular nodules. B, higher-power examination of the cellular nodules shows mitotically active, malignant-appearing, round-to-spindled cells.

301.caption: Malignant solitary fibrous tumor: transition from typical to cellular nodules. High-power shows mitotically active, malignant round-to-spindled cells.
301.original_caption: A, Low-power view of a malignant solitary fibrous tumor of soft tissue showing a clear transition from typical solitary fibrous tumor to much more cellular nodules. B, higher-power examination of the cellular nodules shows mitotically active, malignant-appearing, round-to-spindled cells.

302.original_caption: Solitary fibrous tumor, positive for CD34.

304.caption: Intramuscular hemangioma with abnormal vascular channel aggregates.
304.original_caption: abnormal aggregates of vascular channels of different types in intramuscular hemangioma.

305.caption: Intramuscular hemangioma (vascular malformation), abundant mature adipose tissue, abnormal vascular channels resembling arteries, veins, cavernous hemangioma.
305.original_caption: Intramuscular hemangioma (vascular malformation), with abundant mature adipose tissue, and numerous abnormal vascular channels, resembling arteries, veins, and cavernous hemangioma.

306.caption: Nuclear expression of HHV-8 LANA in Kaposi sarcoma, specific among vascular tumors.
306.original_caption: Nuclear expression of human herpes virus 8 latency-associated nuclear antigen (LaNa) protein in Kaposi sarcoma. this finding is specific for Kaposi sarcoma, among vascular tumors.

307.caption: Uniform cell spacing, bland cytology, amitotic round-ovoid cells, fibromyxoid matrix in ossifying fibromyxoid tumor.
307.original_caption: Uniform cell-cell spacing, cytologically bland, amitotic round to ovoid cells, and fibromyxoid matrix in ossifying fibromyxoid tumor.

308.original_caption: Area of transition from typical to malignant ossifying fibromyxoid tumor. Note retention of the bone shell and maintenance of the overall cyto architectural pattern in the much more cellular malignant zone.

309.original_caption: typical ossifying fibromyxoid tumor of soft parts, with a peripheral shell of bone surrounding a lobulated, moderately cellular proliferation of uniform cells in a fibromyxoid background.

310.caption: Cutaneous myxoma cells normochromatic, distinguishing from myxofibrosarcomas. Stromal neutrophils present.
310.original_caption: the cells of cutaneous myxoma are uniformly normochromatic, assisting in its distinction from superficially located myxofibrosarcomas. Note also the presence of stromal neutrophils, a useful clue.

311.original_caption: A, Diffuse neurofibroma involving dermis and subcutis, with honeycomb pattern of subcutis infiltration (B). Hallmark Wagner-Meissner bodies (B, C) are positive for S-100 protein (D).

324.original_caption: Whether clear, eosinophilic, epithelioid, or spindled, clear cell sarcoma always has large eosinophilic prominent nucleoli (A-D).

365.caption: Spindle cell lipoma: eosinophilic collagen, bland spindle cells, mature adipocytes. Myxoid change mimics myxoid liposarcoma. Cellular variants show minimal adipocytes. Floret-like giant cells typical in spindle/pleomorphic lipoma.
365.original_caption: A, Eosinophilic coarse collagen bundles, bland spindle cells, and mature adipocytes are the main components of spindle cell lipoma. B, Myxoid change in spindle cell lipoma may lead to diagnostic confusion with myxoid liposarcoma. C, In cellular variants of spindle cell lipoma, the adipocytic component can be minimal. D, Floret-like multinucleated giant cell represents a typical feature of spindle cell and pleomorphic lipoma.

407.caption: Osteofibrous dysplasia with cytokeratin-positive stromal cells.

408.caption: Fibrous dysplasia. A: Bony trabeculae show curvilinear branching (Chinese characters/hockey stick shapes) in fibrous stroma. B: Immature woven bone trabeculae lack osteoblasts, in whorled fibrous stroma. C: Immature bone merges with mature cortex; thick trabeculae in craniofacial skeleton. D: Occasional cementoid
408.original_caption: Fibrous dysplasia. A, Low-power view shows bony trabeculae with a curvilinear branching appearance, so-called Chinese characters, hockey stick, or C, S, and Y shapes, within a fibrous stroma. B, At higher power, trabeculae of immature woven bone are devoid of a plump lining osteoblast layer and lie within a fibrous stroma comprising bland stromal cells arranged in a whorled or storiform manner. C, Trabeculae of immature bone merge with mature cortical bone. The trabeculae are somewhat thick in this example from the craniofacial skeleton. D, Rounded cementoid bodies occur occasionally, most frequently in the craniofacial skeleton. E, At high power, immature bony trabeculae are bordered by somewhat retracted osteoblast/stromal cells and exhibit continuity of collagen fibers between stroma and trabeculae, so-called combed bone or Sharpey’s fibers. F, Polarization microscopy accentuates the woven nature of trabeculae and Sharpey’s fibers. G, Focal fatty change within the stroma may be seen. H, Areas of chondroid metaplasia may occur and may be extensive.

B, At higher power, trabeculae of immature woven bone are devoid of a plump lining osteoblast layer and lie within a fibrous stroma comprising bland stromal cells arranged in a whorled or storiform manner. C, Trabeculae of immature bone merge with mature cortical bone. The trabeculae are somewhat thick in this example from the craniofacial skeleton. D, Rounded cementoid bodies occur occasionally, most frequently in the craniofacial skeleton. E, At high power, immature bony trabeculae are bordered by somewhat retracted osteoblast/stromal cells and exhibit continuity of collagen fibers between stroma and trabeculae, so-called combed bone or Sharpey’s fibers. F, Polarization microscopy accentuates the woven nature of trabeculae and Sharpey’s fibers. G, Focal fatty change within the stroma may be seen. H, Areas of chondroid metaplasia may occur and may be extensive.

416.caption: Osteofibrous dysplasia. A, Central lesion: fibrous tissue, storiform pattern, tiny bone trabeculae. B, Central trabeculae: woven texture, plump osteoblasts. C, Peripheral trabeculae: curvilinear, osteoblasts, osteoclasts; fibrous stroma, stellate. D, Peripheral bone: mature, lamellar. E, Polarization
416.original_caption: Osteofibrous dysplasia. A, At low power, the central portions of the lesion are usually composed predominantly of fibrous tissue, which has a storiform pattern within which an occasional tiny trabecula of bone can be seen. B, Centrally the trabeculae are largely woven in texture lined, in part, by plump osteoblasts. C, Peripherally, bony trabeculae are more numerous and often have a curvilinear architecture, again lined by plump osteoblasts and scattered osteoclasts. The stroma is fibrous with a loose stellate appearance. D, Peripherally, the bone is, in part, mature and lamellar in nature. E, Polarization microscopy accentuates admixed lamellar and woven bone.

445.caption: Palisading encapsulated neuroma (solitary circumscribed neuroma) typically occurs in face/perioral region. Well-delineated, Schwannian appearance at low power. C, At low power it looks Schwannian with palisading of tumor cells. However, it is probably a neurofibroma variant but demonstrates spindled Schwann cells without well-formed Verocay bodies (B D). The lesion has abundant axons like a neurofibroma but is not associated with neurofibromatosis type 1.

Sometimes clear cell sarcoma has a focal epithelioid appearance to tumor cells (B), and in other areas of the tumor it may be more spindled (C).

487.caption: Desmoid tumor. Infiltrative borders invading skeletal muscle.
487.original_caption: Desmoid tumor. Infiltrative borders encroaching on the surrounding skeletal muscle.

497.caption: undifferentiated spindle cell sarcoma transitioning to neoplastic osteoid production
497.original_caption: A transition between an undifferentiated spindle cell sarcoma region of a tumor and an area that demonstrates clear neoplastic osteoid production.

495.caption: Clear cell sarcoma has nests with fibrous septa, clear/eosinophilic cytoplasm (A), and variable epithelioid/spindled tumor cells.

502.caption: Diffuse histiocytic infiltrate in subsynovial connective tissue.

498.caption: Early malignant neurofibroma transformation. A, Cytologic atypia not worrisome. B, Cellularity resembles fibrous histiocytoma but not malignant. C, Fascicular growth, atypical mitoses indicate early malignancy, especially in NF1. These tumors treated as low-grade malignant.
498.original_caption: early malignant transformation of neurofibroma. A, Cytologic atypia by itself is not worrisome. B, Cellularity usually makes neurofibroma resemble the loose storiform pattern of fibrous histiocytoma but is not, by itself, diagnostic of malignant change. C, Fascicular growth and mitoses, especially atypical mitoses (D), are the first signs of early malignant transformation, especially in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). With these latter early changes, the tumors are treated as low-grade malignant.

506.caption: Giant cell fibroblastoma. Multinucleated giant cells lining pseudovascular spaces.
506.original_caption: Giant cell fibroblastoma. Multinucleated giant cells with smudged chromatin lining pseudovascular (angiectid) spaces.

508.caption: Fibrosarcomatous change in DFSP. Increased cellularity & mitotic activity.
508.original_caption: Fibrosarcomatous change in a dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Cellularity and mitotic activity are significantly increased.

500.caption: Early malignant neurofibroma transformation. A, Cytologic atypia not worrisome. B, Cellularity resembles fibrous histiocytoma but not malignant. C, Fascicular growth, atypical mitoses indicate early malignancy, esp. in NF1. These treated as low-grade malignant.

504.caption: Bone lymphomas mostly diffuse large B-cell type. Large round noncleaved nuclei, clumped chromatin, scant cytoplasm.
504.original_caption: Almost all lymphomas of bone are diffuse large B-cell lymphomas. The cells have a large, round, noncleaved nucleus with clumped chromatin. Cytoplasm is scant.

507.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Spindled tumor cells CD34+.
507.original_caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. pindled tumor cells are diffusely positive for CD34.

509.caption: Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma: spindle cell lesion with plump cells, heavy pigmentation obscuring detail. Melanophages present. Psammoma bodies (arrow) are diagnostic.
509.original_caption: A, Typical morphologic appearance of psammomatous melanotic schwannoma: a spindle cell lesion with plump cells and heavy pigmentation obscuring morphologic detail. Melanophages (histiocytes that have engulfed melanin pigment from the tumor) are also present. B, The helpful additional diagnostic feature is the psammoma bodies (arrow).

510.caption: Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma: spindle cells with plump morphology, heavy pigmentation obscuring details. Melanophages present. Psammoma bodies (arrow) aid diagnosis.

Melanophages (histiocytes that have engulfed melanin pigment from the tumor) are also present. B, The helpful additional diagnostic feature is the psammoma bodies (arrow).

515.caption: Biphasic synovial sarcoma, glandular differentiation.
515.original_caption: Biphasic synovial sarcoma, with overt glandular differentiation.

516.caption: Poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma, malignant hemangiopericytoma pattern.
516.original_caption: poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma, showing a malignant hemangiopericytoma growth pattern.

517.caption: Simple bone cyst wall: fibrous membrane, flat lining, bordered by bony trabeculae. Pink cementum-like fibrin material common. Extravasated RBCs, osteoclast-like giant cells suggest fracture.
517.original_caption: A, Histologically, the cyst wall of this simple bone cyst is composed of a fibrous membrane with a flat inconspicuous lining layer, bordered in this instance by bony trabeculae. B, In many simple bone cysts, pink cementum-like material probably representing fibrin can be seen, a characteristic finding. C, Extravasated red cells and scattered osteoclast-like giant cells can be seen, suggestive of associated fracture.

514.caption: Stromal calcification suggests synovial sarcoma in small spindle cell tumors of hands/feet.
514.original_caption: Stromal calcification should always suggest the possibility of synovial sarcoma in a small spindle cell tumor of the hands and feet.

511.caption: Malignant ossifying fibromyxoid tumor: high cellularity, high nuclear grade, brisk mitotic activity.
511.original_caption: Malignant ossifying fibromyxoid tumor, showing high cellularity, high nuclear grade, and brisk mitotic activity.

512.caption: Biphasic synovial sarcoma with occult glandular differentiation. Cytokeratin immunostains aid in detecting small glandular foci.
512.original_caption: Biphasic synovial sarcoma with occult glandular differentiation. Immunostains for cytokeratins may be helpful in identifying small, inapparent foci of glandular differentiation.

513.caption: Monophasic synovial sarcoma, hypercellular/hypocellular areas, long fascicles, wiry collagen, hyperchromatic spindled cells.
513.original_caption: Monophasic synovial sarcoma, with alternating areas of hypercellularity and hypocellularity, moderately long fascicles, wiry collagen, and uniform hyperchromatic spindled cells.

C, Extravasated red cells and scattered osteoclast-like giant cells can be seen, suggestive of associated fracture.

520.caption: Giant notochordal rest. A, single mass amid trabeculae of lamellar bone. B, physaliphorous cells mimic fat necrosis.

526.original_caption: Fibrous hamartoma of infancy, showing a characteristic triphasic pattern, with mature fat, bland fibroblastic fascicles, and nodules of primitive mesenchymal cells.

528.original_caption: 3-13 Hyalinized area within fibrous hamartoma of infancy.

522.original_caption: Bacillary angiomatosis, presenting as an ulcerated dermal nodule composed of blood vessels lined by epithelioid endothelial cells in association with marked acute inflammation.

524.original_caption: Adult sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma (A) with desmin and (B) myogenin expression.

535.original_caption: Nodular growth phase in Kaposi sarcoma.

533.caption: Fibrosarcomatous spindle cells in nodular Kaposi sarcoma.
533.original_caption: Fibrosarcomatous spindle cell proliferation in nodular Kaposi sarcoma.

534.caption: Chronic inflammatory cell aggregates, diagnostic clue for Kaposi sarcoma.
534.original_caption: Chronic inflammatory cell aggregates, a clue to the diagnosis of Kaposi sarcoma.

530.original_caption: Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma, consisting of an ­infiltrative proliferation of bland fibroblastic cells, with abrupt ­cartilaginous differentiation.

536.original_caption: Vaguely myoid-appearing spindled cells forming slit-like vascular spaces in Kaposi sarcoma.

543.original_caption: Myolipoma is composed of mature fat and smooth muscle cells.

547.original_caption: Pilar leiomyosarcoma displaying fascicular architecture and cytologic atypia.

540.caption: Ewing sarcoma with rosette-like tumor cell organization. Low-power view shows Homer Wright rosettes in intramedullary (left) and soft tissue (right). Inset: small cells arranged around neural processes.

549.original_caption: Chondrosarcoma permeates bone as a single, confluent mass entrapping existing bony trabeculae.

541.original_caption: A, Ewing sarcoma demonstrating rosette-like organization of tumor cells. 550.original_caption: Permeation in chondrosarcoma may also extend through the Haversian canals of the cortex.

552.original_caption: Myxoid change in chondrosarcoma results in a paler blue, stringy quality to the matrix.

553.original_caption: Synovial chondromatosis. Multiple cartilaginous nodules involving the subsynovial connective tissue.

557.original_caption: Atypical fibroxanthoma. Low-power view showing a small, well-circumscribed, atypical dermal lesion occurring in association with actinic damage.

555.original_caption: Desmoplastic fibroma of bone. The spindle cells show no atypia, and mitotic figures are extremely rare.

556.original_caption: Atypical fibroxanthoma. Dermal proliferation of spindle-to-giant pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and mitotic figures, including atypical mitoses.

554.original_caption: Desmoplastic fibroma of bone. Bland spindle cells are present in a heavy collagenized matrix.

561.caption: Traumatic neuroma: disorganized axon bundles with fibrosis.
561.original_caption: Traumatic neuroma is composed of bundles of disorganized axons surrounded by fibrosis.

558.caption: Normal nerve has axons with Schwann cells, collagen, capillaries, mast cells in endoneurium. Axon groups form fascicles (B,C) surrounded by perineurium. Multiple fascicles enclosed by epineurium.

569.original_caption: Cellular angiofibroma is closely related to angiomyofibroblastoma but consists of more spindled cells arrayed about thicker, hyalinized blood vessels.

563.caption: Langerhans cell histiocytosis. A, Inflammatory infiltrate in granulation tissue with abundant eosinophils. B, Eosinophils obscure Langerhans cells. C, Langerhans cells show irregular nuclei, poorly demarcated cytoplasm, binucleated forms, eosinophils, neutrophils. D, Langerhans cells have powdery, vacuolated cytoplasm.
563.original_caption: Langerhans cell histiocytosis. A, At low power, an intense inflammatory cell infiltrate is usually lying within loose granulation tissue. Abundant eosinophils are present. B, Eosinophils may obscure the Langerhans cells present in the background. C, At high power, the Langerhans cells have irregular, indented nuclei with somewhat poorly demarcated eosinophilic cytoplasm. A single binucleated form and admixed eosinophils and neutrophils are present. D, Langerhans cells have abundant lightly eosinophilic powdery and lightly vacuolated cytoplasm. E, At the margins of the more cellular area, organizing fibrosis with admixed inflammatory cells is seen extending between and around the adjacent trabeculae. F, Wet fixed smears confirm the presence of numerous irregular nuclear indentations (hematoxylin and eosin).

596.caption: Neuroblastoma immature round cells mature to ganglion cells. Ganglioneuroblastoma subtypes: diffuse, nodular (50% schwannian stroma), then ganglioneuroma (no small round cells).

Depending on the percentage of ganglioneuroma (schwannian stroma), these can be then classified into ganglioneuroblastoma subtypes of diffuse, nodular when the stomal component reaches 50% and then final maturation without small round cells (ganglioneuroma).

613.original_caption: Metaplastic spindle cell carcinoma. A Two aggregates of carcinoma are separated by neoplastic spindle cells. B Immunostaining shows absence of reactivity with a pan-keratin antibody cocktail in the mesenchymal component, while the epithelial cells are positive.

615.caption: Solid papillary carcinoma w/ adjacent invasive NST carcinoma.
615.original_caption: Solid papillary carcinoma with adjacent invasive carcinoma of no special type.

611.caption: B Carcinoma with mesenchymal (osseous) differentiation, well-delineated pushing margin. Osseous/chondroid areas scattered in NST carcinoma. C Adenocarcinoma mixed with chondroid matrix, lacunar spaces, rare chondrocytes.
611.original_caption: B Carcinoma with mesenchymal (osseous) differentiation. Typically, these carcinomas have a well-delineated pushing margin. Areas of osseous and/or chondroid differentiation are variably scattered in an otherwise typical invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST). C The adenocarcinoma is admixed, in part, with chondroid matrix containing lacunar spaces and rare chondrocytes.

612.caption: B Carcinoma with mesenchymal (osseous) differentiation, well-delineated pushing margin. Osseous/chondroid areas scattered in NST carcinoma. C Adenocarcinoma mixed with chondroid matrix, lacunar spaces, rare chondrocytes.

Areas of osseous and/or chondroid differentiation are variably scattered in an otherwise typical invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST). C The adenocarcinoma is admixed, in part, with chondroid matrix containing lacunar spaces and rare chondrocytes.

610.caption: Paget nipple disease. A Nipple epidermis: Paget cells, pale cytoplasm, large irregular nuclei, prominent nucleoli. B HER2+: strong membrane staining. C Glandular Paget: keratin 7+.
610.original_caption: .04 Paget disease of the nipple. A Nipple epidermis containing Paget cells with pale stained cytoplasm and large irregular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. B HER2 immunostaining showing strong positive membrane staining of Paget cells. C Glandular Paget disease showing positive immunostaining for keratin 7.

619.original_caption: .03 Melanoma metastatic to the breast. The spindle cells and intra-nuclear inclusion are clues to the diagnosis.

605.caption: Malignant granular cell tumor: high-grade sarcoma features, pleomorphism, enlarged nucleoli, high N:C ratio, mitoses, necrosis (A-B, better seen elsewhere).
605.original_caption: Malignant granular cell tumor with obvious high-grade sarcoma features: diffuse pleomorphism, diffusely enlarge nucleoli, high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, mitoses, and necrosis (A-B, better demonstrated in other areas of the tumor).

618.caption: Syringomatous nipple tumor: irregular glandular structures amid smooth muscle bundles. Actin immunostaining highlights muscle, tumor unstained.
618.original_caption: .02 Syringomatous tumour of the nipple. A Irregularly shaped glandular structures are present between smooth muscle bundles. B Immunostaining for actin delineates the fascicles of smooth muscle but the syringomatous tumour is unstained.

606.caption: Malignant granular cell tumor: high-grade sarcoma features, pleomorphism, enlarged nucleoli, high N:C ratio, mitoses, necrosis (A-B, better seen elsewhere).
606.original_caption: Malignant granular cell tumor with obvious high-grade sarcoma features: diffuse pleomorphism, diffusely enlarge nucleoli, high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, mitoses, and necrosis (A-B, better demonstrated in other areas of the tumor).

617.caption: Solid papillary carcinoma. Solid epithelial nodules in geographic, jigsaw-like pattern within fibrous desmoplastic stroma, suggesting possible invasion. Fibrovascular cores in solid islands.
617.original_caption: Solid papillary carcinoma. A Solid cellular epithelial nodules arranged in a geographic, jigsaw-like pattern within a fibrous, focally desmoplastic background, suggesting possible invasive disease. B Higher magnification shows fibrovascular cores within some of the solid islands.

621.caption: Mucinous carcinoma. A: Hypercellular variant, dense malignant cell clusters. B: Hypocellular variant, mucus lakes with fibrous septae, scattered carcinoma cells.
621.original_caption: Mucinous carcinoma. A Hypercellular variant with large clusters of densely packed malignant cells. B Hypocellular variant. Lakes of mucus are separated by fibrous septae. A few isolated or clusters of carcinoma cells are floating in the mucus lakes.

622.caption: Mucinous carcinoma. A: Hypercellular variant, dense malignant cell clusters. B: Hypocellular variant, mucus lakes with fibrous septae, scattered carcinoma cells.
622.original_caption: Mucinous carcinoma. A Hypercellular variant with large clusters of densely packed malignant cells. B Hypocellular variant. Lakes of mucus are separated by fibrous septae. A few isolated or clusters of carcinoma cells are floating in the mucus lakes.

620.caption: Phyllodes tumour. A Borderline: stromal cellularity accentuated peri-epithelial. B Malignant: marked stromal pleomorphism. C Malignant: brisk mitotic activity in stroma.
620.original_caption: Phyllodes tumour. A Stromal cellularity is accentuated in the peri-epithelial zones of a borderline phyllodes tumour. B Malignant phyllodes tumour shows marked pleomorphism of stromal cells. C Brisk mitotic activity is observed in the stromal cells of a malignant phyllodes tumour.

616.caption: Solid papillary carcinoma. A: Synaptophysin diffuse positivity. B: Smooth-muscle myosin heavy chain shows absent peripheral myoepithelial lining around nodules, with geographic jigsaw epithelial islands suggesting invasion. C: Larger nests show intact keratin 14+ myoepithelial layer, indicating in situ process.
616.original_caption: Solid papillary carcinoma. A There is diffuse positivity for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry. B Immunohistochemistry for smooth-muscle myosin heavy chain shows complete absence of a peripheral myoepithelial lining around the cellular nodules. Together with the geographic, jigsaw pattern of epithelial islands, this appearance may be considered invasive. C In these larger rounded nests, the myoepithelial cell layer is generally intact, as demonstrated by immunostaining for keratin 14, indicating an in situ process.

623.caption: Combined mucinous & invasive carcinoma NST. Favorable prognosis of pure mucinous lost when mixed with invasive carcinoma NST.
623.original_caption: Combined mucinous and invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST). The favourable prognosis associated with pure mucinous carcinoma is no longer expected when it is admixed with regular invasive carcinoma NST.

625.caption: Myofibroblastoma. IHC: nuclear ER+, mimics invasive lobular carcinoma.
625.original_caption: Myofibroblastoma. Immunohistochemistry shows nuclear positivity for estrogen receptor, and thus potential diagnostic confusion with an invasive lobular carcinoma.

624.caption: Myofibroblastoma. Classic-type: spindle cell fascicles, thick collagen bands. Epithelioid type: plump medium/larger cells, obvious nucleoli, interspersed collagen.
624.original_caption: Myofibroblastoma. A Classic-type myofibroblastoma showing fascicles of spindle cells, interrupted by thick bands of collagen. B Epithelioid cell myofibroblastoma showing plump, medium to occasionally larger cells with obvious nucleoli. Collagen bands are interspersed among neoplastic cells.

626.caption: Fibromatosis. A: Spindle myofibroblast fascicles infiltrate adipose tissue and breast lobules. B: Intersecting fascicles of bland spindle cells with elongated wavy nuclei.
626.original_caption: Fibromatosis. A Fascicles of spindle myofibroblasts extend into adipose tissue and in between breast lobules (on the left). B Higher magnification shows intersecting fascicles of bland spindle cells with narrow, elongated, slightly wavy nuclei.

629.caption: Polymorphous carcinoma, alveolar & single-cell pattern.
629.original_caption: Polymorphous carcinoma with alveolar and single-cell pattern.

628.original_caption: Sebaceous carcinoma. The tumour shows neat borders. Clear (sebaceous cells) represent > 50% of the total neoplastic proliferation.

635.original_caption: A Carcinoma in situ involving a lobular unit, misinterpreted as lobular type. B Ductal carcinoma in situ. Immunostaining for E-cadherin shows strong membranous expression, establishing the presence of ductal differentiation.

631.original_caption: Morphological aspects on fine-needle aspiration (Papanicolaou staining). A Invasive carcinoma of no special type. B Invasive lobular carcinoma, classical type. C Invasive mucinous carcinoma. D Tubular carcinoma.

636.caption: Mucocele-like lesion on biopsy, misread as mucinous carcinoma. Key features: bland epithelium strips from ruptured cyst, no thin vessels in mucinous lakes. Contrast with mucinous carcinoma.
636.original_caption: A Mucocele-like lesion on needle-core biopsy, misinterpreted as mucinous carcinoma. The presence of strips of bland epithelium which represent the lining of a ruptured cystic space, and the absence of thin blood vessels crossing the mucinous lakes should be the key to the diagnosis. Contrast this image with that of mucinous carcinoma (B).

638.caption: Invasive carcinoma NST, grade I. Invasive carcinoma NST, grade II. Invasive carcinoma NST, grade III, no glandular differentiation. Numerous mitotic cells, some abnormal.
638.original_caption: A Invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST), grade I. B Invasive carcinoma NST, grade II. C Invasive carcinoma NST, grade III, with no evidence of glandular differentiation. Note the presence of numerous cells in mitosis, with some abnormal mitotic figures present.

644.original_caption: Invasive carcinoma of no special type: pleomorphic carcinoma. A Poorly differentiated cells without distinctive architecture often lead to misinterpretation of the lesion as a sarcoma. B Immunostaining for keratin (AE1/AE3) confirms the epithelial nature of the process

642.original_caption: Invasive carcinoma of no special type and invasive lobular carcinoma. Two distinct morphological patterns are seen in this tumour, no special type on the left and lobular on the right.

641.original_caption: A Invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST), grade I. B Invasive carcinoma NST, grade II. C Invasive carcinoma NST, grade III, with no evidence of glandular differentiation. Note the presence of numerous cells in mitosis, with some abnormal mitotic figures present.

645.original_caption: A Invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST) with stromal osteoclastic giant cells and haemosiderin-laden macrophages. B The invasive carcinoma NST is of low grade. Multinucleated giant cells are evident in the stroma.

643.original_caption: Invasive carcinoma of no special type: pleomorphic carcinoma. A Poorly differentiated cells without distinctive architecture often lead to misinterpretation of the lesion as a sarcoma. B Immunostaining for keratin (AE1/AE3) confirms the epithelial nature of the process

649.caption: In situ and invasive lobular carcinoma. Left/lower field shows larger invasive tumor cells.
649.original_caption: In situ and invasive lobular carcinoma. The larger cells on the left and lower part of the field are invasive tumour cells.

640.caption: Invasive carcinoma NST, grades I-III. Grade III lacks glandular differentiation, shows mitotic cells with abnormal figures.
640.original_caption: A Invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST), grade I. B Invasive carcinoma NST, grade II. C Invasive carcinoma NST, grade III, with no evidence of glandular differentiation. Note the presence of numerous cells in mitosis, with some abnormal mitotic figures present.

646.caption: Invasive carcinoma NST with osteoclastic giant cells, haemosiderin-laden macrophages. Low-grade carcinoma, multinucleated giant cells in stroma.
646.original_caption: A Invasive carcinoma of no special type (NST) with stromal osteoclastic giant cells and haemosiderin-laden macrophages. B The invasive carcinoma NST is of low grade. Multinucleated giant cells are evident in the stroma.

648.original_caption: Invasive carcinoma of no special type: carcinoma with choriocarcinomatous features. A, B Multinucleated tumour cells with smudged nuclei extend their irregular, elongated cytoplasmic processes around clusters of monocytic tumour cells, mimicking the biphasic growth pattern of choriocarcinoma. Note the abnormal mitotic figures in this high-grade carcinoma.

650.original_caption: A Invasive lobular carcinoma. B Loss of E-cadherin expression is typical of lobular carcinoma cells. Note immunoreactivity of entrapped normal ductules. C There is a large number of signet ring cells and intracytoplasmic lumina (targetoid secretion).

647.caption: Invasive carcinoma, no special type, with choriocarcinomatous features. Multinucleated tumor cells with smudged nuclei, irregular cytoplasmic processes around monocytic tumor cells, mimicking choriocarcinoma biphasic growth. High-grade carcinoma with abnormal mitoses.
647.original_caption: Invasive carcinoma of no special type: carcinoma with choriocarcinomatous features. A, B Multinucleated tumour cells with smudged nuclei extend their irregular, elongated cytoplasmic processes around clusters of monocytic tumour cells, mimicking the biphasic growth pattern of choriocarcinoma. Note the abnormal mitotic figures in this high-grade carcinoma.

651.caption: Invasive lobular carcinoma. Loss of E-cadherin typical. Normal ductules immunoreactive. Signet ring cells, intracytoplasmic lumina (targetoid secretion).
651.original_caption: A Invasive lobular carcinoma. B Loss of E-cadherin expression is typical of lobular carcinoma cells. Note immunoreactivity of entrapped normal ductules. C There is a large number of signet ring cells and intracytoplasmic lumina (targetoid secretion).

652.caption: Invasive lobular carcinoma. Loss of E-cadherin typical. Normal ductules immunoreactive. Signet ring cells, intracytoplasmic lumina (targetoid secretion).
652.original_caption: A Invasive lobular carcinoma. B Loss of E-cadherin expression is typical of lobular carcinoma cells. Note immunoreactivity of entrapped normal ductules. C There is a large number of signet ring cells and intracytoplasmic lumina (targetoid secretion).

654.caption: Classic invasive lobular carcinoma: uniform single-cell files. Invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma: pleomorphic atypical nuclei.
654.original_caption: A Classic invasive lobular carcinoma with uniform, single-cell files compared with (B). B Invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma with characteristic pleomorphic, atypical nuclei.

657.caption: Invasive cribriform carcinoma. Irregular angulated invasive areas contrast rounded ducts with cribriform DCIS on left.
657.original_caption: nvasive cribriform carcinoma. The haphazard distribution of irregularly shaped and angulated invasive areas contrasts with the rounded configuration of the ducts with cribriform ductal carcinoma in situ on the left-hand side.

655.caption: Tubular carcinoma: haphazard rounded/angulated tubules with open lumina, single epithelial layer, abundant fibroblastic stroma. Neoplastic cells in tear-drop tubules lack significant atypia.
655.original_caption: Tubular carcinoma. A There is a haphazard distribution of rounded and angulated tubules with open lumina, lined by only a single layer of epithelial cells separated by abundant reactive, fibroblastic stroma. B The neoplastic cells lining the tear-drop-shaped tubules lack significant atypia.

653.caption: Classic invasive lobular carcinoma: uniform single-cell files. Invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma: pleomorphic atypical nuclei.
653.original_caption: A Classic invasive lobular carcinoma with uniform, single-cell files compared with (B). B Invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma with characteristic pleomorphic, atypical nuclei.

656.caption: Tubular carcinoma: haphazard rounded/angulated tubules with open lumina, single epithelial layer, abundant fibroblastic stroma. Neoplastic cells in tear-drop tubules lack significant atypia.
656.original_caption: Tubular carcinoma. A There is a haphazard distribution of rounded and angulated tubules with open lumina, lined by only a single layer of epithelial cells separated by abundant reactive, fibroblastic stroma. B The neoplastic cells lining the tear-drop-shaped tubules lack significant atypia.

658.caption: Medullary carcinoma: well-circumscribed >75%, syncytium >75%, necrosis, lymphocytic infiltrates.
658.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma A Typical medullary carcinoma, > 75% well-circumscribed. B Typical medullary carcinoma with > 75% syncytium. Note the necrotic area and the prominent lymphocytic infiltrates.

659.caption: Medullary carcinoma: well-circumscribed >75%, syncytium >75%, necrosis, lymphocytic infiltrates.
659.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma A Typical medullary carcinoma, > 75% well-circumscribed. B Typical medullary carcinoma with > 75% syncytium. Note the necrotic area and the prominent lymphocytic infiltrates.

661.caption: Poorly differentiated angiosarcoma post-breast-conserving treatment. Vascular channels difficult to discern. CD31 immunostaining shows solid endothelial cell areas with occasional vascular channels.
661.original_caption: Angiosarcoma after breast-conserving treatment. A As in the majority of cases, this is a poorly differentiated angiosarcoma in which vascular channels are difficult to discern. B Immunostaining for the endothelial marker CD31 clearly demonstrates the solid areas of endothelial cells with occasional vascular channels.

662.caption: Invasive papillary carcinoma, irregular pattern, crowded papillae.
662.original_caption: Invasive papillary carcinoma showing an irregular pattern with crowded papillae.

663.caption: Invasive papillary carcinoma with crowded malignant-lined papillary structures, broad invasive edge.
663.original_caption: Invasive papillary carcinoma showing crowded papillary structures lined by malignant cells. The invasive edge is broad.

660.caption: Primary (de novo) angiosarcoma. A: Well-differentiated with anastomosing vascular channels, atypical hyperchromatic nuclei. B: Plump endothelial cells, hyperchromatic nuclei, erythrocytes. C: Poorly differentiated, solid growth, spindled morphology, nuclear pleomorphism, karyorrhexis, mitoses.
660.original_caption: Primary (de novo) angiosarcoma. A Morphologically well-differentiated angiosarcoma is composed of complex anastomosing and dissecting vascular channels. The endothelial cells have atypical hyperchromatic nuclei but endothelial multilayering and mitoses are often absent. B Higher magnification shows plump endothelial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei lining anastomosing spaces that contain erythrocytes. C Poorly differentiated angiosarcoma has a more solid, cellular growth pattern, typically with spindled morphology and more limited formation of vascular channels. There is marked nuclear pleomorphism of malignant endothelial cells with karyorrhexis and mitoses.

664.caption: Microinvasive carcinoma: 0.8 mm focus adjacent to DCIS ducts, lobular morphology. CK14 shows absent MEC layer in invasive tubules vs normal tubule's distinct MEC layer.
664.original_caption: Microinvasive carcinoma. A A small focus of invasive carcinoma of 0.8 mm in maximum extent is present adjacent to ducts with DCIS. The invasive carcinoma focally has a lobular morphology. B Immunostaining for CK14 shows no evidence of a myoepithelial cell (MEC) layer around the invasive tubules, in contrast to the distinct MEC layer around an adjacent normal tubule.

665.caption: Microinvasive carcinoma: 0.8 mm focus adjacent to DCIS ducts, lobular morphology. CK14 shows absent MEC layer in invasive tubules vs normal tubule's distinct MEC.
665.original_caption: Microinvasive carcinoma. A A small focus of invasive carcinoma of 0.8 mm in maximum extent is present adjacent to ducts with DCIS. The invasive carcinoma focally has a lobular morphology. B Immunostaining for CK14 shows no evidence of a myoepithelial cell (MEC) layer around the invasive tubules, in contrast to the distinct MEC layer around an adjacent normal tubule.

669.caption: Intraductal papilloma. Epithelial layer surrounded by myoepithelial layer. Calponin immunostaining highlights myoepithelial cells.

668.caption: Microinvasive carcinoma. A: Ducts with DCIS, small invasive clusters in stroma (upper left) with lymphocytic infiltrate. B: 0.7 mm stromal invasive clusters, dense lymphocytic infiltrate. C: Actin+ vessels, no myoepithelial cells around tumor clusters confirms invasion.
668.original_caption: Microinvasive carcinoma. B Higher magnification shows small invasive cell clusters within stromal spaces distributed over a 0.7 mm area and surrounded by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate. C Immunostaining for actin highlights the vessel walls, while absence of myoepithelial cells around the tumour cell clusters confirms their invasive nature.

681.caption: Leiomyoma. Well-circumscribed margin. Bland smooth-muscle cells proliferate in whorls and fascicles.

685.caption: Angiolipoma. Well-circumscribed, partially encapsulated lesion with lobular conglomerates of cellular, densely packed congested capillaries, interspersed with fibrous stroma bands. Fibrin thrombi in some capillary lumina.

680.original_caption: Mixed metaplastic carcinoma with spindle, mesenchymal (chondroid) and squamous differentiation.

Fine delicate fibrovascular septa are discovered amid the solid proliferation.

694.caption: Neuroendocrine breast carcinoma. Alveolar pattern with solid nests of spindle cells invading collagenous stroma.
694.original_caption: Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the breast. Alveolar pattern with rounded solid nests of spindle cells invading a dense collagenous stroma.

637.caption: A Mucocele-like lesion on needle-core biopsy, misinterpreted as mucinous carcinoma. Contrast this image with that of mucinous carcinoma .

712.caption: Invasive breast cancers show ER expression (1%-100% tumor-cell nuclei) via IHC; ~80% ER+, ~65% PR+. DCIS similar. Positive: ≥1% nuclear staining; negative: <1%. Examples: A 0%; B ~1%; C ~10%; D ~30%; E ~60%; F ~100%.
712.original_caption: Expression of estrogen receptor (ER) in invasive breast cancers, as determined by immunohistochemistry. About 80% of these cancers and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) express ER in tumour-cell nuclei with a range of < 1% to 100 % (A 0% ; B Approx. 1%; C Approx. 10%; D Approx. 30%; E Approx. 60%; F Approx. 100%). Approx. 65% express progesterone receptor (PR), with a similar broad range. The remaining tumours are entirely negative (0% of cells; A). A clinically positive test for both receptors is defined as nuclear staining in ≥ 1% of tumour cells, and a negative result as < 1%.

706.caption: HER2 testing in breast cancer: IHC and FISH are validated assays. Positive IHC shows strong membrane staining in >30% tumor cells; negative shows weak/absent staining.
706.original_caption: HER2 testing in invasive breast cancers. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) are the most comprehensively validated assays for use in routine clinical practice. A clinically positive IHC test is defined as strong circumferential membrane staining in > 30% of tumour cells (A), while a negative result is defined as weak or entirely absent staining.

B Higher magnification shows small invasive cell clusters within stromal spaces distributed over a 0.7 mm area and surrounded by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate. C Immunostaining for actin highlights the vessel walls, while absence of myoepithelial cells around the tumour cell clusters confirms their invasive nature.

796.caption: High-grade DCIS with comedo necrosis, calcification, chronic inflammation. Viable cells with high-grade nuclei, nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic figures. Solid pattern with punctate necrosis. Clinging pattern, nuclear pleomorphism, mitoses. Involves lobular acini.
796.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of high nuclear grade. A Multiple spaces involved by DCIS of high nuclear grade, some with comedo necrosis and calcification. There is a chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate in surrounding stroma. B This space shows a rim of viable cells with high-grade nuclei. There is comedo-type necrosis and calcification. C Higher-power view of lesion shown in B. The cells show nuclear pleomorphism and several mitotic figures are evident. D Solid pattern with punctate necrosis. E Clinging pattern with significant nuclear pleomorphism and several mitotic figures. F DCIS of high nuclear grade involving lobular acini.

790.caption: Low-grade ductal carcinoma in situ. A: Micropapillary pattern - bulbous epithelial projections, no fibrovascular cores, uniform cells. B: Cribriform pattern - sieve-like proliferation, uniform cells, rounded spaces, organized distribution. C: Uniform round nuclei, polarized around lumina.
790.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in situ of low nuclear grade. A Micropapillary pattern characterized by numerous, often bulbous epithelial projections into the duct lumen. B Micropapillary pattern. The micropapillae lack fibrovascular cores and are composed of uniform cells with rounded, monomorphic nuclei. C Cribriform pattern. Multiple adjacent ducts are distended by a sieve-like proliferation of monotonous uniform cells. The multiple spaces within the proliferation are rounded and distributed in an organized fashion. D Cribriform pattern. A highly uniform population of cells with round nuclei distributed equidistant from one another and polarized around extracellular lumina.

804.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in situ of intermediate nuclear grade. A Solid pattern with cells polarized around a few microacini. B Cribriform pattern with scattered calcifications. C Micropapillary pattern with epithelial projections into the duct lumen that lack fibrovascular cores. D Cribriform pattern with comedo necrosis and calcifications. E Solid pattern with punctate areas of necrosis. F High-power view showing cytological detail. The cells show some variation in nuclear size and the nuclei exhibit variably prominent nucleoli.

813.caption: Pulmonary adenocarcinoma metastatic to breast. Unusual mammary primary pattern. TTF-1 immunostain positive.
813.original_caption: .02 Pulmonary adenocarcinoma metastatic to the breast. The growth pattern is unusual for a mammary primary. Immunostaining for thyroid transcription factor-1 was positive.

808.caption: PASH with anastomosing empty slits resembling vascular neoplasm.
808.original_caption: PASH with anastomosing empty slits resembling a vascular neoplasm.

805.caption: Ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate nuclear grade. A Solid pattern, polarized cells around microacini. B Cribriform pattern, scattered calcifications. C Micropapillary pattern, epithelial projections lack fibrovascular cores. D Cribriform pattern, comedo necrosis, calcifications. E Solid pattern, punctate necrosis. F High-power view: nuclear size
805.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in situ of intermediate nuclear grade. A Solid pattern with cells polarized around a few microacini. B Cribriform pattern with scattered calcifications. C Micropapillary pattern with epithelial projections into the duct lumen that lack fibrovascular cores. D Cribriform pattern with comedo necrosis and calcifications. E Solid pattern with punctate areas of necrosis. F High-power view showing cytological detail. The cells show some variation in nuclear size and the nuclei exhibit variably prominent nucleoli.

810.caption: Medullary carcinoma. A High-grade tumor cells with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumor nests with lymphocytes/plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma, no special type, lacks lymphoid stroma.
810.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma. A Typical medullary carcinoma comprising high-grade malignant tumour cells and admixed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumour nests accompanied by abundant lymphocytes and plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type without lymphoid stroma shows similar high-grade tumour cells.

816.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ membranous staining, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+ cytoplasmic, HER2+ membranous.
816.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

807.caption: PASH. IHC: CD34+ myofibroblasts lining slit-like spaces.
807.original_caption: PASH. Immunohistochemistry shows CD34positive myofibroblasts lining the slit-like spaces.

815.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ tumor cells, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+ cytoplasm, HER2+ membranous.
815.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

809.caption: Medullary carcinoma. A High-grade tumor cells with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumor nests with lymphocytes/plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma, no special type, lacks lymphoid stroma.
809.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma. A Typical medullary carcinoma comprising high-grade malignant tumour cells and admixed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumour nests accompanied by abundant lymphocytes and plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type without lymphoid stroma shows similar high-grade tumour cells.
