819.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ membranous, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+ cytoplasmic, HER2+ membranous.
819.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

811.caption: Medullary carcinoma. A: High-grade tumor cells with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B: Histological necrosis. C: Syncytial tumor nests with lymphocytes/plasma cells. D: Grade 3 invasive carcinoma, no special type, lacks lymphoid stroma.
811.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma. A Typical medullary carcinoma comprising high-grade malignant tumour cells and admixed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumour nests accompanied by abundant lymphocytes and plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type without lymphoid stroma shows similar high-grade tumour cells.

812.caption: Medullary carcinoma. A: High-grade tumor cells with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B: Histological necrosis. C: Syncytial tumor nests with lymphocytes/plasma cells. D: Grade 3 invasive carcinoma, no special type, lacks lymphoid stroma.
812.original_caption: Medullary carcinoma. A Typical medullary carcinoma comprising high-grade malignant tumour cells and admixed lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates. B Histological necrosis. C Syncytial tumour nests accompanied by abundant lymphocytes and plasma cells. D Grade 3 invasive carcinoma of no special type without lymphoid stroma shows similar high-grade tumour cells.

817.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ membranous staining, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+ cytoplasmic, HER2+ membranous.
817.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

818.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ membranous, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+ cytoplasmic, HER2+ membranous.
818.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

820.caption: Inflammatory carcinoma: dermal lymphatic emboli, E-cadherin+ tumor cells, ER-, high Ki67, MUC1+, HER2+.
820.original_caption: Typical histophenotypical features of inflammatory carcinoma. A Pathognomonic dermal lymphatic emboli. B Strong membranous staining for E-cadherin in the intralymphatic tumour cells. C Absence of estrogen-receptor expression in tumour cells. D High proliferation index in tumoral nuclei (Ki67 staining). E Intense and diffuse MUC1 staining in cytoplasm of tumour cells. F Strong and crisp membranous staining for HER2.

821.caption: Signet-ring-cell carcinoma with lobular growth pattern, abundant intracytoplasmic mucin.
821.original_caption: Carcinoma with signet-ring-cell differentiation. The invasive cells assume a lobular growth pattern and contain abundant intracytoplasmic mucin, conferring a signet-ring-cell appearance to the cells.

823.caption: Autoimmune gastritis. Fundic biopsy shows atrophy: goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia) (1), inflammation, mucinous antral-type glands replacing secretory glands (2), residual oxyntic cells (3).
823.original_caption: . Autoimmune gastritis. This fundic biopsy specimen shows several features of atrophy. The surface shows goblet cells, which are indicative of intestinal metaplasia (1); deep to this there is inflammation and replacement of the secretory glands by mucinous, antral-type glands (2). Some residual oxyntic cells are also visible (3).

830.caption: Extraprostatic extension. Malignant glands wrap around nerve (arrow) near extraprostatic fat, diagnostic of focal extension. Margin (ink at top) negative.
830.original_caption: . Extraprostatic extension. Malignant glands are seen wrapping around a nerve (arrow) adjacent to extraprostatic fat, diagnostic of focal extraprostatic extension. The margin, seen as the ink at the top of the photograph, is negative.

822.caption: Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma. Sheets of lymphocytes under epithelium, invading muscularis mucosa (arrow). Lymphoepithelial lesions: residual gland islands (pink cytoplasm) infiltrated/destroyed by lymphocytes (arrowheads).
822.original_caption: . Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma. There are sheets of lymphocytes under the epithelium and dissecting into the muscularis mucosa (arrow). Inset: Lymphoepithelial lesions are typical, in which residual glands (seen here as little more than islands of pink cytoplasm) are infiltrated and destroyed by lymphocytes (arrowheads).

825.caption: Papillary projections, intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm with moderate dysplasia. Mucinous cells show moderate dysplasia, akin to PanIN 2.
825.original_caption: . Papillary projections, intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm with moderate dysplasia. These tall papillary fronds are covered with mucinous cells showing moderate dysplasia, similar to PanIN 2.

829.caption: Proliferative endometrium. Multiple donut-shaped glands, dark oblong nuclei, frequent mitoses (arrow).
829.original_caption: . Proliferative endometrium. Multiple donut-shaped glands are visible, with dark oblong nuclei and frequent mitoses (arrow).

828.caption: Atrophic endometrium. Curettage yields thin epithelium strips resembling hairpins (arrow). Scant specimen.
828.original_caption: . Atrophic endometrium. When curetted, the epithelium typically comes off in thin strips resembling hairpins (arrow). The specimen is also scant.

824.caption: Mucinous cystic neoplasm. Cyst lining has mucinous cells (benign) with ovarian-type stroma (arrow).
824.original_caption: . Mucinous cystic neoplasm. The cyst lining is composed of mucinous cells, benign in this example, and underlying blue spindly ovarian-type stroma (arrow).

826.caption: Intrabronchial carcinoid with nested/trabecular pattern, oval nuclei, neuroendocrine chromatin (finely speckled), no nucleoli/prominent membranes.
826.original_caption: . Carcinoid. This high-power view of an intrabronchial carcinoid shows a nested and trabecular pattern of cells with oval nuclei and typical neuroendocrine chromatin, meaning finely textured and speckled, without nucleoli or prominent nuclear membranes.

831.caption: Follicular lymphoma. Lymph node replaced by malignant follicles (arrows), lacking mantle zones, polarization, germinal center heterogeneity.
831.original_caption: . Follicular lymphoma. The lymph node is replaced by malignant follicles (arrows), which lack the mantle zones, polarization, and cell heterogeneity of germinal centers.

833.caption: Intradermal nevus. Exophytic with dermal nests of nevus cells (arrow). Symmetric, cells smaller/mature at base (arrowhead).
833.original_caption: . Intradermal nevus. This exophytic nevus has only dermal nests of nevus cells (arrow). The lesion is roughly symmetric, and the cells are smaller and more mature at the base (arrowhead).

834.caption: Paraganglioma with fibrovascular septa dividing tumor into zellballen pattern. Cells show round nuclei with neuroendocrine chromatin. Resembles carcinoid more than pheochromocytoma despite extraadrenal classification.
834.original_caption: . Paraganglioma. Fibrovascular septa (arrowhead) divide the neoplasm into small balls of cells (the zellballen pattern). The cells have small, perfectly round nuclei with neuroendocrine chromatin. Despite the paragangliomas classification as an extraadrenal pheochromocytoma, it resembles the carcinoid tumor more closely than the pheochromocytoma.

836.caption: Papilloma with fibrovascular core (asterisk), normal urothelium thickness/cytology, large umbrella cells (arrow).
836.original_caption: . Papilloma. There is a prominent fibrovascular core (asterisk), and the urothelium resembles normal urothelium both in thickness and in bland cytology. Some large umbrella cells are visible (arrow).

835.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor resembling neurofibroma (probable origin). Myxoid background, wavy collagen, hyperchromatic atypical cells vs neurofibroma.
835.original_caption: . Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Although the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor sometimes resembles a fibrosarcoma, in this example it is more reminiscent of a neurofibroma, which was probably the origin in this case. There is a myxoid background and wavy collagen, but the cells are much more hyperchromatic and atypical than in a neurofibroma.

837.caption: Craniopharyngioma, adamantinomatous type. Stellate reticulum (1), calcification (2), peripheral palisading (3), wet keratin (4).
837.original_caption: . Craniopharyngioma, adamantinomatous type. There are areas of stellate reticulum (1), calcification (2), peripheral palisading (3), and accumulated wet keratin (4).

838.caption: H&E biopsy: erythroid precursors (1), myeloid precursors (2), megakaryocytes (3), maturing neutrophils (4). Normal megakaryocytes, erythroids, myelocytic precursors.
838.original_caption: . Normal megakaryocytes, erythroids, and myelocytic precursors. In this H&E stained core biopsy specimen, there are erythroid precursors (1), myeloid precursors (2), megakaryocytes (3), and maturing neutrophils (4).

839.caption: Blast on aspirate, Wright-Giemsa stain. High nuclear-cytoplasm ratio, immature chromatin (fine, uniform with nucleoli, arrowhead). Nearby promyelocyte has blast-like nucleus but granular cytoplasm (arrow).
839.original_caption: . Blast on aspirate, Wright-Giemsa stain. The key to identifying a blast is the high nuclear to cytoplasm ratio and immature chromatin pattern, which consists of very finely grained, uniform chromatin with several nucleoli that show up as negative images on this stain (arrowhead). The immature cell nearby is a promyelocyte, which has the same nuclear qualities as a blast but has abundant cytoplasm with granules (arrow).

840.caption: Atypical lipoma with lipoblasts (arrow), fat vacuoles indenting nucleus, hyperchromatic cells in fibrous stroma (arrowhead).
840.original_caption: . Lipoblast in an atypical lipoma. What you do not want to see in your lipoma—lipoblasts (arrow), with small fat vacuoles indenting the nucleus and atypical hyperchromatic cells within the fibrous stroma (arrowhead).

841.caption: Gangrenous toe ulcer: epidermis visible (arrow), ulcer bed shows obliterated epidermis/dermis, dense blue debris line (dying bacteria/cells, arrowhead).
841.original_caption: . Gangrene. In this gangrenous ulcer of the toe, the epidermis is visible to the right (arrow), while the ulcer bed to the left shows an obliteration of epidermis and dermis, with a dense blue line of debris representing dying bacteria and cells (arrowhead).

827.caption: Chronic viral hepatitis. Portal inflammation with lymphocytes spilling into limiting plate (arrow).
827.original_caption: . Portal inflammation. This is an example of chronic viral hepatitis. Lymphocytes in the portal tract spill out into the limiting plate of surrounding hepatocytes (arrow).

832.caption: Blue nevus. Small pigmented cells scattered in dermal collagen (arrow). Elongated, fusiform/stellate cells, no rounded nests. Larger pigmented cells likely melanophages.
832.original_caption: . Blue nevus. Small, indistinct, pigmented cells are scattered throughout the dermal collagen (arrow). The cells are elongated and fusiform or stellate and do not make rounded nests like typical nevus cells. Some of the larger cells with chunky pigment are likely melanophages.

842.caption: Intratubular germ cell neoplasia. Large cells with clear cytoplasmic halos, prominent nucleoli at tubule perimeter (1). Hyperchromatic solid malignant nuclei (2). Compare to endothelial cell euchromatin (3).
842.original_caption: . Intratubular germ cell neoplasia. Large cells with clear halos of cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli are seen at the tubule perimeter (1). Other malignant nuclei appear hyperchromatic and solid (2). Compare the malignant cells to the euchromatin of nearby endothelial cells (3).

847.caption: Papilloma: squamous epithelium overlying branching fibrovascular cores (arrow).
847.original_caption: . Papilloma. The squamous papilloma is defined by a squamous epithelium overlying branching fibrovascular cores (arrow).

845.caption: Meconiophages between amnion and chorion, brown pigment deposits (arrowheads).
845.original_caption: . Meconiophages between the amnion and chorion, with deposits of brown pigment (arrowheads).

846.caption: Fibrinoid necrosis: dark pink arterial wall condensation (arrow), seen in preeclampsia.
846.original_caption: . Fibrinoid necrosis. The dark pink condensation of the wall of this small artery (arrow) is an early sign of fibrinoid necrosis, which may be seen in preeclampsia.

848.caption: Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia: thin epithelial strands (arrow) extend into dermis/lamina propria, lacking nests or deep keratinization (cf. 4.4).
848.original_caption: . Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia. In this reactive condition, thin strands of epithelium (arrow) are pulled down into the underlying dermis or lamina propria. However, the strands should not expand out into nests or show deep keratinization (compare to 4.4).

844.caption: Complex atypical hyperplasia. Crowded, back-to-back glands with branching, irregular lumens (arrow). Hyperplastic epithelium (arrow) vs. normal glands (arrowhead): round nuclei, pale vesicular chromatin, prominent nucleoli, diagnostic atypia.
844.original_caption: . Complex atypical hyperplasia. (A) At low power, the glands are very crowded, even back to back, and the gland lumens have become branching and irregular (arrow). (B) At high power, comparing the hyperplastic epithelium (arrow) with normal residual glands (arrowhead), the hyperplastic cells have round nuclei, and pale, vesicular chromatin with prominent nucleoli, diagnostic of atypia.

849.caption: Dermatofibroma: poorly circumscribed tumor, blue haze in dermis (arrowheads), pigmented epidermal rete (arrow). Stops at subcutaneous fat. Inset: cells infiltrate collagen, small pale round-to-oval nuclei.
849.original_caption: . Dermatofibroma. This poorly circumscribed tumor creates a blue haze in the dermis (outlined by arrowheads), and the epidermal rete above it may become pigmented and prominent (arrow). The lesion mainly stops at the subcutaneous fat. Inset: The cells infiltrate between collagen bundles but have small pale round-to-oval nuclei.

843.caption: Complex atypical hyperplasia. Crowded, back-to-back glands with branching, irregular lumens (arrow). Hyperplastic epithelium (arrow) vs. normal glands (arrowhead): round nuclei, pale vesicular chromatin, prominent nucleoli, diagnostic atypia.
843.original_caption: . Complex atypical hyperplasia. (A) At low power, the glands are very crowded, even back to back, and the gland lumens have become branching and irregular (arrow). (B) At high power, comparing the hyperplastic epithelium (arrow) with normal residual glands (arrowhead), the hyperplastic cells have round nuclei, and pale, vesicular chromatin with prominent nucleoli, diagnostic of atypia.

851.caption: Trichilemmal cyst: no granular layer, abrupt transition to dense wet keratin. Epidermoid cyst: granular layer (arrow), dry flaky keratin.
851.original_caption: . Cysts. (A) The trichilemmal cyst has no granular layer, with large pink puffy cells showing an abrupt transition to dense wet appearing keratin. (B) The epidermoid cyst more closely resembles epidermis, with a granular layer (arrow) and layers of dry flaky keratin.

850.caption: Trichilemmal cyst: no granular layer, pink puffy cells, abrupt transition to dense wet keratin. Epidermoid cyst: resembles epidermis, granular layer (arrow), dry flaky keratin.
850.original_caption: . Cysts. (A) The trichilemmal cyst has no granular layer, with large pink puffy cells showing an abrupt transition to dense wet appearing keratin. (B) The epidermoid cyst more closely resembles epidermis, with a granular layer (arrow) and layers of dry flaky keratin.

853.caption: Herpesvirus: molded nuclei, peripheral chromatin rim, glassy inclusion replacing chromatin (arrow).
853.original_caption: . Herpesvirus. The classic nuclear changes include multiple molded nuclei with a peripheral rim of chromatin and a glassy inclusion nearly replacing the chromatin (arrow).

852.caption: Cytomegalovirus-infected GI tract endothelial cell (arrow) shows typical nuclear changes: central reddish dense inclusion, clear halo, purple chromatin rim.
852.original_caption: . Cytomegalovirus. This infected endothelial cell in the gastrointestinal tract (arrow) shows the typical nuclear changes of cytomegalovirus, with a central reddish dense nuclear inclusion, surrounded by a clear halo and a rim of purple chromatin.

860.caption: Adenoid cystic carcinoma. Small nuclei, high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, blue tumor at low power. Cribriform architecture with punched-out spaces containing pink secretions.
860.original_caption: . Adenoid cystic carcinoma. Although the nuclei are small, the nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is high, making the tumor appear blue at low power. The architecture is classically cribriform, with sharply punched-out spaces full of pink secretions.

862.caption: Funisitis. Neutrophils (arrowheads) migrate through umbilical artery muscular layer, indicating fetal infection response.
862.original_caption: . Funisitis. Neutrophils (arrowheads) can be seen squeezing through the muscular layer of an umbilical artery (A). This migration is a fetal response to infection.

863.caption: Chorioamnionitis. Neutrophils (pus) between amnion and chorion (arrow), beneath amnion (arrowhead). Decidual inflammation (oval) may be physiologic, not diagnostic. Maternal response to infection.
863.original_caption: . Chorioamnionitis. A collection of neutrophils (pus) has formed between the amnion and chorion (arrow). Neutrophils can also be seen beneath the amnion (arrowhead). Inflammation in the decidua (oval) may be physiologic and is not sufficient to diagnose chorioamnionitis. This is a maternal response to infection.

861.caption: Gallbladder with cholesterolosis. Mucosal folds distended with foamy macrophages (arrow), minimal inflammation. Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses penetrate deeply (arrowhead).
861.original_caption: . Gallbladder with cholesterolosis. The mucosal folds are distended with foamy macrophages (arrow), called cholesterolosis. Inflammation is minimal in this example. Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses can penetrate deeply into the gallbladder wall (arrowhead).

864.caption: High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Papillary infoldings resemble benign prostate, nuclei larger/darker with prominent nucleoli (arrow). Basal cells present (arrowhead).
864.original_caption: . High-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Although the papillary infoldings resemble benign prostate, the nuclei are larger and darker and show occasional prominent nucleoli (arrow). Basal cells are still present (arrowhead).

865.caption: Lymphoepithelial-like carcinoma. Malignant cells (arrowheads) obscured by lymphocytes (arrow). Atypical mitoses (circle).
865.original_caption: . Lymphoepithelial-like carcinoma. The malignant cells (arrowheads) are almost obscured by the background of lymphocytes (arrow). Atypical mitoses are present (circle).

866.caption: Low-grade DCIS: monotonous cells, cribriform spaces, polarized lumens (arrows). High-grade DCIS: pleomorphic cells, prominent nucleoli (arrowhead), comedo-type necrosis (asterisk).
866.original_caption: . Ducal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). (A) In low-grade DCIS, the cells are monotonous, uniform, and largely nonoverlapping, and they form cribriform duct spaces with the cells polarized around the tiny lumens (arrows). (B) In high-grade DCIS, the cells have lost their monotony and are instead pleomorphic, some with prominent nucleoli (arrowhead). At the center of the dilated duct there is necrosis (asterisk), indicating comedo-type DCIS.

867.caption: Low-grade DCIS: monotonous, uniform cells form cribriform duct spaces (arrows). High-grade DCIS: pleomorphic cells, prominent nucleoli (arrowhead), central necrosis (asterisk) indicating comedo-type.
867.original_caption: . Ducal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). (A) In low-grade DCIS, the cells are monotonous, uniform, and largely nonoverlapping, and they form cribriform duct spaces with the cells polarized around the tiny lumens (arrows). (B) In high-grade DCIS, the cells have lost their monotony and are instead pleomorphic, some with prominent nucleoli (arrowhead). At the center of the dilated duct there is necrosis (asterisk), indicating comedo-type DCIS.

869.caption: Papillary architecture, breast papillary carcinoma.
869.original_caption: . Papillary architecture, papillary carcinoma of breast.

870.caption: Hobnailed cells, angiosarcoma. Microcystic pattern, acinic cell carcinoma.
870.original_caption: . Hobnailed cells, angiosarcoma. 2.8. Microcystic pattern, acinic cell carcinoma.

872.caption: Micropapillary architecture, micropapillary serous ovarian carcinoma.
872.original_caption: . Micropapillary architecture, micropapillary serous carcinoma of the ovary.

873.caption: Reticular pattern, yolk sac tumor, testis.
873.original_caption: . Reticular pattern, yolk sac tumor of testis.

874.caption: Schneiderian papilloma: squamous/respiratory epithelium w/ goblet cells (1), fibrovascular cores (2). Neutrophils not seen.
874.original_caption: . Schneiderian papilloma. The typical features are a squamous or respiratory epithelium with goblet cells (1) and neutrophils (not seen at this power). As in any papilloma, there are fibrovascular cores (2).

875.caption: Well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. Golden bile in tumor cells, hard to differentiate from normal liver. No portal tracts.
875.original_caption: . Well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. Golden bile can be seen in the tumor cells, which are hard to differentiate from normal liver. Portal tracts are absent.

876.caption: Basal cell carcinoma. Blue nests drop from epidermis. Palisading of basal cells at periphery (arrowhead). Clefting of tumor from stroma (arrow).
876.original_caption: . Basal cell carcinoma. Blue nests of cells appear to drop down from the epidermis. There is prominent palisading of the basal cells at the periphery of the nests (arrowhead) and clefting of the tumor cells away from the stroma (arrow).

877.caption: Seborrheic keratosis. Exophytic lesion with hyperkeratosis (arrowhead), no parakeratosis. Epidermis shows intertwining rete with trapped keratin forming horn cysts (arrow). Compare acellular lamellated keratin balls vs squamous cell carcinoma keratin pearls.
877.original_caption: . Seborrheic keratosis. This exophytic lesion shows hyperkeratosis (arrowhead) but not parakeratosis (no visible nuclei in the keratin). The epidermis takes on a complicated pattern of intertwining rete, and in some areas foci of keratin are trapped within the lesion, forming horn cysts (arrow). Compare these blue, acellular, lamellated balls of keratin with the pink keratin pearls of squamous cell carcinoma (see 27.14).

878.caption: High-grade serous carcinoma invading stroma. Pleomorphic dark cells with prominent nucleoli, solid nests with slit-like spaces (arrow).
878.original_caption: . High-grade serous carcinoma. This tumor is shown invading the stroma. The cells are pleomorphic and dark, with prominent nucleoli, and grow in solid nests with slit-like spaces (arrow).

879.caption: Borderline mucinous tumor. Cyst lining (arrowhead) mucinous, resembles endocervical cells. Invaginations into stroma (arrow) not invasion.
879.original_caption: . Borderline mucinous tumor. The cyst lining (arrowhead) is mucinous and resembles endocervical cells in this example. As with the borderline serous tumor, invaginations into the stroma should not be mistaken for invasion (arrow).

880.caption: Diffuse alveolar damage. Alveolar spaces contain fluid, blood (asterisk), forming pink hyaline membranes (arrow). Interstitial edema.
880.original_caption: . Diffuse alveolar damage. The alveolar spaces are full of fluid and blood (asterisk), which in some areas is beginning to coalesce into thick pink hyaline membranes (arrow). The interstitial spaces are thickened due to edema.

881.caption: Neurofibroma: poorly defined dermal tumor (arrowheads), paler than surrounding dermis. Inset: tapering undulating nuclei (arrow), wavy collagen fibers (arrowhead).
881.original_caption: . Neurofibroma. Like the dermatofibroma, this diffuse neurofibroma is a poorly defined dermal tumor (arrowheads), but, unlike the dermatofibroma, it tends to appear more pale than the surrounding dermis. Inset: On higher power, the tapering, undulating nuclei (arrow) are visible, as is the background of wavy collagen fibers (arrowhead).

882.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). DFSP more cellular than dermatofibroma, shows storiform pattern of spindled cells infiltrating fat.
882.original_caption: . Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP). The DFSP is more cellular than the dermatofibroma and shows a prominent storiform pattern of spindled cells infiltrating between fat cells.

883.caption: Hyperplastic polyp with frilly surface (arrow), hyperplastic mucinous epithelium, prominent goblet cells. Deeper crypts (arrowhead) show star-shaped lumens.
883.original_caption: . Hyperplastic polyp. The surface of the polyp shows a characteristic frilly appearance (arrow), with hyperplastic mucinous epithelium and prominent goblet cells. Deeper crypts (arrowhead) show star-shaped lumens.

884.caption: Histiocytes show pale folded nuclei in inflammation; indistinct borders, light pink cytoplasm (circle). Compare chromatin to lymphocyte (arrowhead).
884.original_caption: . Histiocytes appear as pale folded nuclei within an area of inflammation; the cell borders are indistinct, but the nuclei are surrounded by light pink cytoplasm (circle). Compare the pale chromatin to that of the neighboring lymphocyte (arrowhead).

885.caption: Diffuse large B-cell CNS lymphoma. Malignant cells cluster around blood vessels (arrows), typical of brain lymphoma.
885.original_caption: . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the central nervous system. The tendency of the malignant cells to cluster around blood vessels (arrows) is typical of lymphoma within the brain.

886.caption: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Sheets of discohesive cells, no architectural patterns. Large nuclei, irregular membranes, nucleoli (arrow). Compare to lymphocyte (arrowhead).
886.original_caption: . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The usual appearance is that of sheets of discohesive cells that do not form any recognizable architectural patterns (such as glands or trabeculae). The cells typically have large nuclei, irregular and prominent nuclear membranes, and nucleoli (arrow). Compare the cell size to a background lymphocyte (arrowhead).

887.caption: Microglandular hyperplasia. Endocervical glands show cellular proliferation with mucinous cells (arrow), squamous metaplasia (arrowhead), and cribriform lumens. Benign.
887.original_caption: . Microglandular hyperplasia. These endocervical glands show a very cellular proliferation composed of mucinous cells (arrow) and squamous metaplasia (arrowhead) and a cribriform pattern of lumens. This is benign.

888.caption: Placental site nodule, cervix. Dark nuclei, pink cytoplasm mimic squamous cell carcinoma, but nuclei are small, oval, few large nuclei (arrowhead) with smudgy chromatin, lacking HSIL's chunky texture or invasive carcinoma's nuclear irregularity. Peripheral decidualized cell (arrow) is key.
888.original_caption: . Placental site nodule, cervix. Although the dark nuclei and pink cytoplasm are concerning for squamous cell carcinoma, the nuclei are predominantly small and oval, with a few large nuclei visible (arrowhead). These large cells have dark but smudgy (blurred or indistinct) chromatin, without the chunky texture seen in HSIL (see 16.6) and do not have the nuclear membrane irregularity of invasive squamous cell carcinoma (see 16.7). The final clue is what appears to be a decidualized cell at the periphery (arrow).

889.caption: Leiomyoma. Fascicles of cells, parallel (arrow) and right angles (arrowhead). Nuclei tapered, pale, paranuclear vacuoles, corkscrew morphology.
889.original_caption: . Leiomyoma. The low-power impression is that of fascicles or bundles of cells, some parallel to the slide (arrow) and some coming out at right angles (arrowhead). Inset: The nuclei are tapered and pale, with occasional paranuclear vacuoles, and sometimes show corkscrew morphology, as though the nucleus was twisted longitudinally. (Dog owners may liken this lumpy shape to something else.)

890.caption: Malignant mullerian mixed tumor: carcinomatous cells (arrow) in epithelium (hyperchromatic, crowded) and sarcomatous cells (circle) in stroma (hyperchromatic, irregular, resembling malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Malignant glands present.
890.original_caption: . Malignant mullerian mixed tumor. This tumor is defined by the presence of carcinomatous cells in the epithelium (arrow) and sarcomatous cells in the stroma (circle). The carcinomatous cells are hyperchromatic and crowded; elsewhere in this biopsy specimen there were malignant glands. The sarcomatous cells are hyperchromatic, large, and irregular in shape, similar to malignant fibrous histiocytoma-type cells found in other sarcomas (see Chapter 28).

891.caption: Nonparatrabecular aggregate in CLL. Arrow indicates free-floating rounded lymphoid aggregate center.
891.original_caption: . Nonparatrabecular aggregate in chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The arrow here points to the center of a free-floating, rounded lymphoid aggregate.

892.caption: Paratrabecular lymphoid aggregate, arrow at center (bluer vs. marrow), adherent to bony trabeculum.
892.original_caption: . Paratrabecular aggregate. The arrow points to the center of this lymphoid aggregate, which appears more blue, relatively, than the surrounding marrow. One surface of the aggregate is plastered down to the bony trabeculum.

893.caption: Parotid ducts: terminal/intercalated ducts (cuboidal epithelium, arrowheads), striated ducts (oncocytic, pink cytoplasm, arrow), interlobular ducts (pseudostratified columnar epithelium, arrow), squamous at gingival junction.
893.original_caption: . Types of ducts. (A) In the parotid, which has mainly serous glands, the terminal or intercalated ducts are visible as small tubules lined by cuboidal epithelium (arrowheads). The medium-sized striated ducts are more oncocytic in appearance, with abundant pink cytoplasm (arrow). (B) The large interlobular ducts have pseudostratified columnar epithelium (arrow), with occasional goblet cells, and become squamous at their junction with the gingival mucosa.

894.caption: Parotid ducts: terminal/intercalated ducts (cuboidal epithelium, arrowheads), striated ducts (oncocytic, pink cytoplasm, arrow), interlobular ducts (pseudostratified columnar epithelium, arrow), with goblet cells, squamous at gingival junction.
894.original_caption: . Types of ducts. (A) In the parotid, which has mainly serous glands, the terminal or intercalated ducts are visible as small tubules lined by cuboidal epithelium (arrowheads). The medium-sized striated ducts are more oncocytic in appearance, with abundant pink cytoplasm (arrow). (B) The large interlobular ducts have pseudostratified columnar epithelium (arrow), with occasional goblet cells, and become squamous at their junction with the gingival mucosa.

895.caption: Normal salivary gland. Columnar secretory cells (arrowhead) form acini around ducts (arrow). Myoepithelial cells not visible on H&E.
895.original_caption: . Normal salivary gland. In this example of mucinous salivary gland, the columnar secretory cells (arrowhead) form acini arranged around salivary ducts (arrow). Myoepithelial cells are not particularly visible on H&E stain.

896.caption: Adenocarcinoma (arrows) infiltrates benign glands (arrowheads). Malignant glands are back-to-back, denser cytoplasm, no basal layer, straight luminal borders.
896.original_caption: . Low-power features of carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma (arrows) is seen infiltrating throughout benign glands (arrowheads) in this core biopsy specimen. The malignant glands are often back to back and have relatively denser cytoplasm, no basal layer, and straight luminal borders.

897.caption: Benign prostate glands with basal cell layer (arrowhead), papillary fronds (arrow), and corpora amylacea (CA).
897.original_caption: . Benign prostate glands. These glands have a distinct basal cell layer underlying the epithelial cells (arrowhead) and papillary fronds in the lumen (arrow). Corpora amylacea (CA) are concentrically laminated concretions associated with benign glands.

898.caption: Follicular cells: normal epithelium has round uniform nuclei, no overlap/crowding (arrow). Large/small follicles with colloid; may be normal thyroid, nodular hyperplasia, or follicular neoplasm.
898.original_caption: . Follicular cells. Normal follicular epithelium has round uniform nuclei that tend not to overlap or crowd each other (arrow). This field is a combination of large and small follicles full of colloid and could represent normal thyroid, nodular hyperplasia, or a follicular neoplasm.

899.caption: Low-grade papillary urothelial cancer. Fibrovascular cores (arrow) lined by thickened, disorganized urothelium (circle) with enlarged nuclei.
899.original_caption: . Low-grade papillary urothelial cancer. The fibrovascular cores (arrow) are lined by urothelium that is thicker than normal, increasingly disorganized (circle), and with enlarged nuclei.

900.caption: Papillary urothelial neoplasm, low malignant potential. Thickened urothelium, uniform organized cells.
900.original_caption: . Papillary urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential. This papillary lesion shows an increased thickness relative to normal urothelium, but the cells remain uniform and organized.

901.caption: Ischemic colitis: small dark regenerative crypts, lamina propria hyalinization/fibrosis, ulceration, crypt dropout.
901.original_caption: . Ischemic colitis. Features include small dark regenerative crypts (1), hyalinization and fibrosis of the lamina propria (2), ulceration (3), and crypt dropout (4).

902.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma: hypocellular dermal scar (arrow), lymphocytes (arrowhead). Inset: enlarged hyperchromatic cells (arrow), S100+ vs fibroblasts.
902.original_caption: . Desmoplastic melanoma. At low power, there appears to be a hypocellular scar in the dermis (arrow). The clue to melanoma lies in the collection of lymphocytes (arrowhead). Inset: On higher power, there are enlarged and hyperchromatic cells (arrow) in the scar. These would be positive for S100, unlike fibroblasts.

903.caption: Barretts esophagus: columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Goblet cells appear clear on H&E, flanked by purplish absorptive cells. Gastric foveolar epithelium shows back-to-back mucinous cells. Goblet cells present at surface (arrow) or deep glands (arrowhead). PAS/alcian blue stains goblet cells indigo blue (arrow
903.original_caption: . Goblet cells in Barretts esophagus. The presence of columnar epithelium with goblet cells indicates Barretts esophagus. Goblet cells are round cells that appear clear on hematoxylin and eosin stain and are typically flanked by the purplish absorptive-type cells. Back-to-back mucinous cells resembling a row of teeth are more likely to be gastric foveolar epithelium. Goblet cells may be present at the surface (arrow) or in deep glands (arrowhead). Inset: A periodic-acid Schiff/alcian blue stain confirms the goblet cells, which stain indigo blue (arrowhead).

904.caption: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma. Nuclei (arrow) larger than normal lymphocyte (arrowhead), chromatin immature (dispersed). No prominent nucleoli/thick nuclear membranes vs. large B-cell lymphoma.
904.original_caption: . Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma. The nuclei (arrow) are larger than a normal lymphocyte (arrowhead), and the chromatin is very immature (meaning widely dispersed throughout the nucleus). Unlike large B-cell lymphoma, there are no prominent nucleoli or thick nuclear membranes.

905.caption: High grade sarcomas: fibrosarcoma (hyperchromatic spindle cells), pleomorphic MFH (bizarre cells), myxoid MFH/myxofibrosarcoma (pleomorphic cells in myxoid stroma), leiomyosarcoma (perpendicular fascicles).
905.original_caption: . High grade sarcomas. (A) Fibrosarcoma, with densely packed hyperchromatic spindle cells. (B) Pleomorphic MFH, with very large and bizarre cells (arrowhead). (C) Myxoid MFH or myxofibrosarcoma, showing pleomorphic cells in a myxoid background. (D) Leiomyosarcoma, with perpendicular fascicles.

906.caption: High grade sarcomas: fibrosarcoma (hyperchromatic spindle cells), pleomorphic MFH (bizarre cells), myxoid MFH/myxofibrosarcoma (pleomorphic cells in myxoid stroma), leiomyosarcoma (perpendicular fascicles).
906.original_caption: . High grade sarcomas. (A) Fibrosarcoma, with densely packed hyperchromatic spindle cells. (B) Pleomorphic MFH, with very large and bizarre cells (arrowhead). (C) Myxoid MFH or myxofibrosarcoma, showing pleomorphic cells in a myxoid background. (D) Leiomyosarcoma, with perpendicular fascicles.

907.caption: High grade sarcomas: Fibrosarcoma (hyperchromatic spindle cells), pleomorphic MFH (bizarre cells), myxoid MFH/myxofibrosarcoma (pleomorphic cells in myxoid stroma), leiomyosarcoma (perpendicular fascicles).
907.original_caption: . High grade sarcomas. (A) Fibrosarcoma, with densely packed hyperchromatic spindle cells. (B) Pleomorphic MFH, with very large and bizarre cells (arrowhead). (C) Myxoid MFH or myxofibrosarcoma, showing pleomorphic cells in a myxoid background. (D) Leiomyosarcoma, with perpendicular fascicles.

908.caption: High grade sarcomas: fibrosarcoma (hyperchromatic spindle cells), pleomorphic MFH (bizarre cells), myxoid MFH/myxofibrosarcoma (pleomorphic cells in myxoid background), leiomyosarcoma (perpendicular fascicles).
908.original_caption: . High grade sarcomas. (A) Fibrosarcoma, with densely packed hyperchromatic spindle cells. (B) Pleomorphic MFH, with very large and bizarre cells (arrowhead). (C) Myxoid MFH or myxofibrosarcoma, showing pleomorphic cells in a myxoid background. (D) Leiomyosarcoma, with perpendicular fascicles.

909.caption: Chromophobe carcinoma. Low-power: cell packets, clear-to-pink cytoplasm, perinuclear halos, binucleate cells. Distinct membranes, cobblestone/alligator-skin texture. High-power (eosinophilic variant): granular pink cytoplasm, koilocytic nuclei, crinkly outlines, perinuclear halos. Preserved crisp membranes.
909.original_caption: . Chromophobe carcinoma. (A) Low-power view of a chromophobe, showing packets of cells with clear-to-pink cytoplasm, perinuclear halos, and occasional binucleate cells (arrow). The cell membranes are distinct, giving the tumor a cobblestone or alligator-skin texture. (B) High-power view of a chromophobe carcinoma, eosinophilic variant. Although the granular pink cytoplasm resembles an oncocytoma (see 13.9), the nuclei are distinctly koilocytic, with crinkly outlines and perinuclear halos (arrow). In addition, the crisp cellular membranes are preserved (arrowhead).

910.caption: Chromophobe carcinoma. Low-power: cell packets, clear-to-pink cytoplasm, perinuclear halos, binucleate cells (arrow), distinct membranes (cobblestone/alligator-skin). High-power (eosinophilic variant): granular pink cytoplasm, koilocytic nuclei, crinkly outlines, perinuclear halos (arrow), crisp membranes (arrowhead
910.original_caption: . Chromophobe carcinoma. (A) Low-power view of a chromophobe, showing packets of cells with clear-to-pink cytoplasm, perinuclear halos, and occasional binucleate cells (arrow). The cell membranes are distinct, giving the tumor a cobblestone or alligator-skin texture. (B) High-power view of a chromophobe carcinoma, eosinophilic variant. Although the granular pink cytoplasm resembles an oncocytoma (see 13.9), the nuclei are distinctly koilocytic, with crinkly outlines and perinuclear halos (arrow). In addition, the crisp cellular membranes are preserved (arrowhead).

911.caption: Cirrhosis in biopsy. Trichrome stain: collagen (blue) outlines liver lobules, bridges portal tracts, creates nodular pattern; parenchyma (red).
911.original_caption: . Cirrhosis in a biopsy specimen. In this trichrome stain, collagen is blue, while hepatic parenchyma is red. Collagen can be seen outlining the lobules of the liver, bridging the portal tracts and creating a nodular pattern.

912.caption: Steatohepatitis. Portal tract shows minimal inflammation. Lobule exhibits macrovesicular steatosis and neutrophil collections attacking hepatocytes.
912.original_caption: . Steatohepatitis. An adjacent portal tract (1) shows minimal inflammation. In the lobule, there is macrovesicular steatosis (2) and collections of neutrophils attacking individual hepatocytes (arrows).

913.caption: Mallorys hyaline. Steatosis, inflammation, pink refractile wormlike structure in hepatocyte (arrow) shows cytoskeletal collapse.
913.original_caption: . Mallorys hyaline. In the background of steatosis and inflammation, a pink refractile wormlike structure in the hepatocyte (arrow) is evidence of cytoskeletal collapse.

914.caption: Oncocytoma: round, uniform nuclei; evenly spaced. Nucleoli present, no perinuclear halos. Pink, granular cytoplasm, like other oncocytic neoplasms.
914.original_caption: . Oncocytoma. The nuclei are typically very round, uniform in size, and evenly spaced. Nucleoli may be seen, but there are no perinuclear halos. The cytoplasm is pink and granular, similar to oncocytic neoplasms elsewhere in the body.

915.caption: Papillary renal cell carcinoma. Tumor cells eosinophilic, cuboidal to columnar (arrowhead). Grows as solid sheets/tubules; papillary structures with foamy histiocytes (arrow) diagnostic. Low grade cytologically, high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio, blue on low power.
915.original_caption: . Papillary renal cell carcinoma. The tumor cells are eosinophilic, not clear, and range from cuboidal to columnar (arrowhead). This tumor may grow as solid sheets and tubules, but finding papillary structures with central cores packed with foamy histiocytes (arrow) is diagnostic. Although the tumor in this example is low grade cytologically, the cells have a relatively high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio, and therefore this would be somewhat blue on low power.

916.caption: Ductal adenocarcinoma. Tumor cells show tall columnar morphology. Nuclei resemble conventional prostate adenocarcinoma.
916.original_caption: . Ductal adenocarcinoma. In this variant, the tumor cells have a tall columnar morphology. The nuclei still resemble conventional prostate adenocarcinoma.

917.caption: Follicular variant of papillary carcinoma. Architecture resembles follicular adenoma, but nuclei are oval, crowded (arrows), typical of papillary carcinoma.
917.original_caption: . Follicular variant of papillary carcinoma. The architecture is that of a follicular adenoma, but the nuclei, oval in shape and crowded together (arrows), are those of papillary carcinoma.

918.caption: Oligodendroglioma: cellular tumor with packed oligodendroglia, round nuclei, clear halos, fine capillary network (arrow).
918.original_caption: . Oligodendroglioma. This is a very cellular example of an oligodendroglioma. The closely packed oligodendroglia have very round nuclei which are surrounded by clear halos. The tumor cells are suspended in a network of fine capillaries (arrow).

919.caption: Celiac disease: duodenal villi blunted, mucosa colon-like. Lamina propria chronic inflammation (arrow). Inset: intraepithelial lymphocytes ↑ (arrowheads).
919.original_caption: . Celiac disease. The normal villi are blunted almost out of existence, with the duodenal mucosa resembling colon. There is chronic inflammation within the lamina propria (arrow). Inset: Increased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes are present (arrowheads).

920.caption: Duodenal adenoma with low-grade dysplasia: crowded, elongated nuclei, lost mucinous differentiation (arrow). Residual duodenal mucosa beneath (arrowhead).
920.original_caption: . Duodenal adenoma. As in the colon, the tubular adenoma is characterized by low-grade dysplasia, showing crowded and elongated nuclei and loss of mucinous differentiation (arrow). Residual duodenal mucosa is seen underneath the adenoma (arrowhead).

921.caption: Neurofibroma with thin, wavy nuclei (arrowhead), paucicellular tumor, myxoid background, delicate curly collagen strands (arrow).
921.original_caption: . Neurofibroma. The nuclei tend to be thin and wavy (arrowhead), much like in a normal nerve. The tumor is usually paucicellular, with a myxoid background and delicate curly strands of wispy collagen (arrow).

922.caption: Adenocarcinoma with cribriform glandular spaces (arrow) and small malignant glands/single cells in desmoplastic stroma (arrowhead), confirming invasion.
922.original_caption: . Adenocarcinoma. In some areas this tumor is forming cribriform glandular spaces (arrow), and in others small malignant glands or single cells are seen embedded in a desmoplastic stroma (arrowhead), confirming invasion.

923.caption: Bronchoalveolar carcinoma. Malignant cells line alveolar walls without stromal invasion.
923.original_caption: . Bronchoalveolar carcinoma. The malignant cells line the alveolar walls but do not invade the stroma.

924.caption: Candida. Tiny purple yeasts & pseudohyphae (arrow) in squamous debris. H&E stain; magenta on PAS. May lack neutrophilic response.
924.original_caption: . Candida. Tiny purple yeasts and pseudohyphae (arrow) are seen among the squamous debris at the surface of the epithelium. This is a hematoxylin and eosin stain; the yeasts are magenta on periodic-acid Schiff stain. Note that sometimes there is not a significant neutrophilic response.

925.caption: Pituitary adenoma: monomorphic neuroendocrine cells, sheets without reticulin encirclement. Normal pituitary: mixed eosinophilic/basophilic cells, reticulin shows discrete nests.
925.original_caption: . Pituitary adenoma versus normal. (A) In a pituitary adenoma, there is a monomorphic population of neuroendocrine-type cells. A collagen or reticulin stain would show sheets of cells no longer encircled by reticulin. (B) Normal pituitary is a mix of many different cell types, both eosinophilic and basophilic, and a reticulin stain would show the tissue divided into small discrete nests.

926.caption: Pituitary adenoma: monomorphic neuroendocrine cells, sheets without reticulin encirclement. Normal pituitary: mixed eosinophilic/basophilic cells, reticulin divides tissue into nests.
926.original_caption: . Pituitary adenoma versus normal. (A) In a pituitary adenoma, there is a monomorphic population of neuroendocrine-type cells. A collagen or reticulin stain would show sheets of cells no longer encircled by reticulin. (B) Normal pituitary is a mix of many different cell types, both eosinophilic and basophilic, and a reticulin stain would show the tissue divided into small discrete nests.

927.caption: Mantle cell lymphoma. Neoplastic cells more irregular than small lymphocytic lymphoma, with angular nuclei. Chromatin pattern shows soccer-ball splotches, similar to small lymphocytic lymphoma.
927.original_caption: . Mantle cell lymphoma. The neoplastic cells in mantle cell tend to be more irregular in shape than those of small lymphocytic lymphoma, with slightly angular nuclei. The chromatin pattern, with the soccer-ball splotches, is similar to small lymphocytic lymphoma.

928.caption: Marginal zone lymphoma. Marginal zone cells show monocytoid appearance with clear cytoplasmic halo (arrow).
928.original_caption: . Marginal zone lymphoma. The marginal zone cells classically have a monocytoid appearance, meaning there is a distinct thin halo of clear cytoplasm (arrow).

929.caption: Serous cystadenoma, high power. Cells lining multilocular cyst: small, dense round nuclei, clear cytoplasm (arrow).
929.original_caption: . Serous cystadenoma, high power. The cells lining the multilocular cyst are small, with dense round nuclei and clear cytoplasm (arrow).

930.caption: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor with reactive fibroblasts (arrow), capillaries, and plasma cells (arrowhead).
930.original_caption: . Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. The tumor is composed of a network of reactivelooking fibroblasts (arrow), capillaries, and inflammation, especially plasma cells (arrowhead).

931.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma. Cells resemble pleomorphic malignant fibrous histiocytoma, but stroma is myxoid with unique short arc vessels (arrow). Unlike myxoid liposarcoma's branching vessels, tumor cells adhere closely to vessels like wax on a candle.
931.original_caption: . Myxofibrosarcoma. Although the cells here resemble those of pleomorphic malignant fibrous histiocytoma, the stroma is myxoid, and the vessels are unique (arrow). They appear as short arcs or segments, unlike the complex branching vessels of myxoid liposarcoma, and the tumor cells are intimately associated with the vessels, like wax dripping down the side of a candle.

932.caption: Dermal scar. Dense pink collagen replaced adnexal structures, displaced subcutaneous fat.
932.original_caption: . Dermal scar. Dense pink collagen has replaced the adnexal structures and displaced the subcutaneous fat in this biopsy site.

933.caption: Biopsy site changes: subcutaneous specimen shows collagen replacing fat cells, foamy histiocytes ingesting residual fat (arrow). Inset: hemosiderin in macrophages (golden yellow-brown granules) at prior trauma/bleeding sites.
933.original_caption: . Biopsy site changes. In this subcutaneous specimen, collagen has replaced most of the fat cells, and foamy histiocytes can be seen ingesting some residual fat (arrow). Inset: Hemosiderin in macrophages (golden yellow to brown granules) can be seen in sites of prior trauma or bleeding.

934.caption: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Koilocytes show HPV cytopathic effect: hyperchromatic, raisinoid nuclei with cytoplasmic halos. Features include enlarged superficial nuclei and binucleation.
934.original_caption: . Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. The hallmark of low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion is the koilocyte, which is a squamous cell with HPV viral cytopathic effect. The nuclei are hyperchromatic (dark) and raisinoid (crinkly; see arrows), with a surrounding clear halo in the cytoplasm. Other good features include superficial nuclei that are larger than the nuclei below them and binucleated cells.

935.caption: Myxoid liposarcoma: subtle fatty component, delicate chicken-wire vasculature (thin capillaries, 3-4 way branches). Small cells with fat vacuoles, myxoid background, no atypia. Inset: packed small cells indicate round cell differentiation.
935.original_caption: . Myxoid liposarcoma. The fatty component may be very subtle in myxoid liposarcoma; the vessels are more often the tip off. The vasculature is composed of a delicate network of very thin capillaries with three- and four-way branch points, similar to chicken-wire (arrow). The cell population is composed of small cells, which may have fat vacuoles in them, and a myxoid background. Large atypical cells should not be present. Inset: Areas of closely packed small cells are indicative of round cell differentiation.

936.caption: Reparative changes near ulcer. Fragment shows poorly formed glands with infiltrative appearance, high N/C ratio (arrows). Nuclei similar to gastric glands, glands stream parallel to surface, consistent with regeneration.
936.original_caption: . Reparative changes next to an ulcer. The tip of this fragment has a collection of poorly formed glands with an infiltrative look and minimal cytoplasm, giving the appearance of a high nuclear/ cytoplasmic ratio (arrows). However, the nuclei are of about the same size and shape as the rest of the gastric glands, and these small glands stream in parallel toward the surface, consistent with regenerative or reparative glands.

937.caption: Apocrine metaplasia in fibrocystic disease. Epithelial cells lining dilated duct: large, plump, abundant dark pink cytoplasm, round nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Lumen contains granular secretions.
937.original_caption: . Apocrine metaplasia in fibrocystic disease. The epithelial cells lining the dilated duct are large and plump, with abundant dark pink cytoplasm, and round nuclei with prominent nucleoli. Secretions (the granular schmutz in the lumen) are common.

938.caption: Sclerosing adenosis: benign, infiltrative. Tiny tubules in fibrotic stroma, some in fat (arrow). Compressed myoepithelial cells absent. Clues: circumscribed lesion, no desmoplastic reaction, intact myoepithelial layer on immunostains.
938.original_caption: . Sclerosing adenosis. On high power, this benign lesion looks infiltrative. Tiny tubules are entrapped in a fibrotic stroma, and some tubules are even seen among fat (arrow). Because of the compression, myoepithelial cells are not visible. Clues to the diagnosis include a circumscribed lesion at low power, the lack of desmoplastic (edema and fibrosis) reaction, and an intact myoepithelial cell layer seen on immunostains.

939.caption: Lentigo simplex in acral skin. Dense keratin typical of acral skin (hands/feet). Linear proliferation of benign melanocytes at dermoepidermal junction (arrows).
939.original_caption: . Lentigo simplex in acral skin. The dense keratin seen here is typical of acral skin (hands and feet). There is a linear proliferation of single benign melanocytes along the dermoepidermal junction (arrows).

940.caption: Compound nevus: nests of nevocellular cells at dermoepidermal junction (arrow) and dermis (arrowhead). Deepest cells smaller, more bland (maturation). Differentiates from junctional nevus.
940.original_caption: . Compound nevus. This nevus shows nests of nevocellular (melanocytic) cells attached to the dermoepidermal junction (arrow). A nevus with only dermoepidermal junction nests would be a junctional nevus. In this example, as there are also nevus cells dropping down into the dermis (arrowhead); this is a compound nevus. In a compound nevus, the cells at the deepest point should appear slightly smaller and more bland than those at the dermoepidermal junction (maturation).

944.caption: Caseating necrosis, granuloma, TB.
944.original_caption: . Caseating necrosis in a granuloma, tuberculosis.

947.caption: Endometriosis. Cervical biopsy shows squamous epithelium over stroma with hemorrhage. Dark cuboidal lining (arrow) resembles endometrial epithelium. Endometrial stroma (arrowhead) obscured by blood.
947.original_caption: . Endometriosis. This cervical biopsy specimen shows a squamous epithelium overlying stroma with hemorrhage. At the bottom of the fragment there is a dark cuboidal lining (arrow) resembling endometrial epithelium. The telltale endometrial stroma (arrowhead) is mostly obscured by blood.

948.caption: Periodic-acid Schiff stain shows thick, hollow, irregular Mucor outlines (arrow).
948.original_caption: . Mucor. A periodic-acid Schiff stain shows the thick, hollow, irregular outlines of Mucor (arrow).

949.caption: Primary biliary cirrhosis. Granulomatous portal inflammation, bile ductule destruction (arrow).
949.original_caption: . Primary biliary cirrhosis. There is a granulomatous inflammation of the portal tract, with destruction of a bile ductule (arrow).

950.caption: Fibroblast foci: H&E shows pale myxoid fibroblast swirls (arrows). Movats stain: turquoise (arrow).
950.original_caption: . Fibroblast foci. (A) By H&E stain, these myxoid swirls of new fibroblasts are pale and streamy (arrows). (B) On Movats stain, they are turquoise (arrow).

951.caption: Fibroblast foci. H&E stain: pale myxoid swirls of fibroblasts (arrows). Movats stain: turquoise (arrow).
951.original_caption: . Fibroblast foci. (A) By H&E stain, these myxoid swirls of new fibroblasts are pale and streamy (arrows). (B) On Movats stain, they are turquoise (arrow).

952.caption: Usual interstitial pneumonia. Thickened, fibrotic interstitial spaces (arrowhead), chronic inflammation (arrow). Scarred alveolar spaces lined with atypical type II pneumocytes.
952.original_caption: . Usual interstitial pneumonia. The interstitial spaces are thickened and fibrotic (arrowhead), and there is abundant chronic inflammation (arrow). Inset: The scarred down, irregularly shaped, residual alveolar spaces are lined with type II pneumocytes, which protrude into the lumen and may have atypical nuclei.

953.caption: Tubular carcinoma. Well-formed tubules with pointed ends (arrow), monotonous cells infiltrating stroma/fat. Absent myoepithelial layer (H&E/immunostain). Subtle desmoplastic reaction around tubules (arrowhead).
953.original_caption: . Tubular carcinoma. Well-formed tubules with pointed ends (arrow) and round, monotonous cells infiltrate through the stroma and fat. The myoepithelial layer is absent, both on H&E stain and by immunostain, and there is a subtle desmoplastic reaction around some of the tubules (arrowhead).

954.caption: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Irregular border with angular tubules radiating into fat. Grossly stellate, dense stromal reaction makes lesion hard. Inset: Irregular tumor nests cause desmoplastic reaction (edema + fibrosis).
954.original_caption: . Infiltrating ductal carcinoma. At low power, the irregular border of the lesion is evident, with small angular tubules radiating outward into the fat. Grossly, this lesion would have a stellate appearance, and the dense stromal reaction would make the lesion very hard. Inset: The irregularly shaped nests of tumor cells create a desmoplastic stromal reaction, which is a combination of edema (white space) and fibrosis (pink collagen).

955.caption: Adenocarcinoma. Infiltrative glands show incomplete lumens, cribriform growth, perineural invasion. Nuclear size variation diagnostic. Large nucleus with prominent nucleolus vs smaller nuclei.
955.original_caption: . Adenocarcinoma. On high power, the infiltrative glands show incomplete lumens (arrow), cribriform growth pattern (arrowhead), and perineural invasion (N). Inset: Marked variation in nuclear size is diagnostic of cancer. Note the large nucleus with prominent nucleolus (arrowhead) across the gland from nuclei less than one fourth of its size.

956.caption: Chronic pancreatitis vs cancer. In pancreatitis, large ducts show reactive changes but remain between acini lobules (arrow). Acini atrophy, fibrosis; small ducts appear infiltrative but lobules retain circumscribed outline. In adenocarcinoma, irregular ducts scatter disregarding normal architecture (1). Ducts near vessels (2) or nerves (3) indicate cancer.
956.original_caption: . Chronic pancreatitis versus cancer, low power. (A) In chronic pancreatitis, the large ducts may show marked reactive changes, appearing blue and prominent, but they should still be located between lobules of acini (arrow). The acini show marked atrophy and fibrosis such that only the small ducts remain and appear infiltrative; however, the lobules retain a circumscribed outline (black line). (B) In adenocarcinoma, large, prominent, irregularly shaped ducts are scattered throughout, without respect to normal architecture (1). Large ducts next to vessels (2) or nerves (3) are diagnostic of cancer.

957.caption: Chronic pancreatitis vs cancer. In pancreatitis, large ducts show reactive changes but remain between acinar lobules (arrow). Acini atrophy, fibrosis; small ducts appear infiltrative but lobules retain circumscribed outline (black line). In adenocarcinoma, large irregular ducts disrupt normal architecture (1). Ducts near vessels (2) or nerves (3) indicate cancer.
957.original_caption: . Chronic pancreatitis versus cancer, low power. (A) In chronic pancreatitis, the large ducts may show marked reactive changes, appearing blue and prominent, but they should still be located between lobules of acini (arrow). The acini show marked atrophy and fibrosis such that only the small ducts remain and appear infiltrative; however, the lobules retain a circumscribed outline (black line). (B) In adenocarcinoma, large, prominent, irregularly shaped ducts are scattered throughout, without respect to normal architecture (1). Large ducts next to vessels (2) or nerves (3) are diagnostic of cancer.

958.caption: Verruca vulgaris. Epidermis shows sharply pointed spires with hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.
958.original_caption: . Verruca vulgaris. The epidermis in this wart is thrown up into sharply pointed spires, which are topped by hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.

959.caption: Ewing's sarcoma: medullary cavity replaced by small round blue cell tumor.
959.original_caption: . Ewings sarcoma. The medullary cavity of bone is replaced by a small round blue cell tumor.

960.caption: Fibrothecoma, mainly fibroma component, bland spindled cells in fascicles.
960.original_caption: . Fibrothecoma. This specimen shows mainly the fibroma component, with fascicles of bland spindled cells.

961.caption: Granulosa cell tumor, low power. Characteristic cords and rows of granulosa cells, pattern resembling watered silk or topographic map.
961.original_caption: . Granulosa cell tumor, low power. This section shows the characteristic cords and rows of granulosa cells, creating a pattern like watered silk, or (for those not frequenting fabric stores), a topographic map.

962.caption: Trophoblasts in vessels. Intermediate trophoblasts (arrow) invade maternal arteries, normal process supplying placenta.
962.original_caption: . Trophoblasts in vessels. Intermediate trophoblasts (arrow) invading the wall of the maternal arteries. This is a normal process, opening fire hoses of blood to supply the placenta.

963.caption: Hernia sac with thick fibrous tissue, fat, and visible mesothelial lining (arrow).
963.original_caption: . Hernia sac. Thick fibrous tissue and fat characterize the typical hernia sac. In this section, the delicate mesothelial lining (arrow) is visible.

964.caption: Appendicitis. Residual colonic mucosa (arrowhead) surrounded by fibrinopurulent debris (arrow).
964.original_caption: . Appendicitis. In this close-up view, a small amount of residual colonic-type mucosa is visible (arrowhead), surrounded by mounds of fibrinopurulent debris (arrow).

965.caption: Adult Sertoli-only syndrome. Tubules lined with spindly Sertoli cells, no germ cells.
965.original_caption: . Sertoli-only syndrome in an adult. The tubules are lined with spindly Sertoli cells, and no germ cells are visible.

966.caption: Seminoma, classic type. Fibrovascular septae divide cells into packets (arrow); lymphocytes along septae. Nuclei widely spaced, clear cytoplasm. Mitoses common (circle). Nuclei with distinct membranes, prominent nucleoli (arrowhead).
966.original_caption: . Seminoma, classic type. Delicate fibrovascular septae divide the cells into packets (arrow); collections of lymphocytes can be seen along the septae. The nuclei are widely spaced, with clear cytoplasm. Mitoses are common (circle). Nuclei have distinct nuclear membranes and prominent nucleoli (arrowhead).

967.caption: Gleason pattern 5: malignant cells, no gland formation, round nuclei, prominent nucleoli.
967.original_caption: . Gleason pattern 5. Individual malignant cells, without evidence of gland formation, are typical of pattern 5. The individual cells still cytologically resemble well-differentiated carcinoma, with round nuclei and prominent nucleoli (circle).

968.caption: Gleason pattern 4: cribriform growth (arrow) and fused glands typical of pattern 4.
968.original_caption: . Gleason pattern 4. The area of cribriform growth (arrow) and adjacent fused glands is typical of pattern 4.

969.caption: Low-grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma. Tumor resembles metaplastic epithelium in interlobular duct, with clear goblet-like mucinous cells (arrow) and squamous cells (arrowhead).
969.original_caption: . Mucoepidermoid carcinoma, low grade. This tumor resembles the metaplastic epithelium within an interlobular duct and is composed predominantly of clear goblet-like mucinous cells (arrow) and squamous cells (arrowhead).

970.caption: Nephrogenic adenoma. Bladder biopsy shows tiny tubules in lamina propria (arrowheads) with dark nuclei. Urothelium absent.
970.original_caption: . Nephrogenic adenoma. In this bladder biopsy specimen, there are multiple tiny tubules in the lamina propria (arrowheads) with prominent dark nuclei. The urothelium is not seen here.

971.caption: Reactive urothelial nuclei: enlarged, prominent nucleoli (arrow), smooth nuclear outline, pale even chromatin, benign.
971.original_caption: . Reactive nuclei. These urothelial nuclei are somewhat enlarged and have prominent nucleoli (arrow) but retain a smooth nuclear outline and pale, even chromatin. They are benign.

972.caption: Invasive adenocarcinoma. Poorly formed glands, single cells infiltrate desmoplastic stroma. Marked pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli.
972.original_caption: . Invasive adenocarcinoma. Poorly formed glands and single cells (arrow) infiltrate through a desmoplastic stroma (arrowhead). Cells show marked pleomorphism and prominent nucleoli.

973.caption: High-grade dysplasia in adenoma. Based on cribriform growth (arrow).
973.original_caption: . High-grade dysplasia in an adenoma. The diagnosis is largely based on architectural features, such as cribriform growth (arrow).

974.caption: Fat necrosis: fat cell death post-trauma/surgery, lipid globs persist. Foamy macrophages (arrow) digest lipid; fibrosis (arrowhead) fills spaces.
974.original_caption: . Fat necrosis. In an area of fat necrosis, secondary to trauma or surgery, the fat cells die but the globs of lipid remain. Foamy macrophages ring each dead fat cell (arrow), digesting the lipid; the spaces between the fat cells are filled in by fibrosis (arrowhead).

975.caption: Fibroadenoma: well-circumscribed nodule. Secretory lobules in edematous stroma (arrowhead), ducts compressed to slit-like spaces (arrow) by proliferative stroma.
975.original_caption: . Fibroadenoma. At low power, the fibroadenoma is a well-circumscribed nodule. Within the lesion, the secretory lobules stand out in slightly edematous (pale) stroma (arrowhead), and the ducts are compressed into slit-like spaces (arrow) by the proliferative stroma.

976.caption: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in marrow. Infiltrated by large atypical cells with prominent nucleoli, thick nuclear rims, abundant cytoplasm, irregular membranes (arrow). Suggestive of DLBCL or carcinoma.
976.original_caption: . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in the marrow. The marrow is infiltrated by large atypical cells with prominent nucleoli, thick nuclear rims, abundant cytoplasm, and irregular nuclear membranes (arrow). This is suggestive of involvement by diffuse large B-cell lymphoma or carcinoma.

977.caption: Normal pancreatic acinus. Central duct (arrowhead), surrounded by secretory acini (arrow).
977.original_caption: . Normal pancreatic acinus. The duct is seen at the center (arrowhead), with surrounding acini of secretory cells (arrow).

978.caption: Simple hyperplasia. Biopsy shows proliferative, crowded glands (gland-to-stroma ratio >1). Cells resemble normal endometrium, no atypia.
978.original_caption: . Simple hyperplasia. In this biopsy specimen, the glands appear proliferative and are too crowded (the gland-to-stroma ratio is greater than 1). The cells resemble normal endometrium and are not atypical.

979.caption: Chronic endometritis. Plasma cells not visible at low power. Spindly, swirling blue stroma (arrow) suggests closer exam. Proliferative epithelium (arrowhead).
979.original_caption: . Chronic endometritis. At low power, the diagnostic plasma cells are not visible, but the spindly, swirling blue stroma (arrow) should be a clue to look more closely. The epithelium here is proliferative (arrowhead).

980.caption: Angiomyolipoma without fatty component. Classic prominent vessels and smooth muscle. Spindle cells merge with thick-walled vessels (arrow).
980.original_caption: . Angiomyolipoma. This example does not show the fatty component, but the prominent vessels (V) and smooth muscle components here are classic. In angiomyolipoma, the spindle cells seem to merge with, or spin off from, the thick-walled vessels (arrow).

981.caption: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Irregular nests and spicules invade stroma (top). Deep aberrant keratinization (arrow) indicates invasion.
981.original_caption: . Invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Irregular nests and spicules of cells invade down into the stroma from the surface (top). Although single infiltrating cells are not visible at this magnification, the deep aberrant keratinization (arrow), in which a deep nest of cells takes on the color and texture of the normal surface keratin, is highly suspicious for invasion.

982.caption: Metanephric adenoma, benign tumor with high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio. Tiny primitive blue tubules adjacent to normal kidney.
982.original_caption: . Metanephric adenoma. This benign tumor is the bluest of them all because of the very high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio of the cells. Here you can see tiny primitive blue tubules on the left, adjacent to normal kidney on the right.

983.caption: Chronic peptic duodenitis. Surface shows metaplastic change (arrow), normal cells replaced by mucinous foveolar-type cells. Increased chronic inflammation in lamina propria, Brunners gland hyperplasia (arrowhead).
983.original_caption: . Chronic peptic duodenitis. At the surface, there is a subtle metaplastic change (arrow), where the normal absorptive and goblet cells are replaced by mucinous, foveolar-type cells, similar to those seen in antrum. There is increased chronic inflammation in the lamina propria and Brunners gland hyperplasia (arrowhead).

984.caption: Multilocular cystic renal cell carcinoma. Cyst and fibrovascular septa (arrowhead) lined by clear cells with small dark nuclei (arrow); compare to conventional renal cell carcinoma.
984.original_caption: . Multilocular cystic renal cell carcinoma. The cyst and fibrovascular septa (arrowhead) are lined by single clear cells with small dark nuclei (arrow); compare these cells to conventional renal cell carcinoma (see 13.6).

985.caption: Graves disease with papillary hyperplasia. Follicular epithelium hyperplasia forms papillae. Follicular cells round, evenly spaced, dark uniform chromatin (arrow), resembling normal follicles.
985.original_caption: . Graves disease with papillary hyperplasia. These papillary formations are due to hyperplasia of the follicular epithelium. The follicular cells are round, fairly evenly spaced, and have dark uniform chromatin (arrow), similar to normal follicles.

986.caption: Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Thyroid follicles displaced by germinal centers (arrow).
986.original_caption: . Hashimotos thyroiditis. The thyroid follicles are displaced by germinal centers (arrow).

987.caption: Anaplastic carcinoma. Nests/sheets of poorly differentiated carcinoma, squamoid areas (arrow).
987.original_caption: . Anaplastic carcinoma. Nests and sheets of poorly differentiated carcinoma, some areas with a squamoid appearance (arrow).

988.caption: Medullary carcinoma. Infiltrative nests resemble anaplastic carcinoma, but nuclei are bland with pale, speckled neuroendocrine chromatin.
988.original_caption: . Medullary carcinoma. Although the pattern of infiltrative nests of cells may resemble anaplastic carcinoma, the nuclei are much more bland, with pale, finely speckled, neuroendocrine-type chromatin.

989.caption: Syncytial meningioma. Small oval nuclei cluster in syncytial groups (arrowhead) or form whorls (arrow).
989.original_caption: . Syncytial meningioma. The meningioma nuclei are small and oval and tend to cluster in syncytial groups (arrowhead) without visible cell borders, or make whorls (arrow).

990.caption: Aggressive meningioma variants. Clear cell clusters (arrow) in clear cell meningioma. Rhabdoid meningioma shows eosinophilic cells (arrow) with rhabdoid morphology.
990.original_caption: . Aggressive variants of meningioma. (A) Clusters of distended clear cells (arrow) are visible in this meningioma, indicative of clear cell meningioma. (B) Rhabdoid meningioma has plump eosinophilic cells (arrow) with rhabdoid (resembling immature skeletal muscle) morphology.

991.caption: Aggressive meningioma variants. Clear cell clusters (arrow) indicate clear cell meningioma. Rhabdoid type shows plump eosinophilic cells (arrow) with rhabdoid morphology.
991.original_caption: . Aggressive variants of meningioma. (A) Clusters of distended clear cells (arrow) are visible in this meningioma, indicative of clear cell meningioma. (B) Rhabdoid meningioma has plump eosinophilic cells (arrow) with rhabdoid (resembling immature skeletal muscle) morphology.

992.caption: Acute leukemia aspirate: sheets of blasts, high N:C ratio, immature chromatin.
992.original_caption: . Monomorphic aspirate in acute leukemia. This aspirate is composed of sheets of blasts, identified by high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratios and immature chromatin.

993.caption: Dyserythropoiesis, dysgranulopoiesis. Binucleated erythroid precursors (arrow), bilobed agranular neutrophils (arrowheads) indicate dysplasia.
993.original_caption: . Dyserythropoiesis and dysgranulopoiesis. Binucleated erythroid precursors (arrow) and bilobed neutrophils without granules (arrowheads) are indicative of dysplasia.

994.caption: Biphasic synovial sarcoma: gland-like spaces with epithelial cells (arrowhead) amid spindle cells (arrow). Monophasic lacks epithelial component, resembles fibrosarcoma.
994.original_caption: . Biphasic synovial sarcoma. There are gland-like spaces surrounded by epithelial cells (arrowhead), set in a background of spindle cells (arrow). Monophasic synovial sarcoma lacks the epithelial component and can resemble fibrosarcoma.

995.caption: Nodular fasciitis. Fusiform/stellate fibroblasts with delicate processes in myxoid background (arrow). Inflammatory component less prominent.
995.original_caption: . Nodular fasciitis. In this field the inflammatory component is not prominent, but the tissue culture pattern is seen clearly, with fusiform and stellate fibroblasts stretching delicate processes through the myxoid background (arrow).

996.caption: Adenocarcinoma in situ. Residual normal endocervical glands (arrowhead) adjacent to abnormal cells with dark, elongated, crowded, stratified nuclei. Intestinal-type goblet cells (arrow) and mitoses (circles) present.
996.original_caption: . Adenocarcinoma in situ. This field shows some residual normal endocervical glands (arrowhead) adjacent to a very abnormal population with dark, elongated, crowded, and stratified nuclei representing adenocarcinoma in situ. Occasional intestinal-type goblet cells (arrow) and mitoses (circles) are present.

997.caption: Candida in esophagus: magenta pseudohyphae & yeasts (arrows, PAS stain).
997.original_caption: . Candida. This example from the esophagus shows magenta pseudohyphae and yeasts (arrows, periodic-acid Schiff stain).

998.caption: Aspergillus. Branching hyphae visible by GMS stain.
998.original_caption: . Aspergillus. A forest of branching hyphae are visible by Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

999.caption: Cryptococcus. Same magnification as 3.14. Larger organisms, varied sizes/shapes on GMS stain.
999.original_caption: . Cryptococcus. This photograph is taken at the same magnification as 3.14. The organisms are significantly larger and show a range of sizes and shapes on Gomoris methenamine silver stain.

1000.caption: Histoplasmosis. Yeasts visible on GMS stain (40x).
1000.original_caption: . Histoplasmosis. Tiny yeasts are visible on Gomoris methenamine silver stain (40x objective).

1001.caption: Ovarian stroma: blue, cellular, fascicular/storiform. Primary follicle: central oocyte (arrow), granulosa cells (arrowhead).
1001.original_caption: . Ovarian stroma with follicle. Typical ovarian stroma is blue and cellular, with a vaguely fascicular or storiform pattern. A small primary follicle is seen with the central oocyte (arrow) and a ring of granulosa cells (arrowhead).

1002.caption: Hemorrhagic corpus luteum with luteinized granulosa cells (arrow) and blood. Corpus albicans, prior corpus luteum remnant.
1002.original_caption: . (A) Hemorrhagic corpus luteum, with undulating layers of luteinized granulosa cells (arrow) and associated blood. (B) A corpus albicans, the remnant of a prior corpus luteum.

1003.caption: Hemorrhagic corpus luteum with luteinized granulosa cells (arrow) and blood. Corpus albicans, prior corpus luteum remnant.
1003.original_caption: . (A) Hemorrhagic corpus luteum, with undulating layers of luteinized granulosa cells (arrow) and associated blood. (B) A corpus albicans, the remnant of a prior corpus luteum.

1004.caption: Reactive astrocytes: compact shape, dense pink cytoplasm, stubby processes (arrow). Normal resting astrocytes lack visible cytoplasm. Response to inflammation/injury.
1004.original_caption: . Reactive astrocytes. Normal resting astrocytes generally do not have visible cytoplasm. When responding to inflammation or injury, they become compact in shape, with dense pink cytoplasm and stubby processes (arrow).

1005.caption: Pilocytic astrocytoma: fibrillary background, large dark nuclei, Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies.
1005.original_caption: . Pilocytic astrocytoma. The classic features shown here are a fibrillary or hair-like background (1), scattered large dark nuclei (2), Rosenthal fibers (3), and eosinophilic granular bodies (4).

1006.caption: Squamous mouth dysplasia. Between arrows: dysplastic cells, high N/C ratios, hyperchromatic irregular nuclei in lower epithelium. Surface parakeratosis (arrowhead), clinically white plaque. Inset: oral keratinizing dysplasia shows prominent nucleoli (vs cervical). Note irregular nuclear membranes.
1006.original_caption: . Squamous dysplasia in the mouth. In the area between the arrows, dysplastic cells with high N/C ratios and hyperchromatic, irregular nuclei can be seen occupying the lower half of the epithelium. The surface shows parakeratosis (arrowhead), which clinically will appear as a white plaque. Inset: Unlike in cervical dysplasia, prominent nucleoli are often seen in keratinizing dysplasia of the oral cavity. Notice the irregularly shaped nuclear membranes.

1007.caption: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Immature cells persist throughout epithelium. Nuclei hyperchromatic, slightly irregular. High nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio top to bottom.
