1007.original_caption: . High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. In a high-grade lesion, paradoxically, the nuclei may not look as abnormal as in low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. The hallmark of highgrade squamous intraepithelial lesion is a persistence of immature-appearing cells throughout the epithelium. The nuclei are hyperchromatic and may have slightly irregular nuclear outlines, but the most striking feature at low power is the high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios present from top to bottom.

1008.caption: Melanoma. Large, irregular melanocytes infiltrate epidermis (pagetoid, arrowheads). No dermal component = in situ. Dermal malignant melanocytes: atypical nuclei, nucleoli (arrowhead), mitoses (arrow). Adjacent lymphocytes (asterisk) present.
1008.original_caption: . Melanoma. (A) Large, dark, irregular melanocytes can be seen infiltrating upward through the epidermis (arrowheads) in pagetoid fashion. If there were no dermal component, this would qualify as melanoma in situ. (B) Malignant melanocytes deep in the dermis. Large atypical nuclei with large nucleoli (arrowhead) plus the presence of mitoses (arrow) is diagnostic of invasive melanoma. Adjacent lymphocytes (asterisk left side of the field) are common.

1009.caption: Melanoma. Large, irregular melanocytes infiltrate epidermis (pagetoid, arrowheads). No dermal component = in situ. Dermal malignant melanocytes: atypical nuclei, nucleoli (arrowhead), mitoses (arrow). Adjacent lymphocytes (asterisk) present.
1009.original_caption: . Melanoma. (A) Large, dark, irregular melanocytes can be seen infiltrating upward through the epidermis (arrowheads) in pagetoid fashion. If there were no dermal component, this would qualify as melanoma in situ. (B) Malignant melanocytes deep in the dermis. Large atypical nuclei with large nucleoli (arrowhead) plus the presence of mitoses (arrow) is diagnostic of invasive melanoma. Adjacent lymphocytes (asterisk left side of the field) are common.

1010.caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Uterine diagnosis threshold high. Lesion more cellular than leiomyoma, with mitoses (arrow), atypical pleomorphic cells (circle), necrosis (not seen).
1010.original_caption: . Leiomyosarcoma. The threshold for diagnosing leiomyosarcoma in the uterus is high. This lesion should be a much more cellular version of the leiomyoma, with mitoses (arrow), atypical and pleomorphic cells (circle), and necrosis (not seen here).

1011.caption: Pleomorphic lipoma: benign with bizarre stromal cells mimicking sarcoma. Classic floret cell has circular wreath of nuclear lobes (arrows), suggesting diagnosis.
1011.original_caption: . Pleomorphic lipoma. This type of benign lipoma is known for having very bizarre stromal cells that mimic sarcoma. The classic cell is the floret cell, with a circular wreath of nuclear lobes (arrows). Their presence suggests the diagnosis of pleomorphic lipoma.

1012.caption: Well-differentiated liposarcoma. Increased fibrous interstitium between fat cells, atypical cells visible at low power (arrowheads).
1012.original_caption: . Well-differentiated liposarcoma. There is an increased amount of fibrous interstitium between fat cells, and atypical cells stand out at low power (arrowheads).

1013.caption: Follicular cyst lined by luteinized cells (arrow), adjacent hemosiderin (oval). Inclusion cyst lined by attenuated epithelium (arrow) or tubal metaplasia (arrowhead).
1013.original_caption: . Follicular cyst versus inclusion cyst. (A) A follicle cyst is lined by luteinized cells, similar to those seen in the corpus luteum (arrow). There is adjacent hemosiderin (oval). (B) An inclusion cyst may be lined by an attenuated epithelium, similar to the surface epithelium (arrow), or may show tubal metaplasia (arrowhead).

1014.caption: Follicular cyst lined by luteinized cells (arrow), adjacent hemosiderin (oval). Inclusion cyst lined by attenuated epithelium (arrow) or tubal metaplasia (arrowhead).
1014.original_caption: . Follicular cyst versus inclusion cyst. (A) A follicle cyst is lined by luteinized cells, similar to those seen in the corpus luteum (arrow). There is adjacent hemosiderin (oval). (B) An inclusion cyst may be lined by an attenuated epithelium, similar to the surface epithelium (arrow), or may show tubal metaplasia (arrowhead).

1015.caption: Rete ovarii: vestigial structure at ovarian hilum, adjacent to large vessels. Slit-like channels with cuboidal cell lining (arrow).
1015.original_caption: . Rete ovarii. This vestigial structure is found at the hilum of the ovary, adjacent to large arteries (A) and veins. The rete consist of slit-like channels with a cuboidal cell lining (arrow).

1016.caption: Endometrioid carcinoma. Well-differentiated foci resemble complex atypical hyperplasia. Fused cribriform glands diagnostic of carcinoma. Nuclear features similar to atypical hyperplasia.
1016.original_caption: . Endometrioid carcinoma. Foci of well-differentiated endometrioid carcinoma can be difficult to distinguish from complex atypical hyperplasia. However, the complicated proliferation of fused and cribriform glands in this biopsy specimen is diagnostic of carcinoma. The nuclei in this example resemble those of complex atypical hyperplasia.

1017.caption: Fibrocystic disease. Large dilated duct spaces, some with apocrine metaplasia (arrow). Dense, fibrotic stroma (pink).
1017.original_caption: . Fibrocystic disease. In this example, large dilated duct spaces are visible, some with a lining of apocrine metaplasia (arrow). The stroma is dense and fibrotic (pink).

1022.caption: Foamy macrophages, papillary RCC.
1022.original_caption: . Foamy macrophages, papillary renal cell carcinoma.

1024.caption: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. Abrupt transition (arrow) between normal (left) and dysplastic (right) epithelium. Right shows immature cells (large nuclei, high N/C ratios) to surface. Contrast left's basal-maturing cell distinction.
1024.original_caption: . High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion. An abrupt transition (arrow) is visible between normal (left) and dysplastic (right) epithelium. The epithelium at right shows a persistence of immature cells (large nuclei and high N/C ratios) up to the surface. Compare this to the clear distinction between basal cells and maturing cells seen at left.

1025.caption: Poroma. Eccrine tumor continuous with epidermis (arrow). Tumor cells (arrowhead) uniform, small, round, pale, may form rudimentary ducts.
1025.original_caption: . Poroma. This eccrine tumor is continuous with the epidermis, which can be seen at left (arrow). The tumor cells (arrowhead) are uniform, small, round, and pale and in some areas may form rudimentary duct spaces.

1026.caption: Eccrine spiroadenoma. Dermal cannonballs tumor. Small bland cells. Cords of hyaline pink basement membrane material (arrow).
1026.original_caption: . Eccrine spiroadenoma. Cannonballs in the dermis is the catch phrase for this tumor. Like the poroma, the cells are small and bland. Cords of hyaline pink basement membrane material are seen throughout the tumor (arrow).

1027.caption: Reflux esophagitis. Inflamed vs normal mucosa (6.1). Thickened basal layer (arrow), dense blue epithelium. Scattered inflammatory cells: eosinophils (circle), lymphocytes (arrowhead).
1027.original_caption: . Reflux esophagitis. Compare this inflamed epithelium to the normal mucosa in 6.1. The basal layer is increased in thickness (arrow), creating a more dense and blue look to the epithelium. There are inflammatory cells scattered throughout, including eosinophils (circle) and lymphocytes (arrowhead).

1028.caption: Normal esophageal mucosa. Basal layer (arrow) is crowded, blue. Cells mature into flat nonkeratinizing squamous cells with small nuclei; clear cytoplasm is glycogen. Vascular pegs (arrowhead) penetrate epithelium. Vascular lamina propria below basal layer.
1028.original_caption: . Normal esophageal mucosa. The basal layer (arrow) is seen as a crowded and blue layer at the base. The cells mature into flat nonkeratinizing squamous cells with small nuclei; the clear cytoplasm seen here is glycogen. Vascular pegs penetrate into the epithelium (arrowhead). The vascular lamina propria is visible below the basal layer.

1029.caption: Normal urothelium: 5-7 cell layer, large umbrella cells (arrow). Nuclei polarized, perpendicular to surface (except umbrella cells). Nuclei 2-3x lymphocyte size (arrowhead).
1029.original_caption: . Normal urothelium. The urothelial cells form a layer five to seven cells thick, with large umbrella cells sitting on top (arrow). The urothelial nuclei are generally polarized and oriented perpendicular to the surface, with the exception of the umbrella cells. The nuclei are two to three times the size of a lymphocyte (arrowhead).

1030.caption: Von Brunn's nest: urothelium invaginated into lamina propria (arrow). Cystitis glandularis: nest center shows lumen & columnar metaplasia (asterisk).
1030.original_caption: . Von Brunns nest and cystitis glandularis. The normal urothelium has invaginated down into the lamina propria, forming a rounded von Brunns nest (arrow). The center of the nest has acquired a lumen and columnar cell metaplasia (asterisk), which is known as cystitis glandularis.

1031.caption: Solar elastosis. Microscopic: sun-damaged skin. Collagen replaced by gray-blue elastin strands (arrow).
1031.original_caption: . Solar elastosis. This is the typical microscopic appearance of sun-damaged skin. The collagen is replaced by wispy gray-blue strands of elastin (arrow).

1032.caption: Chronic myeloid leukemia. Hypercellular marrow with small hypolobated megakaryocytes (arrow) and maturing/mature neutrophils (arrowhead).
1032.original_caption: . Chronic myeloid leukemia. This hypercellular marrow is full of small, hypolobated megakaryocytes (arrow) and maturing and mature neutrophils (arrowhead).

1033.caption: Marrow fibrosis. H&E stain shows streaming texture (arrow), collagen strands separating hematopoietic cells into nests/channels.
1033.original_caption: . Marrow fibrosis. On hematoxylin and eosin stain, the marrow has a streaming texture (arrow), indicative of strands of collagen separating the hematopoietic cells into nests and channels.

1034.caption: Polymorphous low-grade adenocarcinoma. Small tubules of bland cells infiltrate benign mucinous glands. PLGA resembles pleomorphic adenoma but invades surrounding tissues, sometimes as single-file lines like lobular breast carcinoma.
1034.original_caption: . Polymorphous low-grade adenocarcinoma. Small tubules of bland cells (arrow) creep between benign mucinous glands (arrowhead). On high power, these infiltrative cells resemble those of the pleomorphic adenoma, but, unlike that benign tumor, the PLGA infiltrates surrounding tissues. PLGA cells may also invade as single-file lines, like lobular breast carcinoma.

1035.caption: Acute inflammation, abscess formation. Neutrophils (1), extravasated blood (2), capillaries (3), fibrin (4). Inset: mixed infiltrate - plasma cells (PC), neutrophils, eosinophils (Eo), lymphocytes.
1035.original_caption: . Acute inflammation and abscess formation. This example of the acute inflammatory response shows collections of neutrophils (abscess formation, 1), extravasated blood (2), prominent capillaries (3), and fibrin accumulation (4). Inset: the mixed inflammatory infiltrate includes plasma cells (PC), neutrophils (N), eosinophils (Eo), and lymphocytes (L).

1036.caption: Granulation tissue shows loose myxoid stroma with fibroblasts, inflammatory cells, and thick-walled capillaries featuring plump endothelial cells. Stroma condenses around capillaries, forming pink halos (arrow).
1036.original_caption: . Granulation tissue is characterized by a loose myxoid background with fibroblasts and inflammatory cells and by prominent capillaries with plump endothelial cells and thick walls. The stroma appears condensed and thickened around the capillaries, giving them a pink halo (arrow).

1037.caption: Hyperplastic polyp, corkscrew glands, hyperplastic foveolar epithelium. Inflammation, intestinal metaplasia possible.
1037.original_caption: . Hyperplastic polyp. This polyp is reminiscent of chemical gastritis, with corkscrew glands (arrow) and hyperplastic foveolar epithelium. Inflammation and intestinal metaplasia may be present.

1038.caption: Fundic gland polyp with oxyntic/fundic-type glands, occasional dilated glands.
1038.original_caption: . Fundic gland polyp. This polypoid fragment shows oxyntic- or fundic-type glands, with occasional dilated glands (circle).

1039.caption: Dermal scar. Pale, homogeneous collagen beneath epidermis, obliterated adnexal structures, typical scar formation.
1039.original_caption: . Dermal scar. Pale and homogeneous collagen underneath the epidermis, with obliteration of adnexal structures, is typical of scar formation.

1040.caption: Yolk sac tumor cells: cuboidal, pink cytoplasm, microcystic pattern, low-grade vs other germ cell tumors.
1040.original_caption: . Yolk sac tumor. The cells of yolk sac tumor often appear more low grade than other germ cell tumor types. The cells are cuboidal, with pink cytoplasm, and have a tendency to pull apart into a microcystic pattern (shown here).

1041.caption: Carotid plaque: intimal surface with calcification, foamy macrophages (arrowhead), cholesterol clefts (arrow), inflammatory debris.
1041.original_caption: . Carotid plaque. This represents the intimal surface of the artery, in which there may be calcification, foamy macrophages (arrowhead), cholesterol clefts (arrow), or inflammatory debris.

1042.caption: Intervertebral disc: paucicellular, homogeneous translucent stroma (myxoid to collagenous).
1042.original_caption: . Intervertebral disc. The disc substance is paucicellular, with a homogeneous translucent stroma (ranging from myxoid to collagenous).

1043.caption: Portal tract with limiting plate, hepatic artery, bile ductule, portal vein. Central vein from same liver. Both show extensive steatosis.
1043.original_caption: . Portal tract and central vein. The upper panel shows a typical portal tract surrounded by the limiting plate of hepatocytes (1) and containing a branch of the hepatic artery (2), bile ductule (3), and portal vein (4). The lower panel shows a central vein from the same liver. Both panels show extensive steatosis.

1044.caption: Portal tract: limiting plate hepatocytes (1), hepatic artery (2), bile ductule (3), portal vein (4). Central vein. Both show extensive steatosis.
1044.original_caption: . Portal tract and central vein. The upper panel shows a typical portal tract surrounded by the limiting plate of hepatocytes (1) and containing a branch of the hepatic artery (2), bile ductule (3), and portal vein (4). The lower panel shows a central vein from the same liver. Both panels show extensive steatosis.

1045.caption: Endocervical glands: tall columnar cells, apical mucin, small basal nuclei (arrow).
1045.original_caption: . Endocervical glands. Normal endocervical glands are composed of tall columnar cells with apical mucin and small basal nuclei (arrow).

1046.caption: Squamous metaplasia at transition zone. Mature squamous epithelium right of arrow, metaplasia left. Metaplastic nuclei larger, immature; cytoplasm denser.
1046.original_caption: . Squamous metaplasia at the transition zone. Mature squamous epithelium is seen to the right of the arrow, and squamous metaplasia is seen to the left. In squamous metaplasia, the nuclei may be larger and more immature appearing and the cytoplasm more dense.

1047.caption: Infarct vs perivillous fibrin. Infarct shows basophilia loss, apoptotic bodies (coagulative necrosis). Perivillous fibrin: consolidated pink sheet, but villi viable with intact nuclear detail.
1047.original_caption: . Infarct versus perivillous fibrin. (A) In an infarct, there is loss of basophilia and cellular detail with residual apoptotic bodies, as in coagulative necrosis elsewhere. (B) In a mass of perivillous fibrin, while the low power impression is a sheet of consolidated pink, on high power you can see the villi remain viable, with good nuclear detail.

1048.caption: Infarct vs perivillous fibrin. Infarct: loss of basophilia, cellular detail, apoptotic bodies (coagulative necrosis). Perivillous fibrin: consolidated pink sheet, viable villi with good nuclear detail.
1048.original_caption: . Infarct versus perivillous fibrin. (A) In an infarct, there is loss of basophilia and cellular detail with residual apoptotic bodies, as in coagulative necrosis elsewhere. (B) In a mass of perivillous fibrin, while the low power impression is a sheet of consolidated pink, on high power you can see the villi remain viable, with good nuclear detail.

1049.caption: Endometrial stromal breakdown. Condensed blue stroma (arrow). Papillary tufts of pink metaplastic epithelium, some ciliated (arrowhead).
1049.original_caption: . Endometrial stromal breakdown. The stroma is condensed into an extremely blue mass of tightly packed cells (arrow). The overlying epithelium is expanded into papillary tufts of pink cells, some with cilia, which is a metaplastic change (arrowhead).

1050.caption: Benign endometrial polyp with cystic gland dilation (1), secretory epithelium (2), thickened arteries (3), and collagen-rich pink stroma.
1050.original_caption: . Benign endometrial polyp. This polyp shows cystic dilation of glands (1), secretory-type epithelium (2), and thickened arteries (3). The stroma is also pink, indicating a high collagen content.

1051.caption: Seminal vesicle biopsy: scattered large, hyperchromatic, crowded nuclei (arrowhead). Cytoplasmic golden pigment (arrow) confirms seminal vesicle.
1051.original_caption: . Seminal vesicle in a biopsy specimen. There are scattered large, hyperchromatic, and crowded nuclei in this gland (arrowhead). However, golden pigment is visible in the cytoplasm (arrow), identifying this as seminal vesicle.

1052.caption: Small lymphocytic lymphoma. Lymph node shows flat blue appearance, lacks normal sinuses/follicles. Subtle pale pseudofollicles present. Cells small with round dense nuclei; chromatin shows soccer-ball pattern like plasma cells.
1052.original_caption: . Small lymphocytic lymphoma. The lymph node, at low power, is an unnatural flat blue, without the variegation of normal sinuses and follicles. Subtle pale pseudofollicles (arrow) may be seen. Inset: The cells are small and nuclei are round and dense, like normal lymphocytes, except the chromatin has a chunky soccer-ball pattern, similar to a plasma cell.

1053.caption: Normal melanocyte (1) with clear cytoplasmic halo. Basal keratinocytes (2) absorb melanin. Basket weave orthokeratin (3) present.
1053.original_caption: . Normal melanocyte and skin. A normal melanocyte (1) stands out within a clear halo of cytoplasm. The pigmented component of the skin is actually the basal keratinocytes (2), which absorb the melanin. Typical basket weave or orthokeratin is present (3).

1054.caption: Intradermal nevus with melanophages. Nevus cells (arrowhead) show focal pigment specks; macrophages (arrow) digest excess melanin.
1054.original_caption: . Melanophages in an intradermal nevus. The nevus cells (arrowhead) have focal small specks of pigment, but the macrophages digesting the excess melanin (arrow) stand out.

1055.caption: Active colitis. Neutrophils in crypt epithelium (arrow), ulcerated surface (arrowhead).
1055.original_caption: . Active colitis. Neutrophils are seen in the epithelium of the crypts (arrow), and the surface is ulcerated (arrowhead).

1056.caption: Carcinoid tumor. Nests/ribbons of cells with delicate fibrovascular septa. Round regular nuclei, finely speckled chromatin.
1056.original_caption: . Carcinoid tumor. Nests and ribbons of cells separated by delicate fibrovascular septa are classic, as are the round and regular nuclei with finely speckled chromatin.

1057.caption: Reactive bronchial epithelium overlying carcinoid tumor. Proliferative epithelium with enlarged, crowded nuclei, but cilia (arrows) confirm benign cells.
1057.original_caption: . Reactive bronchial epithelium overlying a carcinoid tumor. Although the epithelium is very proliferative and has enlarged and crowded nuclei, the presence of cilia (arrows) indicates that these cells are benign.

1058.caption: Tubular adenoma with low-grade dysplasia in surface glands (arrow), deeper glands uninvolved (arrowhead). Dark adenomatous epithelium: crowded hyperchromatic nuclei, lost mucinous goblet cells. Mitotic activity, neutrophils common.
1058.original_caption: . Tubular adenoma. This section shows an early tubular adenoma in which low-grade dysplasia is seen in the surface glands (arrow), while the deeper glands are uninvolved (arrowhead). The adenomatous epithelium is dark due to crowded and hyperchromatic nuclei and loss of mucinous goblet cells. Mitotic activity and neutrophils are common in adenomas but may also be seen in benign epithelium.

1059.caption: Normal colon: mucosa with parallel crypts, lamina propria (LP), muscularis mucosa (MM), submucosal arteries/veins/lymphatics.
1059.original_caption: . Normal colon. Section through colonic mucosa showing parallel crypts (C), lamina propria (LP), muscularis mucosa (MM), and submucosal arteries (A), veins (V), and lymphatics (L).

1060.caption: Thickened urothelium with nuclei perpendicular to surface. Plump umbrella cells visible (arrow).
1060.original_caption: . Polarity in an epithelium. In this section of urothelium, although it is thickened relative to normal, all of the nuclei can be seen to be roughly perpendicular to the surface; they know which way is up. Plump umbrella cells are visible at the surface (arrow).

1061.caption: Residual islets of Langerhans. Neuroendocrine cells persist in chronic pancreatitis, infiltrating fibrotic stroma (arrowheads). Small, round, dense nuclei differ from pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
1061.original_caption: . Residual islets of Langerhans. Neuroendocrine cells are among the last to go in chronic pancreatitis and appear to infiltrate through the fibrotic stroma (arrowheads). However, their small, round, dense, regular nuclei do not resemble pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

1062.caption: Leiomyoma of colon: smooth muscle cell bundles parallel/perpendicular (*). Benign features: elongated pale nuclei with paranuclear vacuoles (▲), occasional corkscrew nuclei (→), wavy pink fibers between nuclei.
1062.original_caption: . Leiomyoma of colon. As in the leiomyoma of the uterus, there are smooth muscle cells in bundles running parallel to and perpendicular to (asterisk) the slide. The features of benign smooth muscle include elongated pale nuclei with paranuclear vacuoles (arrowhead) and occasional corkscrew nuclei in which the nuclei appear twisted (arrow). Wavy pink muscle fibers are usually visible between the nuclei.

1063.caption: Myxopapillary ependymoma: papillary neoplasm with vascular cores, myxoid stroma (arrow), lined by ependymal cells.
1063.original_caption: . Myxopapillary ependymoma. The tumor is a papillary neoplasm with vascular cores surrounded by a myxoid stroma (arrow) and lined by ependymal cells.

1064.caption: Ependymoma. Fibrillary background, cells lining vessels (arrow), ependymal processes extending to vessels, nuclei around perimeter. Pseudorosette; true rosettes have central lumen, not vessel.
1064.original_caption: . Ependymoma. There is a fibrillary background and a tendency for the cells to line up around vessels (arrow), with the ependymal cell processes extending to the vessel and the nuclei around the perimeter. This is actually an example of a pseudorosette; true rosettes have a lumen, not a vessel, at the center.

1065.caption: Acute myeloid leukemia. Marrow biopsy shows sheets of immature cells, scant hematopoietic elements. Dark nucleoli on H&E stain. Aspirate reveals myeloblast clusters with clear nucleoli (arrow). Visible mitosis (arrowhead), not unusual in marrow.
1065.original_caption: . Acute myeloid leukemia. (A) The marrow biopsy material shows sheets of immature cells, with little or no background hematopoietic elements. Nucleoli appear dark on hematoxylin and eosin stain. (B) The aspirate shows clusters of myeloblasts with clear nucleoli (arrow). A large mitosis is visible (arrowhead); this in itself is not an unusual finding in the marrow.

1066.caption: Acute myeloid leukemia. Marrow biopsy shows sheets of immature cells, scant hematopoietic elements. Nucleoli dark on H&E. Aspirate clusters of myeloblasts with clear nucleoli (arrow). Large mitosis visible (arrowhead).
1066.original_caption: . Acute myeloid leukemia. (A) The marrow biopsy material shows sheets of immature cells, with little or no background hematopoietic elements. Nucleoli appear dark on hematoxylin and eosin stain. (B) The aspirate shows clusters of myeloblasts with clear nucleoli (arrow). A large mitosis is visible (arrowhead); this in itself is not an unusual finding in the marrow.

1067.caption: Solid pseudopapillary tumor. Small plasmacytoid cells with neuroendocrine chromatin mimic islet cell tumor or acinar cell carcinoma. Rosette-like growth around fibrovascular cores (arrows) with cell dropout is typical.
1067.original_caption: . Solid pseudopapillary tumor. The small plasmacytoid cells with neuroendocrine-type chromatin could be mistaken for islet cell tumor or acinar cell carcinoma. However, this growth pattern, with rosette-like growth around fibrovascular cores (arrows) and dropout of the intervening cells, is typical of the solid pseudopapillary tumor.

1068.caption: Cryptorchidism. Infant testis shows large dark spermatogonia (arrow).
1068.original_caption: . Cryptorchidism. In the infant testis, large dark spermatogonia are visible (arrow).

1069.caption: Normal epididymis. Columnar ciliated epithelium.
1069.original_caption: . Normal epididymis. Columnar epithelium with cilia.

1070.caption: Acute rejection: lymphocytes attack bile ducts & venules, invading duct epithelium (arrows).
1070.original_caption: . Acute rejection. Acute rejection refers to the attack on the bile ducts and venules by lymphocytes, which are seen invading the duct epithelium (arrows).

1071.caption: Antral & oxyntic mucosa. Oxyntic: thick, secretory cells (parietal/chief) dominate (arrow), mucinous foveolar surface. Antral: thinner, mucinous glands (arrow), foveolar epithelium (arrowhead).
1071.original_caption: . Antral and oxyntic mucosa. (A) Oxyntic mucosa is relatively thick, with most of the mucosa occupied by secretory cells (arrow), the parietal and chief cells. The surface is composed of mucinous foveolar epithelium. (B) Antral mucosa is thinner, and the glands are mucinous instead of secretory (arrow). However, the surface is still composed of foveolar epithelium (arrowhead).

1072.caption: Antral & oxyntic mucosa. Oxyntic: thick, parietal/chief cells (arrow), mucinous foveolar surface. Antral: thinner, mucinous glands (arrow), foveolar epithelium (arrowhead).
1072.original_caption: . Antral and oxyntic mucosa. (A) Oxyntic mucosa is relatively thick, with most of the mucosa occupied by secretory cells (arrow), the parietal and chief cells. The surface is composed of mucinous foveolar epithelium. (B) Antral mucosa is thinner, and the glands are mucinous instead of secretory (arrow). However, the surface is still composed of foveolar epithelium (arrowhead).

1073.caption: Follicular carcinoma resembles follicular adenoma with microfollicular pattern and thick capsule. Vascular invasion in capsule diagnostic. Tumor plug (asterisk) in vessel lumen (arrow), endothelialized surface (arrowhead).
1073.original_caption: . Follicular carcinoma. The neoplasm here resembles a follicular adenoma at low power, with a dense microfollicular pattern and a thick capsule. However, there is vascular invasion in the capsule, diagnostic of follicular carcinoma. A tumor plug (asterisk) is seen in the lumen of a large vessel (arrow). The surface of the tumor plug becomes endothelialized (arrowhead).

1074.caption: Hurthle cell adenoma with thick fibrous capsule (arrow). Cells show abundant pink cytoplasm, round nonoverlapping nuclei, but increased atypia: prominent nucleoli and irregular nuclear shapes.
1074.original_caption: . Hurthle cell adenoma. Like follicular adenomas, there is a thick fibrous capsule surrounding the neoplasm (arrow). In a Hurthle cell adenoma, the cells have abundant pink cytoplasm, and, although the nuclei are still overall round and nonoverlapping, there is increased nuclear atypia in the form of some prominent nucleoli and irregular nuclear shapes.

1075.caption: Brenner tumor. Nests of transitional-type epithelium (resembling urothelium; arrow) in fibrotic stroma. Gland-like spaces with pink secretions (arrowhead).
1075.original_caption: . Brenner tumor. Nests of transitional-type epithelium (resembling urothelium; arrow) in a fibrotic stroma are typical. Some form gland-like spaces with pink secretions (arrowhead).

1076.caption: Immature neural tissue, teratoma. Hypocellular and dense small round blue cell areas suggest fetal brain. Rosettes (arrow) present. Indicates immature component.
1076.original_caption: . Immature neural tissue, teratoma. The combination of hypocellular areas and dense small round blue cell areas are suggestive of fetal brain. Rosettes (arrow) may also be seen. Finding this histology in a teratoma indicates an immature component.

1077.caption: Mucinous carcinoma. Extruded mucin dissects stroma. Floating cell clumps (arrow) diagnostic of mucinous/colloid carcinoma.
1077.original_caption: . Mucinous carcinoma. Pools of extruded mucin dissect into the stroma. Although this can occur in benign mucocele-like lesions, the presence of floating clumps of cells (arrow) is diagnostic of mucinous, or colloid, carcinoma.

1078.caption: Gleason pattern 3: well-formed malignant glands, blue mucin present (arrow).
1078.original_caption: . Gleason pattern 3. Individual, well-formed malignant glands make up pattern 3 cancer. Blue mucin, often associated with carcinoma, is present (arrow).

1079.caption: Normal adrenal cortex: cells have discrete cytoplasmic vacuoles indenting nuclei, creating stellate outline (arrow). Differs from clear cell carcinoma.
1079.original_caption: . Normal adrenal cortex. Unlike clear cell carcinoma, the cells of the adrenal cortex have discrete cytoplasmic vacuoles that indent the nuclei, creating a stellate outline around the nucleus (arrow).

1080.caption: Dysplastic nevus. Elongated nests of spindly melanocytes bridge adjacent rete (arrow), single melanocytes trail to lesion edge (arrowhead), architectural disorder. Inset: Atypical melanocytes with large nuclei, nucleoli at dermoepidermal junction.
1080.original_caption: . Dysplastic nevus. At low power, elongated nests of spindly melanocytes are seen bridging across adjacent rete (arrow), and single melanocytes trail off to the lateral edge of the lesion (arrowhead). These are features of architectural disorder. Inset: Atypical melanocytes with large nuclei and nucleoli are seen at the dermoepidermal junction.

1081.caption: Mixed cellularity Hodgkins lymphoma. Lymph node effaced by heterogeneous population, slightly pink. Few Reed-Sternberg variants, dominant eosinophils.
1081.original_caption: . Mixed cellularity Hodgkins lymphoma. (A) At low power, the lymph node appears to be effaced by a heterogeneous population, giving a slightly pink color to the node (compare to small lymphocytic lymphoma in 21.7). (B) The Reed-Sternberg variants are few and far between (arrow), with a dominant population of eosinophils (arrowhead).

1082.caption: Mixed cellularity Hodgkins lymphoma. Lymph node effaced by heterogeneous population, slightly pink. Few Reed-Sternberg variants, dominant eosinophils.
1082.original_caption: . Mixed cellularity Hodgkins lymphoma. (A) At low power, the lymph node appears to be effaced by a heterogeneous population, giving a slightly pink color to the node (compare to small lymphocytic lymphoma in 21.7). (B) The Reed-Sternberg variants are few and far between (arrow), with a dominant population of eosinophils (arrowhead).

1083.caption: Wilms tumor: small round blue cell tumor with three components - epithelium (primitive tubules), stroma (mesenchymal), blastema (most primitive). Ratios vary.
1083.original_caption: . Wilms tumor. This small round blue cell tumor classically has three components: (1) epithelium, in which the cells form primitive tubules; (2) stroma, the mesenchymal component; and (3) blastema, the most primitive and undifferentiated component. Ratios may vary by tumor.

1085.caption: Normal bronchus: ciliated columnar epithelium (1), goblet cells (2), cartilage (3), smooth muscle (4). Small arteries (5) are bronchial artery branches carrying oxygenated blood.
1085.original_caption: . Normal bronchus. The bronchus is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium (1), foci of goblet cells (2), cartilage (3), and smooth muscle (4). The small arteries seen here (5) are branches of the bronchial artery, which carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle.

1086.caption: Bronchioles lined by cuboidal epithelium, smooth muscle. Adjacent pulmonary arteriole branch. Veins in septa. Alveolar walls with type I epithelium nuclei. Alveolar macrophages present.
1086.original_caption: . Bronchioles and alveoli. The small bronchiole (B) seen here is lined by a cuboidal epithelium and smooth muscle. The large adjacent arteriole (A) is a branch of the pulmonary artery. The veins or venules (V) run in septa. The alveolar walls (arrow) are normally lined with flat type I epithelium, of which only the nuclei are visible. Alveolar macrophages (arrowheads) are common.

1087.caption: Hemangiopericytoma. Staghorn vessel with small blue cells, epithelioid to spindled.
1087.original_caption: . Hemangiopericytoma. A typical staghorn vessel in a background of small blue cells that are somewhere between epithelioid and spindled.

1088.caption: Insular carcinoma. Tumor shows ribbons, cords, slit-like spaces, no microfollicles.
1088.original_caption: . Insular carcinoma. Instead of microfollicles, the tumor has acquired a pattern of ribbons, cords, and slit-like spaces.

1089.caption: Papillary carcinoma, low power. Clear nuclei give glassy appearance (arrow). Incidental microcarcinoma in Hashimoto's thyroiditis (germinal centers, arrowhead).
1089.original_caption: . Papillary carcinoma, low power. The nuclear features of papillary carcinoma are eyecatching even at low power, as the clear nuclei give a translucent or glassy appearance to the tumor nodule (arrow). This is an example of an incidental microcarcinoma, arising in Hashimotos thyroiditis (note germinal centers, arrowhead).

1090.caption: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN3). Biopsy shows hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis (arrowhead) over blue squamous epithelium. Loss of polarity, high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios. Occasional atypical cells (arrow).
1090.original_caption: . Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN3). This biopsy specimen shows hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis (arrowhead) overlying a very blue squamous epithelium. Although the nuclear changes are not as obvious as in high-grade cervical lesions, there is loss of polarity and high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratios in the superficial epithelium. Occasional large atypical cells (arrow) are visible.

1091.caption: Condyloma: exophytic lesion with fibrovascular cores (arrowhead), thickened hyperkeratotic squamous epithelium (arrow). Koilocytic/LSIL changes not always obvious.
1091.original_caption: . Condyloma. This exophytic lesion has prominent fibrovascular cores (arrowhead) underlying a thickened and hyperkeratotic squamous epithelium (arrow). Koilocytic or LSIL-type changes are not always obvious in condylomas.

1092.caption: Mycobacteria on AFB stain: wine-red rods in tissue (arrows).
1092.original_caption: . Mycobacteria on acid-fast bacteria stain. In this example, tiny wine-red rods are visible within the tissue (arrows).

1093.caption: Pneumocystis in lung, same power as Figs 3.14-3.15, stained with Gomori methenamine silver.
1093.original_caption: . Pneumocystis. This photograph in the lung is taken at the same power as Figures 3.14 and 3.15. The organisms are stained with Gomoris methenamine silver stain.

1094.caption: Immature squamous metaplasia. Tangential cut resembles lesion. Concentric whorls with central pink cytoplasm pools (Yosemite mud puddles pattern) indicate benign squamous metaplasia.
1094.original_caption: . Immature squamous metaplasia. A tangential cut of squamous metaplasia can look like a lesion. However, this pattern of concentric whorls of cells with central pools of pink cytoplasm (resembling the boiling mud puddles of Yosemite) is typical of benign squamous metaplasia.

1095.caption: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion: dysplastic nuclei irregular, interlocking, dark granular chromatin, occasional nucleoli. Reactive changes: nuclei enlarged but smooth/oval, fine pale chromatin, small dense nucleoli.
1095.original_caption: . Dysplasia versus reactive changes. (A) In this example of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, the dysplastic nuclei are irregularly shaped and appear to interlock together like stones in a wall (arrow). The quality of the chromatin is characteristic as well; it is dark and granular. Occasional nucleoli are visible (arrowhead), but they are surrounded by clumpy chromatin within the nucleus. (B) In reactive changes, the nuclei may be enlarged, but each nucleus remains smooth and oval in shape. The chromatin has a fine, even texture and is pale in color compared to the dysplastic cells in A. Small dense nucleoli are visible in many of the cells (arrow).

1096.caption: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion: dysplastic nuclei irregular, interlocking, dark granular chromatin, occasional nucleoli. Reactive changes: nuclei enlarged but smooth/oval, fine pale chromatin, small dense nucleoli.
1096.original_caption: . Dysplasia versus reactive changes. (A) In this example of high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, the dysplastic nuclei are irregularly shaped and appear to interlock together like stones in a wall (arrow). The quality of the chromatin is characteristic as well; it is dark and granular. Occasional nucleoli are visible (arrowhead), but they are surrounded by clumpy chromatin within the nucleus. (B) In reactive changes, the nuclei may be enlarged, but each nucleus remains smooth and oval in shape. The chromatin has a fine, even texture and is pale in color compared to the dysplastic cells in A. Small dense nucleoli are visible in many of the cells (arrow).

1097.caption: Pleomorphic adenoma with bluish myxoid stroma. Small benign epithelial cells form cords/tubules within stroma. Epithelial-stroma ratio varies.
1097.original_caption: . Pleomorphic adenoma. A cluster of cells is visible within the bluish myxoid stroma of a pleomorphic adenoma. The epithelial cells are small and cytologically benign, and they appear as small cords and tubules set within the stroma. The proportion of epithelial cells to stroma can vary widely.

1098.caption: Warthin's tumor: cyst lined by double-layer oncocytic cells (arrow) over dense lymphoid infiltrate.
1098.original_caption: . Warthins tumor. This cyst is lined by a double layer of oncocytic cells (arrow) overlying a dense lymphoid infiltrate.

1099.caption: Acute myeloid leukemia-ETO. Blasts show pink cytoplasm with pale hof, peripheral blue rim, and pink granules (arrow).
1099.original_caption: . Acute myeloid leukemia-ETO. A population of the blasts have pink cytoplasm with pale hof, a peripheral blue rim, and pink granules (arrow).

1100.caption: Acute myeloid leukemia inv(16). Marrow: sheets of immature myeloid cells (blasts) and numerous eosinophils.
1100.original_caption: . Acute myeloid leukemia inv (16). The marrow shows sheets of immature myeloid cells (the aspirate showed blasts) and numerous eosinophils.

1101.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia: expanded basal cell layer, some with prominent nucleoli (arrow). Benign epithelium (arrowhead) shows pale, greyish nuclei.
1101.original_caption: . Basal cell hyperplasia. This proliferation of cells, some with prominent nucleoli (arrow), is actually an expanded basal cell layer. Comparison with benign epithelium (arrowhead) shows the relatively pale and greyish nuclei of the basal cells.

1102.caption: Radiation atypia in benign prostate. Scattered nuclear pleomorphism (arrow). Enlarged nuclei with dense, smudgy chromatin.
1102.original_caption: . Radiation atypia in benign prostate. There is scattered and random nuclear pleomorphism (arrow). Enlarged nuclei classically have dense, uniform, smudgy chromatin.

1103.caption: Carcinoma in detrusor muscle. Thick muscle bands (arrowheads) flank tumor cell nest (arrow).
1103.original_caption: . Carcinoma in detrusor muscle. Thick bands of muscle (arrowheads) are seen on either side of a nest of tumor cells (arrow).

1104.caption: Invasive urothelial carcinoma arising from flat carcinoma in situ above basement membrane (arrow). Lamina propria tumor nests appear pinker than surface CIS, showing paradoxical differentiation.
1104.original_caption: . Invasive urothelial carcinoma. In this case, the carcinoma is arising out of flat carcinoma in situ, seen above the basement membrane (arrow). The nests of tumor in the lamina propria appear more pink than the surface carcinoma in situ, corresponding to paradoxical differentiation.

1105.caption: Intraductal papilloma fills subareolar duct; florid usual ductal hyperplasia fuses branches, distinct fibrovascular cores visible (arrow). Inset: myoepithelial cells (arrowheads) differentiate from papillary carcinoma.
1105.original_caption: . Intraductal papilloma. The branching structure fills a subareolar duct; smaller, more distal examples may be called micropapillomas. Although there is florid usual ductal hyperplasia, resulting in fusion of multiple branches of the papilloma, distinct fibrovascular cores are still visible (arrow). Inset: Along each fibrovascular core, you should still see myoepithelial cells (arrowheads), which differentiates this from a papillary carcinoma.

1106.caption: Leydig cell tumor, reminiscent of oncocytomas. Most benign.
1106.original_caption: . Leydig cell tumor. These neoplasms are reminiscent of oncocytomas in other sites. Most are benign.

1107.caption: Sertoli cell tumor recapitulates seminiferous tubules. Stroma hyalinized (arrow).
1107.original_caption: . Sertoli cell tumor. This tumor attempts to recapitulate the seminiferous tubules. The stroma may become hyalinized (arrow).

1108.caption: Cholesteatoma: pink keratin layers, thin epithelium surrounds keratin nodule (arrow).
1108.original_caption: . Cholesteatoma. The specimen is dominated by layers of pink keratin; the thin epithelium can be seen surrounding the keratin nodule (arrow).

1109.caption: Allergic mucin in sinusitis with tiger-striped appearance (arrow) from eosinophils, mucin, debris. Inset: GMS stain shows fungal hyphae (arrowhead).
1109.original_caption: . Allergic mucin in sinusitis. The allergic mucin takes on a characteristic tiger-striped appearance (arrow) as layers of eosinophils, mucin, and cell debris accumulate. Inset: A Gomoris methenamine silver stain shows black fungal hyphae (arrowhead).

1110.caption: Invasive adenocarcinoma invading stroma as glands (asterisk), cords (arrow), single cells (arrowhead). Prominent nucleoli, atypical for dysplasia.
1110.original_caption: . Invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma can be seen invading the stroma as glands (asterisk), cords (arrow), and single cells (arrowhead). Notice the prominent nucleoli, which are not typically a feature of dysplasia.

1111.caption: High-grade dysplasia. Nuclei show hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, disorganization (arrow). Glands exhibit cribriform growth (arrowhead). Focus suspicious for invasion (circle).
1111.original_caption: . High-grade dysplasia. Nuclei here show marked hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and disorganization (arrow), and the glands are beginning to show cribriform growth ( arrowhead). There is a focus suspicious for invasion highlighted in the circle.

1112.caption: Lipoblast with small fat vacuoles indenting nucleus (arrow) in well-differentiated liposarcoma. Fibrous septa contain sarcoma cells (arrowhead) with irregular, large, dark nuclei.
1112.original_caption: . Lipoblast. Small fat vacuoles indent the nucleus of this lipoblast (arrow), seen in a welldifferentiated liposarcoma. Other cells within the fibrous septa (arrowhead) have the look of sarcoma cells, with irregular, large, dark nuclei.

1113.caption: Solar lentigo. Prominent rete extending from epidermis (arrow), increased basal pigmentation. Underlying solar elastosis. Contrast with lentigo simplex (27.3) showing melanocyte proliferation.
1113.original_caption: . Solar lentigo. Prominent rete are growing down from the epidermis (arrow), with increased basal pigmentation (not clearly visible at this power). Notice the underlying solar elastosis. Compare this lesion to the lentigo simplex (see 27.3), which, in contrast, shows a proliferation of melanocytes.

1114.caption: Actinic keratosis: disorganized enlarged nuclei (1), atypical mitoses (2), dysplasia. Hyperkeratosis/parakeratosis (3), solar elastosis (4). Tangential cut makes lesion appear thick.
1114.original_caption: . Actinic keratosis. This example shows an area of disorganized and enlarged nuclei (1) with prominent and atypical mitoses (2), consistent with dysplasia. There is overlying hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis (3) and underlying solar elastosis (4). This is a slightly tangential cut through the skin, making the lesion appear very thick.

1115.caption: Astrocytoma, grade II. Hypercellular tissue with scattered large, irregular nuclei and coarse chromatin (malignant astrocytes). Fibrillary background with diffuse neuropil network and malignant astrocyte processes.
1115.original_caption: . Astrocytoma, grade II. This field of tissue is hypercellular relative to normal brain. There are scattered large nuclei with irregular shapes and coarse chromatin (arrows); these are malignant astrocytes. The background is fibrillary (arrowhead), meaning there is a diffuse network of native neuropil and the processes of the malignant astrocytes.

1116.caption: Glioblastoma multiforme with necrosis (arrow) and microvascular proliferation (arrowheads), forming glomeruloid capillaries. Malignant astrocytes show gemistocytic morphology (eccentric nuclei, pink cytoplasm). Inset: High-power view of astrocytes with enlarged irregular nuclei and mitoses (arrows).
1116.original_caption: . Glioblastoma multiforme. In this example, there is both necrosis (arrow) and microvascular proliferation (outlined by arrowheads). The microvascular proliferation is an expanding tangle of capillaries, some of which make glomeruloid forms. Many of the malignant astrocytes in this field have a gemistocytic morphology (eccentric nuclei and abundant pink cytoplasm). Inset: A high-power view of malignant astrocytes with enlarged and irregular nuclei and multiple mitoses (arrows).

1117.caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma: rare tumor with fibrotic/sclerotic background, capillary spaces (arrowhead), single cells with intracytoplasmic lumens containing RBCs (arrow).
1117.original_caption: . Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. A rare but distinctive tumor, the epithelioid hemangioendothelioma is characterized by a dense fibrotic or sclerotic background, with small capillary spaces (arrowhead) and single cells with intracytoplasmic lumens complete with red blood cells (arrow).

1118.caption: Angiosarcoma. Tumor cells form solid sheets with visible vascular spaces filled with blood. Large hyperchromatic malignant cells protrude into lumina (hobnail pattern, arrow). Prominent nucleoli present.
1118.original_caption: . Angiosarcoma. In some areas the tumor cells have begun to grow as a solid sheet, but there are still vascular spaces visible, and full of blood. Large and hyperchromatic malignant cells protrude into the lumina (arrow) in a hobnail pattern. The tumor cells also show prominent nucleoli.

1119.caption: Thymus: lobulated, resembles lymph node, lacks germinal centers. Hassalls corpuscles (arrow) visible as pink whorls.
1119.original_caption: . Thymus. The lobulated thymus resembles lymph node at low power but should not have germinal centers. Hassalls corpuscles (arrow) are visible as pink whorls.

1120.caption: Helicobacter pylori gastritis, antrum. Dense inflammatory infiltrate in lamina propria (arrow) with lymphocytes, plasma cells, neutrophils. Neutrophils in glandular/surface epithelium (arrowheads) indicate active gastritis. H. pylori shown in Ch3.
1120.original_caption: . Helicobacter pylori gastritis, antrum. In this disease, the low-power impression is that of a blue biopsy due to the dense inflammatory infiltrate in the lamina propria (arrow). There are lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. Neutrophils in the glandular or surface epithelium (arrowheads) indicate an active component to this gastritis. Helicobacter pylori organisms are pictured in Chapter 3.

1121.caption: Invasive lobular carcinoma. Cells invade stroma, forming single file lines (arrow), single cells, or concentric circles around ducts. Minimal desmoplastic reaction may make lesion hard to palpate/detect.
1121.original_caption: . Invasive lobular carcinoma. The same cells as in 19.14 are seen here invading through the stroma. They often form single file lines (arrow) but may also be seen as single cells or concentric circles around a duct. In some cases there is little to no desmoplastic stromal reaction, making the lesion difficult to palpate or detect.

1122.caption: Lobular carcinoma in situ. Distended lobule with monotonous cells, distinct borders, small round nuclei (arrow). Noncohesive cells disintegrate. Cytoplasmic vacuoles (arrowhead) typical in situ/invasive.
1122.original_caption: . Lobular carcinoma in situ. The lobule is distended by a population of monotonous cells with distinct cellular borders and small round nuclei (arrow). As the lesion expands, the noncohesive cells will begin to fall apart. Cytoplasmic vacuoles (arrowhead) are typical of lobular carcinoma cells both in situ and invasive.

1123.caption: Serous carcinoma. Papillary structures with atypical nuclei, prominent nucleoli (circle).
1123.original_caption: . Serous carcinoma. Papillary structures are lined by atypical nuclei with prominent nucleoli (circle).

1124.caption: Immature villi: large diameter, double cell layer (arrow), nucleated RBCs in capillaries (arrowhead). Mature villi: smaller, prominent capillaries, cytotrophoblasts form syncytial knots (arrow), maternal blood/fibrin between villi.
1124.original_caption: . Immature villi versus terminal villi. (A) Villi at around 8-10 weeks are large in diameter and have a double layer of cells lining the surface (arrow). Tiny fetal capillaries have nucleated red blood cells inside (arrowhead). (B) Taken at the same magnification as A, this shows mature villi at approximately 38 weeks. The villi are much smaller, the fetal capillaries are more prominent, and the cytotrophoblasts have pulled away from the gas-exchange surface into syncytial knots (arrow). Maternal blood and fibrin are visible between villi.

1125.caption: Immature villi (8-10w): large diameter, double cell layer (arrow), nucleated RBCs in capillaries (arrowhead). Mature villi (38w): smaller, prominent capillaries, cytotrophoblasts form syncytial knots (arrow), maternal blood/fibrin between villi. Same magnification.
1125.original_caption: . Immature villi versus terminal villi. (A) Villi at around 8-10 weeks are large in diameter and have a double layer of cells lining the surface (arrow). Tiny fetal capillaries have nucleated red blood cells inside (arrowhead). (B) Taken at the same magnification as A, this shows mature villi at approximately 38 weeks. The villi are much smaller, the fetal capillaries are more prominent, and the cytotrophoblasts have pulled away from the gas-exchange surface into syncytial knots (arrow). Maternal blood and fibrin are visible between villi.

1126.caption: Placental membranes: amnion (1), artifactual space (2) between amnion and chorion (3), decidua (4).
1126.original_caption: . Placental membranes. In the membrane section, you can see amnion (1), an artifactual space (2) between amnion and chorion (3), and underlying decidua (4).

1127.caption: Cystic nephroma: cyst lined with bland epithelial cells (arrowhead), adjacent spindly stroma resembling ovarian stroma (arrow), kidney parenchyma at right.
1127.original_caption: . Cystic nephroma. Like the simple cyst, this cyst is lined with bland epithelial cells (arrowhead). However, there is adjacent spindly stroma, similar to ovarian stroma (arrow). Kidney parenchyma is seen at right.

1128.caption: Simple cyst. Cyst lining: thin cuboidal cells (arrowhead). Below, dilated tubules with proteinaceous fluid (arrow).
1128.original_caption: . Simple cyst. The cyst lining (arrowhead) consists of a thin layer of cuboidal cells. Below the cyst, dilated tubules filled with proteinaceous fluid are visible (arrow).

1129.caption: Caseating granulomas in TB. Histiocytes at periphery, center shows necrosis and debris (arrow).
1129.original_caption: . Caseating granulomas in tuberculosis. The histiocytes in these granulomas are visible only at the periphery, as the center is a mass of necrosis and cellular debris (arrow).

1130.caption: Hyalinized granuloma. Amorphous hyalinized collagen, old burned-out necrosis.
1130.original_caption: . Hyalinized granuloma. The amorphous area of hyalinized collagen likely represents old, burned-out necrosis.

1131.caption: Clear cell carcinoma. Nests of clear cells separated by fibrovascular septa. Less cellular area shows vessel-like spaces lined by atypical hobnail cells (arrow).
1131.original_caption: . Clear cell carcinoma. (A) In this field, nests of clear cells are seen separated by fibrovascular septa. (B) A less cellular area of the same tumor shows vessel-like spaces lined by atypical cells that protrude into the lumen in hobnail fashion (arrow).

1132.caption: Clear cell carcinoma. Nests of clear cells separated by fibrovascular septa. Less cellular area shows vessel-like spaces lined by atypical hobnail cells (arrow).
1132.original_caption: . Clear cell carcinoma. (A) In this field, nests of clear cells are seen separated by fibrovascular septa. (B) A less cellular area of the same tumor shows vessel-like spaces lined by atypical cells that protrude into the lumen in hobnail fashion (arrow).

1133.caption: Endometrioid carcinoma. Nuclei cleared, pleomorphic. Glandular spaces visible (arrows), some with central necrosis.
1133.original_caption: . Endometrioid carcinoma. The nuclei are cleared out and pleomorphic, like endometrioid carcinoma of the endometrium. Distinct glandular spaces are visible (arrows), some with central necrosis.

1134.caption: Signet-ring cell carcinoma. Low power: slightly busy lamina propria. High power: signet-ring cells with mucin vacuoles (circle), infiltrating cells with hyperchromatic nuclei (arrowheads). Signet-ring cells have dark nuclei protruding from vacuoles, unlike fat cells.
1134.original_caption: . Signet-ring cell carcinoma. At low power, this sneaky tumor may be visible as little more than a slightly busy or cellular lamina propria. At high power, you can see individual signet-ring cells with single large mucin vacuoles (circle), plus other single infiltrating cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei (arrowheads). The signet-ring cells differ from fat cells by having large dark nuclei that protrude up from the surface of the central vacuole.

1135.caption: Arias-Stella reaction. Gestational endometrium glands show bizarre cytology: cleared-out cytoplasm, large hyperchromatic irregular nuclei (circle).
1135.original_caption: . Arias-Stella reaction. Glands in the gestational endometrium can show bizarre cytology, including cleared-out cytoplasm and large hyperchromatic irregular nuclei (circle).

1136.caption: Osteosarcoma. Well-differentiated tumors resemble osteoblastoma histologically. Osteoid deposition similar, but osteoblasts more hyperchromatic/atypical (arrow). Poorly differentiated tumors show focal, subtle osteoid (arrowhead).
1136.original_caption: . Osteosarcoma. (A) The most-well differentiated tumors can be very difficult to distinguish from osteoblastoma by histology alone. The osteoid deposition is similar, except the osteoblasts may appear more hyperchromatic and atypical (arrow). (B) A less differentiated tumor can be difficult to identify as osteosarcoma because of the focal and subtle production of osteoid (arrowhead).

1137.caption: Osteosarcoma. Well-differentiated tumors resemble osteoblastoma histologically. Osteoid deposition similar, but osteoblasts more hyperchromatic/atypical (arrow). Poorly differentiated tumors show focal, subtle osteoid (arrowhead), complicating diagnosis.
1137.original_caption: . Osteosarcoma. (A) The most-well differentiated tumors can be very difficult to distinguish from osteoblastoma by histology alone. The osteoid deposition is similar, except the osteoblasts may appear more hyperchromatic and atypical (arrow). (B) A less differentiated tumor can be difficult to identify as osteosarcoma because of the focal and subtle production of osteoid (arrowhead).

1138.caption: Embryonal carcinoma. Large epithelioid cells with pleomorphic nuclei grow in sheets. Dense cytoplasm, irregular nuclear shapes/sizes, nuclear molding. Coarse chromatin, dark nuclear membranes, prominent nucleoli (arrow).
1138.original_caption: . Embryonal carcinoma. Large epithelioid cells with pleomorphic nuclei grow in sheets. Unlike in seminoma, the cytoplasm is dense, and the nuclei have irregular shapes and sizes, some showing nuclear molding. Many have coarse chromatin with dark nuclear membranes and prominent nucleoli (arrow).

1139.caption: Cervical LSIL shows koilocytes: large cells with crinkled dark nuclei, perinuclear halos (arrow). Dysplasia: nuclei enlarge toward surface. Binucleate cells suggest LSIL (arrowhead). Normal glycogenated epithelium has small pyknotic surface nuclei (arrow), larger basal cells (circle).
1139.original_caption: . Viral or koilocytic atypia versus glycogen. (A) In this cervical lesion (low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion [LSIL]), koilocytes are visible as large cells with prominent, crinkled, dark nuclei and perinuclear halos (arrow). Nuclei that get larger as you approach the surface are an indicator of dysplasia. Binucleate cells are suggestive of LSIL (arrowhead). (B) Normal glycogenated cervical epithelium can appear to have prominent nuclear halos, but the nuclei at the surface should be tiny and pyknotic (arrow). Larger cells may be seen near the basal layer (circle).

1140.caption: Cervical LSIL shows koilocytes: large cells with crinkled dark nuclei, perinuclear halos (arrow). Dysplasia: nuclei enlarge toward surface. Binucleate cells suggest LSIL (arrowhead). Normal glycogenated epithelium has tiny pyknotic nuclei (arrow), larger cells near basal layer (circle).
1140.original_caption: . Viral or koilocytic atypia versus glycogen. (A) In this cervical lesion (low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion [LSIL]), koilocytes are visible as large cells with prominent, crinkled, dark nuclei and perinuclear halos (arrow). Nuclei that get larger as you approach the surface are an indicator of dysplasia. Binucleate cells are suggestive of LSIL (arrowhead). (B) Normal glycogenated cervical epithelium can appear to have prominent nuclear halos, but the nuclei at the surface should be tiny and pyknotic (arrow). Larger cells may be seen near the basal layer (circle).

1141.caption: Verrucous pattern in wart. Verruca vulgaris shows exophytic epidermal spires (arrow), hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis.
1141.original_caption: . Verrucous pattern in a wart. Verruca vulgaris is characterized by prominent exophytic spires of the epidermis (arrow), with overlying hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.

1142.caption: Atypical adenomatoid hyperplasia. Tiny focus shows interstitial inflammation (arrow) and type II hyperplasia (arrowhead). Adjacent alveolar walls unremarkable.
1142.original_caption: . Atypical adenomatoid hyperplasia. In this tiny, limited focus, there is interstitial inflammation (arrow) and prominent type II hyperplasia (arrowhead). The adjacent alveolar walls are unremarkable.

1143.caption: Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) grades: PanIN 1 - tall mucinous cells like endocervix. PanIN 2 - nuclear crowding, enlargement, atypia resembling colon tubular adenoma. PanIN 3 - high-grade nuclei, polarity loss, mitoses, mucinous differentiation loss.
1143.original_caption: . The grades of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN). (A) PanIN 1 shows tall mucinous cells resembling endocervix. (B) PanIN 2 shows increasing nuclear crowding, enlargement, and atypia, suggestive of a tubular adenoma of colon. (C) PanIN 3 shows highgrade nuclei with loss of polarity, frequent mitoses, and loss of mucinous differentiation.

1144.caption: Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) grades: PanIN-1 has tall mucinous cells like endocervix. PanIN-2 shows nuclear crowding, enlargement, atypia resembling colon adenoma. PanIN-3 has high-grade nuclei, polarity loss, mitoses, lost mucinous differentiation.
1144.original_caption: . The grades of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN). (A) PanIN 1 shows tall mucinous cells resembling endocervix. (B) PanIN 2 shows increasing nuclear crowding, enlargement, and atypia, suggestive of a tubular adenoma of colon. (C) PanIN 3 shows highgrade nuclei with loss of polarity, frequent mitoses, and loss of mucinous differentiation.

1145.caption: Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) grades: PanIN 1 - tall mucinous cells like endocervix. PanIN 2 - nuclear crowding, enlargement, atypia, resembling colon tubular adenoma. PanIN 3 - high-grade nuclei, polarity loss, mitoses, mucinous differentiation loss.
1145.original_caption: . The grades of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN). (A) PanIN 1 shows tall mucinous cells resembling endocervix. (B) PanIN 2 shows increasing nuclear crowding, enlargement, and atypia, suggestive of a tubular adenoma of colon. (C) PanIN 3 shows highgrade nuclei with loss of polarity, frequent mitoses, and loss of mucinous differentiation.

1146.caption: Adenocarcinoma adjacent to vessel. Large duct-like structures (arrow) near large-caliber vessel indicate cancer, despite deceptively well-differentiated appearance.
1146.original_caption: . Adenocarcinoma next to a vessel. Large duct-like structures (arrow) next to a large- caliber vessel (V) are almost certainly cancer, even if deceptively well differentiated.

1147.caption: Normocellular marrow (30%) in middle-aged adult. Hypercellular marrow (95%) in AML case.
1147.original_caption: . Marrow cellularity. (A) Normocellular marrow for a middle-aged adult; this cellularity is approximately 30%. (B) Hypercellular marrow for an adult; this cellularity is about 95% and is taken from a case of acute myeloid leukemia.

1148.caption: Normocellular marrow (~30%) in middle-aged adult. Hypercellular marrow (~95%) in AML case.
1148.original_caption: . Marrow cellularity. (A) Normocellular marrow for a middle-aged adult; this cellularity is approximately 30%. (B) Hypercellular marrow for an adult; this cellularity is about 95% and is taken from a case of acute myeloid leukemia.

1149.caption: Follicular lymphoma. Malignant follicles with small cleaved centrocytes (arrowhead) and large centroblasts (arrow).
1149.original_caption: . Follicular lymphoma, high power. The malignant follicles contain a mixture of small cleaved centrocytes (arrowhead) and large centroblasts (arrow).

1150.caption: Islet cell tumor, resembles carcinoids, round well-spaced nuclei, speckled neuroendocrine chromatin.
1150.original_caption: . Islet cell tumor. This resembles carcinoids in other body sites, with round, well-spaced nuclei and speckled neuroendocrine-type chromatin.

1151.caption: Reactive nuclei (A,B): enlarged, visible nucleoli, low N/C ratio, nuclear polarity, smooth oval membranes, chromatin not dark, maturation visible. Dysplastic nuclei (C,D): darker, high N/C ratio, epithelial disorder, irregular packed shapes.
1151.original_caption: . Examples of reactive, benign nuclei (A, B) and dysplastic nuclei (C, D). In reactive conditions, the nuclei may be enlarged and have visible nucleoli, but the N/C ratios are still low (abundant cytoplasm), there is nuclear polarity relative to the surface, the chromatin is not too dark, and the nuclear membranes are smooth and oval. Maturation is visible in that as cells get closer to the surface the nuclei get smaller and the cytoplasm more abundant. In dysplasia, the nuclei are significantly darker, the N/C ratios are higher, there is more disorder to the epithelium, and the nuclei (being more closely packed) may take on irregular shapes to fit more closely together, similar to boulders in a rock wall.

1152.caption: Reactive nuclei (A,B): enlarged, visible nucleoli, low N/C ratio, nuclear polarity, smooth oval membranes, chromatin not dark, maturation visible. Dysplastic nuclei (C,D): darker, high N/C ratio, epithelial disorder, irregular packed shapes.
1152.original_caption: . Examples of reactive, benign nuclei (A, B) and dysplastic nuclei (C, D). In reactive conditions, the nuclei may be enlarged and have visible nucleoli, but the N/C ratios are still low (abundant cytoplasm), there is nuclear polarity relative to the surface, the chromatin is not too dark, and the nuclear membranes are smooth and oval. Maturation is visible in that as cells get closer to the surface the nuclei get smaller and the cytoplasm more abundant. In dysplasia, the nuclei are significantly darker, the N/C ratios are higher, there is more disorder to the epithelium, and the nuclei (being more closely packed) may take on irregular shapes to fit more closely together, similar to boulders in a rock wall.

1153.caption: Reactive nuclei (A,B): enlarged, visible nucleoli, low N/C ratio, nuclear polarity, smooth oval membranes, chromatin not dark, maturation visible. Dysplastic nuclei (C,D): darker, high N/C ratio, epithelial disorder, irregular packed shapes.
1153.original_caption: . Examples of reactive, benign nuclei (A, B) and dysplastic nuclei (C, D). In reactive conditions, the nuclei may be enlarged and have visible nucleoli, but the N/C ratios are still low (abundant cytoplasm), there is nuclear polarity relative to the surface, the chromatin is not too dark, and the nuclear membranes are smooth and oval. Maturation is visible in that as cells get closer to the surface the nuclei get smaller and the cytoplasm more abundant. In dysplasia, the nuclei are significantly darker, the N/C ratios are higher, there is more disorder to the epithelium, and the nuclei (being more closely packed) may take on irregular shapes to fit more closely together, similar to boulders in a rock wall.

1154.caption: Reactive nuclei: enlarged, visible nucleoli, low N/C ratios, nuclear polarity, smooth oval membranes, chromatin not dark. Dysplastic nuclei: darker, high N/C ratios, epithelial disorder, irregular shapes, closely packed. Maturation seen in reactive cells.
1154.original_caption: . Examples of reactive, benign nuclei (A, B) and dysplastic nuclei (C, D). In reactive conditions, the nuclei may be enlarged and have visible nucleoli, but the N/C ratios are still low (abundant cytoplasm), there is nuclear polarity relative to the surface, the chromatin is not too dark, and the nuclear membranes are smooth and oval. Maturation is visible in that as cells get closer to the surface the nuclei get smaller and the cytoplasm more abundant. In dysplasia, the nuclei are significantly darker, the N/C ratios are higher, there is more disorder to the epithelium, and the nuclei (being more closely packed) may take on irregular shapes to fit more closely together, similar to boulders in a rock wall.

1155.caption: Dyskeratotic cells in epidermis: mummified, dying nuclei, lost cell connections, dense pink keratin (arrow).
1155.original_caption: . Dyskeratotic cells in the epidermis. These cells are essentially mummified; their nuclei are dying, and they have lost their connections to other cells. Their dense pink keratin stands out relative to the neighboring cells (arrow).

1156.caption: Leiomyosarcoma: malignant leiomyoma variant, high cellularity, hyperchromatic nuclei, frequent mitoses (arrow), atypical cells (arrowhead).
1156.original_caption: . Leiomyosarcoma. A malignant version of the leiomyoma, this tumor has the architectural pattern and nuclear morphology of its benign cousin but with much higher cellularity, hyperchromatic nuclei, frequent mitoses (arrow), and large atypical cells (arrowhead).

1157.caption: Acinic cell, microcystic pattern. Cells are pink (arrow) without blue granules. Microcystic pattern shows fluid pockets (asterisks) pushing cells apart, typical of acinic cell. Contrast with adenoid cystic carcinoma's cribriform spaces (25.6).
1157.original_caption: . Acinic cell, microcystic pattern. In this example, the cells are nonspecifically pink (arrow) and do not have the telltale blue granules. However, the microcystic pattern, in which cells appear to be pushed apart by expanding pockets of fluid (asterisks), is typical of acinic cell. Compare these microcysts to the sharp cribriform spaces in adenoid cystic carcinoma (see 25.6).

1158.caption: Acinic cell carcinoma, solid pattern. Cells mimic serous acini, blue granular cytoplasm (arrow).
1158.original_caption: . Acinic cell, solid pattern. The cells in acinic cell carcinoma replicate those of serous acini, with blue granular cytoplasm (arrow).

1159.caption: Molar villi, markedly enlarged, some with central cavities/cisterns (arrowhead). Dense trophoblastic proliferation (arrow), pleomorphic cells. Complete mole, no fetal capillaries in villi.
1159.original_caption: . Molar villi. The villi are markedly enlarged, some with central cavities or cisterns (arrowhead). Dense trophoblastic proliferation is visible (arrow); on higher power, the cells may be very pleomorphic. This is a complete mole, so there are no fetal capillaries within the villi.

1160.caption: Fibrin, subchorionic (arrow), normal in term placenta, not infarct. Amnion on fetal surface (arrowhead).
1160.original_caption: . Fibrin, subchorionic. Subchorionic deposits of fibrin (arrow) are normal in a term placenta and should not be mistaken for infarct. The amnion lies atop the fetal surface (arrowhead).

1161.caption: Osteoarthritis: eroded cartilage (dark purple stain), thickened subchondral trabeculae, myxoid degeneration (cyst-like spaces), residual hematopoietic marrow.
1161.original_caption: . Osteoarthritis. Features include (1) eroded cartilage, in this case nearly absent, and irregular mineralization of the cartilage, seen here as a dark purple stain; (2) thickening of the subchondral bony trabeculae; (3) myxoid degeneration of the subchondral bone, forming cyst-like spaces; and (4) some residual hematopoietic marrow.

1162.caption: Osteonecrosis. Necrotic marrow (arrow) shows fat necrosis, absent marrow elements. Osteocytes in lacunae dead/missing (arrowhead).
1162.original_caption: . Osteonecrosis. The necrotic marrow is the most eye-catching feature (arrow), showing fat necrosis and an absence of marrow elements. On close examination, the osteocytes within lacunae are also dead or missing (arrowhead).

1163.caption: Secretory endometrium, various phases. Early: tortuous glands, subnuclear cytoplasmic vacuoles (arrow). Later: vacuoles gone, cuboidal epithelium, small round nuclei (arrow). Edematous stroma, early decidualization (pink cytoplasm) around spiral arteries (arrowhead).
1163.original_caption: . Secretory endometrium, various phases. (A) In early secretory endometrium, the glands have become tortuous in shape, and prominent cytoplasmic vacuoles are present (subnuclear, in this example; arrow). (B) Later in the secretory phase, the cytoplasmic vacuoles are gone, and the epithelium is more cuboidal in shape, with small round nuclei (arrow). The stroma is edematous, and early decidualization (accumulation of pink cytoplasm) is beginning around the spiral arteries (arrowhead).

1164.caption: Secretory endometrium, early phase: tortuous glands, subnuclear cytoplasmic vacuoles (arrow). Late phase: vacuoles absent, cuboidal epithelium, small round nuclei (arrow). Edematous stroma, early decidualization (pink cytoplasm) around spiral arteries (arrowhead).
1164.original_caption: . Secretory endometrium, various phases. (A) In early secretory endometrium, the glands have become tortuous in shape, and prominent cytoplasmic vacuoles are present (subnuclear, in this example; arrow). (B) Later in the secretory phase, the cytoplasmic vacuoles are gone, and the epithelium is more cuboidal in shape, with small round nuclei (arrow). The stroma is edematous, and early decidualization (accumulation of pink cytoplasm) is beginning around the spiral arteries (arrowhead).

1165.caption: Progestin-treated endometrium. Glands tortuous, epithelium thinned (arrow). Stromal cells decidualized (arrowhead): plump pink cytoplasm, distinct borders.
1165.original_caption: . Progestin-treated endometrium. The glands are still tortuous in shape, like secretory endometrium, but the epithelium is markedly thinned (arrow). The stromal cells are decidualized (arrowhead), which means they have plump pink cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.

1166.caption: Normal seminiferous tubules. Spermatogonia with clear cytoplasm at periphery (1). Developing spermatocytes to tiny spermatids (2), indicating spermatogenesis. Plump pink Leydig cells in interstitium (3).
1166.original_caption: . Normal seminiferous tubules. Large spermatogonia with clear cytoplasm are present at the tubule periphery (1). The developing spermatocytes have a wide range of morphologies, ending with the tiny spermatids (2), a marker of successful spermatogenesis. Plump pink Leydig cells are seen in the interstitium (3).

1167.caption: Normal rete testis. Slit-like spaces, cuboidal epithelium.
1167.original_caption: . Normal rete testis. Slit-like spaces with cuboidal epithelium.

1171.caption: Kaposi's sarcoma. Dermal cellularity: slit-like vascular spaces with bland endothelium (arrowheads). Spaces accentuated around capillaries (arrows), promontory sign.
1171.original_caption: . Kaposis sarcoma. The subtle cellularity to the dermis is actually composed of slit-like vascular spaces with bland endothelium (arrowheads). The slit-like spaces are accentuated around existing capillaries (arrows), the promontory sign.

1172.caption: Capillary hemangioma: discrete, well-formed dilated capillaries under epidermis.
1172.original_caption: . Capillary hemangioma. There is a collection of discrete, well-formed, dilated capillaries under the epidermis.

1173.caption: Flat carcinoma in situ. Urothelium partially denuded; remaining cells show enlarged, round, hyperchromatic nuclei popping off surface (arrow). Compare nuclei to underlying lymphocytes.
1173.original_caption: . Flat carcinoma in situ. The urothelium is partially denuded (stripped of cells), but the cells that remain show enlarged, round, hyperchromatic nuclei appearing to pop off the surface (arrow). Compare the nuclear size to the underlying lymphocytes.

1174.caption: Small cell carcinoma. Sheets of molded nuclei, scant cytoplasm. Uniform chromatin, no nucleoli. Necrosis and mitoses (arrow) common.
1174.original_caption: . Small cell carcinoma. Sheets of nuclei appear molded together with interlocking shapes due to the near absence of cytoplasm. The chromatin, like low-grade neuroendocrine neoplasms, is uniform and lacks nucleoli. Necrosis and mitoses (arrow) are common.

1175.caption: Classic neuroendocrine nuclei, smooth oval borders, finely speckled chromatin (salt and pepper), no nucleoli.
1175.original_caption: . Classic neuroendocrine nuclei, with smooth oval nuclear borders, chromatin that is finely speckled throughout (salt and pepper), and no nucleoli.

1176.caption: Medulloblastoma. Small round blue cell tumor with wedge/spindly cells, fine chromatin, frequent apoptoses (arrowhead) and mitoses (arrow).
1176.original_caption: . Medulloblastoma. A small round blue cell tumor composed of cells that are not actually round but more wedge-shaped or even spindly. The chromatin is very fine in texture, and there are frequent apoptoses (arrowhead) and mitoses (arrow).

1177.caption: Granuloma in Crohn's disease. Small histiocyte collection (arrow) between crypts, 40x.
1177.original_caption: . Granuloma in Crohns disease. The granulomas in Crohns are small and subtle. This image, taken at 40x, shows a small collection of histiocytes (arrow) between crypts.

1178.caption: Chronic inflammatory disease. Biopsy shows crypt atrophy (1), distortion (2), elevation off muscularis mucosa, basal lymphocytic infiltrate, Paneth cell metaplasia (3).
1178.original_caption: . Chronic inflammatory disease. This biopsy specimen shows a loss of crypt density (atrophy); crypt distortion (1); elevation of crypts off of the muscularis mucosa (2), often accompanied by a dense basal lymphocytic infiltrate (not seen here); and Paneth cell metaplasia (3).

1179.caption: Normal lymph node. Sinuses: loose histiocytes (1). Primary follicles: B cells, no germinal centers (2). Secondary follicles: germinal centers (3). Paracortex: T cells, spotted/mottled (4). Inset: polarized germinal center, centroblasts clustered (arrowhead), lopsided.
1179.original_caption: . Normal lymph node. The sinuses are visible mainly as loose collections of histiocytes (1). Primary follicles (2) are collections of B cells lacking germinal centers. Secondary follicles contain germinal centers (3). The space between the follicles, or paracortex (4), is composed of T cells and shows a characteristic spotted or mottled appearance. Inset: A normal germinal center should be polarized, with large centroblasts clustered at one side of the follicle (arrowhead), creating a lopsided appearance.

1180.caption: Germinal center with tingible body macrophages (circle), centroblasts with prominent nucleoli (arrow), surrounded by mantle zone B cells (arrowhead).
1180.original_caption: . Germinal center. Other components of a benign germinal center include tingible body macrophages (circle) and large centroblasts with prominent nucleoli (arrow). The germinal center is surrounded by the mature B cells of the mantle zone (arrowhead).

1181.caption: Syringoma. Small dermal tubules with comma-like tails (arrow).
1181.original_caption: . Syringoma. Small tubules with comma-like pointed tails within the dermis (arrow).

1182.caption: Microcystic adnexal carcinoma: small pale nests in dermis, some forming horn cysts (arrow). Infiltrating nests deep into lesion base (arrowheads) and subcutaneous fat distinguish from benign.
1182.original_caption: . Microcystic adnexal carcinoma. A collection of small pale nests of cells can be seen in the dermis, some of them forming horn cysts (arrow). The feature that separates this from a benign lesion is the small nests that are infiltrating deeply into the base of the lesion at right (arrowheads). This small carcinoma infiltrated into the subcutaneous fat (not seen here).

1183.caption: Borderline serous tumor. Epithelial lining: serous/nonmucinous cells (arrow). Complex architecture: papillary branching, invaginated folds (arrowhead), not invasion. Mostly monolayer epithelium.
