1183.original_caption: . Borderline serous tumor. The epithelial lining is composed of serous, or nonmucinous, cells (arrow). The overall architecture is quite complex, with papillary branching and invaginated folds that should not be mistaken for invasion (arrowhead). However, the epithelial component is mostly a monolayer.

1184.caption: Micropapillary serous carcinoma shows tiny cell florets (arrow) in desmoplastic stroma (arrowhead), with psammoma bodies (circle). Medusa-head pattern is diagnostic. Compare to borderline tumor epithelium (15.5).
1184.original_caption: . Micropapillary serous carcinoma. When invasive, micropapillary serous carcinoma looks like tiny florets of cells (arrow) in a desmoplastic stroma (arrowhead). Psammoma bodies are common (circle). Inset: The medusa-head, or micropapillary, pattern is indicative of micropapillary serous carcinoma. Compare the epithelial micropapillae to the simple epithelium of the borderline tumor (see 15.5).

1185.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor. Key features: staghorn vessels (v), small spindle cells (arrowhead), collagenous stroma (arrow). Patternless spindle cell arrangement. Shares features with hemangiopericytoma.
1185.original_caption: . Solitary fibrous tumor. The most noticeable features at low power are the staghorn vessels (v), which this tumor shares with the related hemangiopericytoma. The tumor is composed of areas of small nondescript spindle cells (arrowhead) and collagenous stroma (arrow). The pattern of the spindle cells is described as patternless, meaning somewhat chaotic.

1186.caption: Fibrosarcoma with herringbone pattern, zigzagging spindle cell bands. Common in other tumors.
1186.original_caption: . Fibrosarcoma. This field shows the typical herringbone pattern of fibrosarcoma, with zigzagging bands of spindle cells. Many other tumors can have this pattern.

1187.caption: Enchondroma: well-differentiated cartilage with blue glassy matrix, small chondrocytes in lacunae (arrowhead). Mineralization seam (arrow), not osteoid. Histologically similar to chondrosarcoma.
1187.original_caption: . Enchondroma. This example shows a sheet of well-differentiated cartilage, with the characteristic blue, somewhat glassy matrix and small chondrocytes embedded in lacunae (arrowhead). The seam of mineralization (arrow) should not be mistaken for osteoid formation. A well-differentiated chondrosarcoma could look very similar histologically.

1188.caption: Chondrosarcoma. Cartilage matrix resembles normal cartilage, chondrocytes pleomorphic in size/shape.
1188.original_caption: . Chondrosarcoma. The cartilage matrix resembles normal cartilage, but the chondrocytes are pleomorphic in size and shape.

1189.caption: Helicobacter pylori bacilli visible on H&E stain (arrows) in gastric mucosa pits.
1189.original_caption: . Helicobacter pylori. The bacilli are sometimes visible on hematoxylin and eosin stain, as seen here (arrows), in the pits of the gastric mucosa.

1190.caption: Actinomyces. Filamentous ball resembles fibrin, easily overlooked.
1190.original_caption: . Actinomyces. This filamentous ball of organisms is easily overlooked, as it resembles fibrin.

1191.caption: Pagets disease. Nonsquamous cells (arrowheads) in squamous epithelium.
1191.original_caption: . Pagets disease. Several nonsquamous cells (arrowheads) are visible within the squamous epithelium.

1192.caption: Lichen sclerosus. Thin atrophic epithelium, pale dense homogenized collagen (arrow). Flattened dermal-epidermal junction, absent rete.
1192.original_caption: . Lichen sclerosus. The epithelium is thin and atrophic, and the collagen underneath is pale, dense, and homogenized in texture (arrow). The dermal-epidermal junction is flattened, with an absence of rete.

1193.caption: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Sheets of discohesive tumor cells. Chunky nuclear chromatin.
1193.original_caption: . Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The main histologic feature is sheets of discohesive tumor cells. Nuclear chromatin is chunky.

1194.caption: Granulomas in sarcoid, more substantial than Crohn's. Well-defined pink histiocyte masses with multinucleated giant cells (arrowhead).
1194.original_caption: . Granulomas in sarcoid. These granulomas are often more substantial and more easily recognized than those in Crohns disease. They appear as well-defined masses of pink histiocytes. Occasional multinucleated giant cells (arrowhead) are present.

1195.caption: Granulomas in Crohn's disease: subtle colonic granulomas (arrow), pale histiocytes visible on high power, with lymphocyte collar.
1195.original_caption: . Granulomas in Crohns disease. These granulomas of the colon are subtle (arrow), and the pale histiocytes may be seen only on high power. A surrounding collar of lymphocytes is common.

1196.caption: Parathyroid tissue: chief cells (arrowhead) and oxyphil cells (arrow).
1196.original_caption: . Parathyroid tissue. Normal parathyroid has two cell populations, the chief cells (arrowhead) and oxyphil cells (arrow).

1197.caption: Myxoid degeneration, heart valve. Free end shows attenuated pale area (arrow). Calcifications, vegetations may be present.
1197.original_caption: . Myxoid degeneration, heart valve. In the free end of this heart valve, there is an attenuated pale area of myxoid degeneration (arrow). Calcifications and vegetations may also be seen.

1198.caption: Normal breast. TDLU resembles grape cluster: duct (arrowhead) as stem, secretory lobules (arrow) as grapes. Rounded TDLU border key for noninvasive lesions. Benign breast has two layers: outer myoepithelial (arrow), inner epithelial (arrowhead). In situ lesions retain two layers.
1198.original_caption: . Normal breast. (A) The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is arranged like a cluster of grapes, with the duct (arrowhead) as the stem and secretory lobules (arrow) as the grapes. The rounded and circumscribed border of the TDLU is a key feature of noninvasive lesions. (B) The benign breast always has two cell layers, the outer myoepithelial cells (arrow) and the inner epithelial cells (arrowhead). In situ lesions also have two cell layers.

1199.caption: Normal breast. TDLU arranged like grapes: duct (arrowhead) as stem, secretory lobules (arrow) as grapes. Rounded TDLU border key for noninvasive lesions. Benign breast has two cell layers: outer myoepithelial (arrow), inner epithelial (arrowhead). In situ lesions also have two layers.
1199.original_caption: . Normal breast. (A) The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is arranged like a cluster of grapes, with the duct (arrowhead) as the stem and secretory lobules (arrow) as the grapes. The rounded and circumscribed border of the TDLU is a key feature of noninvasive lesions. (B) The benign breast always has two cell layers, the outer myoepithelial cells (arrow) and the inner epithelial cells (arrowhead). In situ lesions also have two cell layers.

1200.caption: Microcalcifications appear as tiny purple rocks (arrow), may shatter. Calcium oxalate visible with polarizer/down condenser. Oxalate crystals (arrow) in duct space, surrounded by foamy macrophages (arrowhead).
1200.original_caption: . Calcifications. (A) Microcalcifications in this columnar cell lesion appear as tiny purple rocks (arrow), which may shatter and drag through the tissue, creating telltale scratches in the H&E stain. (B) Calcium oxalate does not pick up hematoxylin and therefore is only visible with a polarizer or when the condenser is flipped down, as in this photograph. The oxalate crystals (arrow) are seen in a duct space, surrounded by foamy macrophages (arrowhead).

1201.caption: Microcalcifications appear as tiny purple rocks (arrow), may shatter. Calcium oxalate visible with polarizer/flipped condenser (arrow), in duct space with foamy macrophages (arrowhead).
1201.original_caption: . Calcifications. (A) Microcalcifications in this columnar cell lesion appear as tiny purple rocks (arrow), which may shatter and drag through the tissue, creating telltale scratches in the H&E stain. (B) Calcium oxalate does not pick up hematoxylin and therefore is only visible with a polarizer or when the condenser is flipped down, as in this photograph. The oxalate crystals (arrow) are seen in a duct space, surrounded by foamy macrophages (arrowhead).

1202.caption: Umbilical cord cross section: 2 arteries, 1 vein.
1202.original_caption: . An umbilical cord in cross section, showing two arteries (A) and one vein (V).

1203.caption: Twin placentas. Diamnionic dichorionic: membrane between arrowheads, amnion (a) on both surfaces, chorion (c) in middle. Diamnionic monochorionic: no chorion between amnion (a) layers.
1203.original_caption: . Twin placentas. (A) In a diamnionic, dichorionic placenta, the dividing membrane is captured here between the arrowheads. Amnion is seen on both surfaces (a), and a double layer of chorion is sandwiched in the middle (c). (B) In a diamnionic, monochorionic placenta, no chorion is present between the layers (arrowheads) of amnion (a).

1204.caption: Twin placentas. Diamnionic dichorionic: membrane between arrowheads, amnion (a) on both surfaces, chorion (c) in middle. Diamnionic monochorionic: no chorion between amnion (a) layers (arrowheads).
1204.original_caption: . Twin placentas. (A) In a diamnionic, dichorionic placenta, the dividing membrane is captured here between the arrowheads. Amnion is seen on both surfaces (a), and a double layer of chorion is sandwiched in the middle (c). (B) In a diamnionic, monochorionic placenta, no chorion is present between the layers (arrowheads) of amnion (a).

1210.caption: Basaloid pattern, palisading, basal cell carcinoma.
1210.original_caption: . Basaloid pattern and palisading,basal cell carcinoma.

1211.caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid type. Gelatinous background, small spindle cells. Occasional strap cells with cytoplasmic muscle fibers (arrows).
1211.original_caption: . Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid type. The background is gelatinous, and the small spindle cells are nonspecific in appearance. Occasional strap cells are visible, with cytoplasmic muscle fibers (arrows).

1212.caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma with fibrovascular septa (arrow). Tumor cells detach from nest centers. Rhabdomyoblast differentiation evident (arrowhead): large cells with dense pink cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei. Some cases show small round blue cell phenotype.
1212.original_caption: . Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. The alveolar pattern is outlined by fibrovascular septa (arrow), and the tumor cells tend to fall out of the centers of their nests. This example shows prominent rhabdomyoblast differentiation (arrowhead), with large cells full of dense pink cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. Other specimens may show only small round blue cell phenotype.

1213.caption: Myeloma. Marrow replaced by plasma cell sheets. Thick section, dark chromatin, some nuclei show soccer-ball chromatin. Eccentric nucleus, abundant pink cytoplasm characteristic.
1213.original_caption: . Myeloma. The marrow is replaced by sheets of plasma cells. Although the section is thick and the chromatin appears very dark, some nuclei show the distinct soccer-ball chromatin of plasma cells. The eccentric nucleus and abundant pink cytoplasm are also characteristic.

1214.caption: High-power carcinoma features: malignant glands with distinct nucleoli (arrowhead), sharp luminal borders, no basal cells. Adjacent benign glands (arrow).
1214.original_caption: . High-power features of carcinoma. Malignant glands show distinct nucleoli (arrowhead), sharp luminal borders, and an absence of basal cells. Benign glands are seen adjacent to the cancer (arrow).

1215.caption: Perineural invasion: nerve with undulating axons, sheath nuclei; malignant glands surround nerve (arrow).
1215.original_caption: . Perineural invasion. A nerve (N) is identified by the undulating axons and nerve sheath nuclei. Malignant glands are seen nearly surrounding the nerve (arrow).

1216.caption: Follicular adenoma with microfollicular pattern. Tightly packed small follicles (arrow) with round non-overlapping nuclei. Scattered enlarged nuclei, some with pale chromatin. Capsule not seen.
1216.original_caption: . Follicular adenoma. This field shows a microfollicular pattern in a follicular adenoma. The capsule is not seen here. The neoplasm is composed of tightly packed small follicles (arrow) with round nuclei that, like normal follicular epithelium (see 23.3), tend not to overlap or crowd. There are scattered enlarged nuclei, some with pale chromatin that should not be mistaken for true nuclear clearing.

1217.caption: Papillary nuclei with oval shape, crowded rows (arrow), nuclear grooves (arrowhead), and molding suggest papillary carcinoma. Compare to follicular epithelium (23.3). Nuclear clearing evident, nuclei pop out of rows (arrow).
1217.original_caption: . Papillary nuclei. (A) In this example, although the nuclear clearing is not striking, the presence of oval nuclei crowded into a row (arrow) suggests papillary carcinoma, as does the presence of nuclear grooves (arrowhead). Compare these nuclei to those of follicular epithelium see (23.3). (B) In this lesion the nuclear clearing is much more evident. However, the nuclei are still oval in shape and crammed together such that they mold to each other, popping up and out of their crowded rows (arrow).

1218.caption: Papillary nuclei: oval nuclei crowded in rows (arrow), nuclear grooves (arrowhead) suggest papillary carcinoma. Compare to follicular epithelium (23.3). Nuclear clearing evident, nuclei molded together, popping from crowded rows (arrow).
1218.original_caption: . Papillary nuclei. (A) In this example, although the nuclear clearing is not striking, the presence of oval nuclei crowded into a row (arrow) suggests papillary carcinoma, as does the presence of nuclear grooves (arrowhead). Compare these nuclei to those of follicular epithelium see (23.3). (B) In this lesion the nuclear clearing is much more evident. However, the nuclei are still oval in shape and crammed together such that they mold to each other, popping up and out of their crowded rows (arrow).

1219.caption: Psammoma body: dense purple laminated calcification (arrow) diagnostic of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Scratches (arrowheads) indicate psammoma body dragged during sectioning.
1219.original_caption: . Psammoma body. This dense purple laminated calcification (arrow) is virtually diagnostic of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the thyroid or in a neck lymph node. Telltale scratches in the tissue section (arrowheads) often show where a psammoma body was dragged across the block during sectioning.

1220.caption: Malignant sarcoma cells (MFH/high-grade) show large, irregular nuclei with dark, coarse chromatin (hyperchromatic), swollen from excess chromosomes. Reactive fibroblasts (nodular fasciitis) have large, pale nuclei with smooth oval membranes and prominent nucleoli.
1220.original_caption: . The sarcoma cell vs. the reactive cell. (A) Malignant cells in a MFH or other high-grade sarcoma show large nuclei with irregular shapes and very dark chromatin with a coarse texture (arrowheads). It is as though (in fact, it is likely) the nucleus has way too many chromosomes, and the nucleus is swollen and dark with the extra chromatin (truly hyperchromatic). Nucleoli are not usually prominent. (B) Reactive fibroblasts in nodular fasciitis have large nuclei and prominent nucleoli that stand out against a pale nucleus (arrow). The nuclear membrane is smooth and oval.

1221.caption: MFH/high-grade sarcoma: malignant cells w/ large, irregular nuclei, coarse dark chromatin (hyperchromatic), inconspicuous nucleoli (arrowheads). Nodular fasciitis: reactive fibroblasts w/ large pale nuclei, prominent nucleoli, smooth oval membranes (arrow).
1221.original_caption: . The sarcoma cell vs. the reactive cell. (A) Malignant cells in a MFH or other high-grade sarcoma show large nuclei with irregular shapes and very dark chromatin with a coarse texture (arrowheads). It is as though (in fact, it is likely) the nucleus has way too many chromosomes, and the nucleus is swollen and dark with the extra chromatin (truly hyperchromatic). Nucleoli are not usually prominent. (B) Reactive fibroblasts in nodular fasciitis have large nuclei and prominent nucleoli that stand out against a pale nucleus (arrow). The nuclear membrane is smooth and oval.

1222.caption: Schwannoma with Antoni A (high cellularity) and B (low cellularity) areas. Elongated Schwann cells form parallel streams and Verocay bodies (arrow).
1222.original_caption: . Schwannoma. This lesion shows alternating areas of high and low cellularity, called Antoni A (A) and B (B) areas. The elongated Schwann cells tend to stream in parallel groups and form opposing parallel arrays, called Verocay bodies (arrow).

1223.caption: Hemangioblastoma. Clear lipidized cells, bland nuclei, interlacing dilated capillaries.
1223.original_caption: . Hemangioblastoma. Clear (lipidized) cells with bland nuclei in a background of interlacing and dilated capillaries.

1224.caption: Prolapse lesion. Center shows angulated/diamond-shaped crypts (arrowheads) and smooth muscle between crypts (arrow).
1224.original_caption: . Prolapse lesion. The center of this prolapse-related polyp shows typical features, including angulated or diamond-shaped crypts (arrowheads) and smooth muscle growing between crypts (arrow).

1225.caption: Sessile serrated adenoma. Surface resembles hyperplastic polyp (arrowhead), base shows crypt branching (arrow) due to basal proliferation.
1225.original_caption: . Sessile serrated adenoma. The surface looks similar to a hyperplastic polyp (arrowhead), but the base shows sideways branching of crypts (arrow) caused by proliferation at the base of the lesion.

1226.caption: Florid usual ductal hyperplasia. Cellular proliferation fills duct with swirly, heterogeneous cell population and overlapping nuclei. Peripheral slit-like spaces (arrows) typical of UDH.
1226.original_caption: . Florid usual ductal hyperplasia. The cellular proliferation entirely fills this duct, but the cell population is swirly and heterogeneous, with randomly overlapping nuclei. The peripheral ring of slit-like spaces (arrows), as though this clot of cells floated into the duct and stuck there, is very typical of usual ductal hyperplasia.

1227.caption: Bile duct adenoma: benign bile duct proliferation, surrounded by edema, mimics desmoplasia. No bile or cytologic atypia.
1227.original_caption: . Bile duct adenoma. This is a benign tangle of proliferating bile ducts, surrounded by edema, which may mimic desmoplasia. Bile is absent, as is any cytologic atypia.

1228.caption: Cholangiocarcinoma: adenocarcinoma with intense desmoplastic stroma response (arrow; pale fibrosis around malignant glands).
1228.original_caption: . Cholangiocarcinoma. A nondescript adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma produces an intense desmoplastic response in the stroma (arrow; the pale swirling fibrosis surrounding the malignant glands).

1229.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma. Superficially invasive, paradoxical deep keratinization (arrow), invasive nest. Overlying epidermis shows actinic keratosis-type changes (arrowhead), hyperkeratosis. Thin cords infiltrating stroma (oval) indicate invasion. Higher power: keratin pearls (asterisk), infiltrating single cells (arrow).
1229.original_caption: . Squamous cell carcinoma. (A) Superficially invasive squamous cell carcinoma, showing the paradoxic deep keratinization (arrow), indicating an invasive nest. Actinic keratosis-type changes are seen in the overlying epidermis (arrowhead), including hyperkeratosis. In one area, the pattern of thin cords of cells infiltrating the stroma (oval) is too complex to be explained by a funny plane of section and is another pattern of invasion. (B) Higher power view of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, showing keratin pearls (asterisk) and infiltrating single cells (arrow).

1230.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma. Superficially invasive, paradoxical deep keratinization (arrow), invasive nest. Overlying epidermis shows actinic keratosis-type changes (arrowhead), hyperkeratosis. Thin cords infiltrating stroma (oval) indicate invasion. Keratin pearls (asterisk), infiltrating single cells (arrow).
1230.original_caption: . Squamous cell carcinoma. (A) Superficially invasive squamous cell carcinoma, showing the paradoxic deep keratinization (arrow), indicating an invasive nest. Actinic keratosis-type changes are seen in the overlying epidermis (arrowhead), including hyperkeratosis. In one area, the pattern of thin cords of cells infiltrating the stroma (oval) is too complex to be explained by a funny plane of section and is another pattern of invasion. (B) Higher power view of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, showing keratin pearls (asterisk) and infiltrating single cells (arrow).

1231.caption: Fuhrman grades at 10x: (I) Small dense nuclei like lymphocytes. (II) Larger nuclei, no nucleoli. (III) Larger nuclei, visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Anaplastic nuclei (arrow), atypical mitoses (arrowhead). Same magnification.
1231.original_caption: . Fuhrman grades shown at 10x. (I) Nuclei are small and dense, resembling lymphocyte nuclei. (II) Nuclei are larger, but no nucleoli are visible at this power. (III) Nuclei are even larger, now with some visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Nuclei are frankly anaplastic (arrow) with large atypical mitoses (arrowhead). All images are taken at the same magnification.

1232.caption: Fuhrman grades at 10x: (I) Small dense nuclei like lymphocytes. (II) Larger nuclei, no nucleoli. (III) Larger nuclei with visible nucleoli. (IV) Anaplastic nuclei with atypical mitoses. Same magnification.
1232.original_caption: . Fuhrman grades shown at 10x. (I) Nuclei are small and dense, resembling lymphocyte nuclei. (II) Nuclei are larger, but no nucleoli are visible at this power. (III) Nuclei are even larger, now with some visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Nuclei are frankly anaplastic (arrow) with large atypical mitoses (arrowhead). All images are taken at the same magnification.

1233.caption: Fuhrman grades at 10x: (I) Small dense nuclei like lymphocytes. (II) Larger nuclei, no nucleoli. (III) Larger nuclei, visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Anaplastic nuclei (arrow), atypical mitoses (arrowhead). Same magnification.
1233.original_caption: . Fuhrman grades shown at 10x. (I) Nuclei are small and dense, resembling lymphocyte nuclei. (II) Nuclei are larger, but no nucleoli are visible at this power. (III) Nuclei are even larger, now with some visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Nuclei are frankly anaplastic (arrow) with large atypical mitoses (arrowhead). All images are taken at the same magnification.

1234.caption: Fuhrman grades at 10x: (I) Small dense nuclei like lymphocytes. (II) Larger nuclei, no nucleoli. (III) Larger nuclei with visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Anaplastic nuclei (arrow), atypical mitoses (arrowhead). Same magnification.
1234.original_caption: . Fuhrman grades shown at 10x. (I) Nuclei are small and dense, resembling lymphocyte nuclei. (II) Nuclei are larger, but no nucleoli are visible at this power. (III) Nuclei are even larger, now with some visible nucleoli (arrowhead). (IV) Nuclei are frankly anaplastic (arrow) with large atypical mitoses (arrowhead). All images are taken at the same magnification.

1235.caption: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma with packets of clear cells divided by fibrovascular septa (arrow). Enlarged nuclei, visible nucleoli at high power, Fuhrman grade II.
1235.original_caption: . Clear cell renal cell carcinoma. The tumor is composed of packets of clear cells, divided by delicate fibrovascular septa (arrow). These septa are characteristic of renal cell carcinoma and are seen even in high-grade or metastatic tumors. The nuclei in this example are enlarged, but nucleoli are visible only at high power, consistent with Fuhrman grade II.

1236.caption: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Broad cell fronts invade cervical stroma, with ragged border and infiltrating cells (arrowhead). Occasional pleomorphic cells (arrow).
1236.original_caption: . Invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Broad fronts of cells push into the stroma of the cervix, and at the leading edge there is a ragged border with individual infiltrating cells (arrowhead). Occasional huge and pleomorphic cells are visible (arrow).

1237.caption: Chemical gastritis, antrum. Lamina propria shows minimal inflammation, pale/edematous. Dark reactive gland nuclei contrast. Hyperplastic glands have corkscrew profile (arrowhead), thin smooth muscle strands between glands (arrow).
1237.original_caption: . Chemical gastritis, antrum. In chemical gastritis, the lamina propria shows very little inflammation, unlike in Helicobacter pylori gastritis. The lamina propria is pale and sometimes edematous such that the dark reactive nuclei of the glands stand out sharply in contrast. The corkscrew profile of the hyperplastic glands is a second classic feature (arrowhead), as is the presence of thin strands of smooth muscle between the glands (arrow).

1238.caption: Low-grade dysplasia in Barrett's esophagus: cells lose polarity, nuclei pleomorphic, lift off basement membrane (arrow). Changes extend to surface (arrowheads). Compare nondysplastic epithelium (6.4). Adjacent squamous epithelium (asterisks).
1238.original_caption: . Low-grade dysplasia in Barretts esophagus. The cells begin to lose polarity and organization, with nuclei becoming more pleomorphic and lifting up off the basement membrane (arrow). The changes must extend to the surface (arrowheads) to count. Compare with the nondysplastic epithelium shown in 6.4. Adjacent squamous epithelium can be seen on either side (asterisks).

1239.caption: Endometrial intraepithelial carcinoma. Abrupt transition (arrow) from normal epithelium (left) to malignant cells (right). Cells resemble serous carcinoma.
1239.original_caption: . Endometrial intraepithelial carcinoma. There is an abrupt transition (arrow) from normal surface epithelium (left) to malignant cells (right). The cells of endometrial intraepithelial carcinoma resemble those of serous carcinoma.

1240.caption: Spitz nevus in child: nests of large spindly melanocytes at dermoepidermal junction (arrow), rare epidermal spread (arrowhead). In adult, worrisome pattern.
1240.original_caption: . Spitz nevus. This nevus in a child shows nests of large, spindly melanocytes at the dermoepidermal junction (arrow) and rare melanocytes spreading up through the epidermis (arrowhead). In an adult, this pattern would be very worrisome.

1241.caption: Congenital biliary atresia: bile stasis causes acute inflammation, malformed bile ductule proliferation, bile accumulation (golden globs), progressing to fibrosis and ductule loss.
1241.original_caption: . Bile stasis. In this example of congenital biliary atresia, the downstream obstruction to flow creates the triad of acute inflammation (1), a proliferation of poorly formed bile ductules (2), and the accumulation of golden globs of bile (not seen here). This will progress to fibrosis (3) and eventually loss of ductules.

1242.caption: Atrophy. Hyperchromatic, infiltrative glands. Low cuboidal cells with attenuated cytoplasm (arrow), angular profiles—benign atrophy. Corpora amylacea (arrowhead).
1242.original_caption: . Atrophy. These glands appear hyperchromatic and infiltrative. However, the low cuboidal cells with attenuated cytoplasm (arrow) and angular gland profiles are typical of benign atrophy. Corpora amylacea are present (arrowhead).

1243.caption: Movats stain. Pulmonary arteries show two elastic layers (arrowheads), veins one (arrow). Collagen lining vessels appears pale yellow-green.
1243.original_caption: . Movats stain. The pulmonary arteries (A) have two elastic layers (arrowheads), while the veins (V) have one (arrow). The collagen lining the vessels is pale yellow-green in this stain.

1244.caption: High-grade papillary urothelial cancer. Papillary lesion with large, dark, pleomorphic nuclei, resembling carcinoma in situ. Mitotic figure present (arrow).
1244.original_caption: . High-grade papillary urothelial cancer. This papillary lesion shows large, dark, pleomorphic nuclei popping off the surface, similar to carcinoma in situ (see 12.3). A large mitotic figure is visible (arrow).

1245.caption: Collagenous colitis. H&E shows lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (arrow) with subepithelial pink material (arrowhead). Trichrome confirms thickened collagen table (blue, red arrow), irregular border, entrapped nuclei in lamina propria.
1245.original_caption: . Collagenous colitis. (A) The hematoxylin and eosin stain shows a top-heavy lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (arrow) accompanied by a dense pink material just under the surface epithelium (arrowhead). (B) A trichrome stain confirms the thickened collagen table (blue on this stain, red arrow), which has an irregular border and entraps nuclei within the lamina propria.

1246.caption: Papillary endothelial hyperplasia. Fibrin and RBCs (asterisks), not true fibrovascular cores, lined by bland endothelial cells (arrowhead).
1246.original_caption: . Papillary endothelial hyperplasia. Fingers of fibrin and red blood cells (asterisks), not true fibrovascular cores, are lined by bland endothelial cells (arrowhead).

1247.caption: Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cells (arrows) among inflammatory cells, lymphocytes (arrowhead).
1247.original_caption: . Hodgkins lymphoma. The malignant Reed-Sternberg cells (arrows) are spread out among a background of nonneoplastic inflammatory cells, especially lymphocytes (arrowhead).

1248.caption: Nodular sclerosing Hodgkin's lymphoma. Reed-Sternberg cell aggregates with broad fibrotic bands separating inflammation.
1248.original_caption: . Nodular sclerosing Hodgkins lymphoma. The aggregates of Reed-Sternberg cells and inflammation are separated by broad bands of fibrosis.

1249.caption: Sarcomatoid carcinoma. Spindled cells with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, frequent mitoses (arrow). Cytokeratin-positive confirms epithelial origin.
1249.original_caption: . Sarcomatoid carcinoma. Sheets of spindled cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli are visible. Mitoses (arrow) are common. These cells should be positive for cytokeratin stains, confirming their epithelial origin.

1250.caption: Moderately diff. squamous cell carcinoma: pleomorphic nuclei, dense pink cytoplasm (arrow). Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma: blue tumor cells, high N:C ratio, mitotic rate, central necrosis (asterisk). Keratin pearls in well-diff. tumors.
1250.original_caption: . Squamous cell carcinoma. (A) Moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with irregular nests of cells with highly pleomorphic nuclei and bright pink, dense cytoplasm (arrow). Keratin pearls may also be seen in more well-differentiated tumors. (B) Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma, with rounded nests of very blue tumor cells with high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio and a high mitotic rate. Central necrosis (asterisk) is common.

1251.caption: Moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma: irregular nests, pleomorphic nuclei, dense pink cytoplasm. Basaloid variant: blue tumor cells, high N:C ratio, mitotic rate, central necrosis. Keratin pearls in well-differentiated tumors.
1251.original_caption: . Squamous cell carcinoma. (A) Moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with irregular nests of cells with highly pleomorphic nuclei and bright pink, dense cytoplasm (arrow). Keratin pearls may also be seen in more well-differentiated tumors. (B) Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma, with rounded nests of very blue tumor cells with high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio and a high mitotic rate. Central necrosis (asterisk) is common.

1252.caption: 80yo male with nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy: glomerulus, PASM stain. Basement membrane thickening, no spikes. Membranous nephropathy (early stage), confirmed by Figs 6.11-6.12 immunohistology.
1252.original_caption: Glomerulus stained by periodic acid-methenamine silver in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 80 with the nephrotic syndrome. There is a hint of thickening of basement membranes, but there are no spikes. Immunohistology illustrated in Figs 6.11 and 6.12 shows that this is membranous nephropathy. The lack of spikes indicates an early stage

1253.caption: Electron micrograph of glomerulus in renal biopsy from 37yo male with HIV and nephrotic syndrome. Microtubular structures in mesangium suggest immunotactoid glomerulopathy.
1253.original_caption: Electron micrograph of part of a glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 37, with HIV infection and the nephrotic syndrome. There are microtubular structures in the mesangium, indicating immunotactoid glomerulopathy

1254.caption: Renal biopsy outer medulla in 12yo girl with proteinuria and poorly controlled type 1 diabetes. Proximal tubules show clear glycogen-containing cells - Armanni-Ebstein lesion. First described by Armanni (1872) and Ebstein (1882).
1254.original_caption: Outer medulla in a renal biopsy from a girl of 12 with proteinuria and 8 years of insulin deficient or type one diabetes mellitus that was poorly controlled. Some tubules, probably straight parts of proximal tubules, are lined by clear cells that contain glycogen. This is the Armanni- Ebstein lesion, named after Luciano Armanni (1839-1903), pronounced ar-man-ee, a pathologist in Naples, Italy, who was diabetic himself later in life, and first saw the abnormality in autopsy kidneys in 1872, and Wilhelm Ebstein (1836-1912), pronounced eb-stine, a German physician, who independently saw this in 1882

1255.caption: 34yo F with hematuria, proteinuria, HTN, ARF, rash. Renal biopsy: cortical acute/chronic damage, glomerular mesangial expansion with segmental vasculitic lesions. IgA deposition. Findings consistent with late/active Henoch-Schönlein nephritis.
1255.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 34 with hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, clinically acute renal failure, and a rash. There is marked acute and chronic damage, and a surviving glomerulus shows mesangial expansion with healing segmental vasculitic lesions. There is IgA deposition in glomeruli on immunohistologic study. Features are those of late and active Henoch-Schönlein nephritis

1256.caption: 37F, chronic renal failure, sarcoid, hypercalcemia. Renal cortex biopsy shows calcified deposits in atrophic tubules (arrowed).
1256.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 37 with chronic renal failure, sarcoid, and hypercalcemia. There are calcified deposits in a band of atrophic tubules (arrowed)

1257.caption: 69yo male with nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy shows glomeruli with segmental lesions of varying sizes/sites. Diagnosis: late classic segmental sclerosing glomerulonephritis (focal segmental glomerulosclerosis).
1257.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 69 with the nephrotic syndrome. Glomeruli have segmental lesions of various sizes and at various sites. The diagnosis is late classic segmental sclerosing glomerulonephritis, which can also be called late classic focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

1258.caption: 58F with nasal ulcer, mononeuritis multiplex, cANCA+, hematuria. Renal biopsy: cortical interlobular artery shows focal fibrinoid necrosis with inflammatory infiltrate.
1258.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 58 with nasal ulceration, mononeuritis multiplex, a positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody of cANCA type, and hematuria. An interlobular artery has fibrinoid necrosis of part of its wall, and an infiltrate of inflammatory cells

1259.caption: 23F renal biopsy: lupus nephritis with hematuria/proteinuria. Membranoproliferative (doubled basement membranes), membranous, and early segmental vasculitic patterns. Capillary loop thrombosis/disruption. SLE reactivation after 4y treatment.
1259.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 23 with hematuria, proteinuria, and clinical reactivation of systemic lupus erythematosus that had been treated for 4 years. There is lupus nephritis, seen as a combination of membranoproliferative pattern with doubled basement membranes, membranous pattern, and early segmental vasculitic pattern, with thrombosis and disruption of a capillary loop

1260.caption: 38岁男性肾活检皮质，慢性肾衰、蛋白尿、不对称肾脏。既往膀胱去神经（车祸）。较大肾脏示片状肾小管萎缩，缺血性肾小球缩小，部分肾小管及肾小球增大，大肾小球门部硬化（箭头）。提示慢性引流问题致肾小球减少，对侧肾脏受累更重。
1260.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 38 with chronic renal failure, proteinuria, and asymmetrical kidneys. There had been denervation of the bladder in a road traffic collision, several years before the biopsy. This specimen from the larger kidney shows patchy tubular atrophy, glomeruli with ischemic shrinkage, enlargement of tubules and another glomerulus, and an area of sclerosis at the hilum of the large glomerulus (arrowed). These changes are interpreted to be effects of reduced glomerular numbers, following chronic damage from drainage problems, which particularly affected the other kidney

1261.caption: 25岁男性活检标本皮质，C4d免疫过氧化物酶染色。见许多管周毛细血管内皮C4d沉积，部分箭头标示。移植前供受体HLA匹配良好，受体血清对供体淋巴细胞无细胞毒作用。活检提示抗体介导排斥，进一步检测发现受体有抗供体B细胞HLA II类抗原抗体（未包含
1261.original_caption: Cortex in the biopsy specimen from the man of 25, stained by an immunoperoxidase method for C4d. This is seen on the endothelium of many intertubular capillaries, some of which are arrowed. Before the transplant, there was a close HLA match between donor and recipient, and recipient serum had no cytotoxic effect on donor lymphocytes. When the biopsy findings suggested antibody mediated rejection, further immunologic investigation showed that the recipient had an antibody to an HLA class two antigen, found on donor B cells, but not included in routine HLA typing. The man had had a previous renal transplant, which had the same class two antigen as the new donor

1262.caption: 39yo F w/ lupus nephritis, renal biopsy: glomerulus shows mesangial IgG deposition on immunoperoxidase stain
1262.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 39 with lupus nephritis, which is illustrated in 6.53. An immunoperoxidase stain to detect IgG shows only mesangial deposition

1263.caption: 54岁男性肾活检标本，镜下血尿无蛋白尿。光镜基本正常，免疫组化示IgA肾病。
1263.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 54 with microscopic hematuria, but no proteinuria. This is virtually normal on orthodox light microscopy, but shows IgA nephropathy on immunohistologic study, illustrated in 9.6

1264.caption: 34岁男性死后肾楔形活检：头部外伤、大失血、进行性肾功能损害。肾移植评估见轻度肾小管萎缩，多数小管急性损伤伴上皮变平，细小空泡化（与甘露醇使用一致）。病理建议可用。移植至48岁男性，10天无功能后恢复良好。
1264.original_caption: Cortex in a wedge biopsy specimen of kidney removed after death from a man of 34, who had a head injury, severe loss of blood, and progressive renal impairment over a few hours before death. The biopsy was to see if the kidney could be transplanted. There is a little tubular atrophy, and most tubules show acute damage with flattened epithelium. Tubules also have fine vacuolation, which is consistent with use of mannitol. The pathologist recommended that the kidney should be used. The kidney was transplanted into a man of 48. Although there was no function for 10 days, the graft worked well afterwards

1265.caption: 70yo female, acute renal failure, early scleroderma. Renal biopsy: IgM immunoperoxidase shows heavy arteriolar wall deposition with fibrinoid necrosis, lighter arterial intima deposition (arrow). Diagnosis: small vessel vasculopathy/thrombotic microangiopathy.
1265.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 70 with acute renal failure and clinical features of early scleroderma. An immunoperoxidase method to detect IgM shows heavy deposition in the wall of an arteriole with fibrinoid necrosis, and lighter deposition in the intima of a small artery (arrowed). The diagnosis is small vessel vasculopathy, also called thrombotic microangiopathy

1266.caption: 64yo F with nephrotic syndrome & CLL, renal biopsy: glomerulus shows IgG+ subendothelial deposits, confirming membranoproliferative GN.
1266.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 64 with the nephrotic syndrome and chronic lymphocytic leukemia, stained by an immunoperoxidase method to detect IgG. There are large areas of subendothelial deposition, which confirms subendothelial membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

1267.caption: 57yo F post-acute renal failure, renal biopsy: normal tubules, interstitial edema.
1267.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 57 who had recovered from acute renal failure by the time of biopsy. Most tubules appear normal, but there is interstitial edema

1268.caption: 33yo F with Henoch-Schönlein nephritis: glomerulus shows acute segmental lesion, tuft disruption, cells in Bowman's space, mesangial increase, IgA deposition. Less defined vs other vasculitis (Figs 7.12, 7.15, 7.17).
1268.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 33 with Henoch-Schönlein nephritis, the cortex in which is illustrated in 7.25. There is an acute segmental lesion with tuft disruption and cells in Bowmans space, but this is not so sharply defined as the lesions in other types of vasculitis, such as in Figs 7.12, 7.15, and 7.17. The rest of the tuft is not normal, and has mesangial increase, with IgA deposition on immunohistologic study

1269.caption: 60yo male, acute renal failure. Renal cortex biopsy shows interstitial inflammatory infiltrate (lymphocytes), some tubule epithelial invasion. Acute interstitial nephritis, antibiotic-related (salmonella enteritis treatment).
1269.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 60 with acute renal failure. There is an interstitial infiltrate of inflammatory cells, mostly lymphocytes. A few cells enter the epithelium of tubules. 7.35 illustrates other tubules in this specimen. The diagnosis was acute interstitial nephritis, attributed to a response to antibiotics used to treat salmonella enteritis

1270.caption: 70yo F, chronic renal failure, ureteric TB. Renal biopsy shows thyroidised tubules.
1270.original_caption: Renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 70 with chronic renal failure and ureteric tuberculosis. Many tubules appear thyroidised

1271.caption: Renal biopsy serial sections mounted transversely on slide.
1271.original_caption: Serial sections of a renal biopsy specimen, mounted to run across the slide rather than along its length

1272.caption: Kidney cortex needle biopsy 3mo post-transplant, 24yo male. Shows acute cellular rejection with small vein thrombus.
1272.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 3 months after transplantation into a man of 24. There is evidence of significant acute cellular rejection with a thrombus in a small vein

1273.caption: 44yo male kidney transplant biopsy 2mo post-op. Mild chronic damage, no significant acute rejection. Cyclosporine toxicity diagnosed; function improved with dose reduction.
1273.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 2 months after transplantation into a man of 44. There is a little chronic damage, but there is no evidence of significant acute rejection. The clinical diagnosis was cyclosporine toxicity. Function improved when the dose of cyclosporine was reduced

1274.caption: 45yo cadaveric kidney transplanted to 61yo. Wedge biopsy showed glomerular metastatic carcinoma, altering clinical management. Ref: Barnes AD, Fox M.
1274.original_caption: Wedge biopsy specimen taken at the time of transplantation of a cadaveric kidney from a man of 45 into a man of 61. A glomerulus contains metastatic carcinoma. This finding had an immediate effect on clinical management. The story is given in Barnes AD, Fox M. Transplantation of tumour with a kidney graft.

1275.caption: 17yo female, hereditary Alport nephropathy. Renal cortex biopsy, immunoperoxidase stain for Goodpasture antigen (9.12). No antigen in glomerular/tubular basement membranes. Same expected with anti-α3/α5 collagen IV chains. Ref: 9.2.
1275.original_caption: Cortex in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 17 with hereditary nephropathy of Alport type that is illustrated in 9.2. This is stained by an immunoperoxidase method with the antibody to the Goodpasture antigen that is illustrated in 9.12. No Goodpasture antigen is found in either glomerular or tubular basement membranes. Similar findings are expected with antibodies against alpha three and five chains of collagen type four

1276.caption: 53岁男性肾活检显示慢性缺血性损伤，全球硬化肾小球。PASM染色见萎缩的血管球和Bowman囊仍可辨认。
1276.original_caption: Globally sclerosed glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 53 with chronic ischemic damage. On a section stained by periodic acid-methenamine silver, the shrunken tuft and Bowmans capsule are still recognisable

1277.caption: 22岁男性肾活检标本显示肾小球，有结节。PASM染色示双基底膜，符合膜增生性肾小球肾炎（MPGN）表现。Gordon博物馆中2/3肾脏为MPGN，第三例为继发于肺结核的淀粉样变。Bright首次描述肾病与蛋白尿、水肿关联，提出Bright病术语。
1277.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 22 with hematuria and proteinuria. There are nodules. Periodic acid-methenamine silver staining shows double basement membranes, with other features of subendothelial membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. Subendothelial membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis was found to be the diagnosis in two of the three kidneys in the Gordon Museum at Guys Hospital in London, United Kingdom, that had been described by Bright, who for many years was honoured by the term Brights disease that was applied to clinical renal disorders (6.34). Richard Bright (1789-1858), whose surname is pronounced in the usual way, was born in Bristol, United Kingdom, qualified in medicine in Edinburgh, and became a physician at Guys Hospital at the same time as Addison and Hodgkin, who also had diseases named after them. In 1827, Bright published a book called Reports of medical cases selected with a view of illustrating the symptoms and cure of diseases by a reference to morbid anatomy. He showed the association of edema, then called anasarca or dropsy or dropsical affection, with proteinuria and disorders of the kidney, and separated edema due to renal disorders from edema due to diseases of the heart and liver. The third kidney in the Gordon Museum showed amyloid secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis

1278.caption: 66yo male with nephrotic syndrome, serum/urine paraprotein. Renal biopsy: glomerulus shows mesangial PAS+ material, coarse bristles projecting from basement membranes.
1278.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 66 with the nephrotic syndrome, and a paraprotein in serum and urine. The mesangium contains material stained by periodic acidmethenamine silver, with groups of coarse bristles projecting from basement membranes in places.

1279.caption: 85岁男性急性肾衰竭肾活检皮质。急性肾小管损伤，可见含红/橙色颗粒的管理（箭头），提示肌红蛋白尿，免疫组化证实。血清肌酶升高，考虑酒精性肌病。
1279.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 85 with acute renal failure. There is acute tubular damage, with several casts containing flakes or granules that appear red/orange on hematoxylin and eosin staining (arrowed). This finding suggests myoglobinuria, which is confirmed by immunohistologic study, illustrated in 7.45. The man was found to have high concentrations of muscle enzymes in the serum, attributed to alcoholic myopathy

1280.caption: 29F, post-liver transplant 2y, acute renal failure. Renal biopsy shows cortical arteriole with fibrinoid necrosis. Findings consistent with cyclosporine-induced hemolytic uremic syndrome.
1280.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 29 with acute renal failure, 2 years after a liver transplant. An arteriole has fibrinoid necrosis of its wall. The explanation was hemolytic uremic syndrome, possibly due to cyclosporine treatment

1281.caption: 37yo F, chronic renal failure, systemic sarcoid features. Renal biopsy shows cortex with chronic damage, small granuloma with giant cells, consistent with renal sarcoid.
1281.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 37 with chronic renal failure and systemic features suggestive of sarcoid. There is chronic damage with a small granuloma, which contains giant cells. Appearances are consistent with sarcoid in the kidney

1282.caption: 15yo girl, renal biopsy, thin glomerular basement membrane disease. Glomerulus appears normal on light microscopy. Key landmarks: vascular pole (hilum) where arterioles cross Bowman's capsule, and tubular origin (proximal tubule opening). Hilum denotes entry/exit site in anatomy.
1282.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the girl of 15 with thin glomerular basement membrane disease, which is illustrated in 5.1. This appears normal on orthodox light microscopy, and shows the two landmarks that allow the position of a segmental lesion to be determined. These are the vascular pole, or hilum, where the arterioles cross Bowmans capsule, and the tubular origin, or opening of the proximal tubule from Bowmans space. In Latin, hilum meant a trifle, or that which adheres to a bean. The word is used in botany to mean the scar on a seed where it was attached to its stalk, and in anatomy to mean the site where structures enter or leave an organ

1283.caption: Electron micrograph of tubulo-reticular body in glomerular endothelial cell, seen in HIV and lupus nephritis (diagnosis in this 37F renal biopsy with proteinuria).
1283.original_caption: Electron micrograph showing a tubulo-reticular body in a glomerular endothelial cell. This is frequently found in HIV infection, but is also seen in other conditions, such as lupus nephritis, which is the diagnosis in this renal biopsy specimen, from a woman of 37 with proteinuria

1284.caption: Kidney cortex biopsy 2mo post-transplant in 24yo male shows acute cellular rejection (Fig11.9). Venous endothelial infiltrate present, not acute vascular rejection.
1284.original_caption: Cortex in the needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 2 months after transplantation into the man of 24 with significant acute cellular rejection, which is illustrated in 11.9. A vein has an infiltrate under its endothelium, but this is not a sign of acute vascular rejection

1285.caption: 42岁男性肾活检皮质，心脏移植后急性肾衰竭伴并发症。部分肾小管正常，部分上皮细胞细空泡化，少数萎缩。细空泡化可能为钙调磷酸酶抑制剂（免疫抑制剂）作用，也可见于未用药的急性肾小管损伤。
1285.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 42 with acute renal failure, after heart transplantation with many complications. Some tubules appear normal, some have fine vacuolation of the epithelium, and a few are atrophic. The fine vacuolation may be an effect of a calcineurin inhibitor used as an immunosuppressant, but similar changes can be seen in people with acute tubular damage, not treated with this type of drug (5.9)

1286.caption: 66yo F with chronic renal failure, aortic/pleural/peritoneal fibrosis. Biopsied kidney near-normal on imaging; ureter blocked in contralateral kidney. Specimen shows perirenal tissue, full-thickness cortex/medulla. Retroperitoneal fibrosis with thinned cortex (chronic damage), severely thinned medulla (between arrows). Hydronephrosis from ureter
1286.original_caption: A renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 66 with chronic renal failure, progressive fibrosis around the aorta, and fibrosis in the pleura, peritoneum, and elsewhere. The other kidney was known to have blockage of the ureter, but the biopsied kidney appeared nearly normal on imaging. The two pieces include perirenal tissues and full thickness of the cortex and medulla. There is retroperitoneal fibrosis with thinned cortex, which has areas of chronic damage. The medulla, between both sets of arrows, is severely thinned. This shows there is hydronephrosis, presumed to be due to ureteric obstruction from retroperitoneal fibrosis

1287.caption: 37岁男性肾移植1月后针活检示皮质出血性坏死，无急性血管排斥。影像示部分肾静脉血栓。移植物功能恢复。
1287.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 1 month after transplantation into a man of 37. There is hemorrhagic necrosis without evidence of acute vascular rejection. Only part of the kidney had venous thrombosis on radiographic investigation. The graft recovered function

1288.caption: 60yo F, incidental renal mass on fibromatosis follow-up. Needle biopsy shows uniform eosinophilic cell groups, consistent with oncocytoma.
1288.original_caption: Needle biopsy specimen of a mass found incidentally in the kidney of a woman of 60, during follow up after treatment of fibromatosis. There is a neoplasm consisting of small groups of uniform eosinophilic cells consistent with an oncocytoma

1289.caption: Glomerulus EM in 13yo girl with proteinuria, progressive renal impairment, low C3, C3 nephritic factor. Basement membranes show irregular thickening, dense deposit disease.
1289.original_caption: Electron micrograph of a glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a girl of 13 with proteinuria, progressive renal impairment, a low serum concentration of C3, and C3 nephritic factor in serum. Basement membranes have irregular thickening by material typical of dense deposit disease

1290.caption: 36yo woman with pre-eclampsia-related proteinuria, post-stroke. Renal biopsy: no vasculitis. Glomerulus shows endothelial swelling, tuft prolapse into tubule - typical pre-eclamptic changes. Proteinuria resolved.
1290.original_caption: Glomerulus, photographed at the same magnification as the one in 10.1, in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 36, who had proteinuria apparently related to pre-eclampsia, but also had a stroke at delivery. The biopsy was to exclude vasculitis, of which there is no evidence. There is marked endothelial swelling, and part of the tuft has prolapsed into the tubular opening. These are typical features of pre-eclamptic changes in glomeruli. Proteinuria disappeared soon afterwards

1291.caption: 34yo F with nephrotic syndrome & multisystem illness. Renal biopsy shows skeletal muscle with active myositis. Figs 4.2-4.5 demonstrate need to examine all tissues in specimen, not just kidney.
1291.original_caption: Skeletal muscle included in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 34 with the nephrotic syndrome and a multisystem illness. There is active myositis. This and Figs 4.2-4.5 show that tissues as well as kidney in a specimen should always be examined

1292.caption: 67yo woman's renal biopsy: Glomerulus shows Bowman's space cell-filled, early fibrosis (PASM stain), indicating healing vasculitic glomerulonephritis.
1292.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 67 that is illustrated in 7.15. Bowmans space is filled with cells. Fibres are beginning to appear among the cells, shown by periodic acid-methenamine silver staining. This is early healing of vasculitic glomerulonephritis

1293.caption: 69yo male renal biopsy: C9 immunoperoxidase shows linear GBM deposition with disruption, Bowman's space cells. IgG similar. Indicates anti-GBM disease/Goodpasture's.
1293.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen of the man of 69. An immunoperoxidase method to detect C9 shows linear deposition in the remains of the glomerular basement membrane, which is disrupted in places, with cells throughout Bowmans space. The distribution of IgG is similar. These features indicate antiglomerular basement membrane antibody disease or Goodpastures disease

1294.caption: 61yo male, acute renal failure, myeloma, lambda light chains in serum/urine. Renal biopsy: glomerular nodular appearance. Immunoperoxidase: no kappa deposition.
1294.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 61 with acute renal failure and myeloma, with monoclonal lambda light chains in serum and urine. There is a nodular appearance. Immunoperoxidase staining to detect kappa light chains shows no significant deposition in the kidney

1295.caption: 32M nephrotic syndrome, renal failure, SLE reactivation after 2y quiescence. Renal biopsy glomerulus shows C9 subendothelial deposition on immunoperoxidase.
1295.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 32 with the nephrotic syndrome, renal failure, and reactivation of systemic lupus erythematosus that had been quiescent for 2 years. An immunoperoxidase stain to detect C9 shows heavy subendothelial deposition.

1296.caption: 60yo woman with nephrotic syndrome, recovered untreated. Renal biopsy shows glomerular tip lesion, normal tuft.
1296.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 60 with the nephrotic syndrome, from which she recovered without treatment. There is a tip change, and the rest of the tuft appears normal. The diagnosis is glomerular tip lesion

1297.caption: 30岁男性肾活检显示严重高血压、正常肾大小、急性肾衰。晚期早期肾小管萎缩，多为慢性不可逆损伤。肾小球有IgA肾病证据，伴小血管病变（血栓性微血管病），符合急进性高血压影响。肾功能未恢复。
1297.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 30 with severe hypertension, two kidneys of normal size, and renal failure that clinically appeared acute. There is advanced early tubular atrophy, and much of the damage appears chronic and irreversible, rather than acute and potentially reversible. Glomeruli have evidence of IgA nephropathy, and there is a small vessel vasculopathy, also called thrombotic microangiopathy, consistent with effects of accelerated hypertension. Renal function did not recover

1298.caption: Kidney cortex biopsy post-transplant day 17, non-functioning. Lymphocyte clusters at corticomedullary junction near arcuate vessels (not rejection). No cortical rejection. Tubular crystals present (arrowed), indicating acute tubular damage.
1298.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 8 days after transplantation into a man of 17. There was no function. There are dense clusters of lymphocytes at the corticomedullary junction around arcuate vessels, but these are disregarded in assessment of rejection. There is no evidence of significant rejection in the cortex. A few tubules contain crystals (arrowed), a feature of acute tubular damage

1299.caption: 38岁男性膜性肾病肾活检显示广泛均匀肾小管萎缩，提示长期肾静脉血栓，经影像学证实。肾病综合征持续，1月前出现急性肾衰竭，肾功能未恢复。
1299.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 38 known to have membranous nephropathy, shown by a biopsy nearly 2 years before this one. The nephrotic syndrome had persisted since the first biopsy, and acute renal failure had developed 1 month before this biopsy. There is now widespread uniform tubular atrophy, which suggests longstanding renal vein thrombosis. This was confirmed by radiologic investigation. Renal function did not recover

1300.caption: 62岁男性活检标本皮质。SV40抗体免疫过氧化物酶法检测多瘤病毒，显示多个感染肾小管细胞，符合BK病毒感染。BK源自1971年首例肾移植受者姓名缩写。
1300.original_caption: Cortex in the biopsy specimen from the man of 62. An immunoperoxidase method to detect polyomaviruses using an antibody to SV40 shows several infected tubular cells. This finding is consistent with BK virus infection. B and K were the initials of the first person, a renal allograft recipient, from whom the virus was isolated in 1971

1301.caption: Microscopic field, Congo red stain, crossed polariser/analyser, anomalous colors: blue-green, yellow.
1301.original_caption: The microscopic field in 6.71, stained by Congo red, between crossed polariser and analyser, showing anomalous colours, blue-green and yellow.

1302.caption: Renal biopsy: 3yo girl with nephrotic syndrome. Outer cortex shows possibly enlarged glomeruli, no segmental lesions. Inner cortex in 6.30.
1302.original_caption: Outer cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a girl of 3 with the nephrotic syndrome. Glomeruli are possibly enlarged, but show no other abnormality. In particular, there are no segmental lesions. The inner cortex is illustrated in 6.30

1303.caption: 68岁男性肾活检标本中肾小球，免疫过氧化物酶检测显示淀粉样蛋白A大量沉积。肾小管上皮染色常见，可忽略。诊断为AA型淀粉样变，归因于长期褥疮的持续炎症反应。
1303.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the man of 68 that is illustrated in Figs 6.71 and 6.72. Immunoperoxidase study to detect amyloid A protein shows heavy deposition in the glomerulus. The staining in tubular epithelium is seen in every kidney, and is ignored. Despite the paraprotein, the diagnosis was amyloid of AA type. This was attributed to a persistent inflammatory response to bed sores of long duration

1304.caption: 45岁女性肾活检显示肾小球，伴肾病综合征、急性肾衰及系统性红斑狼疮临床复发（9年治疗史）。狼疮肾炎表现为膜增生性肾小球肾炎伴内皮下免疫沉积（箭头示“铁丝圈”样改变）。
1304.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 45 with the nephrotic syndrome, acute renal failure, and clinical reactivation of systemic lupus erythematosus that had been treated for 9 years. There is lupus nephritis, with the appearance of subendothelial membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, including subendothelial immune deposits (arrowed) that are called wire loops, because they resemble the tools used in microbiology to spread organisms on culture dishes

1305.caption: 34yo woman renal biopsy cortex, Fig10.3, IgM+ in mesangium by immunoperoxidase
1305.original_caption: Cortex in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 34, which is illustrated in 10.3, examined by an immunoperoxidase method to detect IgM, which is found in mesangium

1306.caption: 67M kidney lesion biopsy: complex cyst on imaging, papillary eosinophilic neoplasm, renal cell carcinoma.
1306.original_caption: Needle biopsy specimen of a lesion in the kidney of a man of 67 found to have a complex cyst on radiographic investigation. There is a papillary eosinophilic neoplasm consistent with a renal cell carcinoma

1307.caption: 52yo male with nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy: glomerulus, PASM stain, shows membranous nephropathy (early stage, no spikes). Tuft adhesion to Bowman's capsule at tubule opening, hyaline material in capillary loops. IHC confirms diagnosis.
1307.original_caption: Glomerulus stained by periodic acid-methenamine silver in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 52 with the nephrotic syndrome. Immunohistology shows that this is membranous nephropathy, early because there are no spikes. There is adhesion of the tuft to Bowmans capsule at the opening of the tubule, with hyaline material in capillary loops at this site

1308.caption: 30yo F with chronic renal failure, SLE, recurrent spontaneous abortion, anticardiolipin antibodies. Renal cortex shows small vessel vasculopathy/thrombotic microangiopathy, consistent with antiphospholipid syndrome.
1308.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 30 with chronic renal failure, systemic lupus erythematosus, a history of repeated spontaneous abortion, and anticardiolipin antibodies in the serum. There is late renal damage with features of a small vessel vasculopathy, also called thrombotic microangiopathy, consistent with the antiphospholipid syndrome

1309.caption: Lymphoid infiltrate, immunoperoxidase shows EBV late membrane protein. Many cells express viral antigen.
1309.original_caption: The lymphoid infiltrate, examined by an immunoperoxidase method for a late membrane protein of Epstein Barr virus. Many cells express the viral antigen

1310.caption: 62岁男性肾移植后4个月针活检标本显示皮质区，慢性炎性浸润明显，肾小管可见异常核，箭头处显著。
1310.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 4 months after transplantation into a man of 62. There is a heavy chronic inflammatory infiltrate with abnormal nuclei in tubules, particularly the one arrowed.

1311.caption: 20yo male, chronic renal failure, renal biopsy shows cortex with glomeruli-sized cysts, tuft remnants in cysts, suggestive of glomerulocystic disorder, not early ADPKD.
1311.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 20 with chronic renal failure. There are cysts about the size of glomeruli, and elsewhere remnants of tufts are seen in cysts. This appears a glomerulocystic disorder, rather than an early form of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

1312.caption: 54岁男性肾活检标本显示肾小球，免疫过氧化物酶法检测IgA示轻度系膜沉积，诊断为IgA肾病。任何强度IgA沉积均具意义
1312.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the man of 54, which is illustrated in 9.5. An immunoperoxidase method to detect IgA shows light mesangial deposition, and gives the diagnosis of IgA nephropathy. Definite deposition of IgA of any intensity in glomeruli is significant

1313.caption: 49yo F with nephrotic syndrome, mild acute renal impairment. Minimal change nephropathy. Tubular damage: dilated tubules, irregular epithelium. Suggests renal vein thrombosis, confirmed radiologically.
1313.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 49 with the nephrotic syndrome and mild acute renal impairment. The nephrotic syndrome is explained by minimal change nephropathy. There is extensive acute damage to tubules, which are dilated, with irregular epithelium. This appearance in the nephrotic syndrome suggests the possibility of renal vein thrombosis, which the woman was shown to have on radiologic investigation

1314.caption: 22yo F with nephrotic syndrome, acute renal failure, SLE reactivation. Renal biopsy shows lupus nephritis, acute interstitial nephritis, mesangial expansion, glomerular vasculitic lesions, intracapillary immune aggregates (hyaline thrombi).
1314.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 22 with the nephrotic syndrome, renal failure that appeared acute, and clinical reactivation of systemic lupus erythematosus that had been treated briefly 1 year before. There is lupus nephritis with acute interstitial nephritis, various amounts of mesangial expansion, active and healing glomerular vasculitic lesions, and large intracapillary masses in glomeruli that are often called hyaline thrombi, although they are immune aggregates rather than thromboses

1315.caption: Kidney wedge biopsy cortex from 16yo male donor (subarachnoid hemorrhage) to 24yo female recipient. Normal histology, successful graft.
1315.original_caption: Cortex in a wedge biopsy specimen of kidney taken at the time of transplantation into a woman of 24 from a boy of 16, who died of a subarachnoid hemorrhage. The kidney appears normal, and the graft worked well

1316.caption: 37岁男性肾活检皮质显示肾小球大顶端改变，系膜增生，无节段异常，伴急性肾小管损伤。诊断为早期经典节段硬化性肾小球肾炎（早期经典局灶节段性肾小球硬化）。
1316.original_caption: Cortex in the renal biopsy specimen from the man of 37 that is illustrated in 6.19, which shows a glomerulus with a large tip change. Glomeruli appear large with mesangial increase, but have no segmental abnormalities in this field, because there are no tubular openings. There is acute tubular damage. The diagnosis is early classic segmental sclerosing glomerulonephritis, which can also be called early classic focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

1317.caption: Renal biopsy cortex, 30yo male with acute renal failure. Small vessel vasculopathy/thrombotic microangiopathy: interlobular artery shows loose intimal thickening (single arrow) and intimal hemorrhage (double arrow). Consistent with accelerated hypertension effects.
1317.original_caption: Cortex in the renal biopsy specimen, also illustrated in 7.1, from the man of 30 with acute renal failure. There is a small vessel vasculopathy, also called thrombotic microangiopathy, with loose intimal thickening in one interlobular artery (single arrow), and intimal hemorrhage in another (double arrow). These changes are consistent with effects of accelerated hypertension

1318.caption: 34岁男性肾活检皮质，慢性肾衰、蛋白尿、睡眠呼吸暂停。肾小球增大，系膜区扩张（尤其门部），呈缺氧性改变。
1318.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 34 with chronic renal failure, proteinuria, and sleep apnea. All glomeruli appear large with expanded mesangium, particularly at the hilum. These are hypoxic changes in glomeruli

1319.caption: 52yo woman's renal biopsy: glomerulus shows linear IgG deposition in basement membranes (arrowed), typical in diabetic glomerulopathy. IgG granules in proximal tubules indicate glomerular proteinuria.
1319.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 52 whose diabetic glomerulopathy is illustrated in 6.34. An immunoperoxidase method to detect IgG shows linear deposition of IgG in glomerular basement membranes (arrowed), sometimes found in diabetic glomerulopathy. Granules of IgG are seen in proximal tubular cells, a finding in glomerular proteinuria

1320.caption: 46yo woman, chronic renal failure, non-glomerulonephritic cause. Kidney biopsy shows arteriole with hyalinosis nodules bulging into surrounding tissue. Not calcineurin inhibitor-related.
1320.original_caption: Arteriole in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney from a woman of 46 with chronic renal failure from a nonglomerulonephritic cause. Nodules of hyalinosis bulge into tissues around the arteriole. This is sometimes claimed to be a feature of effects of calcineurin inhibitors, but this woman had never been treated with these drugs

1321.caption: Normal glomerulus in renal biopsy, asymptomatic proteinuria, same magnification as 10.2 for comparison.
1321.original_caption: Apparently normal glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man whose age was not given to the pathologist, but who had asymptomatic proteinuria. This image is at the same magnification as the one in 10.2 to emphasise the changes in that figure

1322.caption: 47岁男性肾活检皮质，多系统疾病，弱阳性ANCA，血尿、蛋白尿，肾功能正常。一肾小球见急性节段性血管炎病变（箭头），可诊断肾血管炎。
1322.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 47 with a multisystem illness, a weakly positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, hematuria, proteinuria, and normal renal function. One glomerulus has a small, acute, segmental vasculitic lesion (arrowed). This is enough to give the diagnosis of renal vasculitis

1323.caption: 27M kidney transplant 17y post-op, needle biopsy: glomerulus shows mesangial expansion, doubled capillary loop basement membranes, chronic allograft glomerulopathy.
1323.original_caption: Glomerulus in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney from a man of 27 taken 17 years after transplantation. There is mesangial expansion, and several capillary loops have doubled basement membranes. These are features of chronic allograft glomerulopathy

1324.caption: Renal biopsy: 38M with 2-year membranous nephropathy. Glomerulus shows PASM-stained uniform capillary loop spikes, indicating late-stage disease. Arrow marks glomerular tuft adhesion to Bowman's capsule near tubular opening.
1324.original_caption: Glomerulus stained by periodic acid-methenamine silver in the renal biopsy specimen, which is illustrated in 6.2, from the man of 38 known to have membranous nephropathy for 2 years. There are uniform spikes on the outside of capillary loops. These indicate a later stage of membranous nephropathy than in 6.9. The arrow indicates adhesion of the glomerular tuft to Bowmans capsule, next to the tubular opening, opposite the hilum

1325.caption: 65yo woman, acute renal failure. Renal biopsy: cortical atrophy (acute on chronic), tubular casts with giant cells, myeloma kidney. Serum lambda light chain paraprotein.
1325.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 65 with acute renal failure. Some tubules are atrophic, which suggests that the renal failure is acute on chronic. There are casts in several tubules, several surrounded by giant cells. These gave the diagnosis of myeloma kidney. After the biopsy, a lambda light chain paraprotein was found in the womans serum

1326.caption: Kidney cortex needle biopsy post-transplant day 4, 25yo male. No graft function. Severe acute tubular damage, neutrophil infiltrate in intertubular capillaries.
1326.original_caption: Cortex in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 4 days after transplantation into a man of 25. There was no graft function. Tubules show severe acute damage, with a heavy infiltrate of neutrophils in intertubular capillaries.

1327.caption: 36yo male, heavy proteinuria, hematuria. Renal biopsy: glomerulus with mesangial expansion, Congo red neg. EM: mesangial fibrillary deposits, fibrillary glomerulopathy.
1327.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 36 with heavy proteinuria and episodes of hematuria. There is mesangial expansion, but no reactivity with Congo red. Electron microscopy shows fibrillary deposits in mesangium, with the appearance of fibrillary glomerulopathy

1328.caption: 67yo woman's renal biopsy: Glomerulus with fibrous segmental lesion on PASM stain, tuft disruption, Bowman's space involvement, capsular adhesion. Healed vasculitic glomerulonephritis.
1328.original_caption: Glomerulus in the renal biopsy specimen from the woman of 67 that is illustrated in Figs 7.15 and 7.16. On a section stained by periodic acid-methenamine silver, there is a sharply defined, fibrous, segmental lesion, which includes a disrupted area in the tuft and adjacent Bowmans space, and is adherent to Bowmans capsule. This is healed vasculitic glomerulonephritis

1329.caption: 54岁男性肾病综合征伴银屑病关节炎行肾活检。标本中无肾组织，见脾组织，刚果红染色示AA淀粉样变性。肾病综合征考虑AA淀粉样变所致。淀粉样物质由希腊语"淀粉样"衍生，1839年由J Vogel和M J Schleiden首次命名。Virchow证实脾脏蜡样
1329.original_caption: Attempted renal biopsy in a man of 54 with the nephrotic syndrome and psoriatic arthropathy. There is no kidney in the specimen, but there is spleen, and this contains amyloid stained by Congo red, shown to be AA amyloid. The nephrotic syndrome was assumed to be due to AA amyloidosis. Amyloid, from Greek words meaning starch and resembling or like, is sometimes mistakenly considered one of the many words invented by Rudolf Ludwig Karl Virchow (1821-1902), called the greatest figure in the history of pathology by E R Long in A History of Pathology, 1928. Virchow apparently pronounced his surname feer-cho, with the ch as the Scottish pronounce it in loch, but several other pronunciations are used in English. The word amyloid was first used by two Germans J Vogel and M J Schleiden in 1839, because of the similar staining properties of cellulose and starch. Virchow showed that waxy or lardaceous change of the spleen was due to amyloid, which he thought was a cellulose like meterial

1330.caption: 23yo woman with nephrotic syndrome, HIV-. Glomerulus shows tuft collapse, mesangium loss. Epithelial cells enlarged, vacuolated. Diagnosis: collapsing glomerulopathy.
1330.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 23 with the nephrotic syndrome, but without HIV infection. The glomerulus shows collapse of the tuft as the mesangium has disappeared. Epithelial cells are enlarged and vacuolated. The diagnosis is collapsing glomerulopathy

1331.caption: 64岁女性慢性肾衰竭肾活检标本示皮质严重慢性损伤，无肾小球病变，病因不明。标本无髓质。数月前国外活检示髓质急性乳头坏死，后归因于非甾体抗炎药。图示皮质损伤为乳头坏死晚期后果。
1331.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 64 with chronic renal failure. There is severe chronic damage without evidence of a glomerular disorder, but otherwise without clues to the cause. There was no medulla in this specimen. A renal biopsy specimen taken in another country a few months before this specimen was reviewed. This contained medulla, which showed acute papillary necrosis, later attributed to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The cortical damage seen in this figure is a late consequence of papillary necrosis

1332.caption: 60yo woman with microscopic hematuria, no proteinuria. EM shows uniformly thin GBM (150nm), prominent lamina densa. Features of thin GBM disease.
1332.original_caption: Electron micrograph of part of the glomerular basement membrane in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 60 with persistent microscopic hematuria, but no proteinuria. This is uniformly thin, with a thickness of about 150 nm. Compared with normal basement membranes in 6.6, photographed at the same magnification, this membrane is not only thinner, but also has a more obvious lamina densa in the middle. Features are those of thin glomerular basement membrane disease

1333.caption: 85岁男性肌红蛋白尿肾活检标本，免疫过氧化物酶染色示皮质小管含肌红蛋白，确诊
1333.original_caption: Cortex in the renal biopsy specimen from the man of 85 with myoglobinuria, which is illustrated in 7.44, stained by an immunoperoxidase method to detect myoglobin. Tubules contain myoglobin, and the diagnosis is confirmed

1334.caption: 21mo girl with 2wk nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy shows normal glomeruli, no immunoprotein deposition. Diagnosis: minimal change nephropathy.
1334.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a girl aged 21 months with the nephrotic syndrome for 2 weeks. This glomerulus and all others appear normal, and there is no significant deposition of immunoproteins on immunohistologic study. The diagnosis is minimal change nephropathy

1335.caption: 66yo woman with nephrotic proteinuria & 8yr T2DM. Renal biopsy shows glomerulus with severe ischemic tuft shrinkage, Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule at tubular origin adherent to Bowman's capsule.
1335.original_caption: Glomerulus in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 66 with proteinuria in the nephrotic range, and 8 years of insulin resistant or type two diabetes mellitus. There is severe ischemic shrinkage of the tuft, but a Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule is still seen, adherent to Bowmans capsule just at the origin of the tubule

1336.caption: 41yo woman, 6mo post-transplant, reduced immunosuppression. Hypercellular glomerulus with endothelial swelling, lymphocyte infiltrates (some clustered), tubular prolapse. Acute allograft glomerulopathy. Acute cellular rejection present.
1336.original_caption: Glomerulus in a needle biopsy specimen of kidney taken 6 months after transplantation into a woman of 41, whose immunosuppressive drugs had been reduced. The glomerulus appears hypercellular with endothelial swelling, an infiltrate of lymphocytes, some of which are clustered and appear to run together, and prolapse into the tubular opening. Features are those of acute allograft glomerulopathy. There is evidence of acute cellular rejection elsewhere in the specimen

1337.caption: 37yo F, chronic renal failure, small symmetrical kidneys, HTN, recent UTI. Renal cortex biopsy shows severe chronic damage, no glomerulonephritis, etiology unclear.
1337.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 37 with chronic renal failure, small symmetrical kidneys, hypertension for a few years, and recent urinary tract infection. There is severe chronic damage, without evidence of a glomerulonephritic disorder. Otherwise, no clue to the cause is seen

1338.caption: 51M kidney mass needle biopsy: squamous carcinoma, partly necrotic, consistent with bronchus carcinoma metastasis.
1338.original_caption: Needle biopsy specimen of a mass found in the kidney of a man of 51 during investigation of a lung mass. There is a squamous carcinoma, partly necrotic, consistent with a metastasis from carcinoma of the bronchus

1339.caption: 44yo F with acute renal failure. Renal biopsy shows thrombotic microangiopathy: small artery with intimal thickening (→) and thrombus (↔). Dx: mixed connective tissue disorder (scleroderma + SLE features).
1339.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a woman of 44 with acute renal failure. There is a small vessel vasculopathy, also called thrombotic microangiopathy, with loose concentric intimal thickening in a small artery (single arrow), and thrombus in another (double arrow). Clinically, the diagnosis was a mixed connective tissue disorder, with features of scleroderma and systemic lupus erythematosus

1340.caption: 65岁男性急性肾衰竭肾活检标本显示皮质严重急性间质性肾炎伴肉芽肿，含巨细胞。诊断为抗生素治疗肝脓肿所致急性肉芽肿性间质性肾炎。需结合临床特征、抗酸染色阴性及无慢性肾损伤（如结核/结节病）排除结核。
1340.original_caption: Cortex in a renal biopsy specimen from a man of 65 with acute renal failure. There is severe acute interstitial nephritis with several granulomas, which include giant cells.
