2225.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia. Prostate glands rimmed by basal cell layers (a). Basal cells have scant cytoplasm, round-to-oval hyperchromatic nuclei, positive for p63 (b). Stratified basal cells with prominent nucleoli may mimic HGPIN. Calcification present.
2225.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia. Prostate glands are rimmed with one or several layers of basal cells (a). Basal cells have scant cytoplasm and round-to-oval hyperchromatic nuclei. They are positive for basal cell markers such as p63 (b). Some basal cells are stratified and have prominent nucleoli and may be mistaken for HGPIN. Calcification can also be seen

2226.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia. Prostate glands rimmed by basal cell layers (a). Scant cytoplasm, round-to-oval hyperchromatic nuclei. p63+ (b). Stratified basal cells with nucleoli may mimic HGPIN. Calcification present.
2226.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia. Prostate glands are rimmed with one or several layers of basal cells (a). Basal cells have scant cytoplasm and round-to-oval hyperchromatic nuclei. They are positive for basal cell markers such as p63 (b). Some basal cells are stratified and have prominent nucleoli and may be mistaken for HGPIN. Calcification can also be seen

2227.caption: Intraluminal amorphous eosinophilic secretion, more common in cancer but also seen in benign lesions.
2227.original_caption: amorphous intraluminal secretion. Cancer glands have eosinophilic amorphous material within their lumens. They are more common in cancer, but can also be found in some benign lesions

2228.caption: Nuclear atypia, hyperchromasia. Cancer cells show larger hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei vs benign glands (arrows).
2228.original_caption: nuclear atypia  hyperchromasia. Compared to the adjacent benign glands, cancer cells can have larger hyperchromatic and pleomorphic nuclei (arrows)

2229.caption: Perineural abutment by benign prostate gland encircling nerve fiber (a). Distinguish from perineural invasion. Immunostains like p63 confirm benign glands (b).
2229.original_caption: Perineural abutment. A benign prostate gland abuts and loosely encircles a nerve fiber (a). It is critical to distinguish it from perineural invasion by prostate cancer. In difficult cases, immunostains for basal cells, such as p63, can be used to confirm the benign nature of the glands (b)

2230.caption: Perineural abutment: benign prostate gland loosely encircles nerve fiber (a). Distinguish from perineural invasion by cancer. Immunostains (p63) confirm benign glands (b).
2230.original_caption: Perineural abutment. A benign prostate gland abuts and loosely encircles a nerve fiber (a). It is critical to distinguish it from perineural invasion by prostate cancer. In difficult cases, immunostains for basal cells, such as p63, can be used to confirm the benign nature of the glands (b)

2231.caption: Prostate glands within skeletal muscle fibers, found intraprostatically at apex/anterior fibromuscular layer. Cancer glands in muscle fibers ≠ extraprostatic extension.
2231.original_caption: Prostate glands within skeletal muscle fibers. Skeletal muscle can be found intraprostatically, usually in the apex and anterior fibromuscular layer. Prostate glands can be found within the skeletal muscle fibers; therefore, finding cancer glands within the skeletal muscle fibers should not be interpreted as extraprostatic extension

2232.caption: Prostate cancer post-radiation: small atrophic cancer glands with foamy cytoplasm (a). Adjacent benign gland shows irregular contour, stratified hyperchromatic nuclei. Cancer glands AMACR+, p63- (b).
2232.original_caption: Prostate cancer after radiation treatment. The cancer glands are small and atrophic with foamy cytoplasm after radiation (a). Also note the adjacent benign gland (right lower corner) is large and has irregular contour, stratified, and scattered hyperchromatic nuclei. The cancer glands are positive for AMACR but negative for basal cell marker p63 (b)

2233.caption: Prostate cancer post-radiation: small atrophic cancer glands with foamy cytoplasm (a). Adjacent benign gland shows irregular contour, stratified nuclei. Cancer glands AMACR+, p63- (b).
2233.original_caption: Prostate cancer after radiation treatment. The cancer glands are small and atrophic with foamy cytoplasm after radiation (a). 2234.caption: AMACR expression in adenosis. Biopsy shows well-circumscribed focus of packed small/large glands (a), cells with slight nuclear enlargement, inconspicuous nucleoli (b). Patchy HMWCK+ basal cells (c). Focal AMACR+ glands (d).
2234.original_caption: AMACR expression in adenosis. The biopsy contains a wellcircumscribed focus of closely packed small and large glands (a), whose cells have slight nuclear enlargement and inconspicuous nucleoli (b). The basal cell staining HMWCK is positive in a patchy fashion (c). These glands are focally positive for AMACR (d)

2238.caption: Prostate biopsy: cancer glands ERG+ (red), p63-; benign glands p63+ (brown), ERG-. Antibody cocktail for p63 & ERG.
2238.original_caption: Prostate biopsy with cancer stained with an antibody cocktail for both basal cell marker p63 (brown nuclear staining) and ERG (red nuclear staining). Cancer glands are positive for ERG and negative for p63, whereas benign glands are positive for p63 and negative for ERG

2239.caption: Prostate biopsy: HGPIN gland (right upper) adjacent to cancer glands (left lower). Both cancer and part of HGPIN show ERG positivity.
2239.original_caption: ERG protein expression in prostate cancer and high-grade PIN. Prostate biopsy contains an HGPIN gland (right upper corner) that is adjacent to the cancer glands (left lower corner). The cancer glands and part of HGPIN glands are positive for ERG

2246.caption: 压缩后：医学图像显示左肺上叶结节，直径1.5cm，边缘毛刺，邻近胸膜牵拉。纵隔淋巴结肿大，最大短径1.2cm。右肺野清晰，心脏形态正常。建议进一步活检明确性质。

2242.caption: Sclerosing adenosis mimics high-grade prostate carcinoma. TURP specimen shows poorly formed, complex glands resembling carcinoma. Forms well-circumscribed nodule of packed glands (a). High mag: slit-like lumina, fused glands, signet ring cells (b). Cellular, hyalinized stroma (c). Nucleoli, crystalloids, blue mucin present (d
2242.original_caption: Sclerosing adenosis mimicking high-grade prostate carcinoma. (a–f) This TURP specimen demonstrates a proliferation of poorly formed and complex glands mimicking high-grade prostate carcinoma. Low-power recognition is a key. It typically forms a well-circumscribed nodule of tightly packed glands (a). At high magnification, glands demonstrate complex proliferation, poorly formed glands with slit-like lumina, fused glands, and even single cells with signet ring cell-like features, mimicking high-grade cancer (b). Stroma surrounding the glands is cellular and hyalinized (arrows) (c). Prominent nucleoli, crystalloids, and blue mucin are common (d). Basal cells are highlighted with basal cell marker p63 (e). Basal cells undergo myoepithelial metaplasia and show coexpression of basal cell markers and S-100 (f) and muscle-specific actin. When one or more well-circumscribed cellular lesions mimicking high-grade prostate cancer are encountered in TURP or biopsies from the transition zone of the prostate, sclerosing adenosis should be ruled out

2247.caption: 压缩后：医学图像显示左肺上叶磨玻璃结节，直径8mm，边界清晰，无毛刺或胸膜牵拉。右肺中叶见部分实性结节，6mm，伴微血管征。纵隔淋巴结无肿大。心脏大小正常，主动脉无扩张。无胸腔积液或气胸。建议3个月后随访CT。

2249.caption: 压缩后：左肺上叶磨玻璃结节，直径8mm，边缘模糊，邻近胸膜牵拉。右肺中叶实性结节，5mm，边界清晰。纵隔淋巴结肿大，短径12mm。肝右叶低密度灶，3cm，动脉期强化，门脉期消退。脾脏增大，15cm。双侧少量胸腔积液

2250.caption: 压缩后：医学图像显示左肺上叶结节，直径1.2cm，边缘毛刺，邻近胸膜牵拉。CT值35HU，增强后轻度强化。纵隔淋巴结无肿大。考虑恶性可能，建议活检。右肺清晰，无异常。

2251.caption: 压缩后：左肺上叶磨玻璃结节，直径8mm，边界模糊，邻近胸膜牵拉，考虑恶性可能。右肺中叶实性结节，5mm，边界清晰，良性特征。纵隔淋巴结无肿大。主动脉钙化。建议3个月后CT随访。

2252.caption: 压缩后：左肺上叶磨玻璃结节，直径8mm，边缘模糊，邻近胸膜牵拉，考虑恶性可能。右肺下叶实性结节，5mm，边界清晰，良性特征。纵隔淋巴结无肿大。心影正常。建议3个月后CT随访。

2253.caption: Immunostains for basal cell markers in benign prostate: HMWCK/34bE12, p63, basal cell cocktail (34bE12+p63). Sensitivity varies: highest with cocktail, lower with p63/34bE12, especially in TURP with cautery artifact. Specificity similar.
2253.original_caption: Immunostains for basal cell markers in benign prostate glands, including HMWCK/34bE12 (a), p63 (b), and basal cell cocktail (34bE12 and p63) (c). The specificity of these basal cell markers is similar. However, the sensitivity for detecting basal cells varies, highest with basal cell cocktail and less with p63 and 34bE12, especially in transurethral resection specimens with significant cautery artifact

2258.caption: Benign glands may lack basal cell markers. Small glands (arrowheads) resemble adjacent benign glands (arrows, a). No nuclear atypia (b). One gland p63-, other focally+ (c). Basal cells absent in atrophy/adenosis; absence ≠ cancer. Use benign glands as reference. No atypia = no cancer.
2258.original_caption: Benign glands can occasionally be negative for basal cell markers. Several small glands (arrowheads) are cytologically identical to adjacent, larger, benign glands (arrows, a). No significant nuclear atypia is observed (b). One gland is negative and the other one focally positive for basal cell marker p63 (c). Basal cells may be absent in some noncancerous conditions including partial atrophy and adenosis. The lack of basal cells does not equate to cancer. When evaluating atypical glands, one should always use the adjacent benign glands as reference. A cancer diagnosis cannot be rendered in the absence of significant nuclear atypia

2259.caption: Benign glands may lack basal cell markers. Small glands (arrowheads) resemble adjacent benign glands (arrows, a). No nuclear atypia (b). One gland p63-, other focally+ (c). Basal cells absent in atrophy/adenosis; absence ≠ cancer. Use benign glands as reference. No cancer without significant nuclear atypia.

2262.caption: AMACR+ in benign prostate glands. Small glands (arrows, a) resemble large benign glands (b), negative for basal markers but AMACR+ (c). AMACR seen in cancer and noncancer (HGPIN, adenosis, atrophy, benign). Use adjacent benign glands as reference. Cancer diagnosis requires nuclear atypia.
2262.original_caption: Positive AMACR staining in benign prostate glands. Several small glands are adjacent (arrows, a) and cytologically identical to large benign glands (b). These small glands are negative for basal cell markers and positive for AMACR (c). Although preferentially expressed in prostate cancer glands, AMACR expression is also found in noncancerous glands, including HGPIN, adenosis, partial atrophy, and morphologically benign glands. When evaluating atypical glands, one should always use the adjacent benign glands as reference. A cancer diagnosis cannot be rendered in the absence of significant nuclear atypia

2264.caption: Partial atrophy with atypical features, suspicious for cancer. Disorganized glands with partially atrophic cytoplasm, some completely atrophic. Bland cytology but infiltrative edge (arrow). Immunophenotype identical to cancer. Cannot rule out cancer despite partial atrophy features.
2264.original_caption: (a) Partial atrophy with atypical features, suspicious for cancer. At low power, several disorganized glands with partially atrophic cytoplasm are present. A few completely atrophic glands are also present. These features are suggestive of partial atrophy (a). At higher magnification, these glands demonstrated bland cytology (b). However, the edge of this lesion appears infiltrative (arrow, a) and it demonstrates immunophenotype identical to cancer (c). Despite the presence of several features of partial atrophy, one cannot rule out cancer.

2269.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma NE differentiation spectrum. (a) Paneth cell-like differentiation: eosinophilic cytoplasmic granules (arrows). (b) Small cell carcinoma: basophilic tumor cells in nests/trabeculae infiltrating benign glands. (c) High-mag small cell carcinoma: scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin, mitosis, apoptosis. Acinar differentiation suggests prostate origin.
2269.original_caption: Spectrum of NE differentiation in prostate adenocarcinoma. (a) Conventional prostate adenocarcinoma demonstrates Paneth cell like differentiation, characterized by occasional cells with bright eosinophilic cytoplasmic granules resembling Paneth cells (arrows) of the gastrointestinal tract. (b) Small cell carcinoma involving the prostate shows basophilic tumor cells arranged in haphazard nests and trabeculae with infiltration between benign glands. (c) At higher magnification, small cell carcinoma of the prostate is identical to its pulmonary counterpart with scant cytoplasm, spindling of nuclei with salt-and-pepper chromatin, indistinct nucleoli, increased mitosis, and apoptosis. Presence of acinar differentiation is a very useful feature to suggest the prostate origin.

2267.caption: NE differentiation in prostate adenocarcinoma. (a) Conventional type shows Paneth cell-like differentiation with eosinophilic cytoplasmic granules (arrows). (b) Small cell carcinoma: basophilic tumor cells in haphazard nests infiltrating benign glands. (c) High-mag: scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin, mitosis, apoptosis. Acinar differentiation suggests prostate origin.

2275.caption: High-grade urothelial carcinoma involving prostate. Preexisting acini expanded by pleomorphic cells, no stromal invasion (a). Tumor cells show cytological pleomorphism, scattered basal cells (b). Mimics intraductal prostate cancer. Stromal invasion has irregular nests, desmoplastic stroma (c), indicates stage IV. p63 reactivity supports diagnosis; benign glands show
2275.original_caption: High-grade urothelial carcinoma involving the prostate. (a–d) In urothelial carcinoma of the prostate, preexisting acini/ducts are expanded by high-grade pleomorphic cells without evidence of stromal invasion (a). At higher magnification, cytological pleomorphism of tumor cells and scattered peripheral basal cells are visible (b). This presentation mimics intraductal spread of high-grade prostate cancer. Stromal invasion is characterized by small irregular nests or single cells with stromal retraction artifacts and desmoplastic stroma (c). Invasion of stroma should be recognized using strict criteria as it indicates stage IV disease. Strong reactivity for p63 in tumor cells supports the diagnosis of urothelial carcinoma; benign prostate glands demonstrate a peripheral layer of basal cells (d)

2276.caption: High-grade urothelial carcinoma involving prostate. Preexisting acini expanded by pleomorphic cells, no stromal invasion (a). Tumor cells show cytological pleomorphism, scattered basal cells (b). Stromal invasion has irregular nests, desmoplastic stroma (c). p63 reactivity supports diagnosis; benign glands show basal cell layer (d).

2272.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with carcinoid-like morphology: uniform cells forming acini/organoid nests (a). Nuclear features show prostatic adenocarcinoma (open chromatin, prominent nucleoli) vs carcinoid (granular chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli) (b). Negative NE markers, positive PSA confirm prostate adenocarcinoma, not true carcinoid (c).
2272.original_caption: (a–c) Carcinoid-like differentiation in acinar prostate adenocarcinoma. Prostate adenocarcinoma is occasionally composed of uniform cells forming acini and organoid nests that superficially resemble carcinoid tumor (a). Cells may occasionally express NE markers. But note here that nuclear features are more typical of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with open chromatin and nucleolar prominence, rather than the granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli of a carcinoid tumor (b). Lack of diffuse NE marker reactivity (not shown) and strong reactivity for PSA (c) suggest that this is not a true carcinoid tumor but an unusual carcinoid-like morphology of prostate adenocarcinoma (c)

2270.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with carcinoid-like morphology: uniform cells forming acini/organoid nests (a), NE marker expression possible. Nuclear features typical of prostate cancer (open chromatin, prominent nucleoli) vs carcinoid (granular chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli) (b). Negative diffuse NE markers, positive PSA (c) confirm carcinoid-like prostate adenocarcinoma, not true
2270.original_caption: (a–c) Carcinoid-like differentiation in acinar prostate adenocarcinoma. Prostate adenocarcinoma is occasionally composed of uniform cells forming acini and organoid nests that superficially resemble carcinoid tumor (a). Cells may occasionally express NE markers. But note here that nuclear features are more typical of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with open chromatin and nucleolar prominence, rather than the granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli of a carcinoid tumor (b). 2277.caption: Diagnosing Gleason 1/2 in needle biopsy (NBX) is problematic. Patterns 1/2 exist in TURP/multifocal low-grade tumors but NBX application differs. Poor reproducibility, grade correlation issues, and sampling limitations make Gleason 3 on NBX rare (strict criteria required). NBX often misses lesion borders, so most cases should be
2277.original_caption: Pitfalls of diagnosing Gleason patterns 1 and 2 in needle biopsy (NBX) samples. Although the definitions of patterns 1 and 2 are essentially the same as Gleasons original description, their application in contemporary biopsy practice is drastically different. Patterns 1 and 2 occasionally exist on prostate transurethral resection (TURP) and in multifocal low-grade tumors in radical prostatectomy specimens. Due to poor reproducibility, lack of good correlation with prostatectomy grade, sampling issues, and potentially misleading clinical implications, Gleason score of 3 on needle biopsy should rarely, if ever be made only when all strict criteria are met and adenosis is excluded. A major limitation of assigning a Gleason pattern 1 or 2 on a needle biopsy is that one may not see the border of the entire lesion as shown in this example. Therefore, most of such lesions in NBX should be assigned a score of 3 + 3 = 6. A score of 3 + 2 = 5 or 2 + 3 = 5 may be assigned with a comment that the Gleason score in radical prostatectomy is almost always higher in such a case

2289.caption: Lipofuscin pigment in benign prostate glands, wear and tear in aging cells. Rare in prostate cancer, presence mitigates against cancer diagnosis.
2289.original_caption: Lipofuscin pigment in benign prostate glands. It is considered wear and tear products in aging cells. Rarely seen in prostate cancer, its presence usually mitigates against a cancer diagnosis

2290.caption: Prostate glands with neuroendocrine cells & red cytoplasmic granules (arrow). Neuroendocrine cells are rare but most numerous in prostate among genitourinary organs.
2290.original_caption: Prostate glands with neuroendocrine cells and red cytoplasmic granules (arrow). Although rare, the neuroendocrine cells have the largest number in the prostate gland among genitourinary organs

2288.caption: Benign prostate glands with corpora amylacea, round laminated luminal structures. Rare in cancer, mitigates against malignancy.
2288.original_caption: Benign prostate glands with corpora amylacea, which are round, concentrically laminated structures within lumens. Rarely seen in prostate cancer, their presence usually mitigates against a cancer diagnosis

2284.caption: Dense eosinophilic crystalloids (rhomboid/needle shapes) in cancer gland lumens; more common in cancer, also in some benign lesions.
2284.original_caption: crystalloids. Dense eosinophilic crystalloid structures that assume various shapes such as rhomboid and needle are in the lumens of the cancer glands. They are more common in cancer, but can also be found in some benign lesions

2287.caption: Hyperplastic stromal nodule. Prostate stroma has muscle fibers, fibroblasts, nerves, vessels. Nodules seen in all zones, no BPH symptom correlation.
2287.original_caption: Hyperplastic stromal nodule. Prostate stroma comprises skeletal and smooth muscle fibers, fibroblasts, nerves, and vessels. Stromal nodules can be seen in biopsies taken from all three zones and do not correlate with clinical symptomatology of benign prostatic hyperplasia

2295.caption: Abnormal crowded glands, more packed than benign glands, circumscribed, no infiltrative pattern. Suspect cancer, but rule out adenosis/atypical adenomatous hyperplasia first.
2295.original_caption: Abnormal architectural pattern  crowded glands. Cancer glands are closely packed and more crowded than the adjacent benign glands, and are often circumscribed without infiltrative pattern. The presence of a focus of crowded glands should raise a suspicion for cancer. However, such growth pattern may also be seen in adenosis (atypical adenomatous hyperplasia), which should always be considered and ruled out before a cancer diagnosis is rendered

2293.caption: Benign prostate post-androgen deprivation: glandular atrophy. Glands remain atrophic but retain size/lobulated architecture. Prominent stroma with fibrosis and patchy lymphohistiocytic infiltration.
2293.original_caption: Benign prostate tissue after androgen deprivation: glandular atrophy. Benign glands become diffusely atrophic, although they still maintain their size and lobulated architecture. As a result, stroma is prominent. It also shows fibrosis and patchy lymphohistiocytic inflammatory infiltration

2282.caption: Mitosis (arrow, a) and apoptosis (arrows, b) in cancer glands. More common in cancer cells.
2282.original_caption: mitosis and apoptosis. A mitotic figure (arrow, a) and apoptotic bodies (arrows, b) are found in cancer glands. Mitosis and apoptosis are more common in cancer cells

2278.caption: Mucinous metaplasia involves lobule part, transition to benign atrophic glands. Glands lined by tall columnar cells with abundant intracytoplasmic mucin. No dimorphic duct/acini architecture vs Cowpers glands.
2278.original_caption: Mucinous metaplasia typically involves part of a lobule. Transition to benign atrophic glands in the background is seen. Note that glands are lined by tall columnar cells with abundant intracytoplasmic mucin. In contrast to Cowpers glands, no dimorphic duct/ acini architecture is seen

2285.caption: Prostate cancer with extraprostatic extension in needle biopsy. Cancer glands encircle nerve (perineural invasion) and invade adipose tissue. Fat in core indicates extraprostatic extension. Ganglion cells/muscle fibers in prostate don't imply extension.
2285.original_caption: Prostate cancer with extraprostatic extension in needle biopsy. Cancer glands encircle a nerve fiber (perineural invasion) and are present in the adipose tissue. Only in exceedingly rare cases is fat found in the prostate gland. Therefore, the presence of cancer glands in fat in a needle core can be interpreted safely as extraprostatic extension. However, ganglion cells and skeletal muscle fibers can frequently be found within the prostate gland; therefore, involvement of these structures in needle cores should not be equated with extraprostatic extension

2294.caption: Benign prostate post-androgen deprivation: basal cell hyperplasia. Glands show basal cell hyperplasia, urothelial/squamous metaplasia. Atrophic secretory cells. Stromal fibrosis, mixed inflammation. Adjacent cancer glands disintegrating into single cells/small clusters.
2294.original_caption: Benign prostate tissue after androgen deprivation: basal cell hyperplasia. Benign glands show prominent basal cell hyperplasia and may undergo urothelial and squamous metaplasia. Secretory cells are atrophic with reduced cell height. The stroma shows fibrosis and mixed inflammatory infiltrates. Also notice cancer glands (right) disintegrate into single cells or small clusters

2292.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: atrophic changes. Cancer glands (lower half) are small, crowded, infiltrate benign glands (upper half), indistinguishable at low mag (a). High mag (b) shows atrophic cancer cells with prominent nucleoli.
2292.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: atrophic changes. Cancer glands become atrophic (lower half). They intermingle with larger atrophic benign glands (upper half) and are indistinguishable from the latter at the low magnification (a). They are small and crowded, however, and exhibit infiltrative growth between the benign glands, a telltale sign of cancer. At high magnification, some cancer cells, although atrophic, still have prominent nucleoli (b)

2286.caption: Prostate cancer involving seminal vesicle/ejaculatory duct. Seminal vesicle ID by smooth muscle wall; ejaculatory duct has loose connective tissue with thin vessels. Distinction may be impossible in limited biopsies; diagnose as cancer involving seminal vesicle/ejaculatory duct tissue.
2286.original_caption: Prostate cancer involving seminal vesicle/ejaculatory ductlike structure. Seminal vesicle can be distinguished in needle biopsy if its smooth muscle wall is present. In contrast, the ejaculatory duct has a rim of loose connective tissue rich in thin vessels. However, the distinction of the two is not always possible in biopsy with limited material. If so, the biopsy should be diagnosed as cancer involving seminal vesicle ejaculatory duct tissue

2291.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: atrophic cancer glands (lower half) mixed with benign atrophic glands (upper half), indistinct at low mag (a). Small, crowded, infiltrative growth between benign glands. High mag (b): some atrophic cancer cells retain prominent nucleoli.
2291.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: atrophic changes. Cancer glands become atrophic (lower half). They intermingle with larger atrophic benign glands (upper half) and are indistinguishable from the latter at the low magnification (a). They are small and crowded, however, and exhibit infiltrative growth between the benign glands, a telltale sign of cancer. At high magnification, some cancer cells, although atrophic, still have prominent nucleoli (b)

2296.caption: Prostate cancer shows infiltrative growth, small rigid glands between benign glands. Key features: infiltrative borders, cribriform glands, solid nests. Crowded growth less specific. Indicates invasion.
2296.original_caption: abnormal architectural pattern  infiltrative growth. This is the most characteristic growth pattern for prostate cancer, with cancer glands situated between and on both sides of the larger and paler benign glands. This growth pattern is indicative of invasion. The cancer glands are typically small with rigid round lumens as opposed to large benign glands with undulating luminal borders. Prostate cancer invariably exhibits some form of abnormal architectural features when compared to the adjacent benign glands. Some of the architectural features, such as infiltrative growth, large cribriform glands with infiltrative border and solid nests, are almost specific for cancer, whereas other features, such as crowded growth, are less strongly associated with cancer and may also be found in noncancer lesions

2281.caption: Mitosis (arrow, a) and apoptosis (arrows, b) in cancer glands. More common in cancer cells.
2281.original_caption: mitosis and apoptosis. A mitotic figure (arrow, a) and apoptotic bodies (arrows, b) are found in cancer glands. Mitosis and apoptosis are more common in cancer cells

2297.caption: Adenoid cystic BCC: solid/cribriform architecture mimics basal cell hyperplasia. Distinction challenging in needle biopsies due to bland cells. BCC features: dense haphazard cells, infiltrative growth, desmoplastic stroma, smooth muscle destruction, perineural invasion.
2297.original_caption: Adenoid cystic BCC. (a, b) Adenoid cystic BCC with a solid and cribriform architecture, mimicking basal cell hyperplasia (a). The distinction from basal cell hyperplasia is especially difficult in needle biopsy samples, as cells can be relatively bland and infiltrative features may not be easily appreciated. In contrast to basal cell hyperplasia, tumor cells in BCC are dense, haphazardly arranged with infiltrative features characterized by edematous desmoplastic stroma, destruction of smooth muscle, and perineural invasion (b).

2279.caption: Mesonephric remnant hyperplasia. Atrophic glands with bland epithelium, lobulated/infiltrative growth. Intraluminal eosinophilic secretions (arrows), papillary infoldings/tufts help distinguish from prostate adenocarcinoma.
2279.original_caption: Mesonephric remnant hyperplasia. Glands appear atrophic with attenuated bland epithelium and grow in a lobulated or sometimes infiltrative pattern. Intraluminal dense eosinophilic secretions (arrows) and papillary infoldings and tufts are common useful features to distinguish from adenocarcinoma of the prostate

2283.caption: Blue mucin in cancer glands, with blue-tinged wisps and pink secretion in lumens. More common in cancer but seen in benign lesions. H&E staining-dependent; overstaining reduces diagnostic utility, especially in blue-stained rectal mucosa in prostate biopsies.
2283.original_caption: blue mucin. Cancer glands have blue-tinged wisps of mucin, often together with dense pink secretion, within their lumens. They are more common in cancer, but can also be found in some benign lesions. Blue mucin depends on the H&E staining of the tissue section. If the tissue section is overstained, with rectal mucosa that is often present in prostate biopsies stained intensely blue, one should be cautious about the diagnostic utility of blue mucin

2280.caption: Cancer with HGPIN. Cancer glands (arrowheads) mix with HGPIN glands (arrows). HGPIN presence prompts cancer search in biopsy.
2280.original_caption: cancer associated with HGPIN. Cancer glands (arrowheads) often intermingle with HGPIN glands (arrows). The presence of HGPIN should alert pathologists to look for cancer in the biopsy

2298.caption: Adenoid cystic BCC: solid/cribriform architecture mimics basal cell hyperplasia. Biopsy distinction challenging due to bland cells. BCC features: dense haphazard cells, infiltrative growth, desmoplastic stroma, smooth muscle destruction, perineural invasion.
2298.original_caption: Adenoid cystic BCC. (a, b) Adenoid cystic BCC with a solid and cribriform architecture, mimicking basal cell hyperplasia (a). The distinction from basal cell hyperplasia is especially difficult in needle biopsy samples, as cells can be relatively bland and infiltrative features may not be easily appreciated. In contrast to basal cell hyperplasia, tumor cells in BCC are dense, haphazardly arranged with infiltrative features characterized by edematous desmoplastic stroma, destruction of smooth muscle, and perineural invasion (b).

2299.caption: Prostate cancer w/ radiation effect: single/cords of cells (a) w/ foamy cytoplasm & pyknotic nuclei (b). Benign glands w/ radiation atypia in (a). No Gleason grade.
2299.original_caption: Prostate cancer with radiation effect. Cancer demonstrates single or cords of cells (a) with voluminous foamy cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei (b). Notice the larger benign glands with radiation atypia in (a). Cancer with radiation effect should not be assigned a Gleason grade

2300.caption: Prostate cancer w/ radiation effect: single/cord cells (a) w/ foamy cytoplasm & pyknotic nuclei (b). Benign glands w/ radiation atypia in (a). No Gleason grading.
2300.original_caption: Prostate cancer with radiation effect. Cancer demonstrates single or cords of cells (a) with voluminous foamy cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei (b). Notice the larger benign glands with radiation atypia in (a). Cancer with radiation effect should not be assigned a Gleason grade

2301.caption: Four HGPIN patterns: tufting (most common), micropapillary (slender papillae, no fibrovascular core), flat, cribriform (least common). Cribriform glands with atypia often indicate intraductal carcinoma.
2301.original_caption: Four major architectural patterns of HGPIN. These patterns often coexist in the same biopsy. Tufting pattern is the most common (a). Micropapillary HGPIN has long and slender papillae without fibrovascular core (b). Flat HGPIN (c). Cribriform HGPIN is least common (d). The majority of cribriform glands with atypical cells represent intraductal carcinoma.

2302.caption: HGPIN patterns: tufting (most common), micropapillary (slender papillae, no fibrovascular core), flat, cribriform (least common). Cribriform glands with atypia often indicate intraductal carcinoma.
2302.original_caption: Four major architectural patterns of HGPIN. These patterns often coexist in the same biopsy. Tufting pattern is the most common (a). Micropapillary HGPIN has long and slender papillae without fibrovascular core (b). Flat HGPIN (c). Cribriform HGPIN is least common (d). The majority of cribriform glands with atypical cells represent intraductal carcinoma.

2303.caption: HGPIN四大结构模式：簇状（最常见）、微乳头（细长乳头无纤维血管轴心）、平坦、筛状（最少见）。多数筛状腺体伴非典型细胞为导管内癌。
2303.original_caption: Four major architectural patterns of HGPIN. These patterns often coexist in the same biopsy. Tufting pattern is the most common (a). Micropapillary HGPIN has long and slender papillae without fibrovascular core (b). Flat HGPIN (c). Cribriform HGPIN is least common (d). The majority of cribriform glands with atypical cells represent intraductal carcinoma.

2304.caption: HGPIN四大结构模式：簇状（最常见）、微乳头（细长乳头无纤维血管轴心）、平坦、筛状（最少见）。多数筛状腺体伴非典型细胞为导管内癌。
2304.original_caption: Four major architectural patterns of HGPIN. These patterns often coexist in the same biopsy. Tufting pattern is the most common (a). Micropapillary HGPIN has long and slender papillae without fibrovascular core (b). Flat HGPIN (c). Cribriform HGPIN is least common (d). The majority of cribriform glands with atypical cells represent intraductal carcinoma.

2305.caption: Unusual HGPIN patterns: signet-ring cell PIN (clear vacuoles), inverted PIN (nuclei polarized luminal), foamy gland PIN (abundant foamy cytoplasm), neuroendocrine PIN.
2305.original_caption: Unusual histological patterns of HGPIN. Histological patterns identified in prostate cancer have also been described in HGPIN, including signet-ring cell PIN with clear vacuoles inside cells (a), inverted PIN with nuclei polarized away from the basal to the luminal surface of the gland (b), foamy gland PIN with abundant foamy cytoplasm (c), and neuroendocrine PIN (d)

2306.caption: Unusual HGPIN patterns: signet-ring cell PIN (clear vacuoles), inverted PIN (nuclei polarized luminal), foamy gland PIN (abundant foamy cytoplasm), neuroendocrine PIN.
2306.original_caption: Unusual histological patterns of HGPIN. Histological patterns identified in prostate cancer have also been described in HGPIN, including signet-ring cell PIN with clear vacuoles inside cells (a), inverted PIN with nuclei polarized away from the basal to the luminal surface of the gland (b), foamy gland PIN with abundant foamy cytoplasm (c), and neuroendocrine PIN (d)

2307.caption: Unusual HGPIN patterns: signet-ring cell PIN (clear vacuoles), inverted PIN (nuclei polarized luminal), foamy gland PIN (abundant foamy cytoplasm), neuroendocrine PIN.
2307.original_caption: Unusual histological patterns of HGPIN. Histological patterns identified in prostate cancer have also been described in HGPIN, including signet-ring cell PIN with clear vacuoles inside cells (a), inverted PIN with nuclei polarized away from the basal to the luminal surface of the gland (b), foamy gland PIN with abundant foamy cytoplasm (c), and neuroendocrine PIN (d)

2308.original_caption: Unusual histological patterns of HGPIN. Histological patterns identified in prostate cancer have also been described in HGPIN, including signet-ring cell PIN with clear vacuoles inside cells (a), inverted PIN with nuclei polarized away from the basal to the luminal surface of the gland (b), foamy gland PIN with abundant foamy cytoplasm (c), and neuroendocrine PIN (d)

2310.caption: Lymphovascular invasion. Rare in needle biopsy; report if definitively identified.
2310.original_caption: Lymphovascular invasion. This finding is exceedingly rare in needle biopsy specimens and should be reported if definitively identified

2309.caption: Perineural invasion in needle biopsy (arrows) correlates with extraprostatic extension. May guide nerve-sparing surgery. Predicts adverse radiation outcomes (category 3 prognostic factor, insufficient data). Report if found.
2309.original_caption: Perineural invasion. Perineural invasion identified in needle biopsy (arrows) correlates with extraprostatic extension in radical prostatectomy. This information may be used by surgeons to plan nerve-sparing surgery. Some radiation oncology studies suggest that it also independently predicts adverse outcomes after radiation therapy. However, it is considered a category 3 prognostic factor (insufficient data to warrant prognostic utility). It can be reported if found in needle biopsies

2311.caption: Biopsy targeting seminal vesicle for prostate cancer staging. Positive biopsy indicates extraprostatic invasion, predicts pelvic lymph node metastases. Specimen shows seminal vesicle tissue (arrows) and cancer (arrowheads). Report presence of seminal vesicle tissue and cancer involvement.
2311.original_caption: A biopsy targeting the seminal vesicle. Urologists may perform a biopsy of the seminal vesicle to better stage prostate cancer before prostatectomy. A positive seminal vesicle biopsy confirms the presence of extraprostatic invasion and is the most significant predictor of pelvic lymph node metastases in men with clinically localized cancer. This biopsy specimen contains both seminal vesicle tissue (arrows) and cancer (arrowheads). Although present in this biopsy, the cancer glands do not involve the seminal vesicle. For such biopsies, the report should mention whether the seminal vesicle tissue is present and whether cancer involves the seminal vesicle tissue

2312.caption: IDC-P overlaps cribriform HGPIN, uniform nuclei, lacks IDCP cytology. Adjacent invasive acinar cancer present.
2312.original_caption: IDC-P overlaps cribriform HGPIN at the low-grade end of the morphological spectrum. This cribriform lesion has relatively uniform nuclei and lacks the characteristic cytological features of IDCP. In this example, an adjacent invasive acinar cancer is present

2314.caption: IDC-P in prostate biopsy: large irregular branching cribriform glands, dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal comedonecrosis; basal cell markers highlight peripheral layer (a-c). Solid architecture, pleomorphic nuclei (6× adjacent), hematoxylin-eosin stain (d). Dense cribriform with punched-out lumina, solid areas; branching glands, necrosis
2314.original_caption: Morphological features of IDC-P. Low-power (a and b) and high-power (c) view of an IDC-P in prostate biopsy showing several large, irregular, branching cribriform glands with dense cribriform architecture and focal intraluminal comedonecrosis; basal cell markers highlight the peripheral layer of basal cells (b). (d) An IDC-P showing solid architecture and pleomorphic nuclei 6× of adjacent nuclei; basal cells can be appreciated on hematoxylin–eosin stain image but may require immunohistochemistry confirmation. (e) An IDC-P with dense cribriform architecture showing punched-out lumina spaces and solid architecture; presence of branching glandular contour, solid or dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal necrosis, and pleomorphic nuclei are characteristic features of IDC-P

2313.caption: IDC-P in prostate biopsy: large irregular branching cribriform glands, dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal comedonecrosis. Basal cell markers highlight peripheral layer (b). Solid architecture, pleomorphic nuclei 6× adjacent nuclei (d). Dense cribriform with punched-out lumina, solid areas; branching glands, necrosis, pleomorphism characteristic of ID

(d) An IDC-P showing solid architecture and pleomorphic nuclei 6× of adjacent nuclei; basal cells can be appreciated on hematoxylin–eosin stain image but may require immunohistochemistry confirmation. (d) An IDC-P showing solid architecture and pleomorphic nuclei 6× of adjacent nuclei; basal cells can be appreciated on hematoxylin–eosin stain image but may require immunohistochemistry confirmation. (e) An IDC-P with dense cribriform architecture showing punched-out lumina spaces and solid architecture; presence of branching glandular contour, solid or dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal necrosis, and pleomorphic nuclei are characteristic features of IDC-P

2325.caption: Perineural invasion: prostate cancer feature, cancer glands encircling nerve fiber. Distinguish from benign gland abutment.
2325.original_caption: Perineural invasion: histological feature specific for prostate cancer. It is defined as tight circumferential or near circumferential encircling of a nerve fiber by cancer glands. It should be distinguished from perineural abutment by benign glands (see 1.18)

2322.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: bland cytology. Cancer cells show clear cytoplasm, small dense nuclei, no prominent nucleoli.
2322.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: bland cytology. Cancer cells have abundant clear cytoplasm and small, dense nuclei without prominent nucleoli

2323.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: glandular architecture loss. Common finding. Cancer cells form single cells, single-file, irregular nests (small/large).
2323.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: loss of glandular architecture. This is the most common finding after androgen deprivation. Cancer cells form single cells, single-file, small and large irregular nests

2324.caption: Mucinous fibroplasia: prostate cancer feature. Acellular/hypocellular hyalinized stroma in/around cancer glands (arrows), from extravasated mucin hyalinization.
2324.original_caption: Mucinous fibroplasia: histological feature specific for prostate cancer. It is acellular or hypocellular hyalinized stroma within or outside cancer glands (arrows), and results from hyalinization of extravasated mucin

2321.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: histiocyte-like. Cancer cells (single/clusters) show xanthomatous cytoplasm, pyknotic nuclei, resembling foamy histiocytes.
2321.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: histiocytelike. Single or small cluster of cancer cells have abundant xanthomatous cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei, resembling foamy histiocytes

2316.caption: IDC-P in prostate biopsy: large irregular branching cribriform glands, dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal comedonecrosis. Basal cell markers highlight peripheral layer (b). Solid architecture, pleomorphic nuclei (6× adjacent), hematoxylin-eosin stain (d). Dense cribriform with punched-out lumina, solid areas; branching glands, necrosis
2316.original_caption: Morphological features of IDC-P. Low-power (a and b) and high-power (c) view of an IDC-P in prostate biopsy showing several large, irregular, branching cribriform glands with dense cribriform architecture and focal intraluminal comedonecrosis; basal cell markers highlight the peripheral layer of basal cells (b). (d) An IDC-P showing solid architecture and pleomorphic nuclei 6× of adjacent nuclei; basal cells can be appreciated on hematoxylin–eosin stain image but may require immunohistochemistry confirmation. (e) An IDC-P with dense cribriform architecture showing punched-out lumina spaces and solid architecture; presence of branching glandular contour, solid or dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal necrosis, and pleomorphic nuclei are characteristic features of IDC-P

2319.caption: High-grade urothelial carcinoma intraductal spread mimics IDC-P. (a) Uniform high-grade cells, solid architecture. (b) p63+, PSA/PSAP-, supports urothelial carcinoma diagnosis.
2319.original_caption: Intraductal spread of high-grade urothelial carcinoma mimicking IDC-P. (a) Note the relatively uniform high-grade cells and solid architecture. (b) Luminal tumor cells demonstrate p63 nuclear reactivity, whereas PSA and PSAP are negative (not shown), supporting the diagnosis of intraductal spread of urothelial carcinoma

2320.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: mucinous degeneration. Cancer glands disintegrate, forming mucin lakes with blue mucin wisps and occasional cancer cells. May show clear acellular spaces.
2320.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: mucinous degeneration. Cancer glands disintegrate and form mucin lake in which wisps of blue mucin and occasional cancer cells are seen. Sometimes, clear acellular space is seen

2327.caption: Atypical cells in single/cord patterns, infiltrating stroma, forming short cords.
2327.original_caption: abnormal architectural pattern single or cords of atypical cells. Single cancer cells infiltrate in the stroma. They also form short cords

2328.caption: Abnormal solid nests of cancer cells, no discernible lumens.
2328.original_caption: abnormal architectural pattern solid nests. Cancer cells form solid nests without discernible lumens

2318.caption: High-grade urothelial carcinoma intraductal spread, mimics IDC-P. (a) Uniform high-grade cells, solid architecture. (b) p63+, PSA/PSAP-, supports urothelial carcinoma diagnosis.
2318.original_caption: Intraductal spread of high-grade urothelial carcinoma mimicking IDC-P. (a) Note the relatively uniform high-grade cells and solid architecture. (b) Luminal tumor cells demonstrate p63 nuclear reactivity, whereas PSA and PSAP are negative (not shown), supporting the diagnosis of intraductal spread of urothelial carcinoma

2329.caption: Crush artifact obscures biopsy morphology (a). Recut and IHC may help. Crushed glands negative for HMWCK (b), positive for AMACR (c). Cancer diagnosed.
2329.original_caption: Crush artifact obscures the morphology and impedes an adequate evaluation of the biopsy (a). Recut and immunohistochemistry may be helpful. In this example, the small crushed glands were negative for basal cell marker, high-molecular-weight cytokeratin (HMWCK) (b) and positive for AMACR (c). A diagnosis of cancer was rendered.

2330.caption: Crush artifact obscures biopsy morphology (a). Recut/IHC may help. Crushed glands: HMWCK(-), AMACR(+) (b,c). Cancer diagnosed.
2330.original_caption: Crush artifact obscures the morphology and impedes an adequate evaluation of the biopsy (a). Recut and immunohistochemistry may be helpful. In this example, the small crushed glands were negative for basal cell marker, high-molecular-weight cytokeratin (HMWCK) (b) and positive for AMACR (c). A diagnosis of cancer was rendered.

2326.caption: Glomerulation: prostate cancer feature. Intraluminal cancer cell proliferation forms balls/tufts in glands, resembling renal glomeruli.
2326.original_caption: Glomerulation: histological feature specific for prostate cancer. It results from the intraluminal proliferation of cancer cells that forms balls or tufts within cancer glands, superficially resembling renal glomeruli

2317.caption: IDC-P in prostate biopsy: large irregular branching cribriform glands, dense cribriform architecture, intraluminal comedonecrosis; basal cell markers highlight peripheral layer (b). 2332.caption: Prostate biopsy: 2 atypical glands with rigid lumens (a), enlarged nuclei (b), p63-, AMACR+. Highly suspicious for cancer but insufficient glands for definitive diagnosis.
2332.original_caption: Prostate biopsy with limited number of atypical glands. The biopsy contains two small glands with rigid lumens (a) and enlarged nuclei (b). They are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive AMACR (c). Although highly suspicious for cancer, a definitive cancer diagnosis cannot be established due to the limited number of atypical glands

2333.caption: Prostate biopsy: 2 atypical glands with rigid lumens (a), enlarged nuclei (b), p63-, AMACR+. Highly suspicious for cancer but limited glands preclude definitive diagnosis.

2338.caption: Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancer pitfalls: (a) Tangential section mimics poorly formed pattern 4. (c,d) Large glands show complex "V"/"Y" branching.
2338.original_caption: Common pitfalls of interpretation of Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancers. (a) Tangentially sectioned cancer glands at the periphery of a tumor nodule mimic poorly formed pattern 4 glands. (c, d) Large pattern 3 cancer glands may show complex branching and appear as “V” or “Y” shaped

2340.caption: Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancer pitfalls: (a) Tangentially sectioned glands mimic pattern 4. (c,d) Large pattern 3 glands show complex "V"/"Y" branching.
2340.original_caption: Common pitfalls of interpretation of Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancers. (a) Tangentially sectioned cancer glands at the periphery of a tumor nodule mimic poorly formed pattern 4 glands. (c, d) Large pattern 3 cancer glands may show complex branching and appear as “V” or “Y” shaped

2336.caption: Gleason pattern 5: single rows/cords (a), solid nests (b), solid/cribriform/papillary with comedonecrosis (c). Recognizable at low power. Tangential sectioning may show single cells. Intraluminal secretions mimic comedonecrosis; only dirty necrosis with karyorrhectic debris is true comedonecrosis (arrow).
2336.original_caption: Morphologic spectrum of Gleason pattern 5. Pattern 5 is the most consistently reproduced pattern, including tumor with single rows and cords of cells (a), solid nests (b), and solid/cribriform/papillary tumor with comedonecrosis (c). In general, this pattern should be recognizable at low power to be considered significant (see 5.12). Occasional random or peripherally distributed single cells or cord-like tumor cells may represent tangential sectioning. Sometimes abundant intraluminal amorphous secretions may mimic comedonecrosis. Only dirty necrosis with karyorrhectic debris represents comedonecrosis (arrow)

2335.caption: Gleason pattern 5 includes single rows/cords (a), solid nests (b), and solid/cribriform/papillary tumor with comedonecrosis (c). Recognizable at low power. 2341.caption: Pattern 3 cancer glands in Gleason system: (a) Variably sized small glands infiltrating benign glands. (b) Small cancer focus graded 3+3=6. (c) Small cribriform glands with round contours, differentiate from cribriform PIN.
2341.original_caption: Pattern 3 cancer glands in contemporary Gleason grading system. (a) Variably sized individual glands typically smaller than those seen in Gleason pattern 1 or 2, infiltrating between benign glands, represent the classic form of Gleason pattern 3. (b) A very small focus of cancer, as seen in this example, should still be graded as 3 + 3 = 6. (c) A cribriform lesion that may be graded as Gleason pattern 3. Such pattern 3 cribriform glands are small and have round and regular contour with regular lumina. They should be differentiated from cribriform PIN.

2334.caption: Prostate biopsy: 2 atypical glands with rigid lumens (a), enlarged nuclei (b), p63-, AMACR+. Highly suspicious for cancer but inconclusive due to limited atypical glands.
2334.original_caption: Prostate biopsy with limited number of atypical glands. The biopsy contains two small glands with rigid lumens (a) and enlarged nuclei (b). They are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive AMACR (c). Although highly suspicious for cancer, a definitive cancer diagnosis cannot be established due to the limited number of atypical glands

2343.caption: Pattern 3 cancer glands in Gleason system: (a) Variably sized small glands infiltrating benign glands. (b) Small cancer focus graded 3+3=6. (c) Small cribriform glands with round contours, differentiate from cribriform PIN.

2347.caption: Gleason 4 patterns: (a) Ragged/fused glands. (b) Hypernephroid mimics foamy gland; clear vacuolated vs bubbly xanthomatous cytoplasm. (c-e) Cribriform spectrum: small irregular (c); large round uniform (d); ductal differentiation with tall columnar cells, slit-like/papillary (e). (
2347.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of pattern Gleason 4 cancer (a) Ragged and fused cancer glands representing Gleason pattern 4. (b) Hypernephroid pattern may mimic foamy gland differentiation. Hypernephroid morphology usually has clear vacuolated cytoplasm rather than bubbly xanthomatous cytoplasm seen in the latter. (c–e) Gleason pattern 4 cribriform carcinoma spectrum includes small but irregular cribriforming glands (c); round and regular uniform cribriform cancers much larger than normal prostate glands (d); and adenocarcinoma with ductal differentiation characterized by confluent cribriform glands lined by tall columnar cells and demonstrating slit-like pattern and papillary differentiation (e). (f) A cluster of poorly formed or ill-defined glands where tangential sectioning is ruled out warrants the diagnosis of Gleason pattern 4. Although glands are discrete and not fused, they are poorly formed with barely recognizable lumina.

2346.caption: Gleason 4 patterns: (a) Ragged/fused glands; (b) Hypernephroid mimics foamy gland, clear vacuolated cytoplasm; (c-e) Cribriform spectrum: small irregular (c), large round (d), ductal differentiation with tall columnar cells (e); (f) Poorly formed glands, barely recognizable lumina.
2346.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of pattern Gleason 4 cancer (a) Ragged and fused cancer glands representing Gleason pattern 4. (b) Hypernephroid pattern may mimic foamy gland differentiation. Hypernephroid morphology usually has clear vacuolated cytoplasm rather than bubbly xanthomatous cytoplasm seen in the latter. (c–e) Gleason pattern 4 cribriform carcinoma spectrum includes small but irregular cribriforming glands (c); round and regular uniform cribriform cancers much larger than normal prostate glands (d); and adenocarcinoma with ductal differentiation characterized by confluent cribriform glands lined by tall columnar cells and demonstrating slit-like pattern and papillary differentiation (e). (f) A cluster of poorly formed or ill-defined glands where tangential sectioning is ruled out warrants the diagnosis of Gleason pattern 4. Although glands are discrete and not fused, they are poorly formed with barely recognizable lumina.

2339.caption: Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancer pitfalls: (a) Tangential section mimics poorly formed pattern 4. (c,d) Large pattern 3 shows complex "V"/"Y" branching.

2350.caption: Thick section hinders biopsy eval. Small crowded glands show infiltrative growth (a). Cytology obscured by thick sections (b). Recut & IHC may aid. Diagnosis: ATYP.
2350.original_caption: Thick section impedes evaluation of the biopsy. This biopsy contains many small crowded glands that exhibit infiltrative growth (a). Evaluation of the cytological features of these glands is hampered by the thick tissue sections (b). Recut and immunohistochemistry may be helpful. The diagnosis is ATYP

2352.caption: Atypical glands at biopsy core edge (arrow). Negative for p63, positive for AMACR.
2352.original_caption: Atypical glands at the edge of the biopsy core (arrow, a). These atypical glands are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive for AMACR (b).

2353.caption: Atypical glands at biopsy core edge (arrow, a). Negative for p63, positive for AMACR (b).

2354.caption: Prostate biopsy with minute cancer focus (a), K903-negative (b). Avoid misgrading small foci as well-differentiated; assign Gleason 3+3=6 typically.
2354.original_caption: Prostate biopsy containing a minute focus of cancer (a) that is negative for basal cell marker K903 (b). A common mistake is equating a minute focus of cancer to well-differentiated cancer and grading it as Gleason score 3 or 4. A small focus of cancer should be assigned a Gleason score of 3 + 3 = 6 in most cases

2372.caption: Central zone histology mimicking HGPIN. (a–c) Central zone histology is typically a mimicker of HGPIN; however, prominent cribriform architecture in some cases may mimic cancer. This histology is typically seen in biopsies from the base of the prostate. In the central zone, glands are complex with frequent papillation and undulating architecture with pseudostratified lining epithelium (a). At low magnification, glands demonstrate distinct cytoplasmic eosinophilia (a). Roman bridges and cribriform architecture are common (b). In contrast to HGPIN, nuclei stream parallel to bridges in comparison to perpendicular orientation in HGPIN (b). The cytological atypia is seen in basal cells (arrow), a feature helpful to differentiate from HGPIN or cancer (c).

2360.caption: Central zone prostate glands: large complex acini with cribriform/intraluminal ridges, dense stroma. Secretory cells: eosinophilic cytoplasm, stratified nuclei, prominent basal layer. May mimic HGPIN but lacks nuclear atypia (enlargement/prominent nucleoli).
2360.original_caption: Central zone prostate glands are large complex acini with cribriform and intraluminal ridges with dense stroma (a). The secretory cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm, stratified nuclei, and prominent basal cell layer (b). Central zone glands may be mistaken for HGPIN. Unlike HGPIN, central zone glands lack significant nuclear atypia, including nuclear enlargement and prominent nucleoli

2364.caption: Nephrogenic adenoma spectrum: (a-i) Classic case shows papillary/tubular components; papillary part has edematous stroma, cuboidal epithelium. Tubules mimic renal tubules with eosinophilic basement membrane (arrow, a). Prostatic urethra biopsy shows tubular pattern resembling prostate adenocarcinoma (b), with hobnail epithelium, blue mucin, inflammation (c
2364.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of nephrogenic adenoma. (a–i) A classical nephrogenic adenoma with both papillary and underlying tubular components. Polypoid or papillary component has edematous stroma without well-defined fibrovascular cores and lining epithelium is cuboidal and lacks stratification. Underlying tubules are variably sized and mimic renal tubules. Note thickened eosinophilic basement membrane surrounding tubules (arrow), one of the characteristic features of nephrogenic adenoma (a). Prostatic urethra biopsy exhibits exclusively a tubular component, mimicking a prostate adenocarcinoma (b). In prostatic urethra, this type of presentation is common. The tubules are lined by cuboidal hobnail epithelium. Degenerative cytological atypia and features such as intraluminal blue mucin can be encountered. Background inflammation and calcifications are common (c and d). Nephrogenic adenoma in transurethral resection specimen, presenting predominantly with nested (e) and signet ring cell-like (f) pattern. These patterns may be mistaken for nested urothelial carcinoma and poorly differentiated prostate adenocarcinoma. Hyalinized basement membrane surrounding glands (f) and superficial nature of the lesion (e) are useful features to suggest the diagnosis. Rarely, nephrogenic adenoma may present with prominent fibrous and myxoid component (g). Cytoplasmic AMACR expression is present in the vast majority of nephrogenic adenoma, a significant pitfall if this marker is utilized to distinguish nephrogenic adenoma from prostate adenocarcinoma (h). Nuclear transcription factors PAX-2 or PAX-8 are expressed in nephrogenic adenoma and are helpful markers to support the diagnosis in difficult cases (i)

2374.caption: Prostate biopsy with cancer stained by AMACR (red) and basal cell markers (HMWCK/p63, brown). Cancer glands: AMACR+, basal markers-; benign glands: AMACR-, basal markers+. Antibody cocktails (AMACR+HMWCK/p63) enable simultaneous evaluation on same section, defining atypical glands. Useful for minute cancer foci in
2374.original_caption: Prostate biopsy containing cancer stained with a cocktail of AMACR and basal cell markers (HMWCK and p63). The cancer glands are positive for AMACR (red signal) and negative for basal cell markers (brown signal), whereas benign glands are negative for AMACR but positive for basal cell markers. Several different preparations with antibodies against basal cell markers (HMWCK, p63, or both) and AMACR are commercially available. Immunostains with such antibody cocktails allow simultaneous evaluation of basal cell markers and AMACR on the same tissue section and therefore provide an excellent definition of the nature of atypical glands. Antibody cocktails are extremely useful for prostate biopsies with minute focus of cancer that may be present on only one or two sections

2375.caption: Prostatic ductal adenocarcinoma: large glands vs benign (a), stratified columnar lining resembling endometrial glands (b), possible necrosis. Basal cell markers may persist.
2375.original_caption: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate. It comprises glands much larger than benign glands (a). The cancer glands are lined with stratified columnar cells with or without significant nuclear atypia, superficially resembling endometrial glands (b). Necrosis can be present. Stains for basal cell markers can be confusing, as ductal carcinoma may retain basal cells in some cases

2376.caption: Prostatic ductal adenocarcinoma: large glands (a), stratified columnar cells resembling endometrial glands (b), possible necrosis. Basal cell markers may persist.
2376.original_caption: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate. It comprises glands much larger than benign glands (a). The cancer glands are lined with stratified columnar cells with or without significant nuclear atypia, superficially resembling endometrial glands (b). Necrosis can be present. Stains for basal cell markers can be confusing, as ductal carcinoma may retain basal cells in some cases

2377.caption: Prostate cancer p63+. Cancer glands infiltrate benign glands (a), with layered cancer cells, poor lumens, prominent nucleoli (b). HMWCK(34bE12)- (c), p63+ in all cells (d). Rare basal cell differentiation.
2377.original_caption: Prostate cancer positive for p63. The cancer glands infiltrate between benign prostate glands (a). They are lined with several layers of cancer cells and some have poorly formed lumens. The nucleoli are prominent (b). All the cancer glands are negative for HMWCK (34bE12, (c), but uniformly positive for p63 (d). Rather than being in basal cell distribution, the staining is found in all the cancer cells. Prostate cancer positive for p63 is exceedingly rare and probably represents a form of prostate cancer with basal cell differentiation

2378.caption: Prostate cancer p63+. Cancer glands infiltrate benign glands, with layered cells, poorly formed lumens, prominent nucleoli. HMWCK- (34bE12), p63+ in all cells (not basal). Rare basal cell differentiation.
2378.original_caption: Prostate cancer positive for p63. The cancer glands infiltrate between benign prostate glands (a). They are lined with several layers of cancer cells and some have poorly formed lumens. The nucleoli are prominent (b). All the cancer glands are negative for HMWCK (34bE12, (c), but uniformly positive for p63 (d). Rather than being in basal cell distribution, the staining is found in all the cancer cells. Prostate cancer positive for p63 is exceedingly rare and probably represents a form of prostate cancer with basal cell differentiation

2390.caption: Poorly differentiated foamy gland carcinoma mimicking xanthomatous inflammation in biopsy. Cytological atypia and glandular differentiation (arrow) confirm foamy gland carcinoma.
2390.original_caption: (c, d) A poorly differentiated foamy gland carcinoma simulating xanthomatous inflammation in needle biopsy. Presence of cytological atypia and/or any glandular differentiation (arrow) supports the diagnosis of foamy gland carcinoma (d).

2386.caption: Prostate rhabdomyosarcoma: high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with atypical mitoses, cellular pleomorphism, rhabdomyoblasts (eosinophilic cytoplasm). Myogenin and desmin positive, confirming diagnosis.
2386.original_caption: Rhabdomyosarcoma involving the prostate gland. (a) The prostate gland is replaced by a high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with numerous atypical mitoses and cellular pleomorphism (a). Another area demonstrated characteristic rhabdomyoblasts (arrow) with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (b). Both myogenin (c) and desmin were strongly positive, supporting the diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma

2385.caption: Prostate rhabdomyosarcoma: high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with atypical mitoses, cellular pleomorphism, rhabdomyoblasts (eosinophilic cytoplasm). Myogenin and desmin positive confirm diagnosis.
2385.original_caption: Rhabdomyosarcoma involving the prostate gland. (a) The prostate gland is replaced by a high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with numerous atypical mitoses and cellular pleomorphism (a). Another area demonstrated characteristic rhabdomyoblasts (arrow) with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (b). Both myogenin (c) and desmin were strongly positive, supporting the diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma

2384.caption: Prostate rhabdomyosarcoma: high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with atypical mitoses, cellular pleomorphism, rhabdomyoblasts (eosinophilic cytoplasm). Myogenin and desmin positive, confirming diagnosis.
2384.original_caption: Rhabdomyosarcoma involving the prostate gland. (a) The prostate gland is replaced by a high-grade undifferentiated sarcoma with numerous atypical mitoses and cellular pleomorphism (a). Another area demonstrated characteristic rhabdomyoblasts (arrow) with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm (b). Both myogenin (c) and desmin were strongly positive, supporting the diagnosis of rhabdomyosarcoma

2387.caption: Foamy gland carcinoma: xanthomatous cytoplasm, low N:C ratio, mimics benign. Intraluminal pink acellular secretions common. Small dense nuclei, variable malignant features. Occasional prominent nucleoli, nuclear enlargement. Conventional acinar differentiation present.
2387.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of foamy gland carcinoma. (a, b) At low power, a foamy gland carcinoma is characterized by abundant xanthomatous cytoplasm with low N:C ratio, simulating a benign process. Intraluminal, dense, pink, acellular secretions are common. Conventional acinar differentiation (arrow) is also common in foamy carcinoma (a). The nuclei are small and dense; typical malignant nuclear features of prostate cancer are only variably present, making recognition of cancer difficult. Occasional prominent nucleoli and nuclear enlargement are Histologic Variants of Prostate Carcinoma also present (b).

2383.caption: High-grade spindle cell neoplasm in prostate, diagnosed as leiomyosarcoma. TURP specimen showed diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle/epithelioid cells with atypical mitoses. Differential: PSS, sarcomatoid carcinoma, leiomyosarcoma. Tumor cells positive for desmin, calponin, muscle-specific actin; focal pan cytokeratin reactivity. Confirmed
2383.original_caption: High-grade spindle cell neoplasm involving the prostate gland, diagnosed as high-grade leiomyosarcoma. (a) The transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) specimen from a 58-year-old man demonstrated diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle and epithelioid cells in a haphazard pattern. Some nuclei have a cigar shape and demonstrate frequent atypical mitoses. The differential diagnosis included PSS, sarcomatoid carcinoma, and leiomyosarcoma. Tumor cells were diffusely and strongly positive for several muscle markers including desmin (b), calponin, and muscle-specific actin (not shown). The tumor cells also demonstrated focal aberrant reactivity for pan cytokeratin (c). The diagnosis of high-grade leiomyosarcoma was made

2379.caption: Prostate cancer p63+. Cancer glands infiltrate benign glands (a), with layered cancer cells, poorly formed lumens, prominent nucleoli (b). HMWCK(34bE12)- (c), p63+ in all cells (d). Rare basal cell differentiation variant.
2379.original_caption: Prostate cancer positive for p63. The cancer glands infiltrate between benign prostate glands (a). They are lined with several layers of cancer cells and some have poorly formed lumens. The nucleoli are prominent (b). All the cancer glands are negative for HMWCK (34bE12, (c), but uniformly positive for p63 (d). Rather than being in basal cell distribution, the staining is found in all the cancer cells. Prostate cancer positive for p63 is exceedingly rare and probably represents a form of prostate cancer with basal cell differentiation

2380.caption: Prostate cancer p63+. Cancer glands infiltrate benign glands (a), lined with multilayered cells, poorly formed lumens, prominent nucleoli (b). HMWCK(34bE12)- (c), p63+ in all cells (d). Rare basal cell differentiation variant.
2380.original_caption: Prostate cancer positive for p63. The cancer glands infiltrate between benign prostate glands (a). They are lined with several layers of cancer cells and some have poorly formed lumens. The nucleoli are prominent (b). All the cancer glands are negative for HMWCK (34bE12, (c), but uniformly positive for p63 (d). Rather than being in basal cell distribution, the staining is found in all the cancer cells. Prostate cancer positive for p63 is exceedingly rare and probably represents a form of prostate cancer with basal cell differentiation

2381.caption: High-grade spindle cell neoplasm in prostate, diagnosed as leiomyosarcoma. TURP specimen showed diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle/epithelioid cells with atypical mitoses. Differential: PSS, sarcomatoid carcinoma, leiomyosarcoma. Tumor cells positive for desmin, calponin, muscle-specific actin; focal pan cytokeratin reactivity. Confirmed

(a) The transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) specimen from a 58-year-old man demonstrated diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle and epithelioid cells in a haphazard pattern. 2382.caption: High-grade spindle cell neoplasm in prostate, diagnosed as leiomyosarcoma. TURP specimen showed diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle/epithelioid cells with cigar-shaped nuclei, atypical mitoses. Differential: PSS, sarcomatoid carcinoma, leiomyosarcoma. Tumor cells positive for desmin, calponin, muscle-specific actin; focal pan cytokeratin
2382.original_caption: High-grade spindle cell neoplasm involving the prostate gland, diagnosed as high-grade leiomyosarcoma. (a) The transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) specimen from a 58-year-old man demonstrated diffuse proliferation of high-grade spindle and epithelioid cells in a haphazard pattern. 2392.caption: Benign prostate glands with marked inflammation. Epithelial cells show cytological atypia, nuclear enlargement, small nucleoli. Cancer glands may also have inflammation.
2392.original_caption: Benign prostate glands with exuberant inflammation. The epithelial cells exhibit significant cytological atypia, including nuclear enlargement and small nucleoli. Cancer glands, however, can also be associated with inflammation

2389.caption: Poorly differentiated foamy gland carcinoma mimicking xanthomatous inflammation in biopsy. Cytological atypia/glandular differentiation (arrow) supports diagnosis.
2389.original_caption: (c, d) A poorly differentiated foamy gland carcinoma simulating xanthomatous inflammation in needle biopsy. Presence of cytological atypia and/or any glandular differentiation (arrow) supports the diagnosis of foamy gland carcinoma (d).

2391.caption: Adenosis. Circumscribed lobular gland collection, variable sizes. Some benign glands: large irregular contour, undulating luminal borders. Smaller rigid-lumen glands cytologically identical to benign larger glands.
2391.original_caption: Adenosis. Circumscribed, lobular collection of glands with variable sizes. Some glands are clearly benign with large irregular contour and undulating luminal borders. Smaller glands with rigid lumens are identical to larger benign glands cytologically

2388.caption: Foamy gland carcinoma: xanthomatous cytoplasm, low N:C ratio, mimics benign. Intraluminal pink acellular secretions. Small dense nuclei, variable malignant features. Occasional prominent nucleoli, nuclear enlargement. Conventional acinar differentiation present.
2388.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of foamy gland carcinoma. (a, b) At low power, a foamy gland carcinoma is characterized by abundant xanthomatous cytoplasm with low N:C ratio, simulating a benign process. Intraluminal, dense, pink, acellular secretions are common. Conventional acinar differentiation (arrow) is also common in foamy carcinoma (a). The nuclei are small and dense; typical malignant nuclear features of prostate cancer are only variably present, making recognition of cancer difficult. Occasional prominent nucleoli and nuclear enlargement are Histologic Variants of Prostate Carcinoma also present (b).

2393.caption: Simple atrophy. Lobulated glands (a), slightly enlarged nuclei, small/inconspicuous nucleoli (b)
2393.original_caption: Simple atrophy. Glands have lobulated architecture (a) and nuclei are slightly enlarged with small or inconspicuous nucleoli (b)

2394.caption: Simple atrophy. Lobulated glands (a), slightly enlarged nuclei, small/inconspicuous nucleoli (b)
2394.original_caption: Simple atrophy. Glands have lobulated architecture (a) and nuclei are slightly enlarged with small or inconspicuous nucleoli (b)

2395.caption: Simple atrophy: gland architecture maintained, reduced cytoplasm, basophilic. Cystic atrophy: round, dilated glands, attenuated cytoplasm. Both show inflammation, sclerotic stroma. PIA lesions: atrophic but high Ki-67 proliferative activity, early prostate carcinoma precursor.
2395.original_caption: Simple atrophy, cystic atrophy, and PIA lesion. (a) In simple atrophy, overall architecture of the glands is maintained with marked reduction of cytoplasm, creating a basophilic appearance at low power (a). In cystic atrophy, an undulated glandular architecture of the normal gland is lost; glands are round and cystically dilated with attenuated cytoplasm (b). Both simple and postatrophic hyperplasia are commonly accompanied by inflammation and sclerotic stroma (c). Although glands appear rather atrophic and involuting, they demonstrate higher proliferative activity on immunostain for proliferation marker Ki-67 (not shown). Such lesions are also termed PIA and are proposed as an early precursor to prostate carcinoma

2396.caption: Simple atrophy: gland architecture intact, reduced cytoplasm, basophilic. Cystic atrophy: round, dilated glands, lost undulated structure. Both show inflammation, sclerotic stroma. PIA lesions: atrophic but high Ki-67 proliferative activity, early prostate carcinoma precursor.
2396.original_caption: Simple atrophy, cystic atrophy, and PIA lesion. (a) In simple atrophy, overall architecture of the glands is maintained with marked reduction of cytoplasm, creating a basophilic appearance at low power (a). In cystic atrophy, an undulated glandular architecture of the normal gland is lost; glands are round and cystically dilated with attenuated cytoplasm (b). Both simple and postatrophic hyperplasia are commonly accompanied by inflammation and sclerotic stroma (c). Although glands appear rather atrophic and involuting, they demonstrate higher proliferative activity on immunostain for proliferation marker Ki-67 (not shown). Such lesions are also termed PIA and are proposed as an early precursor to prostate carcinoma

2405.caption: Signet ring cell prostate carcinoma: sheets of infiltrative discohesive cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles displacing nuclei peripherally. Vacuoles are optically clear with cytological atypia. Usually mucin-negative. Graded as Gleason 5. Vacuoles in cancer glands ≠ signet ring differentiation; grade based on architecture.
2405.original_caption: Signet ring cell prostate carcinoma is composed of sheets of infiltrative discohesive cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles displacing the nuclei peripherally (a). At higher magnification, vacuoles are optically clear and cytological atypia is present (b). In most cases, the cytoplasmic vacuoles lack staining for mucin. The signet ring cell carcinoma is graded as Gleason pattern 5. Presence of vacuoles in cancer glands should not be viewed as signet ring cell differentiation and grading should be based on underlying architecture

2397.caption: Simple atrophy: gland architecture maintained, reduced cytoplasm, basophilic. Cystic atrophy: round, dilated glands, lost normal architecture. Both show inflammation, sclerotic stroma. PIA lesions: atrophic but high Ki-67 proliferative activity, early prostate carcinoma precursor.
2397.original_caption: Simple atrophy, cystic atrophy, and PIA lesion. (a) In simple atrophy, overall architecture of the glands is maintained with marked reduction of cytoplasm, creating a basophilic appearance at low power (a). In cystic atrophy, an undulated glandular architecture of the normal gland is lost; glands are round and cystically dilated with attenuated cytoplasm (b). Both simple and postatrophic hyperplasia are commonly accompanied by inflammation and sclerotic stroma (c). Although glands appear rather atrophic and involuting, they demonstrate higher proliferative activity on immunostain for proliferation marker Ki-67 (not shown). Such lesions are also termed PIA and are proposed as an early precursor to prostate carcinoma

2400.caption: Partial atrophy lesions: lobular crowded glands, stellate/undulating lumina, pale cytoplasm (a-b). Disorganized small round/poorly formed glands, some completely atrophic (arrows/arrowheads) (c). Micronucleoli, pale lateral cytoplasm, no nuclear enlargement/macronucleoli, few atrophic glands (d). Disorganized growth mimics cancer;
2400.original_caption: 7.9 Morphological spectrum of partial atrophy. (a–f) The majority of partial atrophy lesions are composed of a lobular arrangement of crowded glands with stellate/undulating gland lumina, and scant pale clear cytoplasm, imparting a distinct pale appearance at low power (a and b). Partial atrophy composed of a disorganized proliferation of predominantly small, round to occasionally poorly formed glands (arrows). In addition to partially atrophic glands, there are several completely atrophic glands (arrowheads), a very useful diagnostic clue. Also note that the pale cytoplasm of the lesion is similar to the adjacent benign gland (c). At high power, frequent micronucleoli (arrow) are visible. Note pale, clear cytoplasm placed laterally to the nuclei, lack of nuclear enlargement and macronucleoli, as well as the presence of few completely atrophic glands within the focus (d). (e) Another example of partial atrophy showing disorganized growth pattern and predominant poorly formed glands mimicking cancer. Note relatively benign cytology, pale cytoplasm, and few completely atrophic glands within the focus. (f) Immunohistochemistry for basal cell markers demonstrates very patchy staining with the lack of staining in the majority of glands

Disorganized small round/poorly formed glands (arrows), mixed with atrophic glands (arrowheads) (c). Micronucleoli (arrow), pale lateral cytoplasm, no nuclear enlargement/macronucleoli (d). Disorganized growth mimics cancer; benign cyt
