2404.caption: HGPIN four patterns: tufting (most common), micropapillary (slender papillae, no fibrovascular core), flat, cribriform (least common). Cribriform glands with atypia often intraductal carcinoma. Patterns clinically similar, diagnostic recognition only.
2404.original_caption: Four major architectural patterns of HGPIN. These patterns often coexist in the same biopsy. Tufting pattern is the most common (a). Micropapillary HGPIN has long and slender papillae without fibrovascular core (b). Flat HGPIN (c). Cribriform HGPIN is least common (d). The majority of cribriform glands with atypical cells represent intraductal carcinoma. HGPIN of different architectural patterns has no significant clinical difference and its recognition is for diagnostic consideration only

2406.caption: Signet ring cell prostate carcinoma: sheets of infiltrative discohesive cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles displacing nuclei (a). Vacuoles optically clear, cytological atypia (b). Vacuoles usually mucin-negative. Graded Gleason 5. Vacuoles in cancer glands ≠ signet ring differentiation; grade based on architecture.
2406.original_caption: Signet ring cell prostate carcinoma is composed of sheets of infiltrative discohesive cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles displacing the nuclei peripherally (a). At higher magnification, vacuoles are optically clear and cytological atypia is present (b). In most cases, the cytoplasmic vacuoles lack staining for mucin. The signet ring cell carcinoma is graded as Gleason pattern 5. Presence of vacuoles in cancer glands should not be viewed as signet ring cell differentiation and grading should be based on underlying architecture

2408.caption: Prostate cancer post-finasteride. Minimal histologic changes (a). Some glands show atrophic cytoplasm, small dark nuclei (b). PCPT reported decreased overall but increased high-grade cancer with finasteride, possibly due to prostate volume reduction and selective low-grade inhibition.
2408.original_caption: Prostate cancer after finasteride treatment. Cancer glands show minimum histological changes (a). Several glands have slightly atrophic cytoplasm, small and dark nuclei without prominent nucleoli (b). Recently, the Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT) reported a decreased overall incidence of prostate cancer but an increase in the incidence of high-grade prostate cancer with finasteride. It is thought that finasteride might have contributed to the increase in high-grade cancer by reducing the prostate volume and selective inhibition of lowgrade cancer, rather than effects on tumor morphology

2407.caption: Prostate cancer post-androgen deprivation: individual cells mixed with inflammatory cells in fibrotic stroma. Hyperchromatic, atypical nuclei. Pancytokeratin & PSA immunostains needed for identification.
2407.original_caption: Prostate cancer following androgen deprivation: individual cells. Individual cancer cells, mixed with other inflammatory cells and embedded in a fibrotic stroma, are easy to overlook. At high magnification, some nuclei are hyperchromatic and atypical. Immunostains for pancytokeratin and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) markers are often required to identify the cancer cells

2409.caption: Prostate cancer post-finasteride. Minimal histological changes (a). Some glands show atrophic cytoplasm, small dark nuclei (b). PCPT reported decreased overall but increased high-grade prostate cancer with finasteride. Finasteride may increase high-grade cancer by reducing prostate volume and inhibiting low-grade cancer, not affecting tumor morphology.
2409.original_caption: Prostate cancer after finasteride treatment. Cancer glands show minimum histological changes (a). Several glands have slightly atrophic cytoplasm, small and dark nuclei without prominent nucleoli (b). Recently, the Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT) reported a decreased overall incidence of prostate cancer but an increase in the incidence of high-grade prostate cancer with finasteride. It is thought that finasteride might have contributed to the increase in high-grade cancer by reducing the prostate volume and selective inhibition of lowgrade cancer, rather than effects on tumor morphology

2410.caption: Partial atrophy with patchy basal cells. p63 immunostain shows focal/absent staining. Glands with/without basal cells have identical cytology. Adenosis and HGPIN also show patchy/absent basal cells.
2410.original_caption: Partial atrophy with patchy basal cells. Basal cells are not always present in all benign glands, such as partial atrophy (a). Basal cell immunostain for p63 demonstrates focal staining in some glands and complete absence of staining in other glands (b). However, glands with and without basal cell lining have identical cytological features. Other noncancerous lesions that often demonstrate patchy or absent basal cells include adenosis and HGPIN

2416.caption: Nuclear atypia - enlarged nuclei. Cancer cells show significant nuclear enlargement vs. adjacent benign glands (right lower).
2416.original_caption: nuclear atypia – nuclear enlargement. Using the adjacent benign glands (right lower of the image) as reference, the cancer cells have significantly enlarged nuclei

2414.caption: Absence of basal cells. Cancer glands lack basal cells on H&E (a), confirmed by p63 immunostain (b)
2414.original_caption: absence of basal cells. Cancer glands are devoid of basal cells on H&E examination (a), which is confirmed by immunostain for basal cell marker p63 (b)

2415.caption: Absence of basal cells. Cancer glands lack basal cells on H&E (a), confirmed by p63 immunostain (b)
2415.original_caption: absence of basal cells. Cancer glands are devoid of basal cells on H&E examination (a), which is confirmed by immunostain for basal cell marker p63 (b)

2412.caption: Crushed cancer cells mimic basal cells, appearing hyperchromatic (arrows) (a). Basal cells vary in appearance, resembling stromal fibroblasts or crushed cancer cells on H&E. Confirm absence with p63 immunostain (b).
2412.original_caption: Crushed cancer cells mimicking basal cells. Crushed cancer cells appear hyperchromatic (arrows) and different from other cancer cells and therefore may be mistaken for basal cells (a). Basal cells can assume a range of appearances and may be difficult to distinguish from stromal fibroblasts or crushed cancer cells on H&E examination. It is prudent to perform basal cell immunostains, p63 in this case, to confirm the absence of basal cells (b)

2417.caption: Abnormal irregular cribriform structure. Cancer glands show large cribriform architecture with infiltrative borders.
2417.original_caption: abnormal architectural pattern - irregular cribriform structure. Cancer glands demonstrate large cribriform architecture with irregular and infiltrative borders

2418.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate biopsy. Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium. Nuclei stratified with prominent nucleoli. IHC markers (p63) aid diagnosis.
2418.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate needle biopsy. (a) Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium are seen in a haphazard pattern (a). Nuclei are stratified with frequent prominent nucleoli (b). Immunohistochemical markers for basal cell detection are helpful in difficult cases (c, p63)

2419.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate biopsy. Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium. Nuclei stratified with prominent nucleoli. IHC markers (p63) aid diagnosis.
2419.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate needle biopsy. (a) Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium are seen in a haphazard pattern (a). Nuclei are stratified with frequent prominent nucleoli (b). Immunohistochemical markers for basal cell detection are helpful in difficult cases (c, p63)

2411.caption: Partial atrophy with patchy basal cells. Basal cells absent in some benign glands (a). p63 immunostain shows focal/absent staining (b). Glands with/without basal cells have same cytology. Adenosis and HGPIN also show patchy/absent basal cells.
2411.original_caption: Partial atrophy with patchy basal cells. Basal cells are not always present in all benign glands, such as partial atrophy (a). Basal cell immunostain for p63 demonstrates focal staining in some glands and complete absence of staining in other glands (b). However, glands with and without basal cell lining have identical cytological features. Other noncancerous lesions that often demonstrate patchy or absent basal cells include adenosis and HGPIN

2424.caption: Malakoplakia: transurethral resection shows sheets of pink epithelioid histiocytes with inflammatory cells. Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (arrow) confirm diagnosis.
2424.original_caption: Malakoplakia. In this transurethral resection specimen, there is a diffuse sheet-like proliferation of pink epithelioid histiocytes, accompanied by other inflammatory cells, similar to nonspecific xanthogranulomatous prostatitis. The histiocytic nature of epithelioid cells and the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies (arrow) suggest the diagnosis of malakoplakia

2420.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate biopsy. Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium (a). Stratified nuclei with prominent nucleoli (b). IHC markers (p63) aid diagnosis (c).
2420.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia in prostate needle biopsy. (a) Dark-staining nests with stratified epithelium are seen in a haphazard pattern (a). Nuclei are stratified with frequent prominent nucleoli (b). Immunohistochemical markers for basal cell detection are helpful in difficult cases (c, p63)

2413.caption: Crushed cancer cells mimic basal cells, appearing hyperchromatic (arrows). Basal cells vary in appearance, resembling stromal fibroblasts or crushed cancer cells on H&E. Confirm absence with p63 immunostain.
2413.original_caption: Crushed cancer cells mimicking basal cells. Crushed cancer cells appear hyperchromatic (arrows) and different from other cancer cells and therefore may be mistaken for basal cells (a). Basal cells can assume a range of appearances and may be difficult to distinguish from stromal fibroblasts or crushed cancer cells on H&E examination. It is prudent to perform basal cell immunostains, p63 in this case, to confirm the absence of basal cells (b)

2425.caption: Intraductal prostate carcinoma: large irregular glands, dense cribriform/solid architecture, comedo necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, retained basal cells. Distinguishable from HGPIN by size/shape.
2425.original_caption: Intraductal carcinoma of the prostate. Large glands with markedly irregular glandular contour intermingle with invasive cancer (a). These glands have much larger size and more irregular shape than HGPIN glands and are much more likely to have dense cribriform (b) or solid architecture and comedo necrosis (c). In addition, the constituent cells in intraductal carcinoma are more likely to exhibit marked nuclear pleomorphism (d). Basal cells are always retained in these glands (e)

2421.caption: SLL/CLL mimicking chronic inflammation in prostate biopsies. Monotonous small lymphocytic infiltrate, multifocal/diffuse, not around ducts/acini suggests lymphoproliferative process. Check clinical history, blood counts, IHC markers. Example: CLL patient, prostate biopsy showed B-cell markers CD79a (strong), CD20 (weak), coexpressed CD43
2421.original_caption: Small lymphocytic lymphoma/chronic lymphocytic leukemia (SLL/CLL) mimicking nonspecific chronic inflammation. SLL/CLL can be infrequently encountered in the prostate biopsies performed for elevated PSA and/or prostate enlargement. Such infiltrate is often overlooked as nonspecific chronic inflammation. If monotonous small lymphocytic infiltrate is multifocal/diffuse in distribution and is not centered around ducts and acini, a lymphoproliferative process should be considered and ruled out (a and b). Review of clinical history including peripheral blood counts along with a select panel of immunohistochemical markers should be performed to rule out SLL/CLL. In this example, the patient had CLL and small monotonous lymphoid infiltrate in prostate biopsy demonstrated expression for B cell markers CD79a (strong; c) and CD20 (weak) with coexpression of CD43 and CD5 and lack of expression for CD3, supporting the diagnosis of CLL involving the prostate gland

2426.caption: Intraductal prostate carcinoma: large irregular glands with invasive cancer (a), dense cribriform/solid architecture, comedo necrosis (c). Nuclear pleomorphism (d), retained basal cells (e). Larger/more irregular than HGPIN.
2426.original_caption: Intraductal carcinoma of the prostate. Large glands with markedly irregular glandular contour intermingle with invasive cancer (a). These glands have much larger size and more irregular shape than HGPIN glands and are much more likely to have dense cribriform (b) or solid architecture and comedo necrosis (c). In addition, the constituent cells in intraductal carcinoma are more likely to exhibit marked nuclear pleomorphism (d). Basal cells are always retained in these glands (e)

In addition, the constituent cells in intraductal carcinoma are more likely to exhibit marked nuclear pleomorphism (d). Basal cells are always retained in these glands (e)

Clinical history, blood counts, IHC (CD79a+, CD20 weak, CD43/CD5+, CD3-) confirm CLL involving prostate.

2439.caption: HGPIN with adjacent small atypical glands (PINATYP). Small atypical glands near HGPIN show similar nuclear atypia (a,b).
2439.original_caption: HGPIN with adjacent small focus of atypical glands (PINATYP). Several small atypical glands lie immediately adjacent to a larger HGPIN gland (a). The nuclear atypia in these small atypical glands is similar to that in the HGPIN glands (b).

2441.caption: Atypia with marked inflammation. Biopsy shows small glands (a) with nuclear enlargement, prominent nucleoli (b). Marked acute inflammation (b).
2441.original_caption: Atypia associated with marked inflammation. This biopsy harbors a group of small glands (a) that exhibit nuclear enlargement and prominent nucleoli (b). There is marked acute inflammation (b).

2440.caption: Atypia with marked inflammation. Biopsy shows small glands (a) with nuclear enlargement, prominent nucleoli (b). Marked acute inflammation (b).
2440.original_caption: Atypia associated with marked inflammation. This biopsy harbors a group of small glands (a) that exhibit nuclear enlargement and prominent nucleoli (b). There is marked acute inflammation (b).

2430.caption: Aberrant HMWCK in cancer glands: weak cytoplasmic staining (a,b), absent basal distribution. Benign glands (c) show weak secretory & strong basal staining (d). Caused by excessive antigen retrieval/staining.
2430.original_caption: Aberrant HMWCK staining in cancer glands. Cancer glands (a) have weak cytoplasmic staining (b) but not in a basal cell distribution. Benign glands in the same biopsy core (c) also have weak cytoplasmic staining in the secretory cells in addition to strong staining in basal cells (d). Such aberrant staining is due to excessive antigen retrieval and staining

2436.caption: Circumscribed crowded glands (a) with nuclear enlargement, small nucleoli (b). Differential: adenosis vs cancer (anterior/transition zone prostate). Immunostains: basal cell markers, AMACR for definitive diagnosis.
2436.original_caption: A focus of circumscribed crowded glands (a) with slight nuclear enlargement and small nucleoli (b). The differential diagnosis includes adenosis and cancer that is typically found in anterior or transition zone of the prostate. Immunostains for basal cell markers and AMACR should be performed in an attempt to reach a definitive diagnosis

2429.caption: Intraductal prostate carcinoma: large irregular glands with invasive cancer (a), dense cribriform/solid architecture (b), comedo necrosis (c), nuclear pleomorphism (d). Retained basal cells (e). Larger than HGPIN.
2429.original_caption: Intraductal carcinoma of the prostate. Large glands with markedly irregular glandular contour intermingle with invasive cancer (a). 2434.caption: Atrophic glands with crowded growth, nuclear enlargement, small nucleoli. Differential: atrophic cancer vs benign atrophy. Cancer may have atrophic cytoplasm; benign atrophy may show atypia but lacks frank nuclear atypia. Perform basal cell markers and AMACR immunostains in borderline cases.
2434.original_caption: Atrophic glands with crowded growth pattern (a) and nuclear enlargement and small nucleoli (b). The differential diagnosis includes an atrophic cancer and benign atrophy. Cancer glands may have atrophic cytoplasm. Benign atrophic glands may also exhibit some degree of architectural and/or cytological atypia, including nuclear enlargement and small nucleoli. However, frank nuclear atypia typical of cancer is not seen in benign atrophy. Immunostains for basal cell markers and AMACR should be performed in such borderline cases

2442.caption: AMACR shows granular apical staining in cancer glands (a). Benign glands may be focally, weakly positive (a). Positive AMACR is stronger than benign glands. Example: cancer with strong circumferential staining is negative if benign glands match (b). Cancer with weak apical staining is positive if benign glands are negative (c).
2442.original_caption: Expression of AMACR appears as granular staining predominantly in the apical portion of cancer glands (a). An adjacent benign gland is also focally and weakly positive for AMACR (a). Benign glands are occasionally positive for AMACR staining, which is typically focal and weak and may represent field effect. However, this raises the question as to what should be considered as positive AMACR staining. Positive AMACR staining is defined as significantly stronger than that of adjacent benign glands. For example, a prostate cancer (arrows) with strong and circumferential AMACR staining will be considered negative if adjacent benign glands (asterisks) have similar strong and circumferential staining (b). In contrast, a prostate cancer (arrows) with weak apical staining is considered positive for AMACR when the adjacent benign glands (asterisks) are completely negative (c)

2444.caption: AMACR granular staining in apical cancer glands (a). Adjacent benign gland focally weak AMACR+ (a). Benign glands occasionally AMACR+, focal/weak, possible field effect. 2448.caption: Pseudohyperplastic carcinoma with undulating branching contour: Gleason 3. Small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: no grading (unique biology/therapeutic significance).
2448.original_caption: (c) Pseudohyperplastic carcinoma with large undulating and branching contour should be graded as Gleason pattern 3. (e) Small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma should not be graded due to its unique tumor biology and therapeutic Contemporary Approach to Gleason Grading of Prostate Cancer significance

2454.caption: Primary pattern Gleason 3, secondary Gleason 4 (lower right).
2454.original_caption: In this example, the primary pattern is Gleason 3, with a small component of secondary Gleason pattern is 4 (lower right).

2455.caption: Intracytoplasmic vacuoles present in Gleason pattern 3 prostate cancer, not signet-ring differentiation or pattern 5.
2455.original_caption: Intracytoplasmic vacuoles can be seen in many prostate cancers of different patterns and do not equate to signet-ring differentiation or pattern 5. In this example, cytoplasmic vacuoles are seen in Gleason pattern 3 cancer.

2456.caption: Intracytoplasmic vacuoles occur in prostate cancers, not signet-ring/p5. Seen here in Gleason 3.
2456.original_caption: Intracytoplasmic vacuoles can be seen in many prostate cancers of different patterns and do not equate to signet-ring differentiation or pattern 5. In this example, cytoplasmic vacuoles are seen in Gleason pattern 3 cancer.

2452.caption: Intraluminal cribriform proliferation with glomeruloid differentiation (arrows). Grading controversial: Gleason pattern 3 or 4.
2452.original_caption: Intraluminal cribriform proliferation representing glomeruloid differentiation (arrows). Grading of such differentiation remains controversial. Although some experts consider it either Gleason pattern 3 or pattern 4

2449.caption: Pseudohyperplastic carcinoma with undulating/branching contour: Gleason 3. Small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: no grading (unique biology/therapeutic significance).
2449.original_caption: (c) Pseudohyperplastic carcinoma with large undulating and branching contour should be graded as Gleason pattern 3. (e) Small cell neuroendocrine carcinoma should not be graded due to its unique tumor biology and therapeutic Contemporary Approach to Gleason Grading of Prostate Cancer significance

2461.caption: Prostate carcinoma with cribriform architecture. Large cribriform glands may mimic HGPIN but are accompanied by smaller cancer glands. Diagnosis confirmed by perineural invasion, extraprostatic extension, or absent basal cell markers.
2461.original_caption: Prostate carcinoma with cribriform architecture. Large cribriform prostate cancer glands may be mistaken for HGPIN (a), but they are almost always accompanied by smaller cancer glands. The diagnosis can be confirmed by cancer-specific histological features, such as perineural invasion or extraprostatic extension, or confirmed by the absence of basal cell markers (b)

2453.caption: Primary Gleason 3, secondary Gleason 4 (lower right).
2453.original_caption: In this example, the primary pattern is Gleason 3, with a small component of secondary Gleason pattern is 4 (lower right).

2467.caption: Prostate cancer with subtle architectural/cytological atypia. Crowded gland growth (a). Minimal nuclear enlargement, inconspicuous nucleoli (b). Negative p63 (c). Diagnosis requires multiple cancer glands + IHC.
2467.original_caption: Prostate cancer with subtle architectural and cytological atypia. In this case, the cancer glands display crowded growth pattern (a). The cancer cells have minimum nuclear enlargement and inconspicuous nucleoli (b). This focus is negative for basal cell marker p63 (c). The cancer diagnosis in such cases requires a substantial number of cancer glands and ancillary immunohistochemistry

2465.caption: Sarcomatoid carcinoma (carcinosarcoma): high-grade undifferentiated spindle cell sarcoma with myxoid background. Acinar carcinoma (arrow) admixed with sarcomatoid component. Epithelial component is malignant, unlike prostate stromal sarcoma.
2465.original_caption: Sarcomatoid carcinoma (carcinosarcoma). Sarcomatoid carcinoma has high-grade undifferentiated spindle cell sarcoma with a myxoid background (a). Acinar carcinoma is present (arrow) and is intimately admixed with the sarcomaotid component (b). In contrast to prostate stromal sarcoma, epithelial component in sarcomatoid carcinoma is malignant.

2466.caption: Sarcomatoid carcinoma (carcinosarcoma): high-grade undiff spindle cell sarcoma, myxoid background (a). Acinar carcinoma (arrow) admixed with sarcomatoid component (b). Epithelial component malignant, unlike prostate stromal sarcoma.

2464.caption: 9.12 PIN-like prostate cancer mimics HGPIN. Biopsy shows packed large glands with irregular contour, undulating luminal border (a). Glands have stratified nuclei with atypia (b), suspicious for HGPIN. Negative p63, positive AMACR (c).
2464.original_caption: 9.12 PIN-like prostate cancer mimicking HGPIN. The biopsy contains a focus of closely packed large glands with irregular contour and undulating luminal border (a). These glands are lined with stratified nuclei with significant atypia (b), raising the suspicion for HGPIN. However, they are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive for AMACR (c).

2462.caption: 9.12 PIN-like prostate cancer mimics HGPIN. Biopsy shows packed large glands with irregular contour, undulating luminal border (a). Glands have stratified nuclei with atypia (b), suspicious for HGPIN. Negative p63, positive AMACR (c).

2459.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia mimics HGPIN. Benign prostate glands with basal cell rimming, prominent nucleoli. Differs from HGPIN: basal cells proliferate into stroma, not luminal surface. Blue-gray smooth nuclei vs. reddish granular secretory nuclei.
2459.original_caption: Basal cell hyperplasia mimicking HGPIN. Benign prostate glands rimmed with basal cells with prominent nucleoli. Different from HGPIN, basal cells typically proliferate into the surrounding stroma and do not extend to the luminal surface. Their nuclei appear blue-grayish and smooth as opposed to reddish granular nuclei in secretory cells

2460.caption: Prostate carcinoma with cribriform architecture. Large cribriform glands may mimic HGPIN but are accompanied by smaller cancer glands. Diagnosis confirmed by perineural invasion, extraprostatic extension, or absent basal cell markers.

2458.caption: Xanthomatous infiltrate in prostate biopsy. Xanthoma cells show diffuse infiltrative pattern, mimicking poorly differentiated carcinoma. No glandular differentiation, bland nuclei. Immunohistochemistry (CD-68, pancytokeratin) may be needed to exclude carcinoma. Inflammatory cells support diagnosis.
2458.original_caption: Xanthomatous infiltrate in prostate needle biopsy. (a) Xanthoma cells grow in a diffuse infiltrative pattern, mimicking poorly differentiated prostate carcinoma with foamy features (a). Lack of any glandular differentiation and relatively bland nuclear features suggests the diagnosis of xanthomatous infiltrate (b). In small needle biopsy samples, a panel of immunohistochemical markers of histiocytic lineage (CD-68) and pancytokeratin may be necessary to rule out carcinoma. Presence of other inflammatory cells would support the diagnosis of xanthomatous infiltrate

2451.caption: Confluent cancer glands with papillary architecture, tall columnar epithelium: large-duct morphology (Gleason 4). Intraluminal necrosis upgrades to Gleason 5. Other large-duct types: endometrioid (cribriform/papillary) and PIN-like discrete glands with tall columnar epithelium.
2451.original_caption: Confluent cancer glands with papillary architecture lined by tall columnar epithelium represent large-duct morphology and should be graded as Gleason pattern 4. With intraluminal necrosis, it is graded as Gleason pattern 5. Other large-duct morphologies include endometrioid growth pattern with cribriform/papillary morphology and PIN-like large discrete glands, demonstrating tall columnar lining epithelium.

2476.caption: Stromal hyperplasia: nodular proliferation of uniform bland spindle cells, no prostate glands. No cytologic atypia/mitotic activity. Scattered inflammatory cells, thick hyalinized wall blood vessels.
2476.original_caption: Stromal hyperplasia. (a–b) At low magnification, stromal hyperplasia is characterized by nodular proliferation of uniform spindle cells usually without admixed prostate glands (a). At higher magnification, spindle cells are bland, uniform, and lack cytologic atypia and/or mitotic activity. Scattered inflammatory cells and prominent blood vessels with thick hyalinized wall (arrows) are also evident (b)

2469.caption: Prostate cancer with subtle atypia. Crowded gland growth (a). Minimal nuclear enlargement, inconspicuous nucleoli (b). Negative p63 (c). Diagnosis requires multiple cancer glands and IHC.
2469.original_caption: Prostate cancer with subtle architectural and cytological atypia. In this case, the cancer glands display crowded growth pattern (a). The cancer cells have minimum nuclear enlargement and inconspicuous nucleoli (b). This focus is negative for basal cell marker p63 (c). The cancer diagnosis in such cases requires a substantial number of cancer glands and ancillary immunohistochemistry

2471.caption: Limited prostate cancer. Five cancer glands in one core, showing infiltrative growth (a), nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia (b). Atypical glands, non-inflamed/atrophic, p63-negative (c).
2471.original_caption: Limited prostate cancer. There are only five cancer glands present in one needle core. However, they display infiltrative growth pattern (a) and significant nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia (b). These atypical glands are not inflamed or atrophic. These glands are negative for p63 (c).

2468.caption: Prostate cancer with subtle atypia. Crowded gland growth (a). Minimal nuclear enlargement, inconspicuous nucleoli (b). p63 negative (c). Diagnosis requires multiple cancer glands and IHC.
2468.original_caption: Prostate cancer with subtle architectural and cytological atypia. In this case, the cancer glands display crowded growth pattern (a). The cancer cells have minimum nuclear enlargement and inconspicuous nucleoli (b). This focus is negative for basal cell marker p63 (c). The cancer diagnosis in such cases requires a substantial number of cancer glands and ancillary immunohistochemistry

2470.caption: Limited prostate cancer. Five cancer glands in one needle core show infiltrative growth (a), nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia (b). Atypical glands, non-inflamed/atrophic, p63-negative (c).
2470.original_caption: Limited prostate cancer. There are only five cancer glands present in one needle core. However, they display infiltrative growth pattern (a) and significant nuclear enlargement and hyperchromasia (b). These atypical glands are not inflamed or atrophic. These glands are negative for p63 (c).

2478.caption: STUMP: spindle cell proliferation with benign prostate glands, scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows), focal myxoid changes. Stromal/glandular proliferation resembling breast phyllodes tumor. Hypercellular stroma shows atypical stromal proliferation (arrows), no glands; atypia degenerative, no mitoses.
2478.original_caption: STUMP. (a–d) Classic pattern is characterized by proliferation of spindle cells admixed with benign prostate glands. Note the presence of scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows) (a) and focal prominent myxoid changes (b). Another example showing stromal and glandular proliferation reminiscent of phyllodes tumor of the breast (c). Hypercellular stroma pattern demonstrating atypical stromal proliferation (arrows) without admixed prostate glands. Note atypia is degenerative in nature without any mitotic activity (d)

2472.caption: Limited prostate cancer. Five cancer glands in one core, showing infiltrative growth (a), nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia (b). Atypical glands, non-inflamed/atrophic, p63 negative (c).
2472.original_caption: Limited prostate cancer. There are only five cancer glands present in one needle core. These glands are negative for p63 (c).

2477.caption: STUMP: spindle cells + benign prostate glands, scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows), focal myxoid changes. Stromal/glandular proliferation resembling breast phyllodes tumor. Hypercellular stroma with atypical proliferation (arrows), no glands; degenerative atypia, no mitoses.
2477.original_caption: STUMP. (a–d) Classic pattern is characterized by proliferation of spindle cells admixed with benign prostate glands. Note the presence of scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows) (a) and focal prominent myxoid changes (b). Another example showing stromal and glandular proliferation reminiscent of phyllodes tumor of the breast (c). Hypercellular stroma pattern demonstrating atypical stromal proliferation (arrows) without admixed prostate glands. Note atypia is degenerative in nature without any mitotic activity (d)

2473.caption: HGPIN with adjacent atypical glands (PINATYP). Atypical glands (arrowhead) near HGPIN (arrows) (a), p63-, AMACR+ (b). HGPIN glands AMACR+, scant p63+. Uncertain if microfocus of cancer or tangential sectioning/HGPIN outpouching.
2473.original_caption: HGPIN with adjacent small focus of atypical glands (PINATYP). A few atypical glands (arrowhead) lie immediately adjacent to larger HGPIN glands (arrows) (a) and are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive for a-methylacyl-CoA racemase (AMACR) (b). Note the HGPIN glands are also positive for AMACR and are scarcely positive for p63. It is uncertain whether these atypical glands represent a microfocus of invasive cancer or tangential sectioning and/or outpouching of HGPIN glands.

2474.caption: HGPIN with adjacent atypical glands (PINATYP). Atypical glands (arrowhead) near HGPIN glands (arrows) (a), p63- and AMACR+ (b). HGPIN glands AMACR+, p63 scant. Uncertain if microfocus of invasive cancer or tangential sectioning/HGPIN outpouching.
2474.original_caption: HGPIN with adjacent small focus of atypical glands (PINATYP). A few atypical glands (arrowhead) lie immediately adjacent to larger HGPIN glands (arrows) (a) and are negative for basal cell marker p63 and positive for a-methylacyl-CoA racemase (AMACR) (b). 2483.caption: Prostate biopsy with two atypical glands, negative for basal markers, AMACR positive. Insufficient for cancer diagnosis, termed atypical glands suspicious for cancer without immunostains.
2483.original_caption: A prostate biopsy containing two small atypical glands. A definitive cancer diagnosis cannot be established even if these atypical glands are negative for basal cell markers and positive for AMACR. It is therefore diagnosed as atypical gland suspicious for cancer without performing ancillary immunostains

2482.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor in prostate shows bland spindle cells with pattern-less collagenized stroma. Absent prostate glands and prominent collagen distinguish from prostate stromal tumor. Typically CD34+ and often PR+.
2482.original_caption: Solitary fibrous tumor involving the prostate gland demonstrates proliferation of bland spindle cells with a pattern-less pattern of stroma that is collagenized. Lack of admixed prostate glands and prominent collagen deposition in the stroma distinguishes it from a prostate stromal tumor. Immunohistochemical features are usually not helpful in this distinction as solitary fibrous tumors typically express CD34 and often are also positive for progesterone receptor

2481.caption: PSS shows high cellularity, cytologic atypia, frequent mitoses (arrows). Malignant phyllodes-like stromal sarcoma has hypercellular, atypical stromal cells with increased mitoses. Leaflike elements lined by benign prostatic epithelium help differentiate from prostatic carcinosarcoma.
2481.original_caption: PSS. In contrast to STUMP, PSS demonstrates high cellularity and obvious cytologic atypia with frequent mitoses (arrows). In this example, malignant phyllodes-like stromal sarcoma demonstrate hypercellular, atypical stromal cells with increased mitotic activity. The leaflike elements are lined by benign prostatic epithelium, a helpful feature to differentiate it from carcinosarcoma (sarcomatoid carcinoma) of the prostate

2480.caption: STUMP: spindle cells mixed with benign prostate glands, scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows), focal myxoid changes. Stromal/glandular proliferation resembling breast phyllodes tumor. Hypercellular stroma shows atypical proliferation (arrows), no glands, degenerative atypia, no mitoses.
2480.original_caption: STUMP. (a–d) Classic pattern is characterized by proliferation of spindle cells admixed with benign prostate glands. Note the presence of scattered pleomorphic atypical cells (arrows) (a) and focal prominent myxoid changes (b). Another example showing stromal and glandular proliferation reminiscent of phyllodes tumor of the breast (c). Hypercellular stroma pattern demonstrating atypical stromal proliferation (arrows) without admixed prostate glands. Note atypia is degenerative in nature without any mitotic activity (d)

2487.caption: HGPIN glands resemble benign glands but darker (a). At 20×, secretory cells show crowded, stratified nuclei with enlarged size, coarse chromatin, and conspicuous nucleoli (b). Central nuclei less atypical than peripheral. Discontinuous/absent basal layer, especially in small glands (c). Most HGPIN AMACR+ (c).
2487.original_caption: HGPIN. At scanning power, HGPIN glands (arrows) are architecturally similar to but appear darker than the adjacent benign glands (a). At 20× magnification, the secretory cells have crowded and stratified nuclei that are enlarged and have coarse and clumpy chromatin. Importantly, large and conspicuous nucleoli are present in the secretory cells (b). Nuclei toward the center of the gland tend to have less atypia compared with the nuclei at the periphery of the gland. HGPIN glands often have discontinuous basal cell layer, or even absent basal cell layer especially in small glands (c). The majority of HGPIN glands are positive for AMACR (c)

2485.caption: TURP post-laser ablation. Fibrotic area with inflammation (a). Peripheral glands show hyperthermia changes: cytoplasmic vacuolation, pyknotic nuclei (b). Hyperthermia (HIFU/microwave/laser) causes coagulative necrosis, granulation tissue, fibrosis. Residual glands: atrophic, basal cell predominance.
2485.original_caption: Transurethral resection of prostate (TURP) that was previously treated with laser ablation. The specimen contains a fibrotic area surrounded by inflammation (a). The glands on the periphery show hyperthermia-induced changes including cytoplasmic vacuolation and pyknotic nuclei (b). Hyperthermia uses high temperature generated by various sources (high-intensity focused ultrasound, microwave, and laser) to destroy prostate tissue. It produces circumscribed hemorrhagic and coagulative necrosis that later organizes with granulation tissue and fibrosis. Residual prostate glands often are atrophic, with basal cell predominance

2489.caption: HGPIN diagnosed by mitotic figures (a,b, arrow), pleomorphic nuclei (c,d) in glands with HGPIN morphology, inconspicuous nucleoli
2489.original_caption: HGPIN can be diagnosed when there are mitotic figures (a and b, arrow) and/or pleomorphic nuclei (c and d) in glands with HGPIN-associated morphological features but inconspicuous nucleoli

2499.caption: Cowpers glands: extraprostatic structures in urogenital diaphragm, rarely biopsied. Composed of dimorphic ducts, mucinous acini mixed with skeletal muscle fibers.
2499.original_caption: Cowpers glands. They are extraprostatic structures found within the urogenital diaphragm, and therefore are rarely sampled in the biopsy from the apex. They are composed of a dimorphic population of ducts and mucinous acini intermixed with skeletal muscle fibers (a and b)

2491.caption: HGPIN diagnosed by mitotic figures (a,b, arrow) and/or pleomorphic nuclei (c,d) in glands with HGPIN morphology but inconspicuous nucleoli
2491.original_caption: HGPIN can be diagnosed when there are mitotic figures (a and b, arrow) and/or pleomorphic nuclei (c and d) in glands with HGPIN-associated morphological features but inconspicuous nucleoli

2494.caption: Verumontanum mucosal gland hyperplasia. Rare in needle biopsy, packed small acini under urethral mucosa. Orange-brown dense secretion in glandular lumens.
2494.original_caption: Verumontanum mucosal gland hyperplasia. Rarely sampled in needle biopsy, it comprises closely packed small acini beneath the urethral mucosa. Orange-brown dense secretion is found in glandular lumens

2496.caption: Paraganglia常见于前列腺周围软组织，由透明细胞小簇/巢组成，伴显著血管模式，与神经紧密关联(a)。细胞对突触素等神经内分泌标记物阳性(b)
2496.original_caption: Paraganglia are found most commonly in periprostatic soft tissue. They are composed of small clusters or nests of clear cells with a prominent vascular pattern and are intimately associated with nerves (a). Cells are positive for neuroendocrine markers such as synaptophysin (b)

2506.caption: Atypical glands, suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. Small focus of crowded large-mid glands with undulated architecture, papillation, nuclear stratification, eosinophilia. High-power shows cytological atypia. Immunostains: rare basal cells, AMACR+. HGPIN cannot be excluded.
2506.original_caption: Atypical glands suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. Diagnosis of a small focus of pseudohyperplastic prostate carcinoma in needle biopsy should be made with extreme caution. (a–d) In this example, there is a small focus of crowded large- to mid-size glands with undulated architecture, papillation and nuclear stratification, and dense cytoplasmic eosinophilia, suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma (a). High-power view demonstrates marked cytological atypia (b). Immunostains show these glands demonstrating rare basal cells (c) and are strongly positive for AMACR (d). Note here that the focus of concern is very small and a diagnosis of HGPIN cannot be excluded based on morphology or immunoprofile.

2507.caption: Atypical glands, pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. Small focus in biopsy: crowded large-mid glands, undulated architecture, papillation, nuclear stratification, eosinophilia. High-power: cytological atypia. Immunostains: rare basal cells, AMACR+. Small focus, HGPIN not excluded.
2507.original_caption: Atypical glands suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. 2497.caption: Seminal vesicle/ejaculatory ducts indistinguishable in prostate biopsies. Irregular lumen surrounded by small glands with degenerative nuclear atypia, golden brown pigment. May mimic HGPIN or radiation changes.
2497.original_caption: Seminal vesicle/ejaculatory ducts. On prostate biopsies, the two structures cannot be distinguished reliably as they have similar morphology. They have a central irregular lumen with surrounding clusters of smaller glands whose cells display scattered but prominent degenerative nuclear atypia and golden brown pigment in cytoplasm and prostate carcinoma. They may be mistaken for HGPIN, radiationinduced changes

2498.caption: Cowpers glands: extraprostatic structures in urogenital diaphragm, rarely biopsied. Composed of dimorphic ducts, mucinous acini mixed with skeletal muscle fibers.

2502.caption: Pseudohyperplastic prostate carcinoma. Crowded large dilated glands with branching, papillary infoldings, luminal secretions mimic BPH. Small acinar cancer glands present. Cytoplasmic amphophilia, nuclear atypia in large/small glands. Needle biopsy shows bland large glands but crowded, mixed with small glands. Single-layer nuclei with enlargement, prominent nucleoli. Lacks basal
2502.original_caption: Pseudohyperplastic prostate carcinoma. (a, b) At low magnification, pseudohyperplastic carcinoma demonstrates crowded proliferation of large dilated glands with branching and papillary infoldings and luminal secretions. These glands are deceptively bland at low power and mimic BPH. Also note the presence of small conventional acinar cancer glands (arrow, a). At high magnification, both large and small glands display cytoplasmic amphophilia and nuclear atypia suggestive of cancer (b). (c) Another pseudohyperplastic carcinoma in needle biopsy. Note relatively deceptive, bland appearance of large glands at low power. Crowding, admixture with some small glands and differences in cytoplasmic characteristics bring attention to these glands at low power (c). At higher magnification, single layer of nuclei, with nuclear enlargement and prominent nucleoli, is visible (d-e). The lack of basal cell markers (HMWCK and p63) and strong AMACR expression (f) support the diagnosis of pseudohyperplastic prostate carcinoma

2521.caption: Ductal carcinoma shows intraductal spread. Ductal adenocarcinoma: pattern 4; intraluminal necrosis or solid architecture = pattern 5.
2521.original_caption: (e) Ductal carcinoma often demonstrates intraductal spread. (f) Ductal adenocarcinoma is graded as pattern 4; cases with intraluminal necrosis (shown) or with solid architecture are graded as pattern 5

2520.caption: Ductal carcinoma shows intraductal spread. Ductal adenocarcinoma: pattern 4; intraluminal necrosis/solid architecture = pattern 5.
2520.original_caption: (e) Ductal carcinoma often demonstrates intraductal spread. (f) Ductal adenocarcinoma is graded as pattern 4; cases with intraluminal necrosis (shown) or with solid architecture are graded as pattern 5

2518.caption: Ductal adenocarcinoma with papillary/solid-papillary growth, often as urethral polypoid mass. Prominent papillary/solid architecture in transurethral specimens, challenging distinction from urothelial carcinoma.
2518.original_caption: (c–d) Ductal adenocarcinoma with papillary and solid-papillary growth patterns. Ductal adenocarcinoma often grows within the urethra as a papillary or polypoid mass. The tumor often has prominent papillary or solid architecture that is typically encountered in transurethral resection specimens where the distinction from urothelial carcinoma could be problematic.

2519.caption: Ductal adenocarcinoma with papillary/solid-papillary growth, often urethral polypoid mass. Prominent papillary/solid architecture in transurethral specimens, challenging distinction from urothelial carcinoma.
2519.original_caption: (c–d) Ductal adenocarcinoma with papillary and solid-papillary growth patterns. Ductal adenocarcinoma often grows within the urethra as a papillary or polypoid mass. The tumor often has prominent papillary or solid architecture that is typically encountered in transurethral resection specimens where the distinction from urothelial carcinoma could be problematic.

2523.caption: Ductal carcinoma in needle biopsy: fragmented. Cribriform glands (a) with slit-like lumina, pseudostratified tall columnar epithelium (b). Fibrovascular cores suggest papillary architecture (arrow, b).
2523.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in needle biopsy often is fragmented. Note confluent proliferation of cribriform glands (a) with slit-like lumina and pseudostratified tall columnar epithelium (b). Also note the presence of fibrovascular cores in some glands suggesting a papillary architecture (arrow, b)

2511.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Low-power shows scant amphophilic cytoplasm mimicking benign glands, with infiltrative growth (arrows). Higher mag reveals retained cytoplasm and malignant features. Cancer glands lack basal cell markers; benign glands stain strongly.
2511.original_caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. (a–c) At low-power examination, the cancer glands demonstrate scant amphopilic cytoplasm mimicking partially atrophic benign glands. However, infiltrative growth is obvious (arrows, a). At higher magnification, the cancer glands are not completely atrophic and still retain a small amount of cytoplasm. Also note that the cancer glands display unequivocal malignant histologic features (b). Cancer glands lack immunohistochemical markers for basal cells; benign glands demonstrate strong staining (c).

2513.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Cancer glands show basophilic appearance mimicking atrophic glands (d). Cytological atypia indicates malignancy (e). PIN-4 shows absent basal cells and AMACR+, confirming cancer (f).
2513.original_caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. (d–f)Another example in biopsy. Cancer glands impart a basophilic appearance at low power due to marked reduction in cytoplasm mimicking completely atrophic glands (d). Significant cytological atypia argues against the diagnosis of benign atrophy (e). PIN-4 cocktail antibodies demonstrate lack of basal cell expression and strong expression of AMACR, supporting the diagnosis of cancer (f).

2512.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Low-power shows scant amphophilic cytoplasm mimicking benign atrophic glands, with infiltrative growth (arrows). Higher mag reveals retained cytoplasm and malignant features. Cancer glands lack basal cell markers; benign glands stain strongly.
2512.original_caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. (a–c) At low-power examination, the cancer glands demonstrate scant amphopilic cytoplasm mimicking partially atrophic benign glands. However, infiltrative growth is obvious (arrows, a). At higher magnification, the cancer glands are not completely atrophic and still retain a small amount of cytoplasm. Also note that the cancer glands display unequivocal malignant histologic features (b). Cancer glands lack immunohistochemical markers for basal cells; benign glands demonstrate strong staining (c).

2515.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Cancer glands show basophilic appearance mimicking atrophic glands (d). Cytological atypia indicates malignancy (e). PIN-4 shows absent basal cells and AMACR+, confirming cancer (f).
2515.original_caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. (d–f)Another example in biopsy. Cancer glands impart a basophilic appearance at low power due to marked reduction in cytoplasm mimicking completely atrophic glands (d). Significant cytological atypia argues against the diagnosis of benign atrophy (e). PIN-4 cocktail antibodies demonstrate lack of basal cell expression and strong expression of AMACR, supporting the diagnosis of cancer (f).

2514.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Biopsy shows basophilic cancer glands mimicking atrophy (d). Cytological atypia excludes benign atrophy (e). PIN-4 shows absent basal cells and AMACR+, confirming cancer (f).
2514.original_caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. (d–f)Another example in biopsy. Cancer glands impart a basophilic appearance at low power due to marked reduction in cytoplasm mimicking completely atrophic glands (d). Significant cytological atypia argues against the diagnosis of benign atrophy (e). PIN-4 cocktail antibodies demonstrate lack of basal cell expression and strong expression of AMACR, supporting the diagnosis of cancer (f).

2522.caption: Ductal carcinoma in needle biopsy often fragmented. Cribriform glands (a) with slit-like lumina, pseudostratified tall columnar epithelium (b). Fibrovascular cores suggest papillary architecture (arrow, b).
2522.original_caption: Ductal carcinoma in needle biopsy often is fragmented. Note confluent proliferation of cribriform glands (a) with slit-like lumina and pseudostratified tall columnar epithelium (b). Also note the presence of fibrovascular cores in some glands suggesting a papillary architecture (arrow, b)

2509.caption: Atypical glands suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. Small focus shows crowded large-mid glands with undulated architecture, papillation, nuclear stratification, eosinophilia (a). High-power shows cytological atypia (b). Immunostains: rare basal cells (c), strong AMACR+ (d). Very small focus; HGPIN not excluded.
2509.original_caption: Atypical glands suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma. Diagnosis of a small focus of pseudohyperplastic prostate carcinoma in needle biopsy should be made with extreme caution. (a–d) In this example, there is a small focus of crowded large- to mid-size glands with undulated architecture, papillation and nuclear stratification, and dense cytoplasmic eosinophilia, suspicious for pseudohyperplastic carcinoma (a). High-power view demonstrates marked cytological atypia (b). Immunostains show these glands demonstrating rare basal cells (c) and are strongly positive for AMACR (d). Note here that the focus of concern is very small and a diagnosis of HGPIN cannot be excluded based on morphology or immunoprofile.

2524.caption: Mucinous (colloid) carcinoma. Cancer cells float in extracellular mucin, form acini/cribriform patterns (vs conventional acinar carcinoma). Bland cytology. Strong PSA reactivity confirms prostate primary. Discrete glands with cribriform foci (arrow) in mucin pool. Intraluminal collagenous nodules (arrowheads) present. Gleason 3+4
2524.original_caption: Mucinous (colloid) carcinoma. (a–d) Cancer cells float in lakes of extracellular mucin (a) and are arranged in acini and cribriform growth pattern. This is distinct from the intraluminal mucin seen in conventional prostate acinar carcinoma. Cytologically, they usually appear bland (b). Tumor cells in this case demonstrated strong PSA reactivity supporting the diagnosis of primary prostate cancer (c). Example of prostate carcinoma with mucinous features demonstrating well-formed discrete glands with occasional cribriform gland (arrow), floating within the mucin pool. Also note the presence of intraluminal collagenous nodule in some glands (arrowheads), which is common in this variant morphology. Gleason pattern (3 + 4 = 7 in d)

2516.caption: Ductal prostate adenocarcinoma spectrum. (a) Nodule shows endometrioid growth, cribriform/papillary patterns, slit-like lumina, tall columnar epithelium. (b) PIN-like variant: pseudostratified tall columnar cells mimicking HGPIN; distinguished by large glands, crowding vs HGPIN/acinar cancer.
2516.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of ductal prostate adenocarcinoma. (a) Large nodule of ductal adenocarcinoma showing endometrioid growth pattern with admixture of confluent cribriform and papillary patterns with irregular slit-like lumina and glands lined by tall columnar lining epithelium. (b) PIN-like ductal adenocarcinoma often has large well-formed glands lined by pseudostratified tall columnar cells, mimicking HGPIN. Large glandular architecture and tall columnar celllining distinguishes PIN-like ductal adenocarcinoma from conventional acinar cancer. Marked glandular crowding distinguishes it from HGPIN.

2510.caption: Prostate adenocarcinoma with atrophic features. Low-power shows scant amphophilic cytoplasm mimicking benign glands, with infiltrative growth (arrows). Higher mag reveals partial atrophy, minimal cytoplasm, malignant features. Cancer glands lack basal cell markers; benign glands stain strongly.

2538.caption: Benign glands with radiation atypia, basal cell hyperplasia (a), p63+ (b), squamous metaplasia common.
2538.original_caption: Benign glands showing radiation atypia with basal cell hyperplasia (a) confirmed by the immunostain for p63 (b). Squamous cell metaplasia is also commonly seen

2536.caption: Benign glands with radiation atypia. Irregular contour, multilayered cells. Eosinophilic cytoplasm, piled-up degenerative nuclei. Scattered enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei.
2536.original_caption: Benign glands showing radiation atypia. The gland has an irregular contour and is lined with multiple layers of cells. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic rather than being clear. The nuclei are piled up with degenerative appearance. There are scattered, enlarged, and hyperchromatic nuclei

2532.caption: Amphophilic/dark cytoplasm in cancer vs. benign clear cytoplasm. Low-power clue with infiltrative growth. Minor features aid diagnosis, atypical glands stand out.
2532.original_caption: amphophilic cytoplasm. Compared with benign glands with clear cytoplasm, cancer glands often have amphophilic, or dark, cytoplasm. This feature can be appreciated at low scanning power and, together with the infiltrative growth pattern, often provides the first clue to the presence of cancer in the biopsy. Although less strongly associated with cancer and may be seen in noncancer lesions, minor histological features associated with cancer are diagnostically very helpful as the atypical glands with these minor features usually appear significantly different and therefore stand out from the benign glands

2541.caption: Weak AMACR staining in foamy gland carcinoma. Typical acinar cancer glands show strong AMACR positivity, foamy gland cancer (arrow) weakly positive.
2541.original_caption: Weak AMACR staining in foamy gland carcinoma. The typical acinar cancer glands are strongly positive for AMACR expression, while foamy gland cancer (arrow) is only weakly positive

2537.caption: Benign glands with radiation atypia, basal cell hyperplasia (a), p63+ (b). Squamous metaplasia common.
2537.original_caption: Benign glands showing radiation atypia with basal cell hyperplasia (a) confirmed by the immunostain for p63 (b). Squamous cell metaplasia is also commonly seen

2540.caption: Prostate cancer glands with radiation effect: atrophic cytoplasm, pyknotic nuclei (a), mimics benign atrophy. Shows infiltrative growth pattern. p63-, AMACR+ (b).
2540.original_caption: Prostate cancer glands with radiation effect. The cancer glands show atrophic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei (a) indistinguishable from benign atrophy. However, they exhibit characteristic “infiltra-tive growth pattern.” They are negative for p63 but positive for D-methylacyl-CoA racemase (AMACR) (b).

2531.caption: Amphophilic/dark cytoplasm in cancer vs benign clear cytoplasm. Seen at low power, with infiltrative growth, suggests cancer. Minor features aid diagnosis as atypical glands stand out from benign.
2531.original_caption: amphophilic cytoplasm. Compared with benign glands with clear cytoplasm, cancer glands often have amphophilic, or dark, cytoplasm. This feature can be appreciated at low scanning power and, together with the infiltrative growth pattern, often provides the first clue to the presence of cancer in the biopsy. 2530.caption: Nuclear atypia with prominent nucleoli in cancer cells (a). Tissue processing affects nucleolar visibility: alcohol fixatives obscure nuclear detail (b), Hollandes enhances nucleoli (c).
2530.original_caption: nuclear atypia  prominent nucleoli. Compared to the adjacent benign glands, the cancer cells have prominent nucleoli (a). However, nucleolar prominence depends on the several tissue processing factors, including fixation, tissue section thickness, and staining protocols. Alcohol-based fixatives often obscure the nuclear detail with blurred chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli (b) whereas Hollandes fixative enhances nucleoli with visible nucleoli even in basal cells of benign glands (c)

2529.caption: Nuclear atypia with prominent nucleoli in cancer cells (a). Tissue processing affects nucleolar visibility: alcohol fixatives obscure nuclear detail (b), Hollandes enhances nucleoli even in benign glands (c).
2529.original_caption: nuclear atypia  prominent nucleoli. Compared to the adjacent benign glands, the cancer cells have prominent nucleoli (a). 2539.caption: Prostate cancer glands w/ radiation effect: atrophic cytoplasm, pyknotic nuclei (a), mimics benign atrophy. Shows infiltrative growth. p63-, AMACR+ (b).
2539.original_caption: Prostate cancer glands with radiation effect. The cancer glands show atrophic cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei (a) indistinguishable from benign atrophy. However, they exhibit characteristic “infiltra-tive growth pattern.” They are negative for p63 but positive for D-methylacyl-CoA racemase (AMACR) (b).

2544.caption: Positive AMACR staining converts ATYP to cancer. Needle biopsy shows atypical glands with architectural atypia, minimal cytological atypia (a). Negative for K903 (b), highly suspicious but not diagnostic due to absent nuclear atypia. Strong AMACR+ (c). Cancer diagnosis based on morphology, negative basal markers, and AMACR+.
2544.original_caption: Positive AMACR staining converts an ATYP to cancer diagnosis. A needle biopsy contains a small focus of atypical glands with architectural atypia but minimal cytological atypia (a). These glands are negative for basal cell marker K903 (b). These glands are highly suspicious for but not diagnostic of cancer due to lack of nuclear atypia. These glands are strongly positive for AMACR (c). A cancer diagnosis was established based on the morphological features, negative basal cell marker, and positive AMACR staining

2542.caption: Positive AMACR staining converts ATYP to cancer. Needle biopsy shows atypical glands with architectural atypia, minimal cytological atypia (a). Negative for K903 (b), highly suspicious but not diagnostic due to lack of nuclear atypia. Strong AMACR positivity (c). Cancer diagnosis based on morphology, negative K903, positive AMACR.

2535.caption: Benign prostatic tissue with radiation atypia. Atrophic glands retain lobular architecture (a). Irregular glands lined by p63+ basal cells (b). Prominent stroma. Radiation vascular changes: intimal thickening, atheroma-like changes, medial fibrosis (c). Changes vary by dose/duration/treatment interval. Diagnose as benign with radiation atypia.
2535.original_caption: Benign prostatic tissue showing radiation atypia. Benign glands are markedly atrophic but still maintain their lobular architecture (a). Glands have a highly irregular contour and are lined predominantly with basal cells confirmed by the immunohistochemical stain for p63 (b). The stroma is prominent. Radiation-induced vascular changes, including intimal thickening with atheroma-like changes and medial fibrosis (c), can be seen. The degree of radiation-induced changes varies with the dose and duration and the interval between treatments. Such a biopsy should be signed out as benign prostatic tissue with radiation atypia

2545.caption: Heterogeneous AMACR staining in prostate cancer: strong in some glands, weak/negative in others. Typical pattern, 80% positive rate in needle biopsy.
2545.original_caption: Heterogeneous AMACR staining in cancer glands. The staining is strong in some cancer glands and weak or negative in others. This staining pattern is typical in prostate cancer and accounts for an 80% AMACR positive rate in prostate cancer detected on needle biopsy

2547.caption: Prostate biopsy core shows scant fibroadipose tissue, no prostatic glands. Signed out as fibromuscular tissue only. Inadequate biopsy material should be reported to urologist.
2547.original_caption: A prostate biopsy core contains scant amount of fibroadipose tissue and no prostate glands. It is signed out as fibromuscular tissue only; no prostatic glands present. If the biopsy contains a scant amount of tissue or fibromuscular tissue only, it should be mentioned so that the inadequacy of the biopsy material can be brought to the attention of the urologists who performed the biopsy

2546.caption: Prostate biopsy core: stromal nodule with bland spindle cells, hyalinized small vessels, lymphocytic infiltrates. Not hyperplastic tissue/BPH as needle biopsy rarely samples transition zones.
2546.original_caption: A prostate biopsy core containing a stromal nodule with bland spindle cells, several small vessels with hyalinized wall, and lymphocytic infiltrates. It is recommended not to diagnose such a prostate biopsy as hyperplastic prostate tissue or benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) as transrectal prostate needle biopsy typically does not sample transition zones that BPH most commonly affects.

Diagnose as benign prostatic tissue with radiation atypia.

2548.caption: Prostate biopsy shows benign tissue with focal acute glandular inflammation. Avoid "prostatitis" term as it's a clinical diagnosis, not always indicated by microscopic inflammation.
2548.original_caption: A prostate biopsy contains acute inflammation within the lumens of several glands. This biopsy is signed out as benign prostatic tissue with focal acute inflammation. Use of the term prostatitis is discouraged because prostatitis is a clinical diagnosis and microscopic inflammation does not always indicate a clinical prostatitis

2549.caption: Normal prostate glands show irregular contour, luminal undulation, papillary infoldings
2549.original_caption: Normal prostate glands have irregular contour with luminal undulation and papillary infoldings

2554.caption: Focal atrophy pseudoinfiltrative growth. (a-b) Benign atrophic glands with haphazard/pseudoinfiltrative pattern may raise concern (a,b).
2554.original_caption: Pseudoinfiltrative growth patterns in focal atrophy. (a–b) Benign atrophic glands with haphazard or pseudoinfiltrative growth pattern may raise concern at low-power examination (a and b).

2555.caption: Focal atrophy with pseudoinfiltrative growth. (a-b) Benign atrophic glands show haphazard/pseudoinfiltrative pattern, concerning at low-power.
2555.original_caption: Pseudoinfiltrative growth patterns in focal atrophy. (a–b) Benign atrophic glands with haphazard or pseudoinfiltrative growth pattern may raise concern at low-power examination (a and b).

2550.caption: Benign prostatic tissue. Prostate glands medium-large, lobulated with fibromuscular stroma.
2550.original_caption: Benign prostatic tissue. At scanning power, prostate glands are medium to large in size and form lobulated architecture with intervening fibromuscular stroma

2552.caption: Postatrophic hyperplasia (PAH): lobulated small dark atrophic acini around dilated duct. Low power mimics cancer (scant cytoplasm). High power shows cuboidal cells with minimal nuclear enlargement, high N:C ratio, small nucleoli. Sclerotic stroma.
2552.original_caption: Postatrophic hyperplasia. (a) At low power, PAH is characterized by a circumscribed/lobulated collection of small dark atrophic acini with round-to-distorted contours arranged around a larger dilated duct (arrow; a and b). The dark appearance of the lesion at low power may arouse a suspicion for cancer but is due to scant cytoplasm rather than abundant amphophilic/granular cytoplasm seen in cancer. At high magnification (c), the acini are lined by cuboidal secretory cells with minimal nuclear enlargement, increased nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and small but visible nucleoli. The stroma is usually sclerotic

2553.caption: Postatrophic hyperplasia (PAH): lobulated small dark atrophic acini around dilated duct (arrows). Scant cytoplasm mimics cancer but lacks amphophilic/granular cytoplasm. High mag shows cuboidal cells with minimal nuclear enlargement, high N:C ratio, small nucleoli. Sclerotic stroma.

2557.caption: Adenosis (atypical adenomatous hyperplasia). Circumscribed variably sized glands with small round acini and larger benign glands with papillary infolding. Columnar cells show pale/clear cytoplasm, bland nuclei, small nucleoli. Cellular stroma suggests benign nature. Patchy basal cell markers; ~30% show mild-moderate AMACR expression.
2557.original_caption: Adenosis (atypical adenomatous hyperplasia). (a–f) At low power, adenosis is characterized by a circumscribed collection of variably sized glands (a). Within the nodule, small round acini are admixed with larger benign-appearing glands with papillary infolding (arrows). There are no obvious cytoplasmic or cytological differences between them. Essentially, small and large glands merge with each other imperceptibly (b). At high power, the columnar cells have abundant pale to clear cytoplasm and bland-appearing nuclei with inconspicuous to small nucleoli (c). The stroma between the glands is cellular, a feature to suggest a benign reactive nature (d). Basal cell markers typically demonstrate a discontinuous/patchy-staining pattern, with some glands lacking the staining (e). A small percentage (~30%) of adenosis lesions may demonstrate mild-to-moderate AMACR expression (f)

2559.caption: Adenosis (atypical adenomatous hyperplasia). Circumscribed variably sized glands with small round acini mixed with larger benign glands showing papillary infolding. Columnar cells have pale/clear cytoplasm, bland nuclei, small nucleoli. Cellular stroma suggests benign nature. Patchy basal cell marker staining, some glands lack staining. ~30% show mild-moderate

2565.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia spectrum: well-circumscribed nodule (basal cell adenoma) with stratified high N:C ratio cells, basophilic at low mag (a). Incomplete shows luminal differentiation (b); complete has dark nests in cellular stroma, no lumens (c). Nuclei cigar-packed, coffee bean-like with grooves/glassy chromatin, prominent nucleoli
2565.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of basal cell hyperplasia. (a–f) A well-circumscribed nodule of basal cell hyperplasia, also referred to as basal cell adenoma in transurethral resection specimen, is a form of epithelial hyperplasia in which glands have markedly stratified lining cells with high N:C ratio, and appears basophilic at low magnification (a). In incomplete basal cell hyperplasia, a luminal differentiation is seen (b). In complete basal cell hyperplasia, dark-staining nests are seen in a cellular stroma. Note the lack of lumen formation. The presence of cellular spindly stroma is a feature suggestive of the benign proliferative nature (c). In basal cell hyperplasia, nuclei are stratified, arranged like a pack of cigar without visible cytoplasm (c) and are coffee bean–like with frequent grooves and vesicular glassy chromatin. Prominent nucleoli are frequently seen (arrows in d). Basal cell hyperplasia can also present with adenoid cystic carcinoma-like cribriform architecture simulating cribriform carcinoma. Also note cellular spindly stroma (e). Intraluminal calcifications and cytoplasmic hyaline globules can be seen in basal cell hyperplasia (f)

2562.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia spectrum: well-circumscribed nodule (basal cell adenoma) with stratified high N:C ratio glands, basophilic at low power. Incomplete shows luminal differentiation; complete has dark nests in cellular stroma, no lumens. Nuclei cigar-packed, coffee bean-like with grooves/glassy chromatin, prominent nucleoli. May mimic adenoid cystic
2562.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of basal cell hyperplasia. In incomplete basal cell hyperplasia, a luminal differentiation is seen (b). In complete basal cell hyperplasia, dark-staining nests are seen in a cellular stroma. Note the lack of lumen formation. The presence of cellular spindly stroma is a feature suggestive of the benign proliferative nature (c). In basal cell hyperplasia, nuclei are stratified, arranged like a pack of cigar without visible cytoplasm (c) and are coffee bean–like with frequent grooves and vesicular glassy chromatin. Prominent nucleoli are frequently seen (arrows in d). Basal cell hyperplasia can also present with adenoid cystic carcinoma-like cribriform architecture simulating cribriform carcinoma. Also note cellular spindly stroma (e). Intraluminal calcifications and cytoplasmic hyaline globules can be seen in basal cell hyperplasia (f)

The stroma between the glands is cellular, a feature to suggest a benign reactive nature (d). Basal cell markers typically demonstrate a discontinuous/patchy-staining pattern, with some glands lacking the staining (e). A small percentage (~30%) of adenosis lesions may demonstrate mild-to-moderate AMACR expression (f)

2568.caption: Paraganglia mimic high-grade prostate carcinoma, extraprostatic extension. Small solid nests of cells with clear cytoplasm, delicate vascular network (Zellballen), resemble Gleason 4/5. Cells show clear-amphophilic granular cytoplasm, hyperchromatic nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli. Neuroendocrine markers (synaptophysin) aid diagnosis.
2568.original_caption: Paraganglia mimicking high-grade prostate carcinoma and extraprostatic extension. (a) At low power, paraganglia consist of small, solid nests of cells with clear cytoplasm separated by a delicate vascular network, mimicking high-grade Gleason pattern 4 or 5 prostate carcinoma. Its presence in adipose tissue may further impart an impression of extraprostatic tumor extension (a). At high power, the cells have clear to amphophilic, finely granular cytoplasm. Random cytological atypia may be seen and nuclei are often hyperchromatic, but nucleoli are inconspicuous (b). Recognition of the delicate vascular network pattern referred to as the Zellballen arrangement is an important clue. In difficult cases, positive neuroendocrine markers support the diagnosis (c, synaptophysin)

2563.caption: Basal cell hyperplasia: nodular epithelial hyperplasia, high N:C ratio, basophilic. Incomplete form shows luminal differentiation; complete form has dark nests, no lumina, cellular stroma. Nuclei stratified, cigar-like, coffee bean with grooves, vesicular chromatin, prominent nucleoli. May mimic adenoid cystic carcinoma (cribriform). Stroma spindly.
2563.original_caption: Morphological spectrum of basal cell hyperplasia. (a–f) A well-circumscribed nodule of basal cell hyperplasia, also referred to as basal cell adenoma in transurethral resection specimen, is a form of epithelial hyperplasia in which glands have markedly stratified lining cells with high N:C ratio, and appears basophilic at low magnification (a). In incomplete basal cell hyperplasia, a luminal differentiation is seen (b). In complete basal cell hyperplasia, dark-staining nests are seen in a cellular stroma. Note the lack of lumen formation. The presence of cellular spindly stroma is a feature suggestive of the benign proliferative nature (c). In basal cell hyperplasia, nuclei are stratified, arranged like a pack of cigar without visible cytoplasm (c) and are coffee bean–like with frequent grooves and vesicular glassy chromatin. Prominent nucleoli are frequently seen (arrows in d). Basal cell hyperplasia can also present with adenoid cystic carcinoma-like cribriform architecture simulating cribriform carcinoma. Also note cellular spindly stroma (e). Intraluminal calcifications and cytoplasmic hyaline globules can be seen in basal cell hyperplasia (f)

2561.caption: Adenosis (atypical adenomatous hyperplasia). Circumscribed variably sized glands with small acini mixed with larger benign glands showing papillary infolding. 2585.caption: EBER1-3 in situ hybridization shows strong nuclear staining in extranodal T/NK lymphoma, nasal type.
2585.original_caption: In situ hybridization for the detection of Epstein-Barr virus, probe cocktail directed against EBER1 to 3. High-power view showing strong nuclear staining in neoplastic cells of extranodal T- and natural killer lymphoma, nasal type.

2575.caption: Prostate needle biopsy: primary Gleason 3 (well-formed glands), secondary 4 (fused glands), tertiary 5 (cords/single cells). Grade 3+5.
2575.original_caption: Tertiary Gleason pattern 5. A prostate needle biopsy demonstrating primary pattern 3 (well-formed discrete glands, upper right), secondary pattern 4 (poorly formed fused glands, arrows), and tertiary pattern 5 (cords and individual single cells, arrowheads); such a case should be graded 3 + 5

2588.caption: Detection of fungus by ISH. A: Aspergillus in brain biopsy using rRNA-targeted probes visualized with alkaline phosphatase/NBT/BCIP. B: Blastomyces detected by ISH.
2588.original_caption: Detection of fungus by in situ hybridization (ISH). ISH to detect specific fungal organisms. A, Detection of Aspergillus by ISH in a brain biopsy. The organisms are detected using oligonucleotide probes targeted at the ribosomal RNA visualized by alkaline phosphatase and nitroblue tetrazolium and 5-bromo-4chloro-3-indolyl phosphate. B, In situ hybridization detecting Blastomyces infection.

2578.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma of prostate: infiltrating nests of necrotic malignant cells amid benign glands & desmoplastic stroma. Squamous differentiation shown by cytoplasmic eosinophilia.
2578.original_caption: 6.14 Squamous cell carcinoma of the prostate. Pure SCC of the prostate, consisting of infiltrating nests of partially necrotic malignant cells between benign glands and a desmoplastic stroma (a). At higher magnification, evidence of squamous differentiation in the form of cytoplasmic eosinophilia is noted in some cells (b).

2587.caption: Two skin biopsies show lichenoid infiltrate, minimal epidermotropism (A,B). Features suggest mycosis fungoides, supported by clinical findings and persistent identical TCR gene rearrangement (insets).
2587.original_caption: Two skin biopsies taken from different sites at different times with a lichenoid infiltrate and minimal epidermotropism (A and B). Although the histologic features are not diagnostic on their own, a diagnosis of mycoses fungoides was established, given the more characteristic clinical features and presence of a persisting identical T-cell receptor gene rearrangement depicted in the insets.

2573.caption: Negative basal cell marker p63 supports cancer diagnosis. Biopsy shows small crowded infiltrative glands (a). Thick sections hinder cytology (b). Initial: atypical glands suspicious for cancer. Final diagnosis: cancer.
2573.original_caption: Negative basal cell marker staining supports a cancer diagnosis. This biopsy contains many small crowded glands that exhibit infiltrative growth (a). Evaluation of the cytological features of these glands is hampered by the thick tissue sections (b). Without further workup, the diagnosis would be atypical glands suspicious for cancer. By immunohistochemistry, the atypical glands are negative for basal cell marker p63 (c). The final diagnosis is cancer

(B) Peutz-Jeghers edema and active polyp with prominent bands of muscularis mucosae with an arborizing pattern at low magnification. The lamina propria usually lacks infl ammation.

2576.caption: Necrotizing squamous metaplasia of prostate, mimics SCC. TURP post-ablation shows necrotizing squamous metaplasia in hyperplastic glands. Lobulated at low power (a), no infiltrative features at high power (b), suggesting squamous metaplasia.
2576.original_caption: Necrotizing squamous metaplasia of prostate, mimicking SCC. This transurethral resection of the prostate after ablative therapy shows necrotizing squamous metaplasia within the hyperplastic prostate glands mimicking SCC. At low power, lobulated appearance of the lesion (a) and, at high power (b), lack of definitive infiltrative features suggest the diagnosis of squamous metaplasia.

2635.caption: IHC assesses HER2 protein expression at tumor cell membrane. Scores: 0 (no staining), 1 (partial weak staining), 2 (thin circumferential staining), 3 (thick circumferential staining ≥30% cells). Only 3+ correlates with HER2 gene amplification by FISH, indicating Herceptin therapy benefit.
2635.original_caption: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) for the assessment of the level of HER2 protein expression at the tumor cell membrane. The assessment of HER2 by IHC needs to be evaluated critically and semiquantitatively to be clinically relevant. HER2-negative cases either show an absence of membrane staining, and are scored as 0 (upper left panel), or demonstrate partial weak membrane staining of tumor cells with no complete circumferential staining, and are scored as 1 (upper right panel). Equivocal cases, scored as 2 , demonstrate circumferential membrane staining of tumor cells, but the staining ring is thin (lower left panel). HER2-positive cases demonstrate circumferential membrane staining of at least 30% of the tumor cells, but the staining ring is thick, has a retractile quality, and is scored as 3 (lower right panel). Only cases with strong circumferential membrane staining (3 ) show a good concordance with HER2 gene amplification by fl uorescence in situ hybridization, and it is these patients who should be considered candidates for targeted treatment and who are the most likely to benefi t from Herceptin therapy.

2661.caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (ARMS). Myogenin, early skeletal muscle transcription factor. Diffuse nuclear reactivity supports ARMS vs focal in embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.
2661.original_caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma (ARMS). Myogenin is a transcription factor expressed early in skeletal muscle differentiation. Diffuse nuclear reactivity supports a diagnosis of ARMS, because staining is usually focal in embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

2659.caption: Uterine serous carcinoma IHC. H&E stain. Ki-67 shows diffuse intense staining. P53 negative staining indicates frameshift/nonsense mutations.
2659.original_caption: Immunohistochemistry of uterine serous carcinoma. (A) Hematoxylin and eosin stain of a serous tumor. (B) Ki-67 stain of the serous tumor, showing diffuse, intense staining. (C) P53 stain with the negative staining often seen with frameshift and nonsense mutations.
