3230.original_caption: inverted follicular keratosis. The lesion has a smooth peripheral border and contains bland ­keratinocytes. An associated ectatic follicular infundibulum is seen. Many small keratinizing whorls of keratinocytes (squamous eddies) are seen.

3223.caption: Extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma with solid dermal invasion. B, Lymphatic tumor emboli. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma extends along sweat ducts.
3223.original_caption: extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma is associated with a solid dermal invasive component. B, lymphatic tumor emboli are seen. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma may extend along sweat ducts.

3216.caption: Dermatomyofibroma: myofibroblasts in ill-defined fascicles parallel to epidermis.
3216.original_caption: Dermatomyofibroma: myofibroblasts are arranged in ill-defined fascicles parallel to the overlying epidermis.

3222.caption: Extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma with solid dermal invasion. B, Lymphatic tumor emboli. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma extends along sweat ducts.
3222.original_caption: extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma is associated with a solid dermal invasive component. B, lymphatic tumor emboli are seen. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma may extend along sweat ducts.

3228.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Storiform pattern of uniform spindle cells. Subcutaneous infiltration entrapping fat cells.
3228.original_caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. (A) Storiform growth pattern of uniform, slender spindled cells. (B) Ineurofibromailtration into the subcutis resulting in entrapment of individual fat cells is typical.

3220.caption: Acral melanoma in situ: A) lentiginous pattern - melanocytes at base of elongated rete ridges. B) pagetoid pattern. C) Subungual melanoma in situ.
3220.original_caption: Acral melanoma in situ. A, acral in situ melanoma with prominent lentiginous pattern: melanocytes are disposed as solitary units along the base of elongated rete ridges. B, acral in situ melanoma with pagetoid pattern. c, Subungual melanoma in situ.

3221.caption: Extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma with solid dermal invasion. B, Lymphatic tumor emboli. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma extends along sweat ducts.
3221.original_caption: extramammary Pagets disease. A, Intraepidermal adenocarcinoma is associated with a solid dermal invasive component. B, lymphatic tumor emboli are seen. C, Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma may extend along sweat ducts.

3218.caption: Acral melanoma in situ: A) lentiginous pattern - melanocytes at base of elongated rete ridges. B) pagetoid pattern. C) Subungual melanoma in situ.
3218.original_caption: Acral melanoma in situ. A, acral in situ melanoma with prominent lentiginous pattern: melanocytes are disposed as solitary units along the base of elongated rete ridges. B, acral in situ melanoma with pagetoid pattern. c, Subungual melanoma in situ.

3219.caption: Acral melanoma in situ: A) lentiginous pattern, melanocytes at base of rete ridges. B) pagetoid pattern. C) subungual melanoma in situ.
3219.original_caption: Acral melanoma in situ. A, acral in situ melanoma with prominent lentiginous pattern: melanocytes are disposed as solitary units along the base of elongated rete ridges. B, acral in situ melanoma with pagetoid pattern. c, Subungual melanoma in situ.

3231.caption: Pigmented seborrheic keratosis with increased melanin in lesional keratinocytes, showing acanthotic pattern.
3231.original_caption: Pigmented seborrheic keratosis. There is an increased amount of melanin pigment within lesional keratinocytes. This lesion shows an acanthotic pattern.

3234.caption: Proliferative actinic keratosis. Thin rete ridge-like protrusions with atypical basilar keratinocytes.
3234.original_caption: Proliferative actinic keratosis. Thin extensions of rete ridge–like protrusions with atypical basilar ­keratinocytes are seen.

3235.caption: Pigmented actinic keratosis with increased melanin in keratinocytes, possibly due to melanophages or melanocytic hyperplasia.
3235.original_caption: Pigmented actinic keratosis. Actinic keratosis with an associated increase of melanin pigment deposition in keratinocytes. Sometimes pigmentation may also be related to the presence of melanophages or a melanocytic hyperplasia.

3237.caption: Pleomorphic sarcoma. Ulcerated dermal tumor extending into subcutis.
3237.original_caption: Pleomorphic sarcoma. A, Ulcerated dermal-based tumor that extends into the subcutis.

3238.caption: Lichen planopilaris. Interfollicular lichenoid dermatitis. Perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate.
3238.original_caption: lichen planopilaris. B, Interfollicular lichenoid dermatitis. C, perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate.

3236.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma. Pleomorphic tumor cells scattered among low-grade myxoid component, low cell density.
3236.original_caption: myxofibrosarcoma. B, pleomorphic tumor cells are scattered among the low grade appearing myxoid component of low cell density.

3248.caption: Lichen amyloidosis. Hyaline deposits in papillary dermis.
3248.original_caption: Lichen amyloidosis. Small hyaline deposits in papillary dermis.

3239.caption: Lichen planopilaris. Interfollicular lichenoid dermatitis. Perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate.
3239.original_caption: lichen planopilaris. B, Interfollicular lichenoid dermatitis. C, perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrate.

3246.caption: Hyaline amyloid with plasma cells. a, Pink on h&e. B, Orange on Congo red.
3246.original_caption: hyaline amyloid material associated with plasma cells. a, Pink appearance on h&e stain. B, orange color on Congo red stain.

3243.caption: Ganglion cyst contains mucin, fibrous wall. Myxoid degeneration in surrounding tissue. Cyst wall lacks epithelial lining.
3243.original_caption: Ganglion cyst. A, A ganglion cyst contains mucin and has a fibrous wall. B, Myxoid degeneration is often seen in the surrounding fibrous tissue. C, The cyst wall lacks an epithelial lining.

3244.caption: Ganglion cyst contains mucin, fibrous wall. Myxoid degeneration in surrounding tissue. Cyst wall lacks epithelial lining.
3244.original_caption: Ganglion cyst. A, A ganglion cyst contains mucin and has a fibrous wall. B, Myxoid degeneration is often seen in the surrounding fibrous tissue. C, The cyst wall lacks an epithelial lining.

3241.caption: Lupus erythematosus profundus. Lymphoid aggregates in lobules/septa. Lymphocyte infiltration, hyaline deposition between fat cells. Small round lymphocytes, some cluster around fat cells without ring formation.
3241.original_caption: lupus erythematosus profundus. A, lymphoid aggregates are present in the lobules and along the septa. B, Infiltration by lymphocytes and the deposition of hyaline material between the fat cells. C, the lymphocytes are small and round. Some lymphocytes may cluster around fat cells, but they do not form rings.

3242.caption: Lupus erythematosus profundus. A, lymphoid aggregates in lobules/septa. B, lymphocyte infiltration & hyaline deposition between fat cells. C, small round lymphocytes; may cluster around fat cells without ring formation.
3242.original_caption: lupus erythematosus profundus. A, lymphoid aggregates are present in the lobules and along the septa. B, Infiltration by lymphocytes and the deposition of hyaline material between the fat cells. C, the lymphocytes are small and round. Some lymphocytes may cluster around fat cells, but they do not form rings.

3245.caption: Ganglion cyst contains mucin, fibrous wall. Myxoid degeneration in surrounding tissue. Cyst wall lacks epithelial lining.
3245.original_caption: Ganglion cyst. A, A ganglion cyst contains mucin and has a fibrous wall. B, Myxoid degeneration is often seen in the surrounding fibrous tissue. C, The cyst wall lacks an epithelial lining.

3240.caption: Lupus erythematosus profundus. A, lymphoid aggregates in lobules/septa. B, lymphocyte infiltration & hyaline deposition between fat cells. C, small round lymphocytes; some cluster around fat cells without ring formation.
3240.original_caption: lupus erythematosus profundus. A, lymphoid aggregates are present in the lobules and along the septa. B, Infiltration by lymphocytes and the deposition of hyaline material between the fat cells. C, the lymphocytes are small and round. Some lymphocytes may cluster around fat cells, but they do not form rings.

3247.caption: Hyaline amyloid with plasma cells. Pink on H&E. Orange on Congo red.
3247.original_caption: hyaline amyloid material associated with plasma cells. a, Pink appearance on h&e stain. B, orange color on Congo red stain.

3252.caption: Sacral pit: shallow epidermal invagination into dermis, midline sacrum.
3252.original_caption: sacral pit. A shallow invagination of epidermis into the dermis characterizes the sacral pit or dimple arising in the midline of the sacrum.

3251.caption: HPV-related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts show papillomatosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, mostly infundibular keratinization. B, Some show trichilemmal keratinization. C, HPV-infected plantar cyst exhibits viropathic changes.
3251.original_caption: human papillomavirus related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts are characterized by varying degrees of papillomatosis, acanthosis, and hypergranulosis. Most verrucous cysts have infundibular (epidermoid) keratinization. B, Occasionally verrucous cysts can show trichilemmal keratinization. C, Viropathic changes of human papillomavirus are present in this HPV-infected plantar epidermal cyst.

3250.caption: HPV-related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts show papillomatosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, mostly infundibular keratinization. B, Rare trichilemmal keratinization. C, HPV-infected plantar cyst with viropathic changes.
3250.original_caption: human papillomavirus related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts are characterized by varying degrees of papillomatosis, acanthosis, and hypergranulosis. Most verrucous cysts have infundibular (epidermoid) keratinization. B, Occasionally verrucous cysts can show trichilemmal keratinization. C, Viropathic changes of human papillomavirus are present in this HPV-infected plantar epidermal cyst.

3249.caption: HPV-related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts show papillomatosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, mostly infundibular keratinization. B, Rarely trichilemmal keratinization. C, HPV-infected plantar cyst exhibits viropathic changes.
3249.original_caption: human papillomavirus related follicular cyst. A, Verrucous cysts are characterized by varying degrees of papillomatosis, acanthosis, and hypergranulosis. Most verrucous cysts have infundibular (epidermoid) keratinization. B, Occasionally verrucous cysts can show trichilemmal keratinization. C, Viropathic changes of human papillomavirus are present in this HPV-infected plantar epidermal cyst.

3253.caption: Solar lentigo. Elongated rete ridges with basal hyperpigmentation. Solar elastosis present.
3253.original_caption: Solar lentigo. B, histologically slightly elongated rete ridges show basal layer hyperpigmentation. there is associated solar elastosis.

3255.caption: Dermatofibroma: circumscribed dermal spindle cell tumor. Epidermis shows hyperplasia and basilar hyperpigmentation.
3255.original_caption: Dermatofibroma. Circumscribed dermal spindle cell tumor. The epidermis over the dermatofibroma often shows hyperplasia and basilar hyperpigmentation.

3254.caption: Lentigo simplex. Elongated epidermal rete ridges, basal layer hyperpigmentation, increased bland intraepidermal melanocytes.
3254.original_caption: Lentigo simplex. B, histologically the epidermal rete ridges are slightly elongated, associated with basal layer hyperpigmentation as well as a slight increase in the number of cytologically bland intraepidermal melanocytes.

3258.caption: Compound melanocytic nevus, flexural site, large nests, size/shape variation.
3258.original_caption: Melanocytic nevus of flexural site. a compound melanocytic nevus is present with many large nests and variation in the size and shape of nests.

3261.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. HPV cytopathic changes present.
3261.original_caption: squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. Human papillomavirus cytopathic changes are seen in this lesion.

3262.caption: Bowenoid SCC in irritated seborrheic keratosis. a) Broad seborrheic keratosis with edge atypia. B) Close-up shows SCC.
3262.original_caption: Bowenoid squamous cell carcinoma, arising in an irritated seborrheic keratosis. a, Scanning magnification reveals a broad seborrheic keratosis. at one edge, atypia is apparent. B, a close-up of this focus reveals squamous cell carcinoma.

3260.caption: Inflammatory verrucous epidermal nevus. Hyperkeratotic squamous proliferation. Psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with alternating hyperorthokeratosis, parakeratosis, dermal inflammation.
3260.original_caption: inflammatory verrucous epidermal nevus. a, Silhouette of a hyperkeratotic squamous proliferation. B, there is psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia associated with alternating hyperorthokeratosis and parakeratosis, and dermal inflammation.

3257.caption: Dermal scar. A, fibroblast proliferation in superficial dermis, fusiform nuclei parallel to surface, effaced epidermal rete ridges. B, Keloidal scars: broad, glassy collagen fibers.
3257.original_caption: Dermal scar. A, there is a proliferation of fibroblasts in the superficial dermis. their fusiform nuclei run parallel to the surface. epidermal rete ridges are effaced. B, Keloidal scars contain broad, glassy collagen fibers.

3256.caption: Dermal scar. A, fibroblast proliferation in superficial dermis, fusiform nuclei parallel to surface, effaced epidermal rete ridges. B, Keloidal scars: broad, glassy collagen fibers.
3256.original_caption: Dermal scar. A, there is a proliferation of fibroblasts in the superficial dermis. their fusiform nuclei run parallel to the surface. epidermal rete ridges are effaced. B, Keloidal scars contain broad, glassy collagen fibers.

3259.caption: Inflammatory verrucous epidermal nevus. Hyperkeratotic squamous proliferation. Psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with alternating hyperorthokeratosis, parakeratosis, and dermal inflammation.
3259.original_caption: inflammatory verrucous epidermal nevus. a, Silhouette of a hyperkeratotic squamous proliferation. B, there is psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia associated with alternating hyperorthokeratosis and parakeratosis, and dermal inflammation.

3268.caption: Trichilemmal cyst in dermis/subcutis, filled with eosinophilic keratinocytes. Outer layer tends to separate from cyst epithelium.
3268.original_caption: Trichilemmal cyst. a, trichilemmal cysts are located in the dermis or subcutis and the cysts are filled from large eosinophilic keratinocytes. C, the outer layer of trichilemmal cysts has a tendency to separate from the remainder of the cyst epithelium.

3270.caption: Trichilemmal cyst in dermis/subcutis, filled with eosinophilic keratinocytes. Outer layer tends to separate from cyst epithelium.
3270.original_caption: Trichilemmal cyst. a, trichilemmal cysts are located in the dermis or subcutis and the cysts are filled from large eosinophilic keratinocytes. C, the outer layer of trichilemmal cysts has a tendency to separate from the remainder of the cyst epithelium.

3269.caption: Trichilemmal cyst in dermis/subcutis, filled with eosinophilic keratinocytes. Outer layer tends to separate from cyst epithelium.
3269.original_caption: Trichilemmal cyst. a, trichilemmal cysts are located in the dermis or subcutis and the cysts are filled from large eosinophilic keratinocytes. C, the outer layer of trichilemmal cysts has a tendency to separate from the remainder of the cyst epithelium.

3275.caption: Reticulohistiocytoma. Large histiocytes, abundant eosinophilic ground glass cytoplasm.
3275.original_caption: Reticulohistiocytoma. large histiocytes with abundant eosinophilic ground glass cytoplasm.

3266.caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Nested epithelioid tumor cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Stroma hyalinized or myxoid.
3266.original_caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Nested arrangement of epithelioid tumor cells with relatively abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The stromal background is typically hyalinized but may be myxoid.

3265.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. Intraepidermal squamous proliferation with high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, darker than normal epidermis. Inflammation present. Basal layer shows bland keratinocytes; atypical keratinocytes mainly in spinous layer.
3265.original_caption: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. A, Scanning magnification shows an intraepidermal squamous proliferation composed of keratinocytes with a higher nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio than the non-neoplastic epidermis giving the carcinoma a darker appearance than the adjacent normal epidermis. There is associated inflammation. B, The basal cell layer shows bland keratinocytes. Atypical keratinocytes populate primarily the spinous cell layer.

3263.caption: Bowenoid SCC arising in irritated seborrheic keratosis. a) Broad seborrheic keratosis with edge atypia. B) Close-up shows SCC.
3263.original_caption: Bowenoid squamous cell carcinoma, arising in an irritated seborrheic keratosis. a, Scanning magnification reveals a broad seborrheic keratosis. at one edge, atypia is apparent. B, a close-up of this focus reveals squamous cell carcinoma.

3264.caption: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. Intraepidermal squamous proliferation with high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, darker than normal epidermis. Inflammation present. Basal layer shows bland keratinocytes; atypical keratinocytes mainly in spinous layer.
3264.original_caption: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ, bowenoid pattern. A, Scanning magnification shows an intraepidermal squamous proliferation composed of keratinocytes with a higher nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio than the non-neoplastic epidermis giving the carcinoma a darker appearance than the adjacent normal epidermis. There is associated inflammation. B, The basal cell layer shows bland keratinocytes. Atypical keratinocytes populate primarily the spinous cell layer.

3273.caption: Neuronevus. A, Compound melanocytic nevus with neurotized dermal component. B, Nests of epithelioid melanocytes and fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features. C, Epithelioid melanocytes Melan-A+; fusiform negative. D, Neuroid structures present.
3273.original_caption: neuronevus. A, Silhouette of a compound melanocytic nevus with neurotization of its dermal component. B, Superficially a mixture of nests of small epithelioid melanocytes and diffuse arrangement of fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features is seen. c, only the epithelioid melanocytes are immunoreactive for melan-a. the fusiform melanocytes are negative. d, Neuroid structures are present.

3272.caption: Neuronevus. A, Compound melanocytic nevus with neurotized dermal component. B, Mixture of epithelioid melanocyte nests and fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features. C, Epithelioid cells melan-A+; fusiform cells negative. D, Neuroid structures present.
3272.original_caption: neuronevus. A, Silhouette of a compound melanocytic nevus with neurotization of its dermal component. B, Superficially a mixture of nests of small epithelioid melanocytes and diffuse arrangement of fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features is seen. c, only the epithelioid melanocytes are immunoreactive for melan-a. the fusiform melanocytes are negative. d, Neuroid structures are present.

3271.caption: Neuronevus. A, Compound melanocytic nevus with neurotization in dermal component. B, Mixture of nests of small epithelioid melanocytes and fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features. C, Epithelioid melanocytes melan-A+; fusiform melanocytes negative. D, Neuroid structures present.
3271.original_caption: neuronevus. A, Silhouette of a compound melanocytic nevus with neurotization of its dermal component. B, Superficially a mixture of nests of small epithelioid melanocytes and diffuse arrangement of fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features is seen. c, only the epithelioid melanocytes are immunoreactive for melan-a. the fusiform melanocytes are negative. d, Neuroid structures are present.

3280.caption: Shoulder phenomenon. Junctional melanocytic proliferation extends beyond dermal nevus periphery.
3280.original_caption: Shoulder phenomenon. the junctional melanocytic proliferation extends beyond the periphery of the dermal melanocytic nevus component.

3281.caption: Dysplastic nevus with stromal changes, marked lamellar fibrosis in superficial dermis.
3281.original_caption: Stromal changes associated with a dysplastic nevus. there is marked lamellar fibrosis in the superficial dermis.

3279.caption: Xanthoma disseminatum. Mononuclear cell infiltrate, eosinophilic cytoplasm (similar to JXg).
3279.original_caption: Xanthoma disseminatum. Infiltrate of mononuclear cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (indistinguishable from lesions of JXg).

3274.caption: Neuronevus. A, Compound melanocytic nevus with neurotized dermal component. B, Nests of epithelioid melanocytes and fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features. C, Epithelioid melanocytes Melan-A+; fusiform negative. D, Neuroid structures present.
3274.original_caption: neuronevus. A, Silhouette of a compound melanocytic nevus with neurotization of its dermal component. B, Superficially a mixture of nests of small epithelioid melanocytes and diffuse arrangement of fusiform melanocytes with schwannian features is seen. c, only the epithelioid melanocytes are immunoreactive for melan-a. the fusiform melanocytes are negative. d, Neuroid structures are present.

3278.caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. Xanthogranulomatous & lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with foamy histiocytes. Inflammatory cells in histiocyte cytoplasm. Histiocytes S100+.
3278.original_caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. A, Xanthogranulomatous and lymphoplasma cellular infiltrate with large foamy histiocytes. B, Inflammatory cells are seen within the abundant cytoplasm of the histiocytes. C, The large histiocytes are positive for S100 protein.

3277.caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. A, Xanthogranulomatous & lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with foamy histiocytes. B, Inflammatory cells in histiocyte cytoplasm. C, Histiocytes S100+.
3277.original_caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. A, Xanthogranulomatous and lymphoplasma cellular infiltrate with large foamy histiocytes. B, Inflammatory cells are seen within the abundant cytoplasm of the histiocytes. C, The large histiocytes are positive for S100 protein.

3276.caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. Xanthogranulomatous & lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with foamy histiocytes. Inflammatory cells in histiocyte cytoplasm. Histiocytes S100+.
3276.original_caption: Destombes-Rosai-Dorfman disease. A, Xanthogranulomatous and lymphoplasma cellular infiltrate with large foamy histiocytes. B, Inflammatory cells are seen within the abundant cytoplasm of the histiocytes. C, The large histiocytes are positive for S100 protein.

3296.caption: Miliaria. Subcorneal pustule at eccrine duct ostium.
3296.original_caption: miliaria. Subcorneal pustule involving the ostium of the eccrine duct.

3301.caption: Cutaneous myxoid cyst: dermal nodule with mucin, fibroblasts, adjacent epidermis.
3301.original_caption: Cutaneous myxoid cyst. Dermal nodule of mucin and fibroblasts flanked by epidermis.

3289.caption: Intracorneal & subepidermal pustules in small vessel vasculitis from bacterial infection.
3289.original_caption: Intracorneal and subepidermal pustules found in a patient with small vessel vasculitis related to bacterial infection.

3297.caption: Inflamed well-diff squamous cell carcinoma with neutrophilic abscesses.
3297.original_caption: inflamed well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Neutrophilic abscesses are present within the tumor.

3299.caption: Myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Stellate tumor cells in myxoid stroma.
3299.original_caption: myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Widely spaced, stellate tumor cells in a myxoid stroma.

3300.caption: Reticular erythematous mucinosis. Interstitial mucin with perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.
3300.original_caption: Reticular erythematous mucinosis. Interstitial mucin deposition associated with perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate.

3288.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. A, inflamed scarlike tumor. B, tumor cells S-100 positive.
3288.original_caption: desmoplastic melanoma. A, the tumor has an inflamed scarlike appearance. B, the tumor cells are positive for S-100 protein.

3287.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. A, inflamed scarlike tumor. B, S-100 protein positive tumor cells.
3287.original_caption: desmoplastic melanoma. A, the tumor has an inflamed scarlike appearance. B, the tumor cells are positive for S-100 protein.

3290.caption: Clear cell atypical fibroxanthoma: tumor cells with clear cytoplasm, pleomorphic nuclei. (Dr. KJ Busam)
3290.original_caption: Clear cell variant of atypical fibroxanthoma. the tumor cells have a clear cytoplasm and pleomorphoc nuclei. (Courtesy of Dr. KJ Busam)

3286.caption: Simplex squamous dysplasia: marked hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, broad rete ridges, basilar keratinocytic atypia, abnormal maturation, common inflammation.
3286.original_caption: simplex type of squamous dysplasia. The lesion is characterized by marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis, broad rete ridges, basilar keratinocytic atypia, and abnormal maturation. Associated inflammation is common.

3282.caption: Junctional Spitz’s nevus. Nests of large plump spindle/epithelioid melanocytes with clefts. Dull pink "Kamino" bodies present.
3282.original_caption: Junctional Spitz’s nevus. Nests of large plump spindle and epithelioid melanocytes are present with clefts surrounding junctional nests. Dull pink globules (“Kamino” bodies) are also identified.

3284.caption: Silicone injection site. A, Cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles; irregular cystlike cavities. B, CD68 immunoreactivity labels macrophages, not lipoblasts.
3284.original_caption: Silicone fluid injection site. A, Cells with multiple vacuoles in the cytoplasm are numerous. the silicone fluid also produces multiple cavities or cystlike spaces that are irregular in outline. B, Immunoreactivity for CD68, a lysosomal marker, labels the cytoplasm of the cells very heavily, showing that they are macrophages rather than lipoblasts.

3283.caption: Compound Spitz’s nevus. Fascicles of spindle/epithelioid melanocytes with epidermal hyperplasia, dull pink globules at dermal-epidermal junction.
3283.original_caption: compound Spitz’s nevus. Fascicles of spindle and epithelioid melanocytes are present in association with epidermal hyperplasia and dull pink globules at the dermal-epidermal junction.

3285.caption: Silicone injection site. A, Cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles, irregular cystlike cavities. B, CD68 immunoreactivity labels macrophages, not lipoblasts.
3285.original_caption: Silicone fluid injection site. A, Cells with multiple vacuoles in the cytoplasm are numerous. the silicone fluid also produces multiple cavities or cystlike spaces that are irregular in outline. B, Immunoreactivity for CD68, a lysosomal marker, labels the cytoplasm of the cells very heavily, showing that they are macrophages rather than lipoblasts.

3298.caption: Invasive squamous cell carcinoma with keratinization, dermal infiltration, no stromal reaction, overlying epidermis lacks basal layer atypia.
3298.original_caption: Conventional invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The carcinoma shows prominent keratinization. It infiltrates the dermis without a stromal reaction. The overlying epidermis does not show more than basal cell layer atypia.

3291.caption: Sentinel lymph node with intracapsular/subcapsular nevomelanocytes. A, Bland amelanotic epithelioid melanocytes in capsule/subcapsule (breast cancer patient). B, Intranodal melanocytes highlighted by mart-1 immunostain.
3291.original_caption: Sentinel lymph node with intracapsular and subcapsular nodal nevomelanocytes. A, Cytologically bland small amelanotic epithelioid melanocytes are present in the capsule of a sentinel lymph node from a woman with breast cancer. Similar melanocytes are also present in the node beneath the capsule. B, another focus of intranodal melanocytes in the same node highlighted by an immunostain for mart-1.

3294.caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue and nodal parenchyma. Found during axillary node dissection in breast carcinoma patient. Melanocytes in capsule, extend into parenchyma; cytologically bland, clustered around vessels in fibrous trabeculae. Occasional nests surrounded by lymphocytes.
3294.original_caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue and nodal parenchyma. Incidental large nevus found during an axillary node dissection in a patient with breast carcinoma. A, melanocytes are present in the capsule and extend into the nodal parenchyma. B, the melanocytes are cytologically bland; some are clustered around small vessels in fibrous trabeculae. c, an occasional nest of melanocytes is completely surrounded by lymphocytes.

3292.caption: Sentinel lymph node with intracapsular/subcapsular nevomelanocytes. A, Bland amelanotic epithelioid melanocytes in capsule/subcapsule from breast cancer patient. B, Intranodal melanocytes highlighted by mart-1 immunostain.
3292.original_caption: Sentinel lymph node with intracapsular and subcapsular nodal nevomelanocytes. A, Cytologically bland small amelanotic epithelioid melanocytes are present in the capsule of a sentinel lymph node from a woman with breast cancer. Similar melanocytes are also present in the node beneath the capsule. B, another focus of intranodal melanocytes in the same node highlighted by an immunostain for mart-1.

3295.caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue/nodal parenchyma. Found during axillary node dissection in breast carcinoma. A, melanocytes in capsule/extend into parenchyma. B, cytologically bland melanocytes; clustered around vessels in fibrous trabeculae. C, occasional melanocyte nests surrounded by lymphocytes.
3295.original_caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue and nodal parenchyma. Incidental large nevus found during an axillary node dissection in a patient with breast carcinoma. A, melanocytes are present in the capsule and extend into the nodal parenchyma. B, the melanocytes are cytologically bland; some are clustered around small vessels in fibrous trabeculae. c, an occasional nest of melanocytes is completely surrounded by lymphocytes.

3293.caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue/nodal parenchyma. Found during axillary node dissection in breast carcinoma patient. A: Melanocytes in capsule/extend into parenchyma. B: Cytologically bland melanocytes clustered around vessels in fibrous trabeculae. C: Occasional melanocyte nests surrounded by lymphocytes.
3293.original_caption: Large nodal melanocytic nevus in fibrous tissue and nodal parenchyma. Incidental large nevus found during an axillary node dissection in a patient with breast carcinoma. A, melanocytes are present in the capsule and extend into the nodal parenchyma. B, the melanocytes are cytologically bland; some are clustered around small vessels in fibrous trabeculae. c, an occasional nest of melanocytes is completely surrounded by lymphocytes.

3302.caption: Scleredema. Alcian blue shows interstitial mucin.
3302.original_caption: Scleredema. Interstitial mucin deposition highlighted by alcian blue stain.

3309.caption: Porocarcinoma. A, Invasive adenocarcinoma. B, Squamous metaplasia. C, Lymphatic tumor emboli.
3309.original_caption: Porocarcinoma. A, Invasive adenocarcinoma. B, Focal squamous metaplasia is seen. C, lymphatic tumor emboli are present.

3308.caption: Porocarcinoma. A, Invasive adenocarcinoma. B, Squamous metaplasia. C, Lymphatic tumor emboli.
3308.original_caption: Porocarcinoma. A, Invasive adenocarcinoma. B, Focal squamous metaplasia is seen. C, lymphatic tumor emboli are present.

3307.original_caption: Pilomatricoma. A, a circumscribed subcutaneous nodule is present. B, the tumor is composed of basaloid cells as well as “shadow” cells.* C, multinucleated giant cells are also common.

3311.original_caption: Herpetic blister. Acantholytic keratinocytes with viral cytopathic changes.

3314.original_caption: Bullous lupus erythematosus. Clusters of neutrophils in the papillary dermis.

3335.original_caption: mucinous carcinoma. Bland epithelial islands are seen in pools of mucin.

3334.original_caption: hidradenocarcinoma. Infiltrative adenocarcinoma with clear cell features.

3344.original_caption: eosinophilic panniculitis. there is septal edema with abundant eosinophils.

3331.original_caption: spiradenoma. A, multinodular growth pattern. B, two cell population: small basaloid cells surrounding larger pale epithelial cells.

3338.original_caption: squamous cell carcinoma with single cell infiltrative pattern. a, Solitary units of cytologically atypical cells are seen in the dermis. B, they are immunoreactive for 34BE12.

3447.caption: Acute spongiotic dermatitis: spongiotic microvesiculation, intercellular edema (spongiosis), hallmark of eczematous dermatitides (allergic contact, nummular, dyshidrotic, atopic). Chronic spongiotic dermatitis: compact orthokeratosis/parakeratosis, psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia, spongiosis. Granular layer retained/thickened
3447.original_caption: A, Acute spongiotic dermatitis. Spongiotic microvesiculation is the full expression of intercellular edema (spongiosis) that is the hallmark of all forms of spongiotic dermatitis, particularly the so-called eczematous dermatitides, allergic contact, nummular, dyshidrotic, and atopic dermatitis. In most of these cases, the diagnosis is established without biopsy; B, Chronic spongiotic dermatitis is characterized by compact orthokeratosis and/or parakeratosis, psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia, and spongiosis. Compared with psoriasis, the granular layer is retained or thickened in many areas. Spongiosis is often less prominent.

3466.caption: Necrolytic migratory erythema (glucagonoma syndrome). Biopsy 1: vacuolization, pallor in superficial epidermis. Biopsy 2: focal subcorneal pustules. Necrolysis not always present; may resemble psoriasis/inflammatory disorders.
3466.original_caption: Necrolytic migratory erythema (glucagonoma syndrome). B, Initial biopsy revealed vacuolization and pronounced pallor in the superficial epidermis. Necrolysis is not yet evident. C, Subsequent biopsy revealed only focal subcorneal pustule formation. Thus prominent necrolysis is not always a feature, and the findings may resemble psoriasis or other inflammatory disorders.

D, Higher magnification reveals neutrophilic crust, lymphocyte exocytosis, vacuolar alteration, necrotic keratinocytes, and erythrocyte extravasation.

3467.caption: Necrolytic migratory erythema (glucagonoma syndrome). Biopsy 1: superficial epidermal vacuolization, pallor, no necrolysis. Biopsy 2: focal subcorneal pustules, resembles psoriasis/inflammatory disorders.
3467.original_caption: Necrolytic migratory erythema (glucagonoma syndrome). B, Initial biopsy revealed vacuolization and pronounced pallor in the superficial epidermis. Necrolysis is not yet evident. C, Subsequent biopsy revealed only focal subcorneal pustule formation. Thus prominent necrolysis is not always a feature, and the findings may resemble psoriasis or other inflammatory disorders.

3484.caption: Subacute lupus: perivascular/periadnexal lymphocytes, interface changes. Discoid lupus: orthokeratosis, atrophy, vacuolar dermatitis, basilar squamatization, follicular plugging, perivascular/perifollicular lymphocytes, interfollicular atrophy, interface dermatitis. Dermal inflammation centers in deep dermis, surrounds adnexa. Basement membrane
3484.original_caption: Lupus erythematosus. C, Perivascular and periadnexal lymphocytes with focal interface changes in subacute lupus. D, Orthokeratosis, atrophy (with loss of the rete ridges), vacuolar interface dermatitis, and basilar squamatization typify established subacute (this case) or discoid lupus. E, Discoid lupus exhibits follicular plugging, superficial and deep perivascular and perifollicular lymphocytes. There is interfollicular atrophy and interface dermatitis affecting both the epidermis and follicular epithelium. F, Even in sections or examples that do not exhibit active interface dermatitis, the balance of the dermal inflammation is centered in the deep dermis and surrounds adnexal structures. G, Basement membrane thickening may be highlighted by PAS stain.

3471.caption: Erythema multiforme (EM) & Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). D: Basket weave orthokeratosis, vacuolar interface dermatitis, dermal lymphocytes. E: Necrotic keratinocytes throughout epidermis. F: Dense lichenoid infiltrate. G: Keratinocyte necrosis. H: Satellite cell necrosis. I,J: SJS shows conflu
3471.original_caption: Erythema multiforme (EM) and Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). D, Basket weave orthokeratosis, vacuolar interface dermatitis, and superficial lymphocytes in the dermis. E, Prominent single necrotic keratinocytes at all levels of the epidermis. F, Biopsy reveals a denser lichenoid infiltrate. G, Prominent keratinocyte necrosis. H, Satellite cell necrosis. I,J, SJS is characterized by confluent epidermal necrosis and subepidermal clefting. These changes are indistinguishable from some cases of bullous EM. In toxic epidermal necrolysis, inflammation may be absent or minimal, but biopsy of perilesional skin may reveal changes indistinguishable from SJS or EM.

3486.caption: Acute GVHD: vacuolar interface dermatitis, sparse dermal inflammation. Follicular epithelium shows interface dermatitis.
3486.original_caption: Graft versus host disease (GVHD). C, Acute GVHD is characterized by a vacuolar interface dermatitis with relatively sparse dermal inflammation. D, Interface dermatitis within follicular epithelium is characteristic.

3485.caption: Subacute lupus: perivascular/periadnexal lymphocytes, interface changes. Subacute/discoid lupus: orthokeratosis, atrophy, vacuolar dermatitis, basilar squamatization. Discoid lupus: follicular plugging, superficial/deep perivascular/perifollicular lymphocytes, interfollicular atrophy, interface dermatitis. Dermal inflammation centers in deep d

E, Discoid lupus exhibits follicular plugging, superficial and deep perivascular and perifollicular lymphocytes. F, Even in sections or examples that do not exhibit active interface dermatitis, the balance of the dermal inflammation is centered in the deep dermis and surrounds adnexal structures. G, Basement membrane thickening may be highlighted by PAS stain.

3487.caption: Acute GVHD: vacuolar interface dermatitis, sparse dermal inflammation. Follicular epithelium shows interface dermatitis.
3487.original_caption: Graft versus host disease (GVHD). C, Acute GVHD is characterized by a vacuolar interface dermatitis with relatively sparse dermal inflammation. D, Interface dermatitis within follicular epithelium is characteristic.

3493.caption: Lichen striatus. A, Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrates, perivascular/periadnexal. B, Perieccrine lymphocytes (specific but not always present).
3493.original_caption: Lichen striatus. A, Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrates with deep perivascular and periadnexal involvement. B, Perieccrine lymphocytes are relatively specific for lichen striatus, but are not always present.

3489.caption: Lichen sclerosus. Atrophy, follicular plugging, papillary dermal edema, sclerosis. Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate beneath altered connective tissue in subepidermal zone. Early lesions show vacuolar interface dermatitis before edema/sclerosis.
3489.original_caption: Lichen sclerosus. B, Atrophy, follicular plugging, papillary dermal edema, and sclerosis. C, A lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate is typically present beneath the zone of altered connective tissue in the subepidermal zone. Analysis of early lesions or the peripheral area of fully developed ones exhibit vacuolar interface dermatitis before the advent of identifiable edema or sclerosis.

3490.caption: Lichen nitidus. A, "Ball in claw" lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, Parakeratotic, thinned, hypogranulotic epidermis. C, Histiocyte-predominant lichenoid infiltrate.
3490.original_caption: Lichen nitidus. A, Scanning magnification best depicts the “ball in claw” configuration of the focal lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, The overlying epidermis is typically parakeratotic, thinned, and hypogranulotic. C, Histiocytes often predominate in the lichenoid infiltrate.

3491.caption: Lichen nitidus. A, "Ball in claw" lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, Parakeratotic, thinned, hypogranulotic epidermis. C, Histiocytes dominate lichenoid infiltrate.
3491.original_caption: Lichen nitidus. A, Scanning magnification best depicts the “ball in claw” configuration of the focal lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, The overlying epidermis is typically parakeratotic, thinned, and hypogranulotic. C, Histiocytes often predominate in the lichenoid infiltrate.

3488.caption: Lichen sclerosus. Atrophy, follicular plugging, papillary dermal edema, sclerosis. Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate beneath altered connective tissue in subepidermal zone. Early lesions show vacuolar interface dermatitis before edema/sclerosis.
3488.original_caption: Lichen sclerosus. B, Atrophy, follicular plugging, papillary dermal edema, and sclerosis. C, A lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate is typically present beneath the zone of altered connective tissue in the subepidermal zone. Analysis of early lesions or the peripheral area of fully developed ones exhibit vacuolar interface dermatitis before the advent of identifiable edema or sclerosis.

3498.caption: Granuloma annulare. D,E: Palisaded granuloma with mucin. F: Interstitial/incomplete variant.
3498.original_caption: Granuloma annulare. D, E, Palisaded granuloma containing mucin. F, Interstitial/incomplete variant.

3500.caption: Granuloma annulare. D,E: Palisaded granuloma with mucin. F: Interstitial/incomplete variant.
3500.original_caption: Granuloma annulare. D, E, Palisaded granuloma containing mucin. F, Interstitial/incomplete variant.

3494.caption: Lichen striatus. A, Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrates, perivascular/periadnexal. B, Perieccrine lymphocytes specific but not always present.
3494.original_caption: Lichen striatus. A, Lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrates with deep perivascular and periadnexal involvement. B, Perieccrine lymphocytes are relatively specific for lichen striatus, but are not always present.

3497.caption: Sarcoidosis. C: Nodules of pale cells. D: Sarcoidal granulomas. E: Noncaseating granulomas with epithelioid histiocytes, few lymphocytes.
3497.original_caption: Sarcoid (sarcoidosis). C, Scanning magnification reveals nodules of relatively pale staining cells. D, Discrete sarcoidal granulomas. E, These noncaseating granulomas are composed of epithelioid histiocytes with relatively few lymphocytes.

3496.caption: Sarcoidosis. C: Nodules of pale cells. D: Sarcoidal granulomas. E: Noncaseating granulomas with epithelioid histiocytes, few lymphocytes.
3496.original_caption: Sarcoid (sarcoidosis). C, Scanning magnification reveals nodules of relatively pale staining cells. D, Discrete sarcoidal granulomas. E, These noncaseating granulomas are composed of epithelioid histiocytes with relatively few lymphocytes.

3495.caption: Sarcoidosis. C: Pale staining cell nodules. D: Sarcoidal granulomas. E: Noncaseating granulomas with epithelioid histiocytes, few lymphocytes.
3495.original_caption: Sarcoid (sarcoidosis). C, Scanning magnification reveals nodules of relatively pale staining cells. D, Discrete sarcoidal granulomas. E, These noncaseating granulomas are composed of epithelioid histiocytes with relatively few lymphocytes.

3502.caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous elbow nodule. B, Palisaded granulomas in subcutis. C, D, Histiocyte palisade surrounds eosinophilic, smudgy fibrin.
3502.original_caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous nodule on the elbow. B, Palisaded granulomas typically situated in the subcutis. C, D, The palisade of histiocytes surrounds a more intensely eosinophilic, homogeneous, smudgy-appearing substance, fibrin.

3492.caption: Lichen nitidus. A, "Ball in claw" lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, Parakeratotic, thinned, hypogranulotic epidermis. C, Histiocytes predominate in lichenoid infiltrate.
3492.original_caption: Lichen nitidus. A, Scanning magnification best depicts the “ball in claw” configuration of the focal lichenoid interface dermatitis. B, The overlying epidermis is typically parakeratotic, thinned, and hypogranulotic. C, Histiocytes often predominate in the lichenoid infiltrate.

3501.caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous elbow nodule. B, Palisaded granulomas in subcutis. C, D, Histiocyte palisade surrounds eosinophilic, smudgy fibrin.
3501.original_caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous nodule on the elbow. B, Palisaded granulomas typically situated in the subcutis. C, D, The palisade of histiocytes surrounds a more intensely eosinophilic, homogeneous, smudgy-appearing substance, fibrin.

3504.caption: Cellular neurothekeoma with focal myxoid change and spindling. Differs from S-100+ dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma) which has EMA+ perineurial cells.
3504.original_caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Focal myxoid change may be seen, and there may be focal spindling of cells. However, this entity is different from dermal nerve sheath myxoma (also termed neurothekeoma ), which is S-100 protein positive and has peripheral epithelial membrane antigen–positive perineurial cells

3503.caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous elbow nodule. B, Palisaded granulomas in subcutis. C, D, Histiocyte palisade surrounds eosinophilic, smudgy fibrin.
3503.original_caption: Rheumatoid nodule. A, Subcutaneous nodule on the elbow. B, Palisaded granulomas typically situated in the subcutis. C, D, The palisade of histiocytes surrounds a more intensely eosinophilic, homogeneous, smudgy-appearing substance, fibrin.

3506.caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Focal cellular atypia, not prognostically significant.
3506.original_caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Occasional examples display focal cellular atypia, which is not prognostically signi fi cant

3499.caption: Granuloma annulare. Palisaded granuloma with mucin. Interstitial/incomplete variant.
3499.original_caption: Granuloma annulare. D, E, Palisaded granuloma containing mucin. F, Interstitial/incomplete variant.

3505.caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Nodules vary in size, separated by fibrous septa. Cells have rounded nuclei, moderate cytoplasm, focal atypia. Immunoreactive for SMA/NKIC3, negative for S-100/EMA. Resembles plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor but more superficial, lacks giant cells.
3505.original_caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. The cellular nodules vary in size and are separated by slender fi brous septa. The lesional cells have rounded nuclei and contain moderate amounts of cytoplasm. Occasional examples display focal cellular atypia. The cells are immunoreactive for SMA and NKIC3 but lack S-100 protein and epithelial membrane antigen. This tumor is similar to the plexiform fi brohistiocytic tumor, which, however, is located more deeply and more frequently contains giant cells

3508.caption: Epithelioid hemangioma: solid epithelioid endothelial cells, intracytoplasmic lumina, interstitial hemorrhage, admixed eosinophils.
3508.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. The lesion is a solid area composed of epithelioid endothelial cells, some with single or double intracytoplasmic lumina. There is interstitial hemorrhage, and admixed eosinophils may be seen

3507.caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. Dermis shows packed nodules of uniform rounded cells. Papillomatous, facial lesion.
3507.original_caption: Cellular neurothekeoma. The dermis contains closely packed nodules of uniform rounded cells. This example is papillomatous and occurred on the face

3513.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Myxoid and cellular areas form low-power pattern.
3513.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Alternating myxoid and cellular areas form a typical low-power pattern

3511.caption: Hobnail hemangioma: single endothelial layer, nuclei protruding into lumina in hobnail pattern.
3511.original_caption: Hobnail hemangioma. There is a single layer of lining endothelium, with nuclei protruding into vascular lumina in a hobnail fashion

3514.caption: Granular cell tumor: large cells, abundant granular cytoplasm (secondary lysosomes), rounded small nuclei, S-100 positive.
3514.original_caption: Granular cell tumor. The cells are large, with abundant coarsely granular cytoplasm owing to the accumulation of secondary lysosomes. Nuclei are rounded and relatively small, but vary slightly in size. The lesional cells are diffusely positive for S-100 protein

3510.caption: Intramuscular hemangioma. Skeletal muscle infiltrated by proliferating vessels (capillaries to muscular veins). Adjacent muscle replaced by fat. Formerly called infiltrating angiolipomas.
3510.original_caption: Intramuscular hemangioma. Skeletal muscle is in fi ltrated by a proliferation of variably sized vessels, ranging from capillary clusters to muscular-walled veins. The adjacent muscle often is replaced by fat, as seen here. Such lesions formerly were termed in fi ltrating angiolipomas

3515.caption: Malignant myoepithelial tumor (myoepithelial carcinoma). Aggressive neoplasm with mitotically active, pleomorphic polygonal cells, prominent nucleoli, clear cytoplasm, necrosis. Diagnosed by mixed immunophenotype, INI1 loss, EWSR1 rearrangement via FISH.
3515.original_caption: Malignant myoepithelial tumor (myoepithelial carcinoma). This is an aggressive neoplasm composed of sheets of mitotically active, pleomorphic polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli, focally clear cytoplasm, and necrosis. It can be diagnosed by its mixed immunophenotype, with loss of INI1 in some cases, and by demonstration of EWSR1 gene rearrangement by fl uorescence in situ hybridization

3509.caption: Hobnail hemangioma (targetoid hemosiderotic hemangioma). Occurs in young adults on trunk/extremities. Thin-walled dilated lymphatic vessels in superficial dermis, slit-like irregular ones in deeper dermis dissecting collagen.
3509.original_caption: Hobnail hemangioma (targetoid hemosiderotic hemangioma). This lesion occurs in young adults on the trunk or extremities. There are thin-walled dilated lymphatic vessels in the super fi cial dermis and more slit-like irregular ones dissecting collagen in the deeper dermis

3525.caption: Glomangioma. Tumor cells surround dilated vascular spaces.
3525.original_caption: Glomangioma. The tumor cells surround dilated vascular spaces

3521.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor with nuclear palisading. Not schwannoma.
3521.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. This example shows striking nuclear palisading. It should not be confused with a schwannoma

3520.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: spindle cell variant w/ packed fascicles of elongated spindle cells
3520.original_caption: Fig  Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. The spindle cell variant has closely packed fascicles of elongated spindle cells

3512.caption: Malignant granular cell tumor: spindling cells, nuclear pleomorphism, high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, >2 mitoses/10 HPF. Atypical if 1-2 features, usually benign.
3512.original_caption: Malignant granular cell tumor. This example shows spindling of cells and focal nuclear pleomorphism. Malignant granular cell tumors have three or more of the following: spindling of cells, focal nuclear pleomorphism, a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, necrosis, and mitoses exceeding 2 per 10 high-power fi elds (at ×200). Those with one or two of these features are atypical but tend to behave in a benign fashion

3524.caption: Glomus tumor. Glomus cells surround blood vessel. Immunoreactive: SMA, h-caldesmon. Negative: desmin.
3524.original_caption: Glomus tumor. Several layers of glomus cells are arranged around a blood vessel. The cells are immunoreactive for smooth muscle actin and h-caldesmon and negative for desmin

3519.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Cells arranged in nests with "organoid" or paraganglioma-like pattern.
3519.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. The cells are arranged in nests imparting an “organoid” or paraganglioma-like pattern

3522.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Paranuclear vacuoles prominent. Similar to smooth muscle tumors but with blunt-ended nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm, smaller vacuoles, lack CD117/DOG1 immunoreactivity.
3522.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Paranuclear vacuoles sometimes are a prominent feature. Similar features may be seen in smooth muscle tumors, but these have more blunt-ended nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, the vacuoles usually are smaller, and the cells lack immunoreactivity for CD117 and DOG1

3526.caption: Glomangiopericytoma with hemangiopericytic pattern.
3526.original_caption: Glomangiopericytoma. A prominent hemangiopericytic pattern sometimes is seen

3527.caption: Glomus tumor in deep soft tissue, composed of sheets of glomus cells unrelated to vessels.
3527.original_caption: Glomus tumor. This sample arose in deep soft tissue and is composed of sheets of glomus cells that are unrelated to blood vessels

3523.caption: Glomus tumor. Pericytes differentiate into glomus cells with uniform nuclei, moderate cytoplasm, distinct membranes. Intradermal tumor shows cellular infiltrate around vascular spaces. Typically occurs in distal extremities (subungual), deep soft tissue, coccyx, bone, female genital tract; rarely in GI tract (stomach).
3523.original_caption: Glomus tumor. Pericytes may differentiate toward smooth muscle cells and are believed to become modi fi ed as glomus cells, which have rounded uniform nuclei, moderate amounts of cytoplasm, and distinct cell membranes. This is a skin lesion showing the intradermal location of the tumor, which is cellular and in fi ltrative and focally surrounds vascular spaces. Glomus tumors typically occur in distal extremities, often in a subungual location but also in deep soft tissue, near the coccyx, in bone, and in the female genital tract; they also are found rarely in the gastrointestinal tract, especially the stomach

3517.caption: Mixed skin/soft tissue tumor with tubular/glandular formation, polygonal/spindled cells, chondromyxoid/chondroid stroma.
3517.original_caption: Mixed tumor of skin and soft tissue. This tumor has tubular or glandular formation as well as polygonal or spindled cells. The stroma may be chondromyxoid or chondroid

3518.caption: Myoepithelial tumor of skin, infiltrative in dermis, forms plaque/nodule. May involve subcutaneous/deep soft tissue, mainly extremities.
3518.original_caption: Myoepithelial tumor of skin. The lesion is in fi ltrative in the dermis and forms a plaque or nodule. Myoepithelial tumors also may involve subcutaneous and deep soft tissue, mainly in the extremities

3516.caption: Myoepithelial skin/soft tissue tumor. Ovoid cells in myxoid/fibrous stroma, some rhabdoid. Spindled variant exists. Mixed immunophenotype: EMA, S-100, actin. 50% have EWSR1 rearrangement.
3516.original_caption: Myoepithelial tumor of skin and soft tissue. Ovoid tumor cells form branching cords in a myxoid and fi brous stroma. Some cells have a rhabdoid appearance with prominent cytoplasm. A predominantly spindled variant also occurs. The tumor has a mixed immunophenotype, typically including an epithelial marker (especially epithelial membrane antigen), S-100 protein, and sometimes actin. About half the tumors (benign or malignant) have rearrangement of the EWSR1 gene, with a variety of fusion gene partners

3532.caption: Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. Ill-defined myxoid and fibrous areas with swirling pattern.
3532.original_caption: Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. Ill-de fi ned myxoid and more fi brous areas form a vague swirling pattern

3528.caption: Rhabdomyoma, fetal type, intermediate (juvenile). Skeletal muscle more differentiated, some cells show cytoplasmic cross-striations.
3528.original_caption: Rhabdomyoma, fetal type, intermediate (juvenile). The skeletal muscle in this lesion is more differentiated, with some cells showing well-developed cytoplasmic cross-striations

3530.caption: Adult rhabdomyoma: benign tumor of large polygonal cells with abundant cytoplasm, vacuolation. Immunoreactive for desmin, myogenin. Typically in adults >50, located in heart, head/neck, genital tract.
3530.original_caption: Rhabdomyoma, adult type. This is a benign tumor composed of sheets of large polygonal cells with abundant cytoplasm and occasional vacuolation. The tumor cells are immunoreactive for desmin and myogenin. Most examples occur in adults over 50 years old in the heart, head, and neck or in the genital tract

3529.caption: Focal myositis. Skeletal muscle fibers show necrosis/shrinkage with lymphocyte infiltrate. Benign self-limiting lesion forming mass in single muscle, usually lower limb.
3529.original_caption: Focal myositis. Single skeletal muscle fi bers show necrosis or shrinkage, with an in fi ltrate of lymphocytes. This is a benign, selflimiting lesion that forms a mass in a single muscle, usually in the lower limb

3537.caption: Venous hemangioma: ill-defined lesion, may involve deep soft tissue, possible malformation. Thick-walled vessels with smooth muscle, unlike capillary hemangioma.
3537.original_caption: Venous hemangioma. This is an ill-de fi ned lesion that may involve deep soft tissue and might represent a malformation. Unlike in capillary hemangioma, its vessels have thickened walls that sometimes contain smooth muscle

3535.caption: Lymphangioma: cystic mass of dilated lymphatic channels, smooth muscle, lymphoid aggregates in walls. Common in head/neck (childhood) and retroperitoneum.
3535.original_caption: Lymphangioma. The head and neck (especially in childhood) and the retroperitoneum are preferred sites for lymphangioma. It forms a cystic mass of dilated lymphatic channels with variable amounts of smooth muscle and lymphoid aggregates in the cyst walls

3541.caption: Superficial angiomyxoma. Low cellularity, no nuclear atypia, often recurs. Entrapped epidermal cyst seen. Lesional cells CD34+.
3541.original_caption: Super fi cial angiomyxoma. Cellularity is low, and there is no nuclear atypia. However, the lesion often recurs. As shown here, an entrapped epidermal cyst is seen in some examples. The lesional cells are CD34 positive

3539.caption: Superficial acral fibromyxoma (digital fibromyxoma). Benign, locally recurring digit lesion, often in nail bed. Dermal bland spindle cell proliferation, poorly circumscribed. Epidermal hyperkeratosis.
3539.original_caption: Super fi cial acral fi bromyxoma (digital fi bromyxoma). This is a benign but sometimes locally recurring lesion that arises in the digits, especially in the nail bed. There is a poorly circumscribed and variably cellular bland spindle cell proliferation in the dermis. The epidermis shows hyperkeratosis

3536.caption: Atypical vascular lesion post-irradiation, often in breast/chest wall skin. Small, dermal, wedge-shaped. Dilated thin-walled vessels with prominent endothelial cells. No multilayering or atypia.
3536.original_caption: Atypical vascular lesion. This may arise following irradiation, usually for carcinoma, and it is seen most frequently in the skin of the breast or chest wall as one or more discrete foci. The lesion is small, wedge shaped, and con fi ned to the dermis. Its super fi cial part has dilated thin-walled vessels lined by prominent endothelial cells. Multilayering and frank atypia are lacking

3533.caption: Adult fibrosarcoma. Cells arranged in fascicles with herringbone architecture. Rare in adults due to improved categorization of spindle cell sarcomas. Arises in deep soft tissues, can be aggressive. Genetic techniques aid subtype recognition. Pleomorphic sarcomas classified separately.
3533.original_caption: Adult fi brosarcoma. The cells are arranged in fascicles with herringbone architecture. This type of fi brosarcoma is now considered very rare in adults, because most spindle cell sarcomas can be otherwise categorized, speci fi c fi brosarcoma subtypes have become increasingly recognized with the aid of genetic techniques, and pleomorphic sarcomas are classi fi ed separately. Adult fi brosarcomas arise in deep soft tissues and may be aggressive

3531.caption: Fetal rhabdomyoma, immature (myxoid). Spindle cells in myxoid stroma with scattered inflammatory cells. No pleomorphism/necrosis. Mostly childhood tumor.
3531.original_caption: Rhabdomyoma, fetal type, immature (myxoid). Spindle cells are dispersed in myxoid stroma with scattered in fl ammatory cells. Pleomorphism and necrosis are not seen. This tumor occurs mostly in childhood

3540.caption: Superficial angiomyxoma: ill-defined, multinodular, intradermal/subcutaneous tumor. May associate with Carney complex (cardiac/other myxomas, pigmented skin lesions, melanotic schwannomas, endocrine tumors).
3540.original_caption: Super fi cial angiomyxoma. This is an ill-de fi ned, multinodular, intradermal, and subcutaneous tumor. Such lesions (especially when multiple) may form part of the Carney complex, in association with cardiac and other myxomas, pigmented skin lesions, melanotic schwannomas, and endocrine tumors

3534.caption: Adult fibrosarcoma. Tapered nuclei, no pleomorphism. Scanty cytoplasm, indistinct margins. Focal SMA+ (diffuse suggests myofibrosarcoma). Some superficial cases express CD34, COL1A1-PDGRFB fusion; lack dermatofibrosarcoma features.
3534.original_caption: Adult fi brosarcoma. Nuclei are tapered and show no pleomorphism. The cytoplasm is scanty, and cell margins are indistinct. These tumors lack speci fi c antigens except for focal smooth muscle actin (if this is widespread, the tumor may be classi fi ed as a myo fi brosarcoma). A subset of super fi cial fi brosarcomas expresses CD34, and in some of these, COL1A1-PDGRFB fusion transcripts have been identi fi ed; however, they lack features of antecedent dermato fi brosarcoma

3542.caption: Superficial angiomyxoma with scattered neutrophils, characteristic feature
3542.original_caption: Super fi cial angiomyxoma. Scattered neutrophils are a characteristic feature

3538.caption: Massive localized lymphedema in morbid obesity: large ill-defined limb mass. Normal adipose lobules intersected by edematous septa with fibrillary collagen, fibroblasts. Septal edge shows capillary proliferation. No nuclear atypia vs liposarcoma.
3538.original_caption: Massive localized lymphedema in a morbidly obese patient. This entity presents as a large, ill-de fi ned mass in the limbs of morbidly obese patients. Lobules of normal adipose tissue fat are intersected by widened, edematous connective tissue septa containing fi brillary collagen and scattered fi broblasts. Proliferating capillaries are seen toward the edge of the septum. No nuclear atypia is seen, unlike in sclerosing well-differentiated liposarcoma

3543.caption: Cranial fasciitis of childhood. Fibroblasts without atypia in fibromyxoid stroma.
3543.original_caption: Cranial fasciitis of childhood. Loosely arranged fi broblasts without atypia are dispersed in a fi bromyxoid stroma

3544.caption: Nodular fasciitis. Myofibroblasts in loose storiform pattern, stromal microcysts with lymphocytes and RBCs.
3544.original_caption: Nodular fasciitis. Uniform myo fi broblasts are arranged in a loose storiform pattern, with stromal microcysts that contain lymphocytes and extravasated red blood cells

3545.caption: Nodular fasciitis. Myofibroblastic immunophenotype, SMA+ (linear subplasmalemmal), calponin+/desmin±, h-caldesmon-/CD34-/S-100-.
3545.original_caption: Nodular fasciitis. The cells have a myo fi broblastic immunophenotype, with smooth muscle actin positivity in a linear subplasmalemmal distribution. Calponin and occasionally desmin also test positive, whereas h-caldesmon, CD34, and S-100 protein test negative

3546.caption: Nodular fasciitis. Older lesions show focal fibrosis, giant cells. Histologic stages coexist, creating zoning phenomenon - diagnostic clue.
3546.original_caption: Nodular fasciitis. Older lesions have focal fi brosis and contain occasional giant cells. The different histologic stages may coexist in the same lesion, imparting a zoning phenomenon that is a diagnostic clue

3550.caption: Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma transitioning to round cell type: tumor nuclei rounded, hyperchromatic, overlapping. Increased cellularity obscures vascular pattern; myxoid stroma reduced.
3550.original_caption: Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma. In transition to round cell liposarcoma, tumor cell nuclei become rounded and hyperchromatic and appear to overlap. The tumor becomes more cellular, obscuring the vascular pattern, and the amount of myxoid stroma decreases

3547.caption: Myxoid liposarcoma. Myxoid stroma accumulates in microcysts, resembling pulmonary edema. Vascular pattern lost focally; typical areas often found elsewhere in tumor.
3547.original_caption: Myxoid liposarcoma. The myxoid stroma may accumulate in microcysts, imparting an appearance of pulmonary edema. The vascular pattern is lost, but this may be a focal change, and more typical areas often are found elsewhere in the tumor

3549.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma, low-grade. CDK4 nuclear immunoreactivity confirms diagnosis.
3549.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma with low-grade dedifferentiation. Diffuse nuclear immunoreactivity for CDK4 supports the diagnosis

3548.caption: Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma: small uniform spindle cells near capillaries in "chicken-wire" pattern. Occurs in proximal limbs (thigh/groin), rarely abdomen. Metastasizes to soft tissue/lungs. Myxoid & round cell variants share t(12;16)(q13;p11) FUS-DDIT3 fusion, some
3548.original_caption: Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma. This tumor has small, uniform spindle cells that are closely related to the capillary blood vessels that are arranged in a characteristic plexiform or “chicken-wire” pattern. Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma occurs in adults mainly in the proximal limbs, especially the thigh and groin, and very rarely in the abdomen, where it may, however, be mimicked by myxoid change in well-differentiated liposarcoma. This is a soft tissue sarcoma that can metastasize widely, including to other soft tissue sites and to the lungs. Myxoid and round cell variants both have the same translocations. Most have t(12;16)(q13;p11) leading to FUS-DDTIT3 fusion, and a minority harbor a t(12;22)(q13;q12) rearrangement with EWSR1-DDIT3 fusion

3560.caption: Epithelioid inflammatory myofibroblastic sarcoma. ALK positivity on nuclear membrane/perinuclear. Some cases show RANBP2-ALK fusion.
3560.original_caption: Epithelioid in fl ammatory myo fi broblastic sarcoma. There is a distinctive pattern of ALK positivity on the nuclear membrane or in the perinuclear distribution. Some examples are associated with RANBP2-ALK fusion

3551.caption: Juvenile hyaline fibromatosis: uniform ovoid cells in eosinophilic homogeneous stroma. Autosomal recessive with cutaneous/soft tissue/bony lesions. Overlaps infantile systemic hyalinosis.
3551.original_caption: Juvenile hyaline fi bromatosis. Groups of uniform ovoid cells are dispersed evenly in characteristically heavily eosinophilic, homogeneous stroma. This is an autosomal recessive disease that may display cutaneous, soft tissue, and bony lesions. The fi ndings overlap those of infantile systemic hyalinosis

3559.caption: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. Sclerosing areas with sparse spindle cells and plasma cells variably present in tumor regions.
3559.original_caption: In fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor. Sclerosing areas with scanty spindle cells and variable numbers of plasma cells often are present in parts of the tumor

3558.caption: Round cell liposarcoma. Minimal pleomorphism. Cytoplasmic vacuoles show lipoblastic differentiation. Lesional cells may express S-100. Lipoblasts required for diagnosis, especially without molecular diagnostics or myxoid liposarcoma component.
3558.original_caption: Round cell liposarcoma. Minimal pleomorphism is seen. The cytoplasmic vacuoles represent lipoblastic differentiation, and the lesional cells may express S-100 protein. In the absence of an element of typical myxoid liposarcoma in other parts of the tumor, the presence of lipoblasts, at least focally, usually is necessary to make the diagnosis of round cell liposarcoma, especially if molecular diagnostic facilities are not available

3557.caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma: high-grade aggressive tumor in proximal thigh deep soft tissue. Key feature: pleomorphic multivacuolated lipoblasts in undifferentiated sarcoma background. Vacuoles round/empty, nucleus indented/scalloped.
3557.original_caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma. This is a high-grade, aggressive tumor that occurs most commonly in deep soft tissue of the proximal thigh. The diagnostic feature is the presence in variable numbers of pleomorphic, often multivacuolated lipoblasts in a background of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. The vacuoles are round and empty, and the nucleus appears indented or scalloped

3556.caption: Round cell liposarcoma: sheets of vacuolated rounded nuclei, no vascular pattern. High-grade variant of myxoid liposarcoma, no proven genetic differences.
3556.original_caption: Round cell liposarcoma. This tumor has sheets of rounded nuclei, some of which are vacuolated. No vascular pattern is discernible. This is regarded as the high-grade or more aggressive variant of myxoid liposarcoma, although no genetic differences between the two histologic patterns have been shown

3564.caption: Lipoma: differentiated adipocytes, no nuclear atypia. Fat removed in processing, empty cells with thin cytoplasm rim, nucleus pushed to margin.
3564.original_caption: Lipoma. This neoplasm is composed of differentiated adipocytes without nuclear atypia. Most of the cell appears empty because the fat is removed during processing, and there is only a thin rim of cytoplasm. The nucleus is pushed to the margin of the cell

3552.caption: Gingival fibromatosis. Sparse cellular fibrosis with mild inflammation beneath hyperplastic epithelium. Small calcification foci. Mass over teeth/gums. Sporadic or familial, often autosomal dominant. Resembles pregnancy/phenytoin-induced gingival hyperplasia.
3552.original_caption: Gingival fi bromatosis. Sparsely cellular fi brosis tissue with mild in fl ammation is present beneath irregularly hyperplastic epithelium. Small foci of calci fi cation may be seen. This forms a mass that grows over teeth and gums. It may be sporadic but also familial, most often with autosomal dominant inheritance. The appearance resembles that in gingival hyperplasia arising in pregnancy or in phenytoin users

3562.caption: Epithelioid inflammatory myofibroblastic sarcoma, rare aggressive adolescent tumor with predominant ganglion-like cells, distinct from usual inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor.
3562.original_caption: Epithelioid in fl ammatory myo fi broblastic sarcoma. This is a rare but aggressive tumor of adolescents, characterized by large ganglion-like cells. Similar cells occasionally may be seen in usual in fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor, but here they predominate

3563.caption: Intramuscular lipoma. Muscle bundles separated by normal adipose tissue. Infiltrative lesion may recur post-incomplete excision; some have circumscribed margins with lower recurrence risk.
3563.original_caption: Intramuscular lipoma. Skeletal muscle bundles are separated by normal-looking differentiated adipose tissue. The in fi ltrative nature of the lesion means that it may recur after incomplete excision, although some examples have a circumscribed margin and are less likely to recur

3561.caption: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. ALK expressed in some cases, especially childhood visceral tumors. Related to ALK gene rearrangement at 2p23 and fusion with partner genes.
3561.original_caption: In fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor. Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is expressed in some examples, especially visceral examples in childhood. This is related to the rearrangement of the ALK gene at 2p23 and its fusion with one of several different partner genes

3555.caption: Myxoid liposarcoma metastatic to lymph node
3555.original_caption: Myxoid liposarcoma. This is a rare example of myxoid liposarcoma metastatic to a lymph node

3565.caption: Lipoma arborescens: lipomatous synovial infiltration forming multinodular joint tumors (e.g., knee), may be bilateral/multiple. Occurs in nerves/joints.
3565.original_caption: Lipoma arborescens. Lipomas may occur in any anatomic location, including within nerves and joints. The term lipoma arborescens is used for lipomatous in fi ltration of synovium forming a multinodular tumor within a joint, such as the knee. Lesions may be bilateral or multiple

3553.caption: Infantile digital fibromatosis. Rounded eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions near nuclei hallmark. Inclusions are actin filament aggregates, shown by Masson trichrome. Also called inclusion body fibromatosis. Similar inclusions seen in fibroadenoma and breast fibromatosis.
3553.original_caption: Infantile digital fi bromatosis. Rounded, markedly eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions adjacent to nuclei in occasional cells are the hallmark of this disease. The inclusions are thought to represent aggregates of actin fi laments and are best demonstrated by a Masson trichrome stain. The term inclusion body fi bromatosis has been used. Similar inclusions may be seen in other lesions, such as fi broadenoma and fi bromatosis in the breast

3554.caption: Infantile digital fibromatosis: poorly circumscribed dermal/subcutaneous fibrosing lesion with bland myofibroblast-like cells. Occurs on digits (fingers>toes) in infants ≤2yo, may be multiple. Can recur but usually regresses, sometimes with scarring.
3554.original_caption: Infantile digital fi bromatosis. This is a poorly circumscribed dermal and subcutaneous fi brosing lesion composed of bundles of bland myo fi broblast-like cells. It arises mostly on the lateral or extensor aspects of the digits ( fi ngers more often than toes) in infants up to 2 years old and may be multiple. The lesions may recur but usually regress, sometimes with scarring

3566.caption: Ganglioneuroblastoma, intermixed (stroma rich) or nodular (composite stroma rich/dominant/poor)
3566.original_caption: Ganglioneuroblastoma. This is classi fi ed as intermixed (stroma rich) or nodular (composite stroma rich/stroma dominant or stroma poor), as shown here

3567.caption: Neuroblastoma post-chemotherapy: bone marrow deposits replaced by fibrous tissue/differentiated tumor. Shows maturing ganglion cells in S-100+ fibrillary stroma.
3567.original_caption: Neuroblastoma. Following chemotherapy, deposits of neuroblastoma in bone marrow may be replaced by fi brous tissue or by differentiated tumor. This example shows ganglion cells in various stages of maturation in a fi brillary stroma that is S-100 protein positive

3569.caption: Neuroblastoma. CD56 diffusely positive. Neural/neuroendocrine marker; absence in small round cell neoplasm argues against neuroblastoma.
3569.original_caption: Neuroblastoma. CD56 is diffusely positive. This is a marker of neural and neuroendocrine differentiation that is expressed in a range of neoplasms, but its absence in a small round cell neoplasm argues against a diagnosis of neuroblastoma

3568.caption: Ganglioneuroma: stroma-dominant mature neuroblastic neoplasm. Mature ganglion cells in neurofibroma-like stroma. Express neurofilaments, CD56; spindle cells S-100+. Mostly mediastinum/retroperitoneum, often incidental in adults.
3568.original_caption: Ganglioneuroma. This is the stroma-dominant mature neuroblastic neoplasm. Mature ganglion cells are dispersed in a neuro fi broma-like cellular stroma. The ganglion cells express neural markers such as neuro fi laments and CD56, and the spindle cells are S-100 protein positive. Ganglioneuroma occurs mostly in the mediastinum or retroperitoneum and often is found in adults as an incidental fi nding

3573.caption: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Rare metastasis to cervical lymph node. Primary lesion in scalp.
3573.original_caption: Angiomatoid fi brous histiocytoma. This is a rare example of metastasis to a regional (cervical) lymph node. The primary lesion was in the scalp

3574.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor. Inflammatory variant shows dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate obscuring atypical cells. Sclerosing pattern at left aids diagnosis.
3574.original_caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor. The in fl ammatory variant has a dense lymphoplasmacytic in fi ltrate that obscures the atypical cells and overgrows the fat. Here, the sclerosing pattern is seen at the left of the fi eld, which facilitates diagnosis

3572.caption: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Fibrous tissue with lymphoid aggregates surrounds cystic cellular area from hemorrhage. Subcutaneous, circumscribed tumor in upper extremity/head-neck of children/young adults.
3572.original_caption: Angiomatoid fi brous histiocytoma. Fibrous tissue with prominent lymphoid aggregates encloses a cellular area that is variably cystic as a result of intralesional hemorrhage. Typically this is a subcutaneous, circumscribed tumor occurring in the upper extremity or head and neck of children or young adults

3571.caption: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Desmin+, CD68+, EMA+. Associated translocations: t(2:22)(q33:q12) EWSR1-CREB1; t(12:16)(q13:p11) FUS-ATF1; t(12:22)(q13:q12) EWSR1
3571.original_caption: Angiomatoid fi brous histiocytoma. Desmin positivity is characteristic although not always present. CD68 and epithelial membrane antigen also test positive in many cases. The tumor is associated with three characteristic translocations and fusion genes. Most have t(2:22)(q33:q12) with EWSR1 - CREB1 fusion; others are t(12:16) (q13:p11) with FUS - ATF1 and t(12:22)(q13:q12) with EWSR1 - ATF1

3579.caption: Diffuse neurofibroma. Schwannian cells with short nuclei infiltrate subcutaneous tissue and muscle. Associated with NF-1.
3579.original_caption: Diffuse neuro fi broma. Schwannian cells with short, uniform nuclei in fi ltrate widely into subcutaneous tissue and skeletal muscle. These lesions sometimes are associated with NF-1

3576.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor, inflammatory variant. Atypical cells amid lymphocytes. May mimic lymphoma; typical areas often found with further sampling.
3576.original_caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor, in fl ammatory variant. Scattered atypical cells are seen within a sheet of lymphocytes. This tumor may be confused with lymphoma, but more common areas of atypical lipomatous tumor usually are found with further sampling

3578.caption: Myxoid neurofibroma. Myxoid stromal accumulation resembles other myxoid neoplasms. S-100 immunostaining aids diagnosis.
3578.original_caption: Myxoid neuro fi broma. Marked myxoid stromal accumulation may create a resemblance to other myxoid neoplasms. Immunostaining for S-100 protein can indicate the correct diagnosis
