3581.caption: Atypical neurofibroma. Scattered cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei. No hypercellularity, nuclear crowding, or mitotic activity to suggest malignancy.
3581.original_caption: Atypical neuro fi broma. Scattered cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei are seen. In the absence of hypercellularity with backto-back nuclear crowding and mitotic activity, this is not a feature of malignancy

3580.caption: Diffuse neurofibroma with Wagner-Meissner bodies. Shows fully developed and incompletely formed structures composed of schwannian processes, basement membrane material, S-100 protein positive.
3580.original_caption: Diffuse neuro fi broma. A distinctive feature of this lesion is the presence of Wagner-Meissner bodies. This image shows a fully developed Wagner-Meissner body, but incompletely formed examples often may be encountered. These structures are formed of schwannian processes and basement membrane material and are S-100 protein positive

3582.caption: Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. Large collagenous nodules feature in some cases, described as hyalinizing spindle cell tumors with giant rosettes. Genetically identical, no longer separately defined.
3582.original_caption: Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. Large collagenous nodules are a feature in some cases. This feature has led to their description as hyalinizing spindle cell tumors with giant rosettes, but they are genetically identical and no longer separately de fi ned

3583.caption: Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. Nuclei vary slightly. Speckled chromatin, some angulated/rectangular. Differs from myofibroblastic lesions' ovoid nuclei with punctate nucleoli.
3583.original_caption: Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. Nuclei vary slightly in size. Chromatin is speckled, and some show characteristic angulation or rectangular shape. These differ from nuclei of myo fi broblastic lesions that are ovoid with punctate nucleoli

3586.caption: Soft tissue chondroma. Mature chondrocytes in hyalinized stroma.
3586.original_caption: Soft tissue chondroma. Mature chondrocytes are dispersed in hyalinized stroma

3570.caption: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Ovoid lesional cells resemble cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma, arranged in sheets. Lymphoid cuff (top left). Absent lymph node architecture/subcapsular sinus distinguishes from lymph node metastasis.
3570.original_caption: Angiomatoid fi brous histiocytoma. The lesional cells are ovoid and resemble those of cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma. They are arranged in sheets. There is a lymphoid cuff ( top left ). The absence of lymph node architecture, including the subcapsular sinus, enables distinction from a lymph node metastasis

3575.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor (well-differentiated liposarcoma), non-metastasizing but prone to recurrence and dedifferentiation. Intermediate neoplasm, commonly in abdomen, retroperitoneum, deep soft tissue. Large size, especially abdominal. Microscopy: differentiated adipose tissue, variable adipocyte size, hyperchromatic nuclei in fibrous septa. Rare mitoses, lipoblasts
3575.original_caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor. This tumor also is known as well-differentiated liposarcoma, but the former term is used here because this lesion does not metastasize. However, it is prone to repeated recurrences, especially when it is deep-seated, and it may undergo dedifferentiation. It is categorized as an intermediate neoplasm. The most common sites are in the abdomen and retroperitoneum and in the deep soft tissue of the groin, proximal thigh, shoulder girdle, or trunk wall. These tumors often attain a large size, especially in the abdomen. Microscopically, the tumor is made up of differentiated adipose tissue with some variation in adipocyte size and scattered cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei (without prominent nucleoli). These often are present in irregular fi brous septa that traverse the fatty tissue. Mitoses are seen rarely, and although lipoblasts may be found, their presence is not essential for the diagnosis. Sclerosing, in fl ammatory, and lipomalike subtypes are described and may coexist in the same tumor in various proportions. These histologic variants have no clinical signi fi cance

3585.caption: Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. Fibrous areas resemble fibromatosis. Differential includes perineurioma; both may express EMA/claudin-1. MUC4 IHC and genetic analysis confirm diagnosis.
3585.original_caption: Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. The more fi brous areas resemble fi bromatosis. The differential diagnosis includes perineurioma, and both tumors may express EMA and claudin-1. However, immunohistochemical results for MUC4 and genetic analysis can provide the correct diagnosis

3577.caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor, sclerosing variant: irregular collagen fibers with scattered hyperchromatic nuclei, no discernible cytoplasm or adipocytes. Features focal, adjacent to lipoma-like areas.
3577.original_caption: Atypical lipomatous tumor. The sclerosing variant has areas of irregularly arranged collagen fi bers containing scattered, enlarged, irregularly hyperchromatic and sometimes multiple nuclei. Cytoplasm is not discernible, and adipocytes are not seen. However, these features usually are seen focally, with more lipoma-like areas elsewhere

3588.caption: Soft tissue chondroma; may show myxoid change, epithelioid & giant cell granulomatous reaction.
3588.original_caption: Soft tissue chondroma. In some cases, myxoid change and adjacent epithelioid and giant cell granulomatous reaction may be seen

3584.caption: Low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. MUC4 immunoreactivity, highly sensitive/specific. Translocation [t(7;16)(q33;p11)], FUS-CREB3L2 (rarely FUS-CREB3L1) fusion gene.
3584.original_caption: Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. There is diffuse immunoreactivity for MUC4, which is highly sensitive and speci fi c for this tumor type. Low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma has a speci fi c translocation [t(7;16)(q33;p11)], with FUS-CREB3L2 fusion gene (or, rarely, FUS-CREB3L1 )

3587.caption: Soft tissue chondroma: subcutaneous lesion in adult digits, circumscribed, lobules of differentiated cartilage, focal calcification.
3587.original_caption: Soft tissue chondroma. This lesion occurs in subcutaneous soft tissue mainly in the digits of adults. It is circumscribed and formed of lobules of differentiated cartilage, which may show focal calci fi cation

3589.caption: Soft tissue chondroma with stippled calcification and ring-like pericellular deposition
3589.original_caption: Soft tissue chondroma. A distinctive pattern of stippled calci fi cation with ring-like pericellular deposition is sometimes seen

3590.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma, proximal aggressive variant. Cells show rhabdoid morphology, eccentric nucleus displacement by cytoplasmic intermediate filament inclusion.
3590.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma, proximal aggressive variant. Some cells show rhabdoid morphology, with eccentric displacement of the nucleus by a large cytoplasmic inclusion formed of abundant intermediate fi laments

3597.caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Desmin IHC: diffuse cytoplasmic positivity
3597.original_caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Immunohistochemical staining for desmin shows diffuse cytoplasmic positivity

3592.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma, proximal aggressive variant. Large polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli, extensive necrosis. Arises in axial/proximal locations: perineum, trunk, limb girdles. High-grade sarcoma with rapid progression.
3592.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma, proximal aggressive variant. Large polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli and extensive necrosis characterize this variant, which typically arises in central (axial) or proximal locations, including the perineum and trunk and limb girdles. As the name implies, this sarcoma behaves like a high-grade sarcoma with rapid progression

3595.caption: Chordoma. Rare outside spine/skull, metastatic or extra-axial. Similar to skeletal chordoma. Epithelioid cells in myxoid stroma.
3595.original_caption: Chordoma. This tumor occurs very rarely outside the vertebral column and skull either as metastatic disease or as extra-axial chordoma. The appearance is similar to that of skeletal chordoma. Cords of epithelioid cells are dispersed in myxoid stroma

3598.caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Myogenin IHC shows positive nuclei, confirming skeletal muscle differentiation.
3598.original_caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Immunohistochemical staining for myogenin shows numerous positive nuclei, con fi rming skeletal muscle differentiation

3593.caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Rare myxoid change. Lymphocytes adhere to cell bodies/processes. EBV-associated variant in liver/spleen/retroperitoneum.
3593.original_caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Rarely, there is marked myxoid change. The lymphocytes are seen to adhere to cell bodies and processes. An in fl ammatory pseudotumor-like Epstein-Barr virus– associated variant also is described in the liver, spleen, or retroperitoneum

3591.caption: Extrarenal malignant rhabdoid tumor. Rhabdoid cells show eosinophilic cytoplasm displacing nucleus. Seen in epithelioid sarcoma, chondrosarcoma, myoepithelial tumor, melanoma, carcinoma, rhabdomyosarcoma. High-grade neoplasm, expresses epithelial antigens, lacks CD34, INI-1 negative.
3591.original_caption: Extrarenal malignant rhabdoid tumor. Rhabdoid cells have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm that often displaces the nucleus to one side. They may be found in a variety of speci fi c neoplasms, including epithelioid sarcoma, extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma, myoepithelial tumor, melanoma, carcinoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma. Malignant rhabdoid tumor is a high-grade neoplasm that usually expresses epithelial antigens but lacks CD34 and other features of speci fi c differentiation, and it is immunohistochemically negative for INI-1

3594.caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. IHC+ for CD21, CD35, CD23, D2-40, fascin. Some cases express EMA, S-100. Immunoperoxidase.
3594.original_caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD21 (shown here), CD35, CD23, D2-40, and fascin. Some cases also express epithelial membrane antigen and S-100 protein. Immunoperoxidase technique

3596.caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Lesional cells show prominent nuclear membranes, speckled chromatin, small nuclei, indistinct boundaries, syncytial appearance. Multinucleated cells, pleomorphism, necrosis present. Extranodal cases have >40% recurrence rate.
3596.original_caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. The lesional cells have prominent nuclear membranes, with speckled chromatin and small nuclei. Cell boundaries are indistinct, imparting a somewhat syncytial appearance. Multinucleated cells sometimes are seen, and some examples show pleomorphism and necrosis. Extranodal follicular dendritic cell sarcomas have a recurrence rate of over 40 %

3607.caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma. Deeper dermis: slit-like vessels with dense lymphocytic infiltrate.
3607.original_caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma. In the deeper dermis, the vessels are more slit-like and associated with a dense lymphocytic in fi ltrate

3604.caption: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma. Multiple fibrovascular-walled cysts, intra-abdominal lesion, common in adult females with endometriosis, PID, or prior abdominal surgery.
3604.original_caption: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma. Multiple cysts with fi brovascular walls from an intra-abdominal lesion, most commonly in adult females who have had endometriosis, pelvic in fl ammatory disease, or abdominal surgery

3603.caption: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma. Cysts lined with low cuboidal/flat mesothelial cells, immunoreactive for CK5/6 and calretinin.
3603.original_caption: Multicystic peritoneal mesothelioma. The cysts are lined with a layer of low cuboidal or fl at mesothelial cells that are immunoreactive for cytokeratins, including CK5/6 and calretinin

3602.caption: Adenomatoid tumor. Plump mesothelial cells form tubular/gland-like structures in mildly inflamed fibrous stroma. No atypia. Common in genital tracts, rare in adrenals/pancreas/mediastinum.
3602.original_caption: Adenomatoid tumor. Plump mesothelial cells form tubular or gland-like structures in mildly in fl amed fi brous stroma. No atypical features are seen. This occurs mostly in the male and female genital tracts and rarely in other visceral locations, including the adrenals, the pancreas, or the mediastinum

3600.caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid type, bladder. Tumor forms grape-like myxoid protuberances. Cells concentrate beneath epithelium in cambium layer, with deeper myxoid areas containing rhabdomyoblasts.
3600.original_caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, botryoid type, urinary bladder. Embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas in hollow viscera often result in multiple myxoid protuberances supposedly resembling a bunch of grapes. Typically, tumor cells are concentrated beneath surface epithelium in a cambium layer, with myxoid areas located more deeply, here containing rounded rhabdomyoblasts

3601.caption: Reactive mesothelial hyperplasia: sheets/papillary tufts of polygonal cells, no atypia/stroma invasion. Atypical form shows focal/diffuse atypia. Tumor mass suggests mesothelioma. May precede mesothelioma, needs long-term follow-up.
3601.original_caption: Reactive mesothelial hyperplasia. This lesion forms sheets or papillary tufts of polygonal cells that may be distinguished from mesothelioma by the absence of atypical cytologic features and of the invasion of underlying stroma. In atypical mesothelial hyperplasia, there are single or multiple layers of cells with focal or diffuse atypia. The presence of a de fi nite tumor mass or masses favors the diagnosis of mesothelioma. Reactive mesothelial hyperplasia also may herald the later development of mesothelioma, indicating the need for long-term follow-up

3606.caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. Tumor expresses CK AE1/3, variably CD31+. CD34, desmin negative. Immunoperoxidase.
3606.original_caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. This tumor expresses CK AE1/3 and is variably immunoreactive for CD31 (illustrated here). CD34 and desmin are negative. Immunoperoxidase technique

3599.caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: spindle cell tumor with myxoid stroma, mild pleomorphism, mitotic activity. Requires IHC for diagnosis in pediatric GU/pelvic/bile duct/head-neck sites. Lacks translocations seen in alveolar type.
3599.original_caption: Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. This is a spindle cell tumor that often has myxoid stroma, the presence of which reduces its cellularity. There is mild pleomorphism and mitotic activity. Immunohistochemical study usually is required for this diagnosis, which should always be considered in an infant or child when the tumor is in an appropriate anatomic location, including genitourinary, pelvic, bile duct, and head and neck sites. In contrast to alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, this tumor does not have diagnostic translocations

3605.caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma: occurs on extremities/trunk in young adults, locally recurrent, rarely metastasizes. Irregular dilated vessels in superficial dermis, resembling rete testis. Enlarged endothelial cells protrude into lumen with hobnail appearance.
3605.original_caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma. This tumor occurs mostly on the extremities or trunk in young adults and may be locally recurrent but usually does not metastasize. Irregularly dilated vessels are seen in the super fi cial dermis, arranged in a pattern resembling rete testis. Endothelial cells are enlarged and protrude into the lumen with a hobnail appearance

3608.caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma. SMA immunostaining shows absent pericytic layer around lesional vessels.
3608.original_caption: Retiform hemangioendothelioma. Immunostaining for smooth muscle actin shows the absence of the pericytic layer around lesional vessels

3609.caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Nuclear palisading may occur. Differentiated from nerve sheath tumors by SMA, desmin, h-caldesmon positivity and S-100 negativity.
3609.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Nuclear palisading sometimes is a feature of this tumor. It may be distinguished from a nerve sheath tumor by immunoreactivity for SMA, desmin, and h-caldesmon, and the absence of S-100 protein

3616.caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Myxoid stroma separates cells, with parallel not tapered margins.
3616.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Myxoid stromal change separates the cells, which may be seen to have parallel rather than tapered margins

3618.caption: Myopericytoma. Spindle cells in sheets/whorls, focally surround vessels. Thin-walled vessels between cellular areas.
3618.original_caption: Myopericytoma. Spindle cells are arranged in sheets and whorls and focally surround vessels. Thin-walled vessels are seen between cellular areas

3611.caption: Poorly differentiated leiomyosarcoma. Fascicular architecture less defined but evident. Widespread nuclear pleomorphism.
3611.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma, poorly differentiated. The fascicular architecture is less well-de fi ned but still evident. There is more widespread nuclear pleomorphism

3610.caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Cells in fascicles intersecting at right angles. Well-differentiated: abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, focal nuclear pleomorphism.
3610.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma. The cells are arranged in fascicles that intersect at right angles in several planes. In this well-differentiated example, the cytoplasm is abundant and eosinophilic, and there is only focal nuclear pleomorphism

3613.caption: Malignant myoepithelial tumor (myoepithelial carcinoma). Branching cords of atypical cells with mitoses. Spindle cell variant possible.
3613.original_caption: Malignant myoepithelial tumor (myoepithelial carcinoma). This example has branching cords of atypical cells with mitoses. A spindle cell variant may occur

3612.caption: Leiomyosarcoma. Tumor cells with blunt-ended nuclei, paranuclear vacuole (center). Finely fibrillary cytoplasm. Mitoses and nuclear atypia present.
3612.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma. The tumor cells have nontapered bluntended nuclei, sometimes with a paranuclear vacuole ( center ). The cytoplasm is fi nely fi brillary. Mitoses and nuclear atypia usually are present

3617.caption: Leiomyosarcoma cutis. Cellular tumor with irregular margins fills dermis. Malignant histologic features, no subcutis extension, rarely metastasize - termed atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasms.
3617.original_caption: Leiomyosarcoma cutis. A cellular tumor with irregular margins fi lls the dermis. Tumors with malignant histologic features that do not extend into the subcutis metastasize very rarely and have been termed atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasms

3614.caption: Epithelioid leiomyosarcoma: cuboidal cells with pleomorphic nuclei, spindle cell areas. Immunohistochemistry needed. Common in female genital tract; differentiate from PEComa, epithelioid GISTs in abdomen.
3614.original_caption: Epithelioid leiomyosarcoma. Sheets of cuboidal cells with mildly pleomorphic rounded nuclei lack distinguishing morphologic features. More typical spindle cell areas sometimes are found, but immunohistochemical analysis often is required for diagnosis. Epithelioid smooth muscle tumors are most common in the female genital tract and need to be distinguished from PEComa; in the abdomen, they must be distinguished from epithelioid GISTs

3615.caption: Pleomorphic leiomyosarcoma adjacent to undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (MFH-like). Fascicular pattern in leiomyosarcoma (<1/3 tumor). Muscle antigens expressed in fascicular/pleomorphic areas (fewer cells in latter). Muscle antigen expression in pleomorphic sarcoma indicates poor prognosis.
3615.original_caption: Pleomorphic leiomyosarcoma. Undifferentiated (malignant fi brous histiocytoma-like) pleomorphic sarcoma is seen adjacent to the leiomyosarcoma with the characteristic fascicular pattern. The latter component constitutes less than one third of the tumor. Muscle antigens are expressed in fascicular and pleomorphic areas, but in fewer cells in the latter. However, expression of any muscle antigen in a pleomorphic sarcoma is an adverse prognostic factor

3626.caption: Myopericytoma. Concentric myopericytes around vascular lumen.
3626.original_caption: Myopericytoma. Concentric layers of myopericytes are arranged around the vascular lumen

3627.caption: Malignant myopericytoma: rare tumor with nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, necrosis.
3627.original_caption: Malignant myopericytoma. This is an extremely rare tumor that manifests nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and necrosis

3621.caption: Myopericytoma. Uniform cells, no nuclear pleomorphism. SMA+, h-caldesmon+, desmin-, CD34-.
3621.original_caption: Myopericytoma. The cells are uniform and lack nuclear pleomorphism. Immunostaining is positive for smooth muscle actin and h-caldesmon and usually negative for desmin and CD34

3619.caption: Myopericytoma: circumscribed subcutaneous tumor of spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, arranged in sheets with dilated vessels.
3619.original_caption: Myopericytoma. This is a circumscribed subcutaneous tumor of sheets of small spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in sheets punctuated by clusters of dilated vessels

3624.caption: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor. Circumscribed cellular nodules, variable size/number. Proposed deep variant of cellular neurothekeoma.
3624.original_caption: Plexiform fi brohistiocytic tumor. The cellular nodules are circumscribed and of variable size and number. It has been proposed that this represents the deep variant of cellular neurothekeoma

3623.caption: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor. Fibroblastic variant: spindle cells in branching fascicles infiltrate subcutis. Cellular and fibroblastic patterns may coexist.
3623.original_caption: Plexiform fi brohistiocytic tumor. In the fi broblastic variant, branching fascicles of spindle cells permeate the subcutis. The cellular and fi broblastic patterns may coexist

3622.caption: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor at dermal-subcutaneous junction with cellular nodules extending into dermis/subcutaneous fat. Mostly in adolescents' upper limbs.
3622.original_caption: Plexiform fi brohistiocytic tumor. The lesion is based on the dermal–subcutaneous junction and includes cellular nodules that extend into the dermis and subcutaneous fat. This lesion arises mostly in adolescents on the upper limbs

3625.caption: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor: rounded histiocyte-like cells, multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes, hemosiderin, no atypia. Older lesions may fibrose.
3625.original_caption: Plexiform fi brohistiocytic tumor. There is a mixture of rounded histiocyte-like cells, multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes, and hemosiderin, without atypia. Older lesions also may become fi brosed

3628.caption: Sinonasal hemangiopericytoma (glomangiopericytoma). Uniform nuclei, moderate cytoplasm, indistinct boundaries. Perivascular myoid cell tumor. SMA+, CD34-, unlike solitary fibrous tumors.
3628.original_caption: Sinonasal hemangiopericytoma (glomangiopericytoma). The cells have uniform nuclei, moderate amounts of cytoplasm, and indistinct cell boundaries. This now is considered a tumor of perivascular myoid cells. Immunohistochemical analysis is positive for smooth muscle actin and negative for CD34, unlike in solitary fi brous tumors

3620.caption: Malignant glomus tumor. Nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, mitotic activity. Malignancy criteria: deep location, size >2cm, atypical mitoses, high nuclear grade, ≥5 mitoses/50 HPF.
3620.original_caption: Malignant glomus tumor. Nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic activity are features of malignancy seen here. Criteria for malignancy include deep location and size greater than 2 cm, atypical mitotic fi gures, or moderate to high nuclear grade and ³ 5 mitotic fi gures per 50 high-power fi elds

3629.caption: Sinonasal hemangiopericytoma (glomangiopericytoma). Uniform cells around dilated thin-walled vessels. Exophytic nasal/paranasal sinus tumor causing epistaxis/blockage. Local recurrence risk, rare metastasis. Malignant potential if mitoses/pleomorphism/necrosis present.
3629.original_caption: Sinonasal hemangiopericytoma (glomangiopericytoma). Sheets of uniform cells are arranged around dilated thin-walled vessels. This is an exophytic (polypoid) tumor that presents in the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses with epistaxis or blockage. It has the potential for local recurrence but usually does not metastasize. However, some examples have frequent mitoses, pleomorphism, and necrosis, suggesting malignant potential

3630.caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Glandular formations in solid cellular areas.
3630.original_caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Glandular formations are dispersed within solid cellular areas

3631.caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Pleural tumor with papillary, tubular patterns and psammoma bodies.
3631.original_caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. This pleural tumor has complex papillary and tubular patterns and contains psammoma bodies

3633.caption: Adenomatoid tumor. Mesothelial cells line cyst-like spaces, immunoreactive for calretinin (nuclear) and cytokeratins.
3633.original_caption: Adenomatoid tumor. In this example, mesothelial cells are fl attened and appear to line cyst-like spaces. As is the case in other mesothelial proliferations, the cells are immunoreactive for calretinin (in nuclei) and cytokeratins

3637.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Tumor cells infiltrate small blood vessel walls, a characteristic feature.
3637.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. In fi ltration of the walls of small blood vessels by tumor cells is a characteristic feature

3634.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Focal S-100 protein expression, nuclear positivity in single cells. Correlates with Schwann cell differentiation by ultrastructural exam.
3634.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. S-100 protein expression usually is focal, with nuclear positivity in separated groups of single cells. Expression of this antigen correlates with the degree of Schwann cell differentiation as assessed by ultrastructural examination

3638.caption: Myositis ossificans. Older lesions may show zoning with mature bone peripherally.
3638.original_caption: Myositis ossi fi cans. As shown here, older lesions may show a zoning phenomenon with mature bone at the periphery

3635.caption: Epithelioid MPNST, superficial/deep, plump polygonal cells, prominent nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Diffusely S-100+, lacks HMB45/Melan-A. 50% INI1 nuclear loss.
3635.original_caption: Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Epithelioid MPNST may be super fi cial or deep and is composed of plump polygonal cells with prominent nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Unlike regular MPNSTs, the tumor cells are diffusely immunoreactive for S-100 protein but lack HMB45 and Melan-A. About half the cases lack nuclear expression of INI1

3636.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Tumor cells show wavy, buckled, arrowhead-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei.
3636.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. The tumor cells have wavy, buckled, or arrowhead-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei

3632.caption: Well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma. Hypocellular fibrous cores with cuboidal mesothelial cells. No cytologic atypia. Surface cell exfoliation. Occurs in pleura, peritoneum (female predominance), paratesticular tissue. Rare malignant progression.
3632.original_caption: Well-differentiated papillary mesothelioma. Hypocellular fi brous cores are covered by a single layer of cuboidal mesothelial cells. No signi fi cant cytologic atypia is seen. Note the exfoliation of surface cells. This lesion can occur in the pleura, peritoneum (more commonly in females), and paratesticular tissue. Rarely, progression to malignant mesothelioma occurs

3639.caption: Myositis ossificans. Maturing lesion: stroma less cellular, cartilage formation possible.
3639.original_caption: Myositis ossi fi cans. As the lesion matures, the stroma becomes less cellular. Cartilage formation may be seen

3644.caption: Retroperitoneal fibrosis. Inflammatory component: neutrophils, eosinophils, predominant plasma cells.
3644.original_caption: Retroperitoneal fi brosis. The in fl ammatory component includes neutrophil and eosinophil polymorphs and a predominance of plasma cells

3645.caption: Retroperitoneal fibrosis. Early stage shows cellular fibrous tissue with lymphoid aggregates (B/T lymphocytes), plasma cells, eosinophils. Spindle cells immunoreactive for smooth muscle actin, β-catenin negative nuclei.
3645.original_caption: Retroperitoneal fi brosis. In the early stages, cellular fi brous tissue may be seen containing lymphoid aggregates (mixed B and T lymphocytes), clusters of plasma cells, and sometimes eosinophils. The spindle cells are immunoreactive for smooth muscle actin, and nuclei are negative for b -catenin

3647.caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma. PAS-diastase staining shows needle-shaped crystals.
3647.original_caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma. Staining with periodic acid– Schiff (PAS) technique pretreated with diastase shows bundles of characteristic needle-shaped crystals

3640.caption: Fibro-osseous pseudotumor in subcutaneous tissue, mainly proximal phalanges. Shows irregular bone/cartilage formation in fasciitis-like granulation tissue. Variant of nodular fasciitis. No nuclear atypia, excludes extraosseous osteosarcoma.
3640.original_caption: Fibro-osseous pseudotumor. This lesion occurs in subcutaneous soft tissue, mainly of the proximal phalanges of digits, and displays irregular bone and cartilage formation in a background of fasciitis-like granulation tissue. This may be regarded as a variant of nodular fasciitis, although it occurs in a speci fi c clinicopathologic setting. The absence of nuclear atypia and the location exclude extraosseous osteosarcoma

3641.caption: Myositis ossificans. Irregular bone formation in inflamed granulation tissue resembling nodular fasciitis. Occurs in large muscles post-trauma or heterotopic sites like mesentery.
3641.original_caption: Myositis ossi fi cans. Irregular bone formation occurs in in fl amed granulation tissue resembling nodular fasciitis. This arises in large muscles sometimes following trauma, but it also may arise in heterotopic locations, including the mesentery

3650.caption: Atypical fibroxanthoma. Pleomorphic spindle cells in storiform pattern.
3650.original_caption: Atypical fi broxanthoma. Pleomorphic spindle cells are arranged in a storiform pattern

3643.caption: Nuchal/nuchal-type fibroma: thick collagen bundles with scant CD34+ fibroblasts infiltrate dermis/subcutis, entrapping nerves/adnexa. Collagen cracking artifact. 50% associated with diabetes. Gardner fibroma histologically identical to nuchal/nuchal-type fibroma.
3643.original_caption: Nuchal and nuchal-type fi broma. Randomly oriented thick collagen bundles with scanty CD34-positive fi broblasts in fi ltrate the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, often entrapping nerves and adnexa. There is a cracking artifact within the collagen bundles. About half the cases arise in patients with diabetes mellitus. The lesions of Gardner and Gardner-associated fi broma are histologically identical to those of nuchal fi broma and nuchal-type fi broma (which occur in nonnuchal locations)

3642.caption: Reactive nodular fibrous pseudotumor: spindled/stellate fibroblasts in collagenous stroma. Mesentery/intestinal nodules, mainly males, post-abdominal surgery. IHC: β-catenin-, CD34-, CD117-, excludes fibromatosis, solitary fibrous tumor, GIST.
3642.original_caption: Reactive nodular fi brous pseudotumor. Spindled or stellate fi broblasts are scattered in a densely collagenous stroma. This lesion arises in the mesentery or on the intestinal surface as solitary or multiple nodules; it occurs mainly in males and may follow abdominal surgery. Immunohistochemical analysis is negative for b -catenin, unlike in many intra-abdominal fi bromatoses; negative for CD34, helping to exclude solitary fi brous tumor; and negative for CD117, aiding in its distinction from gastrointestinal stromal tumor

3651.caption: Atypical fibroxanthoma. Uniform spindle cells, high mitotic index, no specific differentiation on immunohistochemistry.
3651.original_caption: Atypical fi broxanthoma. More uniform spindle cells sometimes are seen, as in this example. However, there is a very high mitotic index, and immunohistochemical analysis shows no speci fi c differentiation

3646.caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma, solid variant. Neoplastic cells closely packed, nested pattern unclear. More common in childhood.
3646.original_caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma, solid variant. The neoplastic cells are packed closely, and the nested pattern is not apparent. This variant is more common in childhood

3649.caption: Clear cell sarcoma: nests of uniform cells with rounded nuclei, prominent nucleoli, fibrous septa. High-grade tumor in distal extremities (young adults). Immunoreactive for S-100, HMB45, Melan-A; t(12;22)(q13;q12) EWSR1-ATF1 fusion. Absent junctional activity, specific translocation distinguishes from
3649.original_caption: Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue. Nests of uniform cells with rounded nuclei and small prominent nucleoli are separated by fi brous septa. This is a high-grade soft tissue tumor that favors the distal extremities in young adults. The tumor is immunoreactive for S-100 protein, HMB45, and Melan-A and has a t(12;22)(q13;q12) rearrangement with EWSR1 - ATF1 fusion. The absence of junctional activity and the presence of the speci fi c translocation help distinguish this tumor from primary (and metastatic) melanoma

3654.caption: Spindle cell liposarcoma: cellular spindle lesion with lipoblasts, genetically similar to spindle cell lipoma, considered its atypical variant.
3654.original_caption: Spindle cell liposarcoma. This cellular spindle lesion with scattered lipoblasts originally was considered a variant of well-differentiated liposarcoma that might dedifferentiate. However, it has been shown to be genetically similar to spindle cell lipoma and may be regarded as its atypical variant

3652.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma. Epidermis thinned over ill-defined cellular lesion, extending laterally beneath epidermis and into subcutaneous fat. Tumor grows along connective tissue septa parallel to surface.
3652.original_caption: Dermato fi brosarcoma. The epidermis is thinned over an illde fi ned cellular lesion. This extends laterally beneath the epidermis and deeply into subcutaneous fat. The tumor grows along connective tissue septa that are parallel to the surface

3653.caption: Atypical fibroxanthoma: ulcerated, dome-shaped, dermal lesion in sun-exposed areas of older individuals. Deep extension into subcutaneous tissue classifies as superficial undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.
3653.original_caption: Atypical fi broxanthoma. This ulcerated lesion is dome shaped, elevated, and con fi ned to the dermis. It arises typically in sunexposed areas in older individuals. Similar tumors that extend signi fi cantly into subcutaneous tissue are regarded as super fi cial undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas

3655.caption: Microvenular hemangioma: solitary dermal nodule on limbs in young adults. Small thickened-wall vessels dispersed in dermis, often with hemosiderin pigment.
3655.original_caption: Microvenular hemangioma. This is a solitary dermal nodule found on limbs in young adults. Small-caliber vessels with thickened walls are dispersed in the dermis, which often contains hemosiderin pigment

3656.caption: Epithelioid hemangioma (angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia). Localized lesion around central blood vessel, peripheral lymphoid aggregates. Occurs head/neck/other sites, may be multiple.
3656.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. A localized lesion is arranged around a central blood vessel, with peripheral lymphoid aggregates. This lesion may appear on the head and neck and other sites and may be multiple. It is also known as angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia

3658.caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. Thick-walled vessels lined by plump endothelial cells extending into vessel wall.
3658.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. Thick-walled vessels are lined with plump endothelial cells that extend into the vessel wall

3657.caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. Central vessel thrombosed, epithelioid endothelial cell proliferation.
3657.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioma. The central vessel may be thrombosed, with proliferation of epithelioid endothelial cells

3648.caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma. Large polygonal cells in nests with fibrous septa. Tumor cells have rounded nuclei, distinct nucleoli, granular cytoplasm. No pleomorphism. Aggressive neoplasm, proximal limbs in young adults, early metastasis. Head/neck in children. TFE3+ (ASPCR1-TFE3 fusion). Some express desmin.
3648.original_caption: Alveolar soft part sarcoma. Large polygonal cells are arranged in nests separated by slender fi brous septa. The tumor cells have rounded nuclei, each with a small distinct nucleolus. The cytoplasm is fi nely granular. Pleomorphism is absent. This is an aggressive neoplasm that typically presents in the proximal limbs of young adults and metastasizes early. A subset occurs in the head and neck region in children. Transcription factor E3 (TFE3) may be positive, in association with the genetic rearrangement der(17)t(X;17)(p11;q25) that results in the fusion gene ASPCR1 - TFE3 . Some examples also express desmin

3659.caption: Intimal sarcoma in pulmonary trunk/artery, involving right heart/aorta. Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with storiform pattern, focal myxoid stroma.
3659.original_caption: Intimal sarcoma. This arises in the pulmonary trunk and/or artery, involving the right side of the heart and sometimes the aorta. Most examples are undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas, here seen with a storiform pattern and focally myxoid stroma

3678.caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor. Large intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions typical.
3678.original_caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor. Large intranuclear cytoplasmic inclusions are a typical feature

3666.caption: Palisaded encapsulated neuroma consists of Schwann cells, axons, and perineurial cell pseudocapsule.
3666.original_caption: Palisaded encapsulated (solitary circumscribed) neuroma is composed of Schwann cells and axons with a pseudocapsule of perineurial cells

3663.caption: Neurofibroma: thick collagen bundles, sparse cellularity, "shredded carrot" appearance.
3663.original_caption: Neuro fi broma. Thick collagen bundles with sparse cellularity may give a “shredded carrot” appearance

3672.caption: Schwannoma. Blood vessels with hyalinized walls, thrombosis, hemosiderin, foamy macrophages.
3672.original_caption: Schwannoma. Clusters of blood vessels with hyalinized walls often are a feature, sometimes with thrombosis and associated hemosiderin pigmentation and foamy macrophages

3677.caption: Ectopic hamartomatous thymoma. Lower neck tumor in adult males. Spindle cell fascicles with solid/cystic/glandular epithelium ± mature fat.
3677.original_caption: Ectopic hamartomatous thymoma. This tumor occurs in the lower neck in adult males. Fascicles of spindle cells contain solid, cystic, or glandular epithelial elements and sometimes mature fat

3671.caption: Sclerosing perineurioma. Rounded cell cords/nests in fibrous stroma. Involves digits in young males. Immunohistochemically/genetically similar to perineuriomas.
3671.original_caption: Sclerosing perineurioma. Cords and nests of predominantly rounded cells are dispersed in fi brous stroma. This tumor typically involves the digits in young adult males and is immunohistochemically and genetically similar to other perineuriomas

3665.caption: Palisaded encapsulated neuroma. Circumscribed dermal nodule, may be multiple. "Feeder" nerve may enter lesion. Common in head/neck, especially face.
3665.original_caption: Palisaded encapsulated (solitary circumscribed) neuroma. This is a circumscribed dermal nodule, which sometimes may be multiple. In a suitable plane of section, a “feeder” nerve may be found when entering the lesion. The head and neck, especially the face, are the usual sites

3673.caption: Intestinal perineurioma. Slender cells in myxoid stroma with prominent vessels. Mostly in females, colonic/jejunal mucosa/submucosa. Also called polypoid fibroblastic tumors of colon.
3673.original_caption: Intestinal perineurioma. Slender cells are dispersed in a myxoid stroma with prominent blood vessels. These occur mostly in females in colonic or jejunal mucosa or submucosa. Similar tumors have been termed polypoid fi broblastic tumors of the colon

3667.caption: Localized giant cell tumor of tendon sheath (nodular tenosynovitis). Sharp demarcation, characteristic slits and pseudoalveolar spaces from cell separation. Mainly in adult digits, often tendon sheath-related.
3667.original_caption: Localized giant cell tumor of the tendon sheath type (nodular tenosynovitis). There is sharp demarcation, and the tumor shows characteristic slits and pseudoalveolar spaces as a result of loss of cohesion and separation of the cells. This lesion occurs mainly in the digits of adults and often is related to a tendon sheath

3670.caption: Deep benign fibrous histiocytoma. Spindle cells in storiform pattern. Occasional hemangiopericytic pattern, multinucleated cells, foamy cell clusters, fibrosis/ossification. Mitotic activity common, focal necrosis possible, no malignant potential.
3670.original_caption: Deep benign fi brous histiocytoma. Spindle cells are arranged in a storiform pattern. Other occasional features are a focal hemangiopericytic pattern, multinucleated cells, clusters of foamy cells, and fi brosis or even ossi fi cation. Mitotic activity is not uncommon, and focal necrosis may occur, which does not imply malignant potential

3675.caption: Ectopic hamartomatous thymoma. Uniform spindle cells lack nuclear atypia. Diffusely express epithelial antigens (vs focal in synovial sarcoma), sometimes CD34. Possible mixed tumor/myoepithelioma variant, but S-100/GFAP negative.
3675.original_caption: Ectopic hamartomatous thymoma. The spindle cells are uniform and lack nuclear atypia. They express epithelial antigens diffusely (unlike the focal expression in synovial sarcoma) and CD34 in some cases. It has been suggested that this lesion is a variant of mixed tumor/myoepithelioma, although S-100 protein and glial fi brillary acidic protein (GFAP) test negative

3660.caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma. Rare cases show undifferentiated areas with frequent mitoses, lack significant nuclear pleomorphism like most translocation-associated sarcomas.
3660.original_caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma. Rare examples have undifferentiated areas with frequent mitoses, but like most translocation-associated sarcomas, they lack signi fi cant nuclear pleomorphism

3676.caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor. Pleomorphic cells in fibrous stroma near dilated vessel with fibrinoid cuff. Benign subcutaneous lesion, typically in adults on ankle/foot.
3676.original_caption: Pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor. Pleomorphic cells are present within fi brous stroma adjacent to a dilated blood vessel with a cuff of extravasated fi brinoid material. This is a benign subcutaneous lesion that typically arises in adults on the ankle or foot

3668.caption: Diffuse giant cell tumor of tendon sheath (pigmented villonodular synovitis). Involves joint synovium with villous hyperplasia. Common in shoulder, knee, elbow. May extend into adjacent soft tissues or occur extra-articularly.
3668.original_caption: Diffuse giant cell tumor of tendon sheath type (pigmented villonodular synovitis). This lesion involves joint synovium, which shows villous hyperplasia. Large joints such as the shoulder, knee, and elbow are the usual sites. The lesional tissue may extend irregularly into adjacent soft tissues and may occur as a wholly extra-articular lesion

3669.caption: Deep benign fibrous histiocytoma. Tapered uniform cells. 40% focally CD34+. Distinguish from solitary fibrous tumors (no capsule, variable cellularity, diffuse CD34) and dermatofibrosarcomas (dermal, infiltrative, storiform). Some SMA/desmin+ but lack smooth muscle morphology.
3669.original_caption: Deep benign fi brous histiocytoma. The lesional cells are tapered and uniform. About 40 % are focally CD34 positive, and these should be distinguished from solitary fi brous tumors (no capsule, variable cellularity, more widespread CD34) and dermato fi brosarcomas (dermal, widely in fi ltrative, uniform storiform pattern). Some express SMA and desmin but lack smooth muscle morphology

3662.caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma: anastomosing cell strands in myxoid stroma, frequent interstitial hemorrhage. High-grade neoplasm in deep/superficial soft tissues (extremities, head/neck). Indolent but common local recurrence & lung metastasis. Multinodular with myxoid/hemorrhagic cut surface.
3662.original_caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma. Anastomosing strands of cells form complex patterns within myxoid stroma. Interstitial hemorrhage is a frequent feature, although blood vessels are absent or very sparse. This is a high-grade neoplasm arising in deep or sometimes super fi cial soft tissues, mainly in the extremities in adults but also in the head and neck and other locations. Although the tumor is indolent, local recurrence and metastasis to the lung and elsewhere are common. Grossly, it is a multinodular tumor with a myxoid and hemorrhagic cut surface

3664.caption: Neurofibroma: unencapsulated lesion with Schwann cells, fibroblasts, collagen, myxoid stroma. Sporadic in young adults as dermal/subcutaneous nodule or in nerves (no malignancy risk). Multiple in NF-1 (von Recklinghausen), increased MPNST risk. Variants: atypical, diffuse, plexiform, pigmented, dendritic
3664.original_caption: Neuro fi broma. This is an unencapsulated lesion composed of Schwann cells, fi broblastic spindle cells, collagen fi bers, and variably myxoid stroma. It may arise sporadically, usually in young adults as a dermal or subcutaneous nodule, but sometimes in a larger nerve, where it is of little clinical signi fi cance because there is no increased risk of malignancy. Multiple neuro fi bromas are found in patients with NF-1 (von Recklinghausen neuro fi bromatosis), who have an increased risk of developing MPNST. There are several clinicopathologic variants of neuro fi broma, including atypical, diffuse, plexiform, pigmented, dendritic cell with pseudorosettes, and as part of a hybrid nerve sheath tumor

3674.caption: Schwannoma: nerve sheath tumor, often in extremities, head/neck, retroperitoneum, mediastinum, GI wall. Encapsulated, Antoni A (cellular, palisading) & B (myxoid) areas. NF-2 links to multiple schwannomas (e.g., bilateral acoustic neuromas), rarely malignant.
3674.original_caption: Schwannoma. This is a nerve sheath tumor that typically arises from a visible nerve in almost any part of the body. In deep sites, such as the retroperitoneum, it may become very large, up to 20 cm in diameter, before presentation. Schwannomas are most common in adults before middle age and arise mainly in the extremities and head and neck but also in the posterior mediastinum, retroperitoneum, and wall of the stomach or intestine. In nonvisceral soft tissue sites, they typically are encapsulated and have cellular areas, often with nuclear palisading around eosinophilic basement membrane material (immunoperoxidase) (Antoni A areas) and more myxoid foci with dispersed spindle cells (Antoni B areas). Multiple schwannomas, including bilateral acoustic neuromas, are found in NF-2 but rarely undergo malignant change

3661.caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma: dyscohesive cells, rounded nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm. No chondroid differentiation. Translocation-associated (NR4A3 rearrangement, often EWSR1/TAF15N). IHC variably S-100/EMA+, some CD56/chromogranin+ neuroendocrine differentiation.
3661.original_caption: Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma. In this area, the cells are dyscohesive. They have rounded nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. This tumor is unrelated to cartilaginous neoplasms and manifests no evidence of chondroid differentiation. It is a translocation-associated sarcoma, in which the NR4A3 gene at 9q22 is rearranged with one of four different partner genes (most commonly EWSR1 or TAF15N ). Immunohistochemical study is variably positive for S-100 protein and epithelial membrane antigen, and a subset has neuroendocrine differentiation with positivity for chromogranin and CD56

3679.caption: Low-grade myofibrosarcoma. Less cellular, focally myxoid, resembling nodular fasciitis. Focal nuclear pleomorphism and necrosis indicate diagnosis, absent in nodular fasciitis. Image shows pulmonary metastasis from thigh primary.
3679.original_caption: Low-grade myo fi brosarcoma. Some examples are less cellular and focally myxoid and resemble nodular fasciitis. However, focal nuclear pleomorphism and necrosis are clues to the diagnosis, because they are absent from nodular fasciitis. This image is from a pulmonary metastasis of a low-grade myo fi brosarcoma that originated in the thigh

3683.caption: Synovial sarcoma. Rare squamous metaplasia with keratinization in epithelial component.
3683.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. Squamous metaplasia with keratinization is a rare feature within the epithelial component

3687.caption: Spindle cell hemangioma. Epithelioid endothelial cells with vacuolated cytoplasm.
3687.original_caption: Spindle cell hemangioma. Epithelioid endothelial cells with vacuolated cytoplasm sometimes are a feature

3695.caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma, diffusely desmin immunoreactive.
3695.original_caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma. The tumor is diffusely immunoreactive for desmin

3696.caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma. Myogenin, a rhabdomyoblastic marker, shows in scattered tumor nuclei, confirming diagnosis. Immunoperoxidase.
3696.original_caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma. Myogenin, a speci fi c marker for rhabdomyoblastic differentiation, is demonstrable in scattered tumor cell nuclei, con fi rming the diagnosis. Immunoperoxidase technique

3685.caption: Synovial sarcoma. Spindle component with variable myxoid change. Foci of cellular tumors indicate diagnosis.
3685.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. The spindle component may have variable myxoid change that occasionally is marked. Foci of more typical cellular tumors indicate the diagnosis

3693.caption: Neuroblastoma differentiation: neuroblasts show eosinophilic cytoplasm, rounded nuclei with nucleoli.
3693.original_caption: Differentiating neuroblastoma. Neuroblasts show early differentiation with the appearance of eosinophilic cytoplasm and rounding of nuclei that develop nucleoli

3689.caption: Spindle cell hemangioma: bland spindle cells forming fascicles/sheets, adjacent elongated vascular spaces. Spindle cells SMA+, CD34-, CD31-.
3689.original_caption: Spindle cell hemangioma. Bland spindle cells form fascicles or sheets, with adjacent elongated vascular spaces. The spindle cells express smooth muscle actin but not CD34 or CD31

3694.caption: Neuroblastoma: sheets/nests of ovoid tumor cells, hyperchromatic nuclei, scant cytoplasm. Artifactual smearing common. Features: hemorrhage, necrosis, focal calcifications.
3694.original_caption: Neuroblastoma. Characteristic are sheets and nests of ovoid tumor cells with ovoid hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm. The cells often undergo artifactual smearing. Hemorrhage, necrosis, and focal calci fi cations may be features

3684.caption: Synovial sarcoma. TLE1 immunohistochemistry shows strong nuclear positivity. Highly specific for synovial sarcoma, occasionally positive in other soft tissue tumors.
3684.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. Nuclei show strong positivity with immunohistochemical analysis for TLE1. Almost all synovial sarcomas express this antigen, although it is sometimes positive in other soft tissue tumors

3686.caption: Poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma, a small round cell tumor with overlapping nuclei. Further sampling may reveal typical areas. Immunohistochemical/genetic analysis needed to differentiate from other small round cell tumors.
3686.original_caption: Poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma. This is a small round cell tumor. The nuclei appear to overlap. More typical areas usually can be found by further sampling of the tumor, but immunohistochemical and genetic analysis may be required to distinguish this from other small round cell tumors

3680.caption: Low-grade myofibrosarcoma. SMA shows linear subplasmalemmal pattern, characteristic of myofibroblasts. Desmin may be positive, h-caldesmon negative, distinguishing from smooth muscle tumors.
3680.original_caption: Low-grade myo fi brosarcoma. Smooth muscle actin is distributed in a linear subplasmalemmal pattern that is characteristic of myo fi broblasts. Desmin sometimes tests positive but h-caldesmon is negative, assisting in the distinction from smooth muscle tumors

3688.caption: Sinusoidal hemangioma with flattened endothelial lining. Features overlap anastomosing hemangioma in genitourinary tract. SMA immunostaining shows continuous pericytic layer around vessels.
3688.original_caption: Sinusoidal hemangioma. The endothelial spaces are lined by a single layer of fl attened endothelium. A lesion with features of both sinusoidal and hobnail hemangioma has been described in the genitourinary tract as an anastomosing hemangioma. Immunostaining for smooth muscle actin demonstrates a continuous pericytic layer around each vessel

3682.caption: Low-grade myofibrosarcoma. Stromal fibrosis resembles fibromatosis, but variable cellularity and focal nuclear hyperchromasia are diagnostic clues. No nuclear b-catenin immunoreactivity in myofibrosarcomas.
3682.original_caption: Low-grade myo fi brosarcoma. Stromal fi brosis may resemble fi bromatosis, but the variable cellularity and focal nuclear hyperchromasia are clues to the diagnosis. Also, nuclear immunoreactivity for b -catenin is not found in low-grade myo fi brosarcomas

3692.caption: Neuroblastoma. NB84+ in tumor cells. Sensitive but not wholly specific marker for neuroblastoma.
3692.original_caption: Neuroblastoma. NB84 is positive in tumor cells. This is a sensitive but not wholly speci fi c marker for neuroblastoma

3691.caption: Neuroblastoma: cohesive nest in fibrous stroma. Occasional karyorrhexis. Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (per 5,000 cells) prognostic with age, stroma, MYCN, 11q23, ploidy.
3691.original_caption: Neuroblastoma. This example shows a more cohesive nest in fi brous stroma. Fragmentation of occasional nuclei (karyorrhexis) is seen. The mitosis–karyorrhexis index, which indicates the number of mitoses and karyorrhexes per 5,000 cells, is one of the factors used in assessing prognosis; the others include age and amount of stroma, MYCN status, 11q23 allelic status, and ploidy

3690.caption: Spindle cell hemangioma: dermal/subcutaneous distal extremity lesion in young adults. Benign, may recur (intravascular/multiple) but no metastasis. Cavernous vessels with phleboliths, bland spindle cell areas, slit-like vessels.
3690.original_caption: Spindle cell hemangioma. This is a dermal or subcutaneous lesion of the distal extremities in young adults that originally was described as spindle cell hemangioendothelioma but later renamed because of its benign nature. Lesions may recur and be intravascular or locally multiple (spindle cell hemangiomatosis) but do not metastasize. Other characteristics are cavernous vessels sometimes containing phleboliths with interspersed bland spindle cell areas and slit-like vessels

3698.caption: Epithelioid perineurioma: rare, painless superficial/dermal nodule.
3698.original_caption: Epithelioid perineurioma. This rare variant presents as a painless super fi cial or dermal nodule

3681.caption: Low-grade myofibrosarcoma. Neoplastic spindle cells in fascicles infiltrate fat. Cells have ovoid nuclei, more cytoplasm vs fibrosarcoma. Arises in childhood (head/neck) & adults (extremities). Deep soft tissue most common, superficial rare. Local recurrence ~1/3, few metastasize.
3681.original_caption: Low-grade myo fi brosarcoma. Neoplastic spindle cells are arranged in cellular fascicles, here in fi ltrating subcutaneous fat. This tumor simulates fi brosarcoma, but the cells have ovoid rather than tapered nuclei and more cytoplasm. Low-grade myo fi brosarcomas arise in childhood, especially in head and neck sites, and also in adults in the extremities. They are most common in deep soft tissue, although super fi cial examples also occur. There is local recurrence in about one third of cases, and a small number metastasize

3697.caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma: sheets of polygonal rhabdomyoblasts, nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity.
3697.original_caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma. This sample is composed of sheets of polygonal rhabdomyoblasts of varying size, with nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity

3699.caption: Intraneural perineurioma. Nerve expanded by proliferating elongated spindle cells, forming fusiform swelling.
3699.original_caption: Intraneural perineurioma. The nerve is expanded by a proliferation of elongated spindle cells, forming an elongated fusiform swelling

3700.caption: Intraneural perineurioma. EMA+ highlights perineurial cell layers.
3700.original_caption: Intraneural perineurioma. Immunohistochemical testing for EMA is positive, highlighting the layers of perineurial cells

3704.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroplastic sarcoma with vacuolated fibroblasts containing stromal mucin, typical of this tumor type.
3704.original_caption: Lipoblast mimics. This example of myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma shows markedly vacuolated fi broblasts containing stromal mucin. These cells are a typical feature of this tumor type

3701.caption: Epithelioid perineurioma. Elongated spindle cells merge with plumper epithelioid cells, variable fibrous stroma.
3701.original_caption: Epithelioid perineurioma. Typical elongated spindle cells are seen merging with foci of plumper, more epithelioid cells, with variable fi brous stroma

3705.caption: Lipoblast mimics, lymphoma. Lymphoma, melanoma may show signet-ring morphology. Lymphoma ID'd by IHC. Melanoma may mimic round cell liposarcoma, both S-100+.
3705.original_caption: Lipoblast mimics, lymphoma. Both lymphoma and melanoma may assume a signet-ring morphologic appearance. The former is easily identi fi ed by immunohistochemistry. Melanoma may be confused with round cell liposarcoma, as both may have S-100 protein positivity

3702.caption: Lipoblast mimics. Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma: endothelial tumor with intracytoplasmic lumens. Cytoplasm, architecture, and endothelial markers exclude liposarcoma.
3702.original_caption: Lipoblast mimics. Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma is a tumor of endothelial cells that may display intracytoplasmic “lumen” formation. The abundant cytoplasm, the overall architecture, and the immunohistochemical demonstration of endothelial antigens help exclude the diagnosis of liposarcoma

3703.caption: Lipoblast mimics. Myxoid stromal secretion in myxofibrosarcoma causes multivacuolated fibroblasts (pseudolipoblasts). Vacuoles contain alcian blue+ stromal material, unlike lipoblasts.
3703.original_caption: Lipoblast mimics. Intracellular accumulation of myxoid stromal secretion in myxo fi brosarcoma may result in multivacuolated fi broblasts, sometimes termed pseudolipoblasts . An important difference from lipoblasts is that the vacuoles in these fi broblasts are not empty but contain alcian blue–positive stromal material

3715.caption: Epithelioid leiomyosarcoma. Desmin immunostaining positive.
3715.original_caption: Epithelioid leiomyosarcoma. Immunostaining for desmin is positive in many cells

3706.caption: Mammary/myofibroblastoma: benign breast/extramammary lesion (groin, soft tissue). Circumscribed, spindle cells in myxoid stroma with adipose tissue.
3706.original_caption: Mammary and mammary-type myo fi broblastoma. This benign lesion arises in the breast, in both males and females, and also in extramammary locations, including the groin and other subcutaneous soft tissue sites. It is circumscribed and contains clusters of spindle cells in focally myxoid stroma with a component of differentiated adipose tissue

3713.caption: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Lesion cells show nuclear b-catenin immunoreactivity. Some linked to familial adenomatous polyposis.
3713.original_caption: Nasopharyngeal angio fi broma. The lesion cells display nuclear immunoreactivity for b -catenin. Some examples are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis

3707.caption: Leiomyomatosis peritonealis disseminata. Multiple smooth muscle deposits in submesothelial parietal/visceral peritoneum.
3707.original_caption: Leiomyomatosis peritonealis disseminata. Multiple deposits of smooth muscle in a submesothelial location are found in the parietal and visceral peritoneum

3710.caption: Dermatomyofibroma: Uniform myofibroblastic cell fascicles parallel to epidermis. Immunoreactive for SMA, negative for desmin/h-caldesmon.
3710.original_caption: Dermatomyo fi broma. Cellular fascicles of uniform myo fi broblastic cells are arranged mostly parallel to the epidermal surface. The lesional cells are immunoreactive for smooth muscle actin and lack desmin and h-caldesmon

3709.caption: Leiomyomatosis peritonealis disseminata. Mature smooth muscle bundles in fibrous tissue. No atypia/mitoses. May arise during pregnancy/hormone therapy, can regress.
3709.original_caption: Leiomyomatosis peritonealis disseminata. Mature smooth muscle bundles in fi brous tissue. No atypical features or mitoses are seen. These lesions may arise during pregnancy or hormone therapy and subsequently regress

3711.caption: Dermatomyofibroma: benign plaque-like lesion in upper body skin (head/neck, shoulder, axilla, trunk). Forms reticular dermis band, may extend deeper.
3711.original_caption: Dermatomyo fi broma. This is a benign plaque-like lesion arising in the skin of the upper part of the body—head and neck, shoulder, axilla, or trunk. It forms a band in the reticular dermis and occasionally extends more deeply

3708.caption: Intravascular leiomyomatosis. Nodule of well-differentiated smooth muscle in dilated vein lumen. Occurs in myometrium, often with fibroids; may extend to ovary/extrauterine vessels.
3708.original_caption: Intravascular leiomyomatosis. A nodule of well-differentiated smooth muscle is seen within the lumen of a dilated vein. This phenomenon occurs in the myometrium, usually in association with fi broids; it may extend into the ovary or extrauterine vessels, including large veins

3712.caption: Nodular fasciitis: subcutaneous lesion abutting deep fasciae, may be intramuscular. Rapid growth post-trauma, up to 5cm diameter, then stabilizes. Typically circumscribed. Chromosomal rearrangement t(17;22)(p13;q13.1) forms USP6MYH9 fusion gene.
3712.original_caption: Nodular fasciitis. This lesion is subcutaneous and abuts the deep fasciae. Sometimes it arises from the deep aspect of the fasciae and is intramuscular. There typically is a very short clinical history of a rapidly growing lesion at some time at the site of minor trauma, which reaches a diameter of up to 5 cm and then stops growing. The image shows how it is typically circumscribed. Recently, a chromosomal rearrangement t(17;22)(p13;q13.1) with formation of fusion gene USP6MYH9 was identi fi ed in examples of nodular fasciitis

3714.caption: Epstein-Barr virus-associated smooth muscle tumor. Bland spindle cells adjacent to rounded cells with T lymphocytes. EBV antigens positive, desmin positive in 50%. Low-grade tumor in immunocompromised patients, soft tissue/visceral sites. May have multiple clonal lesions.
3714.original_caption: Epstein-Barr virus–associated smooth muscle tumor. Blandappearing spindle cells are seen adjacent to foci of smaller, more rounded cells, with an in fi ltrate of T lymphocytes. The tumor expresses EBV antigens, and desmin is positive in about half the cases. This low-grade tumor arises in immunocompromised patients at soft tissue or visceral sites. Multiple, clonally distinct lesions may be present in an individual

3728.caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma: osteoid formation in spindle cell sarcoma
3728.original_caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma. This example shows a focus of osteoid formation within a spindle cell sarcoma

3726.caption: PEComa: sheets of clear cells, nuclear size variation, perivascular.
3726.original_caption: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. This PEComa is composed of sheets of clear cells with some variation in nuclear size, closely related to blood vessels

3723.caption: Angioleiomyoma. Angiomatous variant shows dilated thin-walled vessels, smooth muscle blending into tumor.
3723.original_caption: Angioleiomyoma. The angiomatous variant has dilated thinwalled vessels, with the smooth muscle coat blending into the main tumor

3718.caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (low malignant potential). Intravascular extension common but not indicative of malignancy.
3718.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (of low malignant potential). Intravascular tumor extension is not an infrequent fi nding but does not indicate malignant potential

3717.caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (low malignant potential). Subcutaneous lesion on extremities in adults. Unencapsulated with cellular nodules and focal hemorrhage.
3717.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (of low malignant potential). This is a subcutaneous lesion arising mainly on the extremities in adults. It is unencapsulated and contains multiple cellular nodules with focal hemorrhage

3716.caption: Fibrosarcoma in dermatofibrosarcoma. Spindle cells uniform, elongated tapered nuclei, scanty cytoplasm. CD34 variable, retains regular dermatofibrosarcoma translocation.
3716.original_caption: Fibrosarcoma in dermato fi brosarcoma. The spindle cells are uniform, with elongated tapered nuclei and scanty cytoplasm. This variant may be either CD34 positive or negative but retains the translocation of regular dermato fi brosarcoma

3720.caption: Fig Bizarre leiomyoma. Atypical/multiple nuclei, intranuclear inclusions. No mitoses. Found in genital tract (scrotum, uterus).
3720.original_caption: Fig  Bizarre leiomyoma. Occasional cells have atypical or multiple nuclei and intranuclear inclusions. No mitotic activity is seen. Such tumors typically are found in the male or female genital tract, including the scrotum and uterus

3727.caption: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. Ovoid nuclei with folded membranes, single large nucleolus. Distinctive appearance/immunophenotype, no normal counterpart described.
3727.original_caption: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. The nuclei are ovoid with distinct, sometimes folded, nuclear membranes and a single large nucleolus. Although the appearance and immunophenotype are distinctive, no normal counterpart cell has yet been described

3729.caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma. Malignant bone/cartilage with pleomorphic polygonal cells. Osteoclastic giant cells present.
3729.original_caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma. Malignant bone and cartilage containing pleomorphic polygonal cells. Osteoclastic giant cells also are seen

3721.caption: Lipoleiomyoma. Benign tumors with adipose tissue and smooth muscle in uterus/soft tissue (groin). Component proportion varies; fatty-predominant may be called myolipomas.
3721.original_caption: Lipoleiomyoma. Benign tumors containing both adipose tissue and smooth muscle occur in the uterus and also in soft tissue, especially in the groin. The proportion of each component varies; those with predominantly fatty tissue may be termed myolipomas

3724.caption: Intimal sarcoma: undifferentiated spindle cells in fibrous stroma, frequent mitoses. Osteochondroid, skeletal muscle, or endothelial differentiation may occur.
3724.original_caption: Intimal sarcoma. This example shows undifferentiated spindle cells in fi brous stroma, with frequent mitoses. Osteochondroid, skeletal muscle, or endothelial differentiation occasionally may be seen

3730.caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma with neoplastic bone formation in "filigree" pattern.
3730.original_caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma. Extensive neoplastic bone formation forming a “ fi ligree” pattern

3722.caption: Leiomyoma of deep soft tissue: normal smooth muscle, myxoid change, focal calcification. Rare in deep tissue; necrosis, atypia, or (male) mitoses suggest leiomyosarcoma. Females may have retroperitoneal uterine-type tumors with ≤5 mitoses/50HPF, ER/PgR+ nuclei.
3722.original_caption: Leiomyoma of deep soft tissue. The tumor is composed of normal-appearing smooth muscle. Myxoid change and focal calci fi cation are common. Benign smooth muscle tumors are very rare in deep soft tissue, and the presence of necrosis, signi fi cant atypia, or (in a male) mitotic activity indicates a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma. In a female, uterine-type benign smooth muscle tumors may occur in the retroperitoneum. They may have mitotic activity up to 5 mitoses per 50 highpower fi elds, and the nuclei are diffusely immunoreactive for ER and PgR

3725.caption: PEComa: benign/malignant tumors of spindled/polygonal clear/granular cells around vessels, with myomelanocytic phenotype (SMA+, Melan-A+, HMB45+, S-100-). Includes angiomyolipoma, lymphangioleiomyomatosis, lung clear cell tumor, abdominopelvic/genital tract PEComas (
3725.original_caption: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumor (PEComa). PEComas comprise a group of benign and malignant neoplasms composed of spindled or polygonal cells with clear or granular cytoplasm that form sheets and nests around thin-walled blood vessels, as seen here. The cells have a characteristic myomelanocytic immunophenotype, expressing smooth muscle actin as well as Melan-A and HMB45, although S-100 protein usually is negative or only very focally positive. The group includes angiomyolipoma, lymphangioleiomyomatosis, clear cell tumor of the lung, and PEComa in various sites, including the abdomen and the female genital tract, which have been described under a variety of names, such as clear cell myomelanocytic tumor and abdominopelvic sarcoma

3719.caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (low malignant potential). Osteoclast-like multinucleated cells among mononuclear cells, with possible peripheral bone formation. Similar to bone giant cell tumor, differs from undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma by lacking nuclear atypia.
3719.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of soft tissue (of low malignant potential). Numerous osteoclast-like multinucleated cells are the distinctive feature of this lesion. They are packed closely among smaller mononuclear cells, and there may be peripheral bone formation. The appearance is similar to that of giant cell tumor of bone (osteoclastoma), and this differs from undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell malignant fi brous histiocytoma) in that it lacks nuclear atypia

3732.caption: Keloid scar. Dermis has cellular lesion with dispersed collagen fibers. Arises at injury sites in predisposed individuals. Extends beyond original wound, unlike nonkeloidal scars.
3732.original_caption: Keloid scar. The dermis contains a variable cellular lesion with numerous randomly dispersed collagen fi bers. Such lesions arise at sites of dermal injury in predisposed individuals. Unlike in nonkeloidal cellular scars, the lesion extends laterally beyond the original wound

3734.caption: Keloid scar. Thick eosinophilic collagen fibers characteristic.
3734.original_caption: Keloid scar. Thick eosinophilic collagen fi bers are a characteristic feature

3731.caption: Calcifying fibrous tumor. Hypocellular fibrous stroma with scattered calcifications. Lymphoid aggregates may be present. Circumscribed lesion in subcutaneous/deep soft tissue or thorax/abdomen, potentially large.
3731.original_caption: Calcifying fi brous tumor. Discrete calci fi cations are scattered within hypocellular fi brous stroma. Lymphoid aggregates sometimes are present. This is a circumscribed lesion that arises in subcutaneous or deep soft tissue and also in the thorax or abdomen, where it may reach a large size

3733.caption: Calcifying (juvenile) aponeurotic fibroma. Amorphous calcification foci in fibrous tissue. Chondroid/ossification may occur. Spindled/rounded cells, multinucleated giant cells. Infiltrates fat/muscle, typically in hands/feet.
3733.original_caption: Calcifying (juvenile) aponeurotic fi broma. Irregular foci of amorphous calci fi cation are seen within the fi brous tissue. Focal chondroid formation or ossi fi cation may occur. There also are cords of spindled or rounded cells and multinucleated giant cells. The tumor in fi ltrates fat and skeletal muscle and usually is found in the hands or feet

3735.caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. Intracytoplasmic lumina with septa suggest vascular lumen formation. May express cytokeratin (mimic adenocarcinoma) but CD31/CD34+; mucin-.
3735.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. Intracytoplasmic lumina occasionally have septa, suggesting attempted vascular lumen formation. Some examples express cytokeratin, which may lead to confusion with adenocarcinoma. However, epithelioid hemangioendothelioma expresses CD31 and often CD34, and mucin stains are negative

3736.caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma with plump cell clusters in chondromyxoid stroma. Typical areas variably present; IHC often needed for diagnosis.
3736.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. Variant patterns include clusters of plump cells in a chondromyxoid stroma. More typical areas sometimes are seen elsewhere in the tumor, but immunohistochemistry often is required to con fi rm the diagnosis

3746.caption: Lymphoma involving soft tissue, extending from lymph nodes or systemic deposits. Can present as primary tumor in trunk/extremities, usually diffuse large B-cell type. Infiltrates between muscle bundles without destruction, unlike sarcoma. Diagnosed via immunohistochemistry.
3746.original_caption: Lymphoma involving soft tissue. This usually extends into adjacent soft tissue from involved lymph nodes or represents systemic tumor deposits in a patient known to have lymphoma. It may, however, present as a primary soft tissue tumor in the trunk or extremities. Soft tissue lymphomas usually are of the diffuse large B-cell type. They may in fi ltrate between skeletal muscle bundles that are separated but not destroyed, unlike in a sarcoma. Diagnosis can be made by appropriate immunohistochemical methods

3739.caption: Myofibroma. Lesions with multinucleated giant cells.
3739.original_caption: Myo fi broma. Some lesions contain multinucleated giant cells

3742.caption: Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue. Multinucleated giant cells present in some cases.
3742.original_caption: Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue. Multinucleated giant cells are a feature in some cases

3741.caption: Clear cell sarcoma: spindled cells, nesting, nuclear morphology, distinctive nucleoli, hemosiderin, melanin present.
3741.original_caption: Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue. In this example, the cells are more spindled, but the characteristic nesting, nuclear morphology, and distinctive nucleoli are maintained. Both hemosiderin and melanin pigments are present

3748.caption: Chordoma: vacuolated (physaliferous) cells, small nuclei, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Immunohistochemistry shows brachyury expression, excludes metastatic carcinoma. Rare dedifferentiation with high-grade component.
3748.original_caption: Chordoma. Typically, there are clusters of vacuolated (physaliferous) cells with small nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Chordoma expresses brachyury, as demonstrated by immunohistochemical analysis, which helps exclude metastatic carcinoma. Rarely, there is dedifferentiation, with development of an undifferentiated high-grade component

3743.caption: Clear cell sarcoma, soft tissue. Diffuse cytoplasmic HMB45 positivity.
3743.original_caption: Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue. There is diffuse cytoplasmic positivity for HMB45

3749.caption: Spindle cell lipoma: mature adipose tissue, spindle cells, wiry/ropy collagen fibers.
3749.original_caption: Spindle cell lipoma. The image shows variable proportions of mature adipose tissue, spindle cells, and wiry or ropy collagen fi bers

3744.caption: Deep benign fibrous histiocytoma. Subcutaneous tissue, rarely mediastinum/retroperitoneum. 22% recurrence, possible metastasis. Circumscribed, sometimes thinly encapsulated. Cellular, uniform tumor.
3744.original_caption: Deep benign fi brous histiocytoma. This tumor occurs in subcutaneous tissue or, rarely, in the mediastinum or retroperitoneum. The recurrence rate is 22 %, and metastasis has been described. It is a circumscribed lesion that sometimes is thinly encapsulated, as shown here. The tumor is cellular and fairly uniform

3753.caption: Angiosarcoma. Spaces lined by endothelial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, multilayering.
3753.original_caption: Angiosarcoma. Higher magni fi cation shows the spaces are lined by endothelial cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei, some with prominent nucleoli, and with multilayering in places

3751.caption: Spindle cell lipoma: slow-growing subcutaneous tumor, typically on neck/shoulder in adults. Encapsulated with white/yellow/myxoid areas.
3751.original_caption: Spindle cell lipoma. Typically this occurs on the back of the neck or shoulder region (and rarely at other sites) in adults as a slowly growing subcutaneous tumor. It is encapsulated with white, yellow, and myxoid-looking areas

3745.caption: Epithelioid cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma: plump ovoid cells with bland nuclei, mixed lymphocytes.
3745.original_caption: Epithelioid cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma. The lesion consists of plump ovoid cells with bland nuclei and a variable admixture of lymphocytes

3740.caption: Clear cell sarcoma-like GI tumor: cells with moderate cytoplasm, osteoclast-like giant cells. Differs from soft tissue type: S-100+, no melanocytic markers, t(2;22)/EWSR1-CREB1. DDx: carcinoma, melanoma, lymphoma.
3740.original_caption: Clear cell sarcoma-like tumor of the gastrointestinal tract. This example shows cells with moderate amounts of cytoplasm. Osteoclast-like giant cells also may be a feature. This variant is immunohistochemically and genetically different from clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue because it expresses S-100 protein but not melanocytic markers, and most have a t(2;22)(q33;q12) rearrangement with EWSR1 - CREB1 gene fusion. Clear cell sarcoma with the same immunophenotype and translocation as the soft tissue type also occur occasionally in the gastrointestinal tract. The differential diagnosis includes carcinoma, metastatic melanoma, and lymphoma
