3752.caption: Spindle cell lipoma with myxoid change. Distinguishable from myxoid liposarcoma by subcutaneous location, absence of lipoblasts and plexiform vascular pattern. Cells evenly dispersed, typical collagen bundles present. Also termed dendritic fibromyxolipomas.
3752.original_caption: Spindle cell lipoma. Myxoid change sometimes is prominent in these tumors. This pattern of spindle cell lipoma is distinguishable from that of myxoid liposarcoma by the subcutaneous location, the subcutaneous origin, and the absence of lipoblasts and the typical plexiform vascular pattern. In myxoid spindle cell lipoma, the cells are evenly dispersed. The typical collagen bundles can be seen. Similar tumors have been described as dendritic fi bromyxolipomas

3738.caption: Myofibroma: tapered cells, uniform ovoid nuclei, whorled cellular pattern, myxoid areas resembling nodular fasciitis.
3738.original_caption: Myo fi broma. The lesional cells are tapered with uniform ovoid nuclei. The cellular areas have a whorled pattern. In the myxoid areas, the appearance resembles nodular fasciitis

3747.caption: Tumefactive extramedullary hemopoiesis. Hemopoietic tissue deposits (extramedullary hemopoietic tumor) in mesentery, retroperitoneum, or urinary tract in myeloproliferative disease. Mixed cellular infiltrate aids differential diagnosis from leukemic soft tissue deposits (chloroma).
3747.original_caption: Tumefactive extramedullary hemopoiesis. Deposits of hemopoietic tissue (extramedullary hemopoietic tumor) may be seen in the mesentery, retroperitoneum, or urinary tract in patients with myeloproliferative disease. The mixed nature of the cellular in fi ltrate helps in the differential diagnosis of leukemic soft tissue deposits (chloroma)

3750.caption: Spindle cell lipoma with pseudoangiomatous change, dilated spaces, rare distinctive feature
3750.original_caption: Spindle cell lipoma. Pseudoangiomatous change, with dilated spaces, is a rare but distinctive occurrence

3755.caption: Cutaneous angiosarcoma, vasoformative with anastomosing vascular channels and solid cellular areas.
3755.original_caption: Angiosarcoma. This cutaneous example is vasoformative, with anastomosing vascular channels and also more solid cellular areas in the center

3737.caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma: plump epithelioid cells in inflamed stroma, cytoplasmic vacuolation. Intermediate malignancy tumor involving skin, soft tissue, viscera (lungs, liver). May show atypia, necrosis, aggressive behavior.
3737.original_caption: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma. Branching cords of plump epithelioid cells in fi ltrate in fl amed stroma. Some cells have cytoplasmic vacuolation. This is a tumor of intermediate malignancy that may involve skin, soft tissue, and viscera, including the lungs and liver. Some examples have atypia and necrosis and behave aggressively

3754.caption: Angiosarcoma. Lesional cells diffusely CD31+, a sensitive/specific endothelial marker. Note CD31+ in macrophages; interpret cautiously.
3754.original_caption: Angiosarcoma. The lesional cells are diffusely positive for CD31, a sensitive and fairly speci fi c marker of endothelial differentiation. However, CD31 also is positive on macrophages; therefore, care is needed in interpretation

3757.caption: Endometriosis: endometrial glands/stroma in skeletal muscle, cesarean scar tissue. Hemosiderin deposition present. Differentiate from synovial sarcoma.
3757.original_caption: Endometriosis. A deposit of endometrial glands and stroma is located in skeletal muscle. These may occur in many locations and are sometimes found in cesarean section scar tissue. Hemosiderin deposition often is a feature. This presentation should not be mistaken for synovial sarcoma

3756.caption: Angiosarcoma in breast. Dilated vessels with single endothelial layer, pseudopapillary structures. Well-differentiated, resembles hemangioma. Key features: irregular infiltration, hyperchromatic nuclei.
3756.original_caption: Angiosarcoma. Early angiosarcoma arising in the breast. Dilated vessels are lined by a mostly single layer of endothelium with occasional pseudopapillary structures. This well-differentiated angiosarcoma may be dif fi cult to distinguish from hemangioma, which also occurs in the breast. The key features indicating the former are the pattern of irregular in fi ltration and the enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei

3759.caption: Amyloid tumor in soft tissue. Irregular amorphous eosinophilic deposits with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation, sometimes giant cells. May occur in secondary amyloidosis.
3759.original_caption: Amyloid tumor of soft tissue. Irregular amorphous eosinophilic material is deposited in soft tissue with adjacent lymphoplasmacytic in fl ammatory response, sometimes including giant cells. This also may occur as part of secondary amyloidosis

3760.caption: Amyloid tumor, soft tissue. Apple green birefringence with Congo red stain under polarized light.
3760.original_caption: Amyloid tumor of soft tissue. Apple green birefringence can be demonstrated with polarized light on sections stained with Congo red

3762.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma with pleomorphism, mitoses, necrosis, inflammatory cells.
3762.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The dedifferentiated area typically is a pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma with pleomorphism, mitoses, necrosis, and admixed in fl ammatory cells

3763.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma abuts well-differentiated component. Transition may be abrupt or intermingled.
3763.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The dedifferentiated component abuts the well-differentiated liposarcoma. The transition may be abrupt, as seen here, or the two components may be intermingled

3758.caption: Rosai-Dorfman disease. Sheets of histiocyte-like cells with abundant cytoplasm, infiltrated by lymphocytes (emperipolesis). Benign lesion involving lymph nodes (sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy) or extranodal sites (skin/soft tissue).
3758.original_caption: Rosai-Dorfman disease. Histiocyte-like cells with large amounts of cytoplasm are arranged in sheets in fi ltrated by lymphocytes and other in fl ammatory cells. Phagocytosed lymphocytes are present in some of the larger histiocyte-like cells (emperipolesis). This is a benign lesion that principally involves the lymph nodes; in these instances, it is known as sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy. The lesion also may arise in extranodal sites such as skin and soft tissue

3768.caption: Fig Sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcoma. Nests of cells separated by thick fibrous septa
3768.original_caption: Fig  Sclerosing epithelioid fi brosarcoma. Variably sized nests of cells are separated by thick fi brous septa

3761.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Myxofibrosarcomatous component common: spindle cells in myxoid stroma. Rare patterns: inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor-like areas, pleomorphic lipoblasts. MDM2 amplification distinguishes from pleomorphic liposarcoma.
3761.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. A variety of other histologic patterns may be seen in the dedifferentiated tumor. A myxo fi brosarcomatous component is relatively common, with spindle cells showing variable pleomorphism in a myxoid stroma. Other patterns rarely seen include in fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor-like areas and pleomorphic lipoblasts within the undifferentiated component. The latter resembles pleomorphic liposarcoma, but can be distinguished from it by demonstration of MDM2 gene ampli fi cation with immunohistochemistry or FISH

3767.caption: Fibrous hamartoma of infancy: differentiated adipose tissue, fibrous bands, cellular spindle/ovoid cell aggregates. Infiltrative, predominantly childhood lesion.
3767.original_caption: Fibrous hamartoma of infancy. The three components of this lesion, found in variable proportions, are differentiated adipose tissue, moderately cellular fi brous bands, and more cellular aggregates of short spindle or ovoid cells with scanty cytoplasm. This is an in fi ltrative lesion that occurs predominantly in childhood

3766.caption: Proliferative myositis: large polygonal ganglion-like cells with basophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli. Similar to proliferative fasciitis. Mitoses rare (may occur in stroma). Cells lack lineage-specific markers, considered modified fibroblasts.
3766.original_caption: Proliferative myositis. This lesion is characterized by large polygonal ganglion-like cells that have basophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli; they also are similar to those found in proliferative fasciitis. Although some have, mitoses are not a feature (although they may be seen in the fasciitis-like stroma). The cells lack lineagespeci fi c immunohistochemical markers and are considered modi fi ed fi broblasts

3769.caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcoma. Uniform rounded cells with folded nuclei, clear cytoplasm. Areas show spindle cell morphology resembling adult-type fibrosarcoma or low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma. Some MUC4+, t(7;16)(q33;p11) translocation present.
3769.original_caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fi brosarcoma. The cells are uniform and rounded with folded nuclei and variably clear cytoplasm. Other parts of the tumor can manifest a more typically spindle cell morphology, resembling adult-type fi brosarcoma or low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma. Some examples are immunoreactive for MUC4 and harbor the t(7;16)(q33;p11) translocation, as found in low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma

3770.caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcoma. Aggressive fibroblastic neoplasm in deep soft tissue/bone. Cellular tumor nodules in dense fibrous tissue. Focal calcification/ossification possible.
3770.original_caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fi brosarcoma. This is an aggressive fi broblastic neoplasm that arises in deep soft tissue or bone. Nodules of cellular tumor lie within dense fi brous tissue. Focal calci fi cation or ossi fi cation may be seen

3765.caption: Ischemic fasciitis (atypical decubital fibroplasty) occurs at pressure points in immobilized/healthy patients. Features: fat infarction, capillary proliferation, scattered spindle/stellate cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Overlying skin intact (vs decubitus ulcer).
3765.original_caption: Ischemic fasciitis. This lesion (also termed atypical decubital fi broplasia ) appears at pressure areas in immobilized patients but also in otherwise healthy individuals. There is infarction of fat with adjacent capillary proliferation and scattered spindle or stellate cells with enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei. The overlying skin is intact, unlike in the decubitus ulcer

3764.caption: Myofibroma: infant lesion of actin+ myofibroblasts, desmin/h-caldesmon-. Central hemangiopericytic focus merges into myxoid nodules. Solitary (skin/subcutis/bone, may regress) or multiple (myofibromatosis, visceral, may progress).
3764.original_caption: Myo fi broma. Primarily found in infants, this lesion is composed of myo fi broblasts that are actin positive but lack desmin and h-caldesmon. A central focus of smaller cells with a hemangiopericytic pattern merges into focally myxoid nodules of loose myo fi broblasts. Myo fi bromas may be solitary or multiple (myo fi bromatosis). Solitary lesions occur in skin, subcutis, or bone and may undergo regression; multiple lesions may involve viscera and may progress

3771.caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcoma. Tumor cells form cords/single files resembling breast lobular carcinoma.
3771.original_caption: Sclerosing epithelioid fi brosarcoma. Tumor cells sometimes form cords or single fi les resembling lobular carcinoma of the breast

3775.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma. Tumor infiltrates fat, arranged in tangential cellular layers with honeycombing pattern.
3775.original_caption: Dermato fi brosarcoma. Fat is in fi ltrated by tumor that is disposed in cellular layers running tangentially to the surface, with a honeycombing pattern in between

3773.caption: Sclerosed dermatofibrosarcoma. Sparse cells within collagen. Storiform pattern preserved. Focal change, may coexist with cellular tumor.
3773.original_caption: Sclerosed dermato fi brosarcoma. The cells are sparse within the collagen. The storiform pattern is preserved. This may be a focal change, coexisting with a more cellular tumor

3774.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma: slender spindle cells, minimal cytoplasm, loose storiform pattern. CD34+, t(17;22)(q21;q13), COL1A1-PDGFB fusion.
3774.original_caption: Dermato fi brosarcoma. Uniform, slender spindle cells with minimal cytoplasm are arranged in a loose storiform pattern. The cells are CD34 positive and have a characteristic t(17;22)(q21;q13) with COL1A1-PDGFB gene fusion

3772.caption: Myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma. Spindle cells with myxoid stroma. No pleomorphism. Vague storiform pattern, continuity with cellular areas.
3772.original_caption: Myxoid dermato fi brosarcoma. Spindle cells are separated by myxoid stroma. No pleomorphism is seen. The vague storiform pattern is a clue to the diagnosis, but continuity with more typical cellular areas often is found with adequate sampling

3781.caption: Infantile fibrosarcoma. Vessels show focal hemangiopericytic pattern.
3781.original_caption: Infantile fi brosarcoma. Blood vessels often show a focal hemangiopericytic pattern

3777.caption: Univacuolated and bivacuolated lipoblasts feature in well-differentiated liposarcoma.
3777.original_caption: Lipoblasts. Univacuolated and bivacuolated lipoblasts are a feature of well-differentiated liposarcoma

3778.caption: Pleomorphic sarcoma with multivacuolated lipoblasts. Nucleus not in all cells, distinctive cytology.
3778.original_caption: Lipoblasts. Multivacuolated lipoblasts are prominent in this pleomorphic sarcoma. The nucleus is not seen in every cell, but the cytologic appearances are distinctive

3776.caption: Silicone from prostheses may leak, be phagocytosed by macrophages, mimicking lipoblasts. Empty tissue spaces also resemble lipoblasts.
3776.original_caption: Lipoblast mimics. Silicone in prostheses may leak into adjacent tissues and be phagocytosed by macrophages. This process and the empty tissue spaces can mimic lipoblasts

3779.caption: Pleomorphic lipoblasts, diagnostic for pleomorphic liposarcoma, have round empty vacuoles indenting nucleus. S-100 positive, lack other markers.
3779.original_caption: Lipoblasts. Pleomorphic lipoblasts are the diagnostic feature of this pleomorphic liposarcoma. They have one or more vacuoles that are perfectly round and empty and frequently indent the nucleus. They often are S-100 protein–positive but lack other markers

3783.caption: Infantile fibrosarcoma. Smaller, rounded cells present.
3783.original_caption: Infantile fi brosarcoma. Other samples are composed of smaller, more rounded cells

3784.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Plaque stage. Spindle cells proliferate, forming dermal bundles.
3784.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Plaque stage. The spindle cells increase, forming bundles in the dermis

3785.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Hyaline globules (center) in plaque & nodular lesions.
3785.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Hyaline globules ( center ) are seen in plaque stages and nodular lesions

3786.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Nodular form: spindle cell proliferation in curved fascicles, extravasated RBCs.
3786.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. In the nodular form, there is a cellular proliferation of spindle cells in curved fascicles, with extravasated red blood cells

3780.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma, originally termed acral, occurs in distal/proximal limbs, skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deeper areas near tendons. Features inflammatory infiltrate, hemosiderin, fibroblastic spindle cells, myxoid nodules, and Reed-Sternberg-like cells. Primarily involves dermis with ill-defined myxoid foci.
3780.original_caption: Myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma. This tumor originally had the pre fi x acral because it arises in distal limbs, but examples in more proximal locations have since been reported. It also has been described as in fl ammatory myxohyaline tumor with virocyte or ReedSternberg–like cells. It occurs in skin and subcutaneous tissue but also may extend more deeply, especially around tendons and tendon sheaths. There is a variable in fl ammatory in fi ltrate with hemosiderin deposition, a fi broblastic spindle cell component, and scattered myxoid nodules. This lesion mainly involves the dermis, with ill-de fi ned myxoid foci at the deep aspect

3782.caption: Infantile fibrosarcoma: occurs in <4-year-olds, rapid growth, deep soft tissue (extremities), circumscribed mass. Spindle cells in herringbone fascicles; hemorrhage/necrosis possible. Intermediate malignancy (<5% metastasize), minimal pleomorphism. Specific t(12;15)(p13;q25) with ETV6-NTRK
3782.original_caption: Infantile fi brosarcoma. This arises in infants less than 4 years old and grows rapidly; it is found in deep soft tissue, mainly of the extremities, forming a circumscribed mass. Spindle cells are arranged in cellular fascicles with a herringbone arrangement, as shown here. Hemorrhage and necrosis may be seen, but unlike its adult counterpart, infantile fi brosarcoma is of intermediate malignant potential, as fewer than 5 % metastasize. Pleomorphism is minimal, and the tumor has a speci fi c t(12;15)(p13;q25) with fusion of ETV6 and NTRK3 genes. This translocation also is found in other tumors, including the cellular variant of congenital mesoblastic nephroma, secretory carcinoma of the breast, and acute myelogenous leukemia

3787.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Nodular lesion cross-sections show sieve-like appearance with interstitial erythrocytes.
3787.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Cross-sections of a lesion of nodular Kaposi sarcoma have a sieve-like appearance, with interstitial erythrocytes

3794.caption: Desmoplastic malignant mesothelioma. Cells dispersed in fibrous stroma. Diagnostic considerations similar to sarcomatoid mesothelioma.
3794.original_caption: Desmoplastic malignant mesothelioma. The lesion’s cells are dispersed in fi brous stroma. Diagnostic considerations similar to those in sarcomatoid mesothelioma apply

3789.caption: Lipo fi bromatosis. Small adipocytes (microfat) seen at fat-fi brous junction.
3789.original_caption: Lipo fi bromatosis. A component of small adipocytes sometimes termed microfat may be seen, especially at the junction of fat and cellular fi brous areas

3790.caption: Plantar fibromatosis. Plump epithelioid/spindle myofibroblasts in dense collagen. Hypocellular lesion. Occasional multinucleated cells.
3790.original_caption: Plantar fi bromatosis. Plump epithelioid and spindle myo fi broblasts are distributed in dense collagen. This is often a hypocellular lesion. Small multinucleated cells sometimes are seen in this variant

3795.caption: Ossifying fibromyxoid tumor, atypical variant: focal spindling, nuclear atypia, mitotic activity, necrosis, intratumoral osteoid. May behave malignantly.
3795.original_caption: Ossifying fi bromyxoid tumor. This atypical variant shows focal spindling. Other atypical features include nuclear atypia, mitotic activity, necrosis, and intratumoral osteoid. Some cases behave in a malignant fashion

3796.caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor. Mitotically active spindle cells with hemosiderin pigment.
3796.original_caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor. Mitotically active spindle cells in fascicles are admixed with abundant hemosiderin pigment

3791.caption: Lipo fi bromatosis: benign infant tumor, mainly extremities/digits. Fibroblastic spindle cells infiltrate fat, variable collagenization, no atypia. CD34/CD99/EMA/SMA+, b-catenin nuclear-.
3791.original_caption: Lipo fi bromatosis. This is a benign tumor of infancy affecting mainly the extremities, including the digits. Cellular fascicles of fi broblastic spindle cells with variable collagenization in fi ltrate fat. Neither component shows cytologic atypia. The lesional cells variably express CD34, CD99, epithelial membrane antigen (EMA), and smooth muscle actin, and b -catenin is negative in nuclei

3788.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor, commonly in pleura, abdomen, viscera, superficial soft tissue. Circumscribed with peripheral hemangiopericytic pattern. Gaping vessels, hyalinized walls, possible vascular lumen thrombus.
3788.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor. This tumor may arise in almost any site but is found most commonly in the pleura, abdomen, viscera, and super fi cial soft tissue. It typically is circumscribed and has a hemangiopericytic pattern that usually is most marked at its periphery. There are gaping vessels that sometimes have hyalinized walls. A thrombus may be seen in one vascular lumen

3798.caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor with giant cells, hemosiderin, mild nuclear pleomorphism in chondromyxoid stroma
3798.original_caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor. This area has numerous giant cells, hemosiderin pigmentation, and a focus of cells with mild nuclear pleomorphism in chondromyxoid stroma

3799.caption: GIST with diffuse strong membranous DOG1 immunoreactivity in muscularis propria. CD117 (KIT) similar pattern.
3799.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. GISTs show diffuse strong membranous immunoreactivity for DOG1, shown here in a tumor involving muscularis propria. CD117 (KIT) shows a similar pattern

3793.caption: Sarcomatoid malignant mesothelioma: dark spindle cells in fascicles, focal cytokeratin/calretinin positivity. Ddx: sarcomatoid carcinoma, synovial sarcoma (bcl-2/CD56+), solitary fibrous tumor (CD34/bcl-2/CD99+).
3793.original_caption: Sarcomatoid malignant mesothelioma. Darkly staining spindle cells without distinguishing features are arranged in fascicles. They may display focal cytokeratin and calretinin positivity but sometimes lack diagnostic markers. Other spindle cell lesions, including sarcomatoid carcinoma, synovial sarcoma (bcl-2, CD56-positive, and speci fi c translocation), and solitary fi brous tumor (CD34, bcl-2, and CD99positive), must be excluded

3800.caption: Extracranial meningioma. Ovoid tumor cells, bland nuclei, sheets/whorls. Express EMA, sometimes claudin-1, cytokeratins, S-100.
3800.original_caption: Extracranial meningioma. Ovoid tumor cells with bland nuclei are arranged in sheets or ill-de fi ned whorls. The cells express epithelial membrane antigen, and sometimes claudin-1, cytokeratins, or S-100 protein

3804.caption: Aggressive angiomyxoma. Short, slender spindle cells, no atypia/mitosis.
3804.original_caption: Aggressive (deep) angiomyxoma. The spindle cells are short and slender and show no atypia or mitotic activity

3792.caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Dyscohesive polygonal cells with focal rhabdoid appearance. Immunophenotypical overlap with carcinoma; calretinin, D2-40, CK5/6 favor mesothelioma. CEA, BerEP4 favor carcinoma. TLE1 positive in mesothelioma.
3792.original_caption: Epithelioid malignant mesothelioma. Dyscohesive polygonal cells form sheets of cells that focally have a rhabdoid appearance. The distinction from carcinoma may be dif fi cult, because there is immunophenotypical overlap. However, positivity for calretinin, D2-40 (podoplanin), and CK5/6 favors mesothelioma, whereas carcinoembryonic antigen and BerEP4 are more often positive in carcinoma. TLE1 also may be positive in all types of mesothelioma

3797.caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor: amorphous calcified material, spindle cells, osteoclast-like giant cells, irregular osteochondroid foci. Associated with oncogenic osteomalacia, renal phosphate loss via FGF-23. Presents as soft tissue limb mass, less commonly bone/sinonasal.
3797.original_caption: Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor. Amorphous material with calci fi cation and adjacent spindle cell proliferation with osteoclastlike giant cells, surrounded by irregular osteochondroid foci, may be observed. This lesion often is associated with oncogenic osteomalacia, a paraneoplastic condition associated with loss of phosphate. It presents as a mass in soft tissue of the limbs or, less commonly, in bone or the sinonasal area. Fibroblast growth factor-23, which is implicated in renal phosphate loss, may be expressed in these tumors

3803.caption: Aggressive angiomyxoma. ER+ in lesional nuclei. PR+.
3803.original_caption: Aggressive (deep) angiomyxoma. Immunochemical examination for estrogen receptor shows diffuse positivity in lesional cell nuclei. Progesterone receptors also are positive

3801.caption: Aggressive angiomyxoma. IHC positive for SMA, desmin, CD34
3801.original_caption: Aggressive (deep) angiomyxoma. Immunohistochemistry is variably positive for smooth muscle actin, desmin (illustrated here), and CD34

3802.caption: Cellular angiofibroma: circumscribed benign lesion in lower female genital tract, male pelvis/scrotum. Bland spindle cells in fibrous stroma with thin-walled/hyalinized blood vessels, often with adipose tissue.
3802.original_caption: Cellular angio fi broma. This is a circumscribed benign lesion occurring in the lower female genital tract and also in the pelvis and scrotum in males. Bland spindle cells are arranged in variably cellular fascicles in fi brous stroma with numerous thin-walled or hyalinized blood vessels of variable caliber. Commonly, there is a component of differentiated adipose tissue

3805.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (inflammatory malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Tumor cells large, polygonal, numerous mitoses, eosinophils admixed with neutrophils.
3805.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with prominent in fl ammation (in fl ammatory malignant fi brous histiocytoma). In this example, the tumor cells are large and polygonal, with numerous mitoses, and eosinophils are admixed with the neutrophils

3806.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with prominent inflammation (inflammatory malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Neutrophils, foamy cells with atypical nuclei. Differential includes lymphoma, carcinoma, dedifferentiated liposarcoma.
3806.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with prominent in fl ammation (in fl ammatory malignant fi brous histiocytoma). Neutrophil polymorphs and foamy cells, some with atypical nuclei, are the additional distinctive features of this tumor. Most examples now are considered to represent speci fi c lesions, including lymphoma, carcinoma, and (especially in the abdomen) dedifferentiated liposarcoma

3809.caption: Retroperitoneal fibrosis. Increased IgG4+ plasma cells, shown by IgG4 immunohistochemistry.
3809.original_caption: Retroperitoneal fi brosis. Increased numbers of IgG4secreting plasma cells may be a feature, as demonstrated by immunohistochemical technique for IgG4

3808.caption: Retroperitoneal fibrosis. Late stage shows paucicellular sclerosis with scattered inflammatory cells, including eosinophils.
3808.original_caption: Retroperitoneal fi brosis. Later stages show paucicellular sclerosis with a sprinkling of in fl ammatory cells, including eosinophils

3807.caption: Sclerosing mesenteritis. Cellular fibrous tissue infiltrates fat, showing fat necrosis features: adipocyte coalescence forming irregular lipid spaces. Calcification may occur.
3807.original_caption: Sclerosing mesenteritis. Variably cellular fi brous tissue in fi ltrates fat, which shows features of fat necrosis, including coalescence of adipocytes resulting in large irregular lipid spaces. Calci fi cation sometimes is seen

3812.caption: Schwannoma. EMA immunostaining shows perineurial cells at lesion periphery, within capsule (left).
3812.original_caption: Schwannoma. Immunostaining for EMA displays layers of thin perineurial cells at the periphery of the lesion, within the capsule ( left )

3814.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Triton tumor shows spindle-shaped, polygonal rhabdomyoblastic cells.
3814.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Higher magni fi cation of this triton tumor shows spindle-shaped and polygonal rhabdomyoblastic cells

3810.caption: Plexiform schwannoma. Nodules of Schwann cells infiltrate subcutaneous tissue. Encapsulated nodules but lesion is infiltrative, not circumscribed. Not associated with NF-1. May be subcutaneous or deep.
3810.original_caption: Plexiform schwannoma. Nodules of Schwann cells in fi ltrate subcutaneous tissue. Each nodule is encapsulated, but the whole lesion is in fi ltrative and not circumscribed. This is not usually associated with NF-1. The lesion may be subcutaneous or deep seated

3811.caption: Intestinal schwannoma. Visceral schwannomas occur in stomach/intestine. Unencapsulated, often with peripheral lymphoid tissue cuff.
3811.original_caption: Intestinal schwannoma. Visceral schwannomas may arise in the stomach or intestine. They are not encapsulated but often have peripheral aggregates of lymphoid tissue forming a cuff

3815.caption: Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Epithelioid cells merge with spindle cell component, aiding diagnosis.
3815.original_caption: Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Epithelioid tumor cells merge with a spindle cell component. The latter fi nding may assist in diagnosis

3818.caption: Sinusoidal hemangioma: circumscribed subcutaneous lesion with dilated vascular spaces, thin septa. Variant of cavernous hemangioma. Frequent thrombosis.
3818.original_caption: Sinusoidal hemangioma. This is a circumscribed subcutaneous lesion with dilated vascular spaces separated by thin septa. It may be regarded as a variant of cavernous hemangioma. Thrombosis is a frequent feature

3819.caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion). Papillary architecture in thrombus with micropapillae in vascular lumen.
3819.original_caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion). Papillary architecture develops within the thrombus with smaller micropapillae in the lumen of the vascular space

3817.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Skeletal muscle shows cytoplasmic cross-striations visible with desmin immunostaining.
3817.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. The skeletal muscle element shows cytoplasmic cross-striations that are readily visualized by immunostaining for desmin

3821.caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion). Papillary structures: fibrin covered by endothelial cells. Hemosiderin present.
3821.original_caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion). The papillary structures are composed of fi brin covered by a layer of endothelial cells. Hemosiderin pigment is present

3816.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) with heterologous mesenchymal differentiation, often in NF-1. Common elements: rhabdomyosarcoma (triton tumor), osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, angiosarcoma. Image shows spindle cell fascicles with eosinophilic cytoplasm and typical MPNST areas.
3816.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. Heterologous malignant mesenchymal differentiation is a feature in a subset of MPNSTs, especially those arising in NF-1. The heterologous element most commonly is rhabdomyosarcoma (triton tumor) but also may be osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, or angiosarcoma. This image depicts fascicles of spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm interspersed with areas of more typical MPNSTs

3823.caption: Traumatic neuroma. Irregular nerve bundles in fibrous tissue post-surgery/nerve disruption during regeneration.
3823.original_caption: Traumatic neuroma. Nerve bundles of varying size ramify irregularly in fi brous tissue. This arises following surgery or another disruption as nerves try to regenerate

3820.caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion) arising within cavernous hemangioma, extending from thrombus. Predilection for head/neck/extremities, may be multiple.
3820.original_caption: Intravascular papillary endothelial hyperplasia (Masson lesion). This usually arises within a preexisting vascular lesion and may be associated with an organizing thrombus. Here the lesion is seen extending down from the thrombus, within a cavernous hemangioma. The lesion has a predilection for the head and neck and extremities, and multiple lesions may occur

3822.caption: Fibrolipomatous hamartoma (lipomatosis) of nerve. Perineurial cell hyperplasia in small nerve bundles within fibrous areas.
3822.original_caption: Fibrolipomatous hamartoma (lipomatosis) of nerve. Perineurial cell hyperplasia is an additional feature of small nerve bundles entrapped within the fi brous areas

3813.caption: Schwannoma: nuclear atypia common, not malignant. Rare MPNST epithelioid type. Epithelioid malignant change: enlarged cells, abundant cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli. Angiosarcoma (epithelioid) reported. S-100+, GFAP focal+. Cytokeratins+, neurofilaments+ (axons). Fewer axons than neurofib
3813.original_caption: Schwannoma. Nuclear atypia is a common feature but does not indicate malignancy. MPNST arising in schwannoma is rare and usually manifests as epithelioid MPNST. A stage of epithelioid malignant change, characterized by foci of enlarged epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli similar to the cells of epithelioid MPNST, has been described. Angiosarcoma, usually of epithelioid type, also has been reported to arise in schwannomas. Schwannomas display diffuse positivity for S-100 protein and may be focally immunoreactive for glial fi brillary acidic protein. Cytokeratins sometimes are expressed, especially in retroperitoneal schwannomas. Also, within many schwannomas, immunostaining for neuro fi laments may reveal axons. Although they usually are fewer in number than in neuro fi bromas, their presence cannot be used to discriminate between the two types of benign nerve sheath tumor

3824.caption: Mucosal neuroma: small nerves with variable diameter and prominent perineurial cells among collagen. Oral/facial/lip lesions, especially multiple, link to MEN IIB (pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, parathyroid hyperplasia).
3824.original_caption: Mucosal neuroma. Small nerves of variable diameter with prominent perineurial cells are dispersed among collagen bundles. Mucosal neuromas on the mouth, face, and lips, especially when multiple, are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome, type IIB (including pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia)

3828.caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath. Multinucleated cells vary from frequent to scanty.
3828.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of the tendon sheath type. Multinucleated cells vary in number from frequent to scanty

3829.caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath type. Cellular composition similar in diffuse/localized types, with cellular/fibrous areas and foamy macrophage clusters.
3829.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath type. The cellular composition is similar in both diffuse and localized types, with cellular and fi brous areas and clusters of foamy macrophages

3826.caption: Giant cell tumor, tendon sheath type. Desmin+ dendritic cells subpopulation. Negative for other myoid markers.
3826.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of the tendon sheath type. Immunostaining for desmin reveals a subpopulation of desmin-positive dendritic cells. These are negative for other myoid markers

3834.caption: Ewing sarcoma, large cell atypical variant: larger nuclei with nucleoli, genetically similar to others.
3834.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma, large cell atypical variant. This is a morphologic variant that has larger nuclei with nucleoli but is genetically similar to other examples

3825.caption: Fibrolipomatous hamartoma (lipomatosis) of nerve. Nerve bundles with endoneurial/perineurial fibrosis in mature adipose tissue. Benign lesion, typically affects median nerve in wrist/palm.
3825.original_caption: Fibrolipomatous hamartoma (lipomatosis) of nerve. Nerve bundles showing endoneurial and perineurial fi brosis are arranged in mature adipose tissue. This is a benign lesion that most commonly affects the median nerve in the wrist and palm

3831.caption: Juxta-articular myxoma. Variable cellularity, usually low. Ganglion-like microcysts possible. Small hemorrhages may occur. Cells lack pleomorphism and mitotic activity.
3831.original_caption: Juxta-articular myxoma. Cellularity is variable but usually low. Ganglion-like microcysts sometimes are seen, and there may be small hemorrhages. The cells lack pleomorphism and mitotic activity

3836.caption: Ewing sarcoma. Rare primary site: skin.
3836.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. The skin is a rare site of primary Ewing sarcoma

3832.caption: Juxta-articular myxoma near large joints (often knee), involving periarticular tissue. Noncircumscribed, multinodular lesion extending into synovium (right side).
3832.original_caption: Juxta-articular myxoma. This tumor occurs adjacent to large joints, most commonly the knee, and involves periarticular tissue. It is a noncircumscribed, multinodular lesion. This example extends into the synovium, the surface of which is seen at the right side

3837.caption: Ewing sarcoma. Intratumoral cyst formation in some cases.
3837.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. Intratumoral cyst formation is a feature in some examples

3827.caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath. Mixed large/small mononuclear cells, folded/reniform nuclei, variable cytoplasm. Mitotic activity present, no prognostic significance. Rare malignant sarcomatous variants. Localized/diffuse forms show t(1;2)(p13;q37) rearrangement, CSF1-COL6A3 fusion gene, CSF1 overexpression.
3827.original_caption: Giant cell tumor of tendon sheath type. The tumor cells are a mixture of large and small mononuclear cells, some with folded or reniform nuclei and variable amounts of cytoplasm. Mitotic activity may be seen and is not of prognostic signi fi cance. Malignant variants, characterized by obviously sarcomatous areas, are very rare. Both localized and diffuse forms of the disease have a t(1;2)(p13;q37) rearrangement with formation of a CSF1-COL6A3 fusion gene. This results in overexpression of colony-stimulating factor-1

3833.caption: Hemosiderotic fibrohistiocytic lipomatous lesion. Circumscribed, cellular. Uniform spindle cells, occasional hyperchromatic nuclei. Abundant hemosiderin. Resembles early pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor. Genetic similarity to myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma.
3833.original_caption: Hemosiderotic fi brohistiocytic lipomatous lesion. Larger lesions are circumscribed and more cellular. The spindle cells are uniform, but occasionally enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei may be seen. There is abundant hemosiderin pigmentation. The appearance resembles that seen in early pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumor, and a genetic similarity to myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma also has been identi fi ed

3830.caption: Hemosiderotic fibrohistiocytic lipomatous lesion (hemosiderotic fibrolipomatous tumor). Ill-defined, occurs in adult females' ankle/foot. Early lesion: spindle cell fascicles in subcutaneous fatty septa & around vessels.
3830.original_caption: Hemosiderotic fi brohistiocytic lipomatous lesion (hemosiderotic fi brolipomatous tumor). This is an ill-de fi ned lesion that occurs mainly in adult females in the ankle and foot. In the early lesion shown here, fascicles of spindle cells form in subcutaneous fatty septa and around blood vessels

3835.caption: Ewing sarcoma. Diffuse CD99 membranous immunoreactivity is characteristic. May express FL11, NSE, neurofilament, cytokeratins (dot pattern), EMA, rarely desmin. CD56 negative vs synovial sarcoma. Divergent immunophenotypes may need molecular pathology for diagnosis.
3835.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. Diffuse membranous immunoreactivity for CD99 is a characteristic fi nding. Other antigens that are variously expressed include FL11, neuron-speci fi c enolase, neuro fi lament, cytokeratins (usually in a dot pattern), epithelial membrane antigen, and, rarely, desmin. CD56 usually is negative in contrast to poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma. Cases with divergent immunophenotypes may require molecular pathologic investigation for diagnosis

3839.caption: Mammary/myo fi broblastoma, rare epithelioid variant. Multinucleated cells possible.
3839.original_caption: Mammary and mammary-type myo fi broblastoma. A rare epithelioid variant has been described. Multinucleated cells also may be seen

3842.caption: Angiomyofibroblastoma. Small polyploid cells linear arrangement. Immunophenotype variable, typically desmin+, ±SMA/CD34. Excised lesions non-recurrent.
3842.original_caption: Angiomyo fi broblastoma. Small polygonal cells are arranged linearly. The immunophenotype is variable but usually includes desmin positivity with or without smooth muscle actin and CD34. Excised lesions usually do not recur

3844.caption: Angiomyofibroblastoma with myxoid areas adjacent to cellular foci and capillary clusters. Overlaps with cellular angiofibroma ("angiomyofibroblastoma-like tumor").
3844.original_caption: Angiomyo fi broblastoma. Myxoid areas are seen adjacent to more cellular foci with clusters of capillary vessels. The appearances overlap with those of cellular angio fi broma (also known as “angiomyo fi broblastoma-like tumor”)

3841.caption: Palisaded myofibroblastoma: elongated cells with palisade-like nuclear alignment. S-100 negative, may mimic schwannoma. Uncertain lineage, possible myofibroblastic/smooth muscle differentiation.
3841.original_caption: Palisaded myo fi broblastoma. The cells are elongated and show focally palisade-like nuclear alignment. This may lead to misdiagnosis as a schwannoma, but S-100 protein tests negative. The lineage of these cells is uncertain; ultrastructural studies have suggested both myo fi broblastic and smooth muscle differentiation

3838.caption: Palisaded myofibroblastoma. Inguinal lymph node replaced by fascicular spindle cell tumor, thin lymphoid rim. Variable cellularity, focal hemorrhage. Common in inguinal nodes, middle-aged males; benign, may recur.
3838.original_caption: Palisaded myo fi broblastoma. Except for a thin rim of lymphoid tissue, this inguinal lymph node has been replaced by a fascicular spindle cell tumor. Cellularity is variable, and there is focal hemorrhage. This lesion is seen most commonly in inguinal lymph nodes in middle-aged males but also occurs in other locations. It is benign but occasionally may recur

3847.caption: Cutaneous PEComa. Clear cell clusters infiltrate dermal collagen.
3847.original_caption: Cutaneous perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. Clusters of clear cells are seen in fi ltrating among dermal collagen bundles

3848.caption: Malignant PEComa. Large epithelioid tumor cells, abundant cytoplasm, marked nuclear pleomorphism.
3848.original_caption: Malignant perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. Tumor cells often are large and epithelioid, with abundant cytoplasm and marked nuclear pleomorphism

3840.caption: Mammary-type myofibroblastoma: bland spindle cells with tapered nuclei between wavy collagen fibers, mast cells present. Lesions express CD34, desmin, sometimes SMA. Resembles spindle cell lipoma, genetic loss of 13q14 (RB1, FOXO1) and 16q.
3840.original_caption: Mammary and mammary-type myo fi broblastoma. Bland spindle cells with tapered nuclei are dispersed between wavy collagen fi bers, and mast cells are seen clearly. The lesions cells express CD34, desmin, and sometimes SMA. This tumor resembles spindle cell lipoma and has similar genetic abnormalities, with loss of 13q14, which includes RB1 and FOXO1 genes, and 16q

3849.caption: Sclerosing perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. Fibrous stroma divides tumor into nests. Tumor cells cuff dilated thin-walled vessel.
3849.original_caption: Sclerosing perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. An extensive fi brous stroma divides the tumor into small nests. A cuff of tumor cells is seen around a dilated thin-walled blood vessel

3845.caption: Aggressive angiomyxoma. Spindle cells in myxoid stroma with scattered vessels, some hyalinized. Infiltrates soft tissue, may recur. HMGA2 rearrangement at 12q13-15.
3845.original_caption: Aggressive (deep) angiomyxoma. Spindle cells are evenly dispersed in myxoid stroma with scattered blood vessels, some with hyalinized walls. This tumor is not circumscribed but in fi ltrates adjacent soft tissue and may recur if not excised completely. Chromosomal rearrangement at 12q13-15 involving the HMGA2 gene has been described

3843.caption: Angiomyofibroblastoma: ovoid, spindled, plasmacytoid, multinucleated cells in clusters/chains, no nuclear atypia, may relate to vessels, fat component possible.
3843.original_caption: Angiomyo fi broblastoma. The tumor is composed of ovoid, spindled, plasmacytoid, or multinucleated cells in clusters or chains, without nuclear atypia, and is sometimes related to blood vessels. A component of fat also may be seen

3850.caption: Desmoplastic fibroblastoma (collagenous fibroma). Circumscribed, sparsely cellular tumor with collagen bundles. Occurs in adult males, subcutis/deep soft tissue, upper limbs/trunk.
3850.original_caption: Desmoplastic fi broblastoma. Although fi rst described under this name, this lesion also has been termed collagenous fi broma . It is a circumscribed, very sparsely cellular tumor predominantly composed of collagen bundles. Typically, it occurs in adult males in the subcutis or deep soft tissue, mainly of the upper limbs or trunk

3852.caption: Elastofibroma. van Gieson stain shows beaded fibers.
3852.original_caption: Elasto fi broma. An elastic van Gieson stain highlights the fi bers and clearly demonstrates the bead-like fragments

3856.caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. Cells show desmin dot positivity. Coexpresses cytokeratins and neurofilament.
3856.original_caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. The cells show dot positivity for desmin. Often there also is coexpression of cytokeratins and neuro fi lament

3851.caption: Elastofibroma. Ill-defined subcutaneous lesion near scapula tip, with thickened fragmented eosinophilic elastic fibers in fibrous stroma, sparse spindle cells.
3851.original_caption: Elasto fi broma. Typically arising beneath the tip of the scapula, this is an ill-de fi ned, in fi ltrative subcutaneous lesion characterized by numerous thickened and fragmented eosinophilic elastic fi bers in a fi brous stroma with sparse spindle cells

3846.caption: Malignant perivascular epithelioid cell tumor (PEComa). Features: nuclear variation, mitoses, necrosis, vascular association. Malignancy criteria: size >5cm, infiltrative growth, high nuclear grade, hypercellularity, >1 mitosis/50 HPF, necrosis, vascular invasion. Small tumors (<5cm) with atypia but no mitoses are
3846.original_caption: Malignant perivascular epithelioid cell tumor. There is marked nuclear variation, and mitoses and necrosis are usual features. The tumor cells are closely related to the thin-walled vessel in the center. PEComas displaying two or more of the following features may be regarded as potentially malignant: large size (>5 cm), in fi ltrative growth, high nuclear grade, hypercellularity, more than one mitosis per 50 highpower fi elds, necrosis, and vascular invasion. Small tumors (<5 cm diameter) with atypia but no mitoses behave in a benign fashion. Those with nuclear pleomorphism or multinucleated giant cells only (termed symplastic PEComas ) or with a maximum dimension exceeding 5 cm may be regarded as of uncertain malignant potential

3854.caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. Nests of uniform rounded cells in fibrous stroma. Aggressive malignant neoplasm, multicentric in pelvis/abdomen of young males. Also occurs in head/neck, paratesticular regions.
3854.original_caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. Variably sized nests of uniform rounded cells are dispersed within a cellular fi brous stroma. This is an aggressive malignant neoplasm that occurs mostly as a multicentric tumor in the pelvis and abdomen of young adults, with a male predominance. It also has been described in many other locations, including head and neck sites and the paratesticular region

3853.caption: Desmoplastic fibrobloma: spindled/stellate myofibroblasts, no atypia. SMA+, CD34-. Translocations include t(2;11)(q31;q12), also in fibroma of tendon sheath.
3853.original_caption: Desmoplastic fi broblastoma. The lesional cells are spindled or stellate myo fi broblasts without atypical features. They are immunoreactive for smooth muscle actin but not for CD34. Various translocations have been described, including t(2;11)(q31;q12), which also is found in fi broma of tendon sheath

3857.caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. WT1 IHC diffusely positive in nuclei. Characteristic t(11;22)(p13;q12) with EWS-WT1 fusion gene.
3857.original_caption: Desmoplastic small round cell tumor. Immunohistochemistry for WT1 is diffusely positive in tumor cell nuclei. The tumor has a characteristic chromosomal rearrangement of t(11;22)(p13;q12) with formation of the EWS - WT1 fusion gene

3855.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma: poorly circumscribed dermal/subcutaneous nodule with central necrosis, often causing nonhealing ulcer. Common in young adults' extremities. Local recurrence with proximal extension, metastasis to lymph nodes, lung, bone, soft tissue.
3855.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. Typically, there is a poorly circumscribed dermal or subcutaneous nodule with central necrosis that often results in a nonhealing ulcer. Epithelioid sarcoma arises most frequently in the extremities of young adults. The natural history is one of local recurrence, typically with proximal extension and eventual metastasis to lymph nodes, lung, bone, and other soft tissue sites, including the scalp

3858.caption: Paraganglioma. Myxoid/fibrous stroma separates tumor cell clusters. Fibrosis prominent in sclerosing variant.
3858.original_caption: Paraganglioma. Focal myxoid and fi brous stroma separates clusters of tumor cells. Stromal fi brosis may be prominent in the sclerosing variant

3859.caption: Paraganglioma. S-100+ sustentacular cells with slender processes surround chief cell nests.
3859.original_caption: Paraganglioma. Sustentacular cells have S-100 protein– positive nuclei and cytoplasm, the latter appearing as long slender processes surrounding the nests of chief cells

3861.caption: Extracranial meningioma, rare head/neck tumor, often scalp/nose. This case shows tumor under respiratory epithelium in paranasal sinus.
3861.original_caption: Extracranial meningioma. Rarely, meningioma occurs outside the cranium, mostly in the head and neck, including the scalp and nose, and occasionally at other sites. This example shows tumor beneath the respiratory epithelium in paranasal sinus

3867.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Lymphangioma-like variant has dilated endothelial-lined spaces, fewer spindle cells.
3867.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. The rare lymphangioma-like variant has dilated endothelial-lined spaces and a smaller component of spindle cells

3860.caption: Paraganglioma: rounded uniform cells, scattered larger nuclei not indicating malignancy. Malignancy criteria limited to metastasis. Suspicious features: mitoses, pleomorphism, vascular invasion, necrosis. Metastases may occur without these.
3860.original_caption: Paraganglioma. The lesional cells are rounded and relatively uniform, although scattered larger nuclei often are a feature and do not indicate malignancy. There are no de fi nite criteria of malignancy other than metastasis. Suspicious features are mitoses, marked pleomorphism, vascular invasion, or necrosis or vascular invasion, but metastases have occurred in tumors without them

3868.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma occurs in children/adults, superficial or deep. Large retroperitoneal lesions may cause Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (consumptive coagulopathy).
3868.original_caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma. Originally described in childhood, these tumors also are found in adults. They may be super fi cial or, less often, deeply located. Large lesions, especially those in the retroperitoneum, may be associated with consumptive coagulopathy (Kasabach-Merritt syndrome)

3864.caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: solid variant with sheets of dark-staining small round cells, focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation, eosinophilic cytoplasm.
3864.original_caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. The solid variant is composed of sheets of darkly staining small round cells. Focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation with eosinophilic cytoplasm sometimes is seen

3865.caption: Sclerosing pseudovascular rhabdomyosarcoma with focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. MyoD1 (nuclear) more diffuse than myogenin. Resembles alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma but lacks specific genetic features.
3865.original_caption: Sclerosing pseudovascular rhabdomyosarcoma. These cells show focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. MyoD1 (in nuclei) is expressed more diffusely than myogenin. Although in places the tumor resembles alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma, no speci fi c genetic features have been identi fi ed

3862.caption: Sclerosing pseudovascular rhabdomyosarcoma: adult deep soft tissue tumor with spindled/rounded cells in hyalinized stroma, osteoid/chondroid appearances, frequent mitoses; spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma variant.
3862.original_caption: Sclerosing pseudovascular rhabdomyosarcoma. This an adult deep soft tissue tumor composed of cords and nests of spindled or rounded cells in a hyalinized stroma with osteoid or chondroid appearances. Mitoses are frequent. This tumor probably represents a variant of spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma

3872.caption: Mesenteric fibromatosis. Keloid-like thick collagen bundles feature.
3872.original_caption: Mesenteric fi bromatosis. Keloid-like thick collagen bundles sometimes are a feature of this lesion

3869.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma with capillary clusters in lymphangiomatous component.
3869.original_caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma. In this example, the capillary clusters lie within a lymphangiomatous component

3866.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. HHV8+ in spindle cell nuclei, all lesion stages. Expressed in endothelial cells of proliferating capillaries, patch stage spindle cells. CD34, CD31, D2-40+. Immunoperoxidase.
3866.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. HHV8 is positive in nuclei in spindle cells. This is found in all stages of the lesion, including the endothelial cells of proliferating capillaries and intervening spindle cells in the patch stage. Also expressed are CD34, CD31, and D2-40. Immunoperoxidase method

3863.caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma: mixture of small rounded cells & large rhabdomyoblastic cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm. High-grade sarcoma in older males, proximal extremities/trunk. Worse prognosis than undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. Abdominal lesions often dedifferentiated liposarcoma with heterologous differentiation.
3863.original_caption: Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma. There is a patternless mixture of smaller rounded cells and large scattered rhabdomyoblastic cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. This is a high-grade sarcoma seen most often in older adult males in the proximal extremities and trunk wall. As with other high-grade sarcomas showing myoid differentiation, pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma has a worse prognosis than undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fi brous histiocytoma). Most similar lesions within the abdomen are considered to represent examples of dedifferentiated liposarcoma with heterologous differentiation

3873.caption: Fibromatosis. Nuclear b-catenin immunoreactivity in ~80% deep, few superficial fibromatoses.
3873.original_caption: Fibromatosis. Nuclear immunoreactivity for b -catenin is found in about 80 % of deep fi bromatoses and a few super fi cial ones

3874.caption: Fibromatosis: ovoid uniform nuclei, punctate nucleoli, amphophilic cytoplasm. No pleomorphism/necrosis, rare mitoses. Mast cells present.
3874.original_caption: Fibromatosis. The cells have ovoid uniform nuclei with punctate nucleoli and variable amounts of amphophilic cytoplasm. Pleomorphism and necrosis are absent, but normal mitotic fi gures sometimes are seen. Mast cells are a typical feature

3870.caption: Mesenteric fibromatosis. Mass infiltrates mesentery and bowel wall muscularis propria.
3870.original_caption: Mesenteric fi bromatosis. This forms a mass that in fi ltrates the mesentery and the muscularis propria of the bowel wall

3875.caption: Aneurysmal fibrous histiocytoma: cutaneous dermatofibroma with central hemorrhage. Distinguish from angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma (subcutaneous, translocation-associated, desmin+).
3875.original_caption: Aneurysmal fi brous histiocytoma. This is a cutaneous dermato fi broma with central hemorrhage. It should not be confused with angiomatoid fi brous histiocytoma, which is located in subcutaneous tissue and is a translocation-associated tumor that often is desmin positive

3871.caption: Fibromatosis: parallel-aligned myofibroblasts in uniform collagen, slit-like vessels. Superficial types in palm, sole, penis, knuckles. Deep lesions (desmoid tumors) in skeletal muscle, abdominal wall (pregnancy/postpartum), or abdomen (linked to familial adenomatous polyposis).
3871.original_caption: Fibromatosis. This tumor is composed of parallel-aligned myo fi broblasts evenly dispersed in uniform collagen, with slit-like vessels. Super fi cial fi bromatoses arise in the palm, sole, penis, or over the knuckles. Deep lesions (desmoid tumors or desmoid-type fi bromatoses) may occur in skeletal muscle, with a distinct subset in the anterior abdominal wall during pregnancy or post partum, and in the abdomen, where they may be associated with familial adenomatous polyposis

3880.caption: Hibernoma: benign neoplasm resembling brown fat. Occurs in adults (thigh, shoulder, back, retroperitoneum). Lobular pattern with thin fibrous septa at low magnification.
3880.original_caption: Hibernoma. This is a benign neoplasm resembling normal brown fat. It arises in adults at various sites, including the thigh, shoulder, back, and retroperitoneum. At low magni fi cation, the tumor has a lobular pattern, de fi ned by thin fi brous septa

3879.caption: Pleomorphic lipoma. Distinguished from atypical lipomatous tumor by superficial location, encapsulation, floret cells, spindle cell component, and absence of MDM2/CDK4 amplification via FISH and immunohistochemistry.
3879.original_caption: Pleomorphic lipoma. This may be distinguished from an atypical lipomatous tumor by the super fi cial location, encapsulation, fl oret cells, and spindle cell lipomatous component, as well as by the absence of MDM2 and CDK4 ampli fi cation by fl uorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and immunohistochemical evaluation

3878.caption: Atypical benign cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma. Scattered hyperchromatic pleomorphic/multinucleated cells in typical lesion. Necrosis possible, may extend into subcut fat. ~15% recur, rare metastasis.
3878.original_caption: Atypical benign cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma. Scattered enlarged hyperchromatic pleomorphic nuclei or multinucleated cells are seen dispersed in an otherwise typical cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma. Necrosis sometimes is seen, and the lesion may extend into subcutaneous fat. About 15 % recur, and an occasional tumor metastasizes

3876.caption: Cellular cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma). Tapered spindle cell fascicles without atypia. SMA+ focal, desmin/h-caldesmon- vs leiomyosarcoma. Leiomyosarcoma: rectilinear fascicles, nontapered eosinophilic cytoplasm, blunt-ended nuclei.
3876.original_caption: Cellular cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma (dermato fi broma). Fascicles of tapered spindle cells without marked atypia characterize this lesion. The cells may express smooth muscle actin (SMA) focally, but desmin and h-caldesmon usually are negative, aiding the distinction from leiomyosarcoma. The cells in leiomyosarcoma are arranged in rectilinear fascicles and have nontapered eosinophilic cytoplasm with blunt-ended nuclei

3884.caption: Spindle cell angiosarcoma. May mimic other spindle cell sarcomas. Diagnosis requires endothelial markers (CD31, CD34, ERG) if typical areas absent.
3884.original_caption: Spindle cell angiosarcoma. Rarely, angiosarcoma may resemble other spindle cell sarcomas. If more typical areas are not present, demonstration of immunoreactivity for endothelial markers, including CD31, CD34, and ERG, often is necessary for diagnosis

3892.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor. Focal or diffuse myxoid change.
3892.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor. Myxoid change may be seen focally or, less often, involving most of the tumor

3890.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor. CD34+, Bcl2+, CD99+.
3890.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor. Immunostaining for CD34 is positive. Bcl2 and CD99 positivity also are seen

3893.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor. Fibrous and cellular areas adjacent.
3893.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor. Fibrous and cellular areas are seen adjacent to each other

3885.caption: Angiosarcoma. Solid tumor, epithelioid cells, minor vasoformative component.
3885.original_caption: Angiosarcoma. This tumor is mostly solid, with sheets of epithelioid cells and a smaller vasoformative component

3886.caption: Perineurioma: elongated, thin bipolar cytoplasmic processes. Occasional nuclear atypia, no malignant potential; rare, no metastasis reported.
3886.original_caption: Perineurioma. The lesional cells have elongated, thin, bipolar cytoplasmic processes. Occasionally there is nuclear atypia, but this does not indicate malignant potential, as perineuriomas rarely occur and have not been reported to metastasize

3877.caption: Aneurysmal fibrous histiocytoma. Multinucleated cells with focally abundant hemosiderin.
3877.original_caption: Aneurysmal fi brous histiocytoma. There are multinucleated cells with hemosiderin, which is focally abundant

3891.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor. Short spindled/ovoid cells in "patternless" arrangement with collagen bundles. No malignant features but unpredictable behavior.
3891.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor. Short spindled or ovoid cells are arranged in a random (“patternless”) pattern, with interspersed collagen bundles. There are no histologic features of malignancy, but the tumor’s behavior is unpredictable

3887.caption: Perineurioma: slender spindle cells in fascicles, whorls, or storiform pattern with fibrous/myxoid stroma. Rare plexiform variant noted.
3887.original_caption: Perineurioma. Slender spindle cells are arranged in fascicles, whorls, or a storiform pattern with fi brous or myxoid stroma. A rare plexiform variant has been described

3882.caption: Hibernoma: cells with small fatty vacuoles, central round nuclei, granular cytoplasm. Genetic 11q13 rearrangements.
3882.original_caption: Hibernoma. The cells have numerous small fatty vacuoles, and the small round nuclei often are centrally located. Some cells have a more granular cytoplasm. Genetically, hibernomas have rearrangements at 11q13

3881.caption: Pleomorphic lipoma, similar to spindle cell lipoma. Contains multinucleated floret cells, hyperchromatic nuclei, and occasional lipoblasts.
3881.original_caption: Pleomorphic lipoma. This tumor is clinically and genetically similar to spindle cell lipoma, and the two patterns may be present in the same neoplasm. Pleomorphic lipoma has multinucleated fl oret cells, and enlarged hyperchromatic nuclei and lipoblasts sometimes are seen

3889.caption: Perineurioma. CD34+, EMA+ in slender processes. Claudin-1+ granular on cell bodies/processes. S-100-, MUC4-, excludes low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma.
3889.original_caption: Perineurioma. Some tumors express CD34, and EMA is positive in many cases; however, this may be dif fi cult to discern when con fi ned to the very slender processes. Immunohistochemical technique for claudin-1, depicted here, may be positive in granular distribution on cell bodies and processes. S-100 protein and MUC4 are negative, the latter helping to exclude low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma

3888.caption: Perineurioma: benign perineurial cell tumor. Subcutaneous, circumscribed, with entrapped fat foci. Occurs anywhere (intestine common), often subcutis/deep soft tissue. Associated with chromosome 22 abnormalities/NF2 mutations.
3888.original_caption: Perineurioma. This is a benign tumor of perineurial cells. This example is located in the subcutaneous tissue and is circumscribed. Foci of entrapped fat are seen within the lesion. Perineurioma may occur at any site, including the intestine, but most often it is found in the subcutis; however, some are located in deep soft tissue. Abnormalities in chromosome 22, including NF2 mutations, have been found in some perineurial cell tumors

3894.caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma: rounded/spindled histiocytoid cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Touton giant cells. Fibrosis progresses. S-100/CD1a-, CD68/CD163+.
3894.original_caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma. There is an admixture of rounded (rarely spindled) histiocytoid cells, lymphocytes, and eosinophils, with scattered Touton-type giant cells. Increasing fi brosis occurs over time. Lesional cells are negative for S-100 protein and CD1a but express macrophage markers CD68 and CD163

3883.caption: Epithelioid angiosarcoma: sheets/cords of polygonal cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Interstitial hemorrhage. Epithelioid change common in postradiation sarcomas, foreign material implants, disused AV fistulae, soft tissue.
3883.original_caption: Epithelioid angiosarcoma. Shown are sheets and cords of polygonal cells with vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is interstitial hemorrhage. Epithelioid change is common in postradiation sarcomas, those associated with prior implantation of foreign material or disused arteriovenous fi stulae, and those in soft tissue

3897.caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma. Thinned epidermis with acanthosis, elongated rete ridge. Dermal cellular infiltrate.
3897.original_caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma. The epidermis is thinned super fi cially but shows acanthosis with an elongated and anastomosing rete ridge. The dermis contains a cellular in fi ltrate

3895.caption: Deep juvenile xanthogranuloma. Intramuscular tumor with histiocytic sheets, scant inflammation, few multinucleated giant cells.
3895.original_caption: Deep juvenile xanthogranuloma. This intramuscular tumor is composed of sheets of histiocytic cells, with scanty in fl ammation and small numbers of multinucleated giant cells

3898.caption: Rosai-Dorfman disease. Lesional cells show nuclear/cytoplasmic S-100 positivity. Immunoperoxidase.
3898.original_caption: Rosai-Dorfman disease. The lesional cells show diffuse nuclear and cytoplasmic positivity for S-100 protein. Immunoperoxidase technique

3896.caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma: infantile/childhood tumor in head/neck skin, proximal limbs, trunk. Deep lesions in trunk muscles. Similar in lung/soft tissue/bone (Erdheim-Chester disease). Dermal lesion extends around hair shaft, not into subcutaneous fat.
3896.original_caption: Juvenile xanthogranuloma. This is a predominantly infantile or childhood tumor arising in the skin of the head and neck, the proximal limbs, or the trunk. Deep-seated lesions may occur in trunk muscles. Similar lesions are described in the lung, soft tissue, or bone, especially in adults, in Erdheim-Chester disease. The lesion occupies the dermis and in this image, extends around a hair shaft but not into subcutaneous fat

3904.caption: Angiolipoma. Some cases show increased vessels forming solid masses with minimal adipose tissue.
3904.original_caption: Angiolipoma. Some examples have increased blood vessels that form more solid masses with a minimal adipose tissue component

3903.caption: Angiolipoma. Capillaries with thickened walls, intervening spindle cells, some thrombi, occasional neutrophils.
3903.original_caption: Angiolipoma. The capillaries have variably thickened walls, with intervening spindle cells; in addition, some contain thrombi, with occasional neutrophils

3899.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma: malignant spindle cells with dark nuclei infiltrating dermal collagen. Predilection for head/neck in older adults, presents as slow-growing plaque/ill-defined nodule. High infiltration risk, frequent local recurrence post-incomplete excision.
3899.original_caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. Malignant spindle cells with darkly staining nuclei irregularly in fi ltrate dermal collagen. This tumor has a predilection for the head and neck region in older adults and appears as a slowly growing cutaneous plaque or ill-de fi ned nodule. The tumor may in fi ltrate widely, and local recurrence is frequent, especially following incomplete excision

3907.caption: Leiomyoma cutis. Well-differentiated smooth muscle bundles in fibrous stroma. No nuclear pleomorphism, mitosis, or necrosis.
3907.original_caption: Leiomyoma cutis. Bundles of well-differentiated smooth muscle are dispersed within variable fi brous stroma. Nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity, and necrosis are absent

3906.caption: Angioleiomyoma: smooth muscle bundles around thick-walled vessels, merging into stromal muscle. No atypia. Morphologic overlap with myopericytoma.
3906.original_caption: Angioleiomyoma. Smooth muscle bundles are arranged around thick-walled vessels and merge into stromal smooth muscle. Cellular atypia is absent. There is some morphologic overlap with myopericytoma

3902.caption: Angiolipoma: circumscribed, thinly encapsulated, subcutaneous tumor, tender. Contains normal fat with peripheral blood vessel clusters.
3902.original_caption: Angiolipoma. This is a circumscribed, thinly encapsulated, subcutaneous tumor that is often tender. It consists of normal fat with clusters of blood vessels that are more frequent toward the periphery of the lesion

3901.caption: Endometrial stromal sarcoma. May contain endometrioid glands. Differentiate from endometriosis and biphasic synovial sarcoma.
3901.original_caption: Endometrial stromal sarcoma. Endometrioid glands sometimes are present. This needs to be distinguished from endometriosis and from biphasic synovial sarcoma

3909.caption: Angioleiomyoma: circumscribed subcutaneous nodule, smooth muscle bundles with variably sized vessels. Occurs in extremities, head/neck, middle-aged females. Painful (cold-sensitive), tender.
3909.original_caption: Angioleiomyoma. Typically this is a circumscribed subcutaneous nodule composed of smooth muscle bundles with variably sized blood vessels. These lesions arise in the extremities and head and neck, with a predilection for middle-aged females. They are painful, especially in the cold, and tender to the touch

3910.caption: Dedifferentiated chondrosarcoma, may occur in primary/recurrent cases or osteochondromatosis. Moderately differentiated (left) abruptly changes to undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.
3910.original_caption: Dedifferentiated chondrosarcoma. This change may occur in primary or recurrent chondrosarcoma, with a subset in patients with osteochondromatosis. Moderately differentiated chondrosarcoma ( left ) is seen with an abrupt change to undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma

3905.caption: Adrenal myelolipoma: mature adipose tissue with normal hemopoietic cells. Rim of adrenal cortex visible. Associated with adrenal tumors, obesity, diabetes. Also occurs in retroperitoneum, presacral region.
3905.original_caption: Myelolipoma of the adrenal gland. Mature adipose tissue is in fi ltrated by aggregates of normal hemopoietic cells. A rim of remaining adrenal cortical tissue is seen at the bottom of the image. Myelolipoma is most common in the adrenal gland but also occurs in other locations, including the retroperitoneum and presacral region. It may be associated with adrenal cortical tumors, obesity, and diabetes

3900.caption: Endometrial stromal sarcoma: small, dark cells in sheets/whorls around vessels. May occur in abdomen/soft tissue, often in endometriosis/metastases. Expresses CD10, ER, sometimes cytokeratins. Genetic variants: t(7;17)(JAZF1-SUZ12) in some, t(10;17)(YWHAE
3900.original_caption: Endometrial stromal sarcoma. Uniform, small, darkly staining cells are arranged in sheets and whorls around small vessels. This may be present in the abdomen and other soft tissue sites, especially in foci of endometriosis or as metastatic deposits. The lesional cells express CD10, ER (in nuclei), and sometimes cytokeratins focally. Some have a t(7;17)(p15;q21), with fusion of JAZF1 and SUZ12 genes, although this is less frequent in extrauterine examples. Recently a t(10;17)(q22;p13) variant was described, with YWHAE - FMA22A / B fusion; this has higher-grade morphology and manifests aggressive behavior

3912.caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma: malignant spindle/polygonal cell tumor with irregular neoplastic bone formation in soft tissue. Histologically resembles osseous type. Mainly proximal extremities, often post-radiation. Associated with MPNST, retroperitoneal dedifferentiated liposarcoma.
3912.original_caption: Extraskeletal osteosarcoma. Irregular neoplastic bone formation is seen in a malignant spindle and polygonal cell tumor in soft tissue. This tumor is histologically similar to its osseous counterpart but does not originate in bone. It arises mainly in the proximal extremities, and a large subset arises in the fi elds of prior therapeutic irradiation. Osteosarcoma also may be seen in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, and in the retroperitoneum it often is a component of dedifferentiated liposarcoma

3908.caption: Leiomyoma cutis. Benign dermal smooth muscle tumor, infiltrative, separated by Grenz zone. Hereditary leiomyomatosis shows multiple limb extensor papules/nodules.
3908.original_caption: Leiomyoma cutis. Benign smooth muscle tumors are relatively common in the dermis. The tumor is in fi ltrative. It is separated from the epidermis by a Grenz zone. In hereditary leiomyomatosis, there are multiple lesions that form small papules or nodules, predominantly on the extensor aspects of the limbs

3911.caption: Extraskeletal mesenchymal chondrosarcoma. Cartilage appears differentiated/mature, may calcify/ossify. Well-demarcated from small cell component (CD99+, FLI1-). Lacks Ewing/synovial sarcoma rearrangements. Small biopsies may lack chondroid. Associated with t(8;8)(q21;q13.3) HEY1
3911.original_caption: Extraskeletal mesenchymal chondrosarcoma. The cartilage usually is differentiated or mature appearing, and it may be calci fi ed or even ossi fi ed. It is often well demarcated from the small cell component. The latter is immunoreactive for CD99 (but not for FLI1), but can be distinguished from Ewing sarcoma and poorly differentiated synovial sarcoma by the absence of their speci fi c genetic rearrangements. This is particularly useful in small biopsies, which might lack the chondroid component. Also, a consistent genetic rearrangement t(8;8) (q21;q13.3) with HEY1-NCOA2 fusion gene recently was described in mesenchymal chondrosarcoma

3917.caption: Dermatofibrosarcoma with pigmented cells (Bednar tumor). Melanin-containing cells show S-100 positivity. No prognostic significance.
3917.original_caption: Dermato fi brosarcoma with pigmented cells (Bednar tumor). Scattered cells contain melanin pigment. These display S-100 protein positivity. The fi nding is of no prognostic signi fi cance

3914.caption: Intramuscular myxoma: low-cellularity tumor with uniform myxoid stroma, circumscribed but infiltrates muscle bundles at margin, separating rather than destroying them.
3914.original_caption: Intramuscular myxoma. This is a tumor of low cellularity with uniform myxoid stroma. It is circumscribed but in fi ltrates muscle bundles at the margin in a characteristic fashion, separating rather than destroying them

3918.caption: Fibrosarcoma in dermatofibrosarcoma. Storiform pattern lost, tumor cells in herringbone fascicles. Increased mitoses (>5/10 HPF), no nuclear pleomorphism.
3918.original_caption: Fibrosarcoma in dermato fi brosarcoma. In fi brosarcomatous change, the typical storiform pattern of dermato fi brosarcoma is lost, and the tumor cells are aligned in fascicles arranged in a herringbone pattern. There is increased mitotic activity (>5 mitoses per 10 highpower fi elds), but nuclear pleomorphism is not a feature

3915.caption: Superficial acral fibromyxoma (digital fibromyxoma). Stroma: myxoid, fibrous, wiry collagen. Cells: uniform, scanty cytoplasm, occasionally multinucleated. Immunostaining: CD34, CD99, sometimes EMA or SMA.
3915.original_caption: Super fi cial acral fi bromyxoma (digital fi bromyxoma). The stroma is variably myxoid and fi brous with wiry collagen fi bers. The cells are uniform with scanty cytoplasm, and occasionally multinucleated. Immunostaining may be positive for CD34, CD99, and sometimes epithelial membrane antigen or smooth muscle actin

3927.caption: Atypical vascular lesion. Deeper areas show capillary clusters. No cytologic atypia.
3927.original_caption: Atypical vascular lesion. Deeper parts of the lesion show clusters of capillary vessels. There are no atypical cytologic features

3921.caption: Silicone granuloma with multinucleated foreign body giant cells, fibrosis, chronic inflammation
3921.original_caption: Silicone granuloma. Later stages are associated with multinucleated foreign body giant cells, fi brosis, and chronic in fl ammation

3916.caption: Intramuscular myxoma: uniform small spindle cells in myxoid stroma with slender collagen bundles, CD34+. Distinguish from myxofibrosarcoma (no nuclear atypia/mitoses) and fibromyxoid sarcoma (MUC4-, no translocation). Some have GNAS1 mutations.
3916.original_caption: Intramuscular myxoma. The lesion is composed of uniform small spindle cells randomly dispersed in myxoid stroma, with slender collagen bundles. The cells usually are CD34 positive. Some examples are more cellular; they may be distinguished from low-grade myxo fi brosarcoma by the absence of nuclear atypia and mitotic activity, and from low-grade fi bromyxoid sarcoma by lack of immunoreactivity for MUC4 and the absence of the speci fi c translocation of the latter. Some lesions have activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene

3913.caption: Extraskeletal mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, rare in soft tissue, common in bone. Primary sites: head, neck, nose, meninges, extremities. Small round cell tumor with hemangiopericytic pattern, cartilage foci. Expresses Sox9, a chondrogenesis regulator; true cartilaginous neoplasm.
3913.original_caption: Extraskeletal mesenchymal chondrosarcoma. This occurs more commonly in bone and rarely in soft tissue. Its primary sites are the head and neck, nose, meninges, and sometimes the extremities. It is a small round cell tumor with a hemangiopericytic pattern and dispersed foci of cartilage. This tumor expresses Sox9, a regulator of chondrogenesis, and is regarded as a true cartilaginous neoplasm

3926.caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Patch stage. Capillary proliferation around vessels & adnexa in reticular dermis with chronic inflammation
3926.original_caption: Kaposi sarcoma. Patch stage. Capillary proliferation around vessels and adnexa in reticular dermis with associated chronic in fl ammation

3923.caption: Tumoral calcinosis. Tissue reaction near calcified deposits: multinucleated giant cells, macrophages, fibrosis.
