3923.original_caption: Tumoral calcinosis. A tissue reaction often is seen adjacent to the calci fi ed deposits, with multinucleated giant cells, macrophages, and variable fi brosis

3920.caption: Giant cell fibro blastoma may recur as dermato fibrosarcoma; scattered multinucleated cells within spindle cells at infiltrating deep lesion aspect.
3920.original_caption: Giant cell fi broblastoma may recur as dermato fi brosarcoma, and the two patterns may be found in the same tumor, seen here as scattered multinucleated cells within spindle cells at the in fi ltrating deep aspect of the lesion

3928.caption: Atypical vascular lesion. SMA immunostain shows dilated vessels lack pericytes vs. adjacent normal vessels.
3928.original_caption: Atypical vascular lesion. Immunostaining for smooth muscle actin reveals that dilated vessels lack an outer pericytic layer in contrast to the positively stained adjacent normal vessels

3929.caption: Proliferative myositis: Fibroblastic proliferation in edematous stroma separates muscle fibers in checkerboard pattern. Benign self-limiting mass in large skeletal muscles, often post-trauma. Mostly adults, occasionally childhood.
3929.original_caption: Proliferative myositis. A fasciitis-like fi broblastic proliferation in edematous in fl amed stroma extends between and separates skeletal muscle fi bers in a checkerboard pattern. This is seen in the body of large skeletal muscles as a rapidly appearing but benign self-limiting mass that sometimes follows trauma. It arises mostly in adults but also may occur in childhood

3930.caption: Proliferative fasciitis, akin to nodular fasciitis, features ganglion-like cells with prominent nucleoli in clusters. Occurs in adults/children.
3930.original_caption: Proliferative fasciitis. This is similar to nodular fasciitis, with the addition of variable numbers of ganglion-like cells with occasionally prominent nucleoli arranged in clusters. It may occur in adults or children

3919.caption: Giant cell fibroblastoma, mainly in childhood. Multinucleated cells among spindle cells in fibrous/myxoid stroma, lining pseudovascular spaces. Shares genetic abnormality with dermatofibrosarcoma.
3919.original_caption: Giant cell fi broblastoma. These tumors occur mainly in childhood. Multinucleated cells are dispersed among spindle cells in fi brous or myxoid stroma, sometimes lining pseudovascular spaces. This tumor has the same genetic abnormality as dermato fi brosarcoma

3924.caption: Tumoral calcinosis. Hydroxyapatite deposits in fibrous tissue. Sporadic/familial disease with subcutaneous cystic lesions near joints/spine. Mimics calcareous lesions. May associate with hyperphosphatemia/scleroderma.
3924.original_caption: Tumoral calcinosis. Crystalline hydroxyapatite is present in irregular deposits in fi brous tissue. This is a sporadic or familial disease in which subcutaneous multilocular cystic lesions form around the joints or the spine. Appearances can mimic those of other calcareous lesions. It sometimes is associated with hyperphosphatemia or scleroderma

3931.caption: Intravascular fasciitis occurs in veins/arteries, causing distension. Lesional tissue infiltrates vessel wall/adjacent soft tissue or forms plexiform lesion. May recur if incompletely excised.
3931.original_caption: Intravascular fasciitis. Nodular fasciitis may occur within veins or, less commonly, within arteries, which become distended. The lesional tissue may in fi ltrate through the vessel wall and involve adjacent soft tissue, or it may grow within the vessels and form a plexiform lesion. This type of fasciitis may recur if not completely excised

3925.caption: Composite hemangioendothelioma, rare lesion in extremities/oral cavity, mixed vascular components (epithelioid/retiform hemangioendothelioma, spindle cell hemangioma, lymphangioma, angiosarcoma). Local recurrence risk, rare metastasis. Case shows dilated angiomatous spaces (left) contiguous with spindle cell angiosarcoma.
3925.original_caption: Composite hemangioendothelioma. This is a rare lesion, occurring in the extremities or the oral cavity, with components of more than one vascular lesion. These may include elements resembling epithelioid hemangioendothelioma, retiform hemangioendothelioma, spindle cell hemangioma, lymphangioma, or angiosarcoma. There is a tendency for local recurrence and a small incidence of metastasis. In the case illustrated here, dilated angiomatous spaces ( left ) are contiguous with spindle cell angiosarcoma

3932.caption: Ossifying fasciitis. Metaplastic bone formation in nodular fasciitis. Fasciitis-like stroma without nuclear atypia excludes extraosseous osteosarcoma.
3932.original_caption: Ossifying fasciitis. Metaplastic bone formation is an unusual feature in some examples of nodular fasciitis. The typical fasciitis-like stroma and absence of nuclear atypia help exclude the diagnosis of extraosseous osteosarcoma

3922.caption: Silicone granuloma, iatrogenic lesion from silicone leakage (e.g., breast prosthesis/cosmetic enhancement). Variably sized spaces mimic fat/lipoblasts, may contain refractile material.
3922.original_caption: Silicone granuloma. This is an iatrogenic lesion associated with leakage of silicone from a prosthesis (e.g., in the breast) or following cosmetic enhancement at other sites. There are variably sized spaces (sometimes containing refractile material) mimicking fat and lipoblasts

3934.caption: Cellular schwannoma with foamy macrophages in lesion.
3934.original_caption: Cellular schwannoma. Clusters of foamy macrophages may be seen within the lesion

3933.caption: Melanotic schwannoma with pigment and psammoma bodies. S-100 and melanocytic antigens positive. Found in Carney complex, spinal nerve roots/autonomic ganglia. May recur/metastasize despite benign histology.
3933.original_caption: Melanotic schwannoma. These tumors contain variable amounts of pigment, and psammoma bodies also are a feature. Both S-100 protein and melanocytic antigens are demonstrable by immunohistochemical techniques. Pigmented schwannomas are found in the Carney complex and may occur in super fi cial and deep soft tissue and in viscera; typically, however, they involve spinal nerve roots or autonomic ganglia. Although they lack overt malignant histologic features, they may recur and metastasize, sometimes after a long interval

3941.caption: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Plump stellate/spindle cells, mild nuclear atypia.
3941.original_caption: Nasopharyngeal angio fi broma. Plump stellate and spindle cells show mild nuclear atypia

3945.caption: Ossifying fibromyxoid tumor. Cells show prominent nuclear membranes, scant clear cytoplasm, resembling glomus tumor.
3945.original_caption: Ossifying fi bromyxoid tumor. The cells may have prominent nuclear membranes and small amounts of clear cytoplasm, resembling the characteristics of a glomus tumor

3938.caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor with rhabdomyoblasts and adenocarcinomatous component (malignant glandular triton tumor)
3938.original_caption: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. This tumor displays a cluster of rhabdomyoblasts and also has an adenocarcinomatous component (malignant glandular triton tumor)

3942.caption: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma in adolescent males. Lesional cells in fibrous stroma with thin-walled blood vessels, incomplete smooth muscle layer.
3942.original_caption: Nasopharyngeal angio fi broma. This occurs in adolescent males in nasal and paranasal areas. Lesional cells are dispersed in fi brous stroma that contain variably sized thin-walled blood vessels with an incomplete smooth muscle layer

3939.caption: Circumscribed storiform collagenoma (sclerotic fibroma). Focally hyalinized collagen. Mucinous material between fibrous layers.
3939.original_caption: Circumscribed storiform collagenoma (sclerotic fi broma). The collagen is focally hyalinized. Stromal mucinous material is seen between the fi brous layers

3936.caption: Neuroblastoma-like schwannoma (neurilemoma). Small dark cells arranged in rosettes around eosinophilic material. S-100 positive. Benign subcutaneous nodule.
3936.original_caption: Neuroblastoma-like schwannoma (neurilemoma). Small darkly staining cells are arranged around fi brillary eosinophilic material in a rosette-like pattern. The lesion is diffusely immunoreactive for S-100 protein. This is a benign lesion that forms a subcutaneous nodule

3948.caption: Ossifying fibromyxoid tumor. Branching cords of cells in myxoid/fibrous stroma.
3948.original_caption: Ossifying fi bromyxoid tumor. Branching cords of cells in variably myxoid and fi brous stroma typically are seen

3940.caption: Circumscribed storiform collagenoma (sclerotic fibroma). Associated with Cowden syndrome, dermal lesion shows thickened collagen laminae with CD34+ fibroblasts.
3940.original_caption: Circumscribed storiform collagenoma (sclerotic fi broma). Associated with Cowden syndrome, this is a dermal lesion that displays thickened collagenous laminae with occasional CD34-positive fi broblasts

3937.caption: Malignant perineurial cell tumor: rare aggressive neoplasm with malignant spindle/polygonal cells, nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic activity. EMA+, S-100-. Diagnosis confirmed by electron microscopy.
3937.original_caption: Malignant perineurial cell tumor. This is a very rare and aggressive neoplasm composed of malignant spindle and sometimes polygonal cells that show nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity. The lesional cells express EMA and lack S-100 protein. The diagnosis can be con fi rmed by electron microscopy

3943.caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma with epithelioid morphology: sheets of vacuolated polygonal cells, granular cytoplasm. May express cytokeratin/Melan-A, mimic adrenal cortical carcinoma. Typical pleomorphic areas often contiguous with epithelioid regions.
3943.original_caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Rarely, an epithelioid morphology is seen with sheets of focally vacuolated polygonal cells, some of which have granular cytoplasm. These sometimes express cytokeratin or Melan-A and may be confused with adrenal cortical carcinoma. However, more typical areas of pleomorphic liposarcoma are present in other parts of the tumor and often are contiguous with the epithelioid areas

3951.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Fibroblastic spindle cells mixed with inflammatory cells, macrophages containing hemosiderin.
3951.original_caption: Myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma. Fibroblastic spindle cells are mixed with in fl ammatory cells and macrophages containing hemosiderin pigment

3944.caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma with sheets of abnormal lipoblasts. Distinguished from atypical lipomatous tumor by absent normal fat, and from round cell liposarcoma by nuclear pleomorphism.
3944.original_caption: Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Some specimens display sheets of abnormal lipoblasts. This lesion may be distinguished from an atypical lipomatous tumor by the absence of normal-appearing fat and distinguished from round cell liposarcoma by the degree of nuclear pleomorphism

3946.caption: Ossifying fibromyxoid tumor: small, rounded, uniform cells in sheets/nests. Immunoreactive for S-100, GFAP, sometimes SMA/desmin, some MUC4+. EP400-PHF1 fusion reported. Possible nerve sheath/chondroid/myoepithelial origin.
3946.original_caption: Ossifying fi bromyxoid tumor. The tumor cells are small, rounded, and uniform and arranged in sheets, nests, or fi les. They are immunoreactive for S-100 protein, GFAP, and less commonly, smooth muscle actin and desmin. Some are positive for MUC4. EP400 - PHF1 gene fusion has been reported, but the nature of the differentiation is unknown. Nerve sheath, chondroid, and myoepithelial lineages have been suggested

3935.caption: Cellular schwannoma: spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm in fascicles, no Antoni A/B patterns. Occurs in deep soft tissue (presacral, retroperitoneum, mediastinum, spinal nerve roots). May erode bone, can recur but no metastasis. Well-defined capsule with lymphoid aggregates. S-100 positive, lacks muscle markers.
3935.original_caption: Cellular schwannoma. Spindle cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm are arranged in fascicles without Antoni type A or B patterns. This variant arises in deep soft tissue, typically in the presacral area, retroperitoneum, or mediastinum, or from a spinal nerve root. It may erode vertebral bone; some examples recur but do not metastasize. Cellular schwannoma has a well-de fi ned capsule associated with lymphoid aggregates. The cells resemble those of smooth muscle but are diffusely positive for S-100 protein and lack muscle markers

3949.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Myxoid foci contain "pseudo-lipoblastic" vacuolated fibroblasts. These differ from lipoblasts by containing intracellular myxoid material resembling stroma, while lipoblastic vacuoles appear empty due to lipid dissolution during processing.
3949.original_caption: Myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma. The myxoid foci contain “pseudo-lipoblastic” vacuolated fi broblasts. These differ from lipoblasts in that they contain intracellular myxoid material resembling that of the stroma, whereas lipoblastic vacuoles appear empty because of the dissolution of the contained lipid during histologic processing

3947.caption: Ossifying fibromyxoid tumor: thick fibrous capsule, often with partial mature bone shell (80%). Mostly subcutaneous, firm rounded nodule, usually benign.
3947.original_caption: Ossifying fi bromyxoid tumor. This rare lesion has a thick fi brous capsule, which in about 80 % of cases contains a partial shell of mature bone. It occurs mostly in subcutaneous tissue as a fi rm, rounded nodule, and most lesions are benign

3952.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Atypical mononuclear, binucleated, or multinucleated cells with large nucleoli hallmark. Eosinophils, plasma cells prominent in inflammatory infiltrate. Some CD34+, lacking CD30/CD15. t(1;10)(p11;q24) rearrangement, FGF8/NPM3 deregulation.
3952.original_caption: Myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma. Atypical mononuclear, binucleated, or multinucleated cells with large nucleoli are a hallmark of this neoplasm. Eosinophils and plasma cells are prominent in the in fl ammatory in fi ltrate. Some examples are CD34 positive, but speci fi c immunohistochemical markers (including CD30 and CD15) are lacking. A speci fi c rearrangement t(1;10)(p11;q24) and deregulation of FGF8 and NPM3 have been described

3953.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Eosinophilic cytoplasm, distinct cell boundaries. Spindle & epithelioid variants share immunophenotype.
3953.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and distinct cell boundaries. Spindle and epithelioid variants have the same immunophenotype

3950.caption: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Larger myxoid foci, mimics myxofibrosarcoma but lacks widespread atypia/pleomorphism.
3950.original_caption: Myxoin fl ammatory fi broblastic sarcoma. This example shows larger myxoid foci and mimics myxo fi brosarcoma, but it lacks the more widespread atypia and pleomorphism of the latter

3958.caption: Intramuscular hemangioma with cellular capillary proliferation mimicking malignancy
3958.original_caption: Intramuscular hemangioma. This example has a cellular capillary proliferation that may be mistaken for malignancy

3961.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Slender elongated cells concentrically arranged around blood vessel.
3961.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The whorls are composed of slender elongated cells arranged concentrically around a blood vessel

3963.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma with heterologous mesenchymal elements. Neoplastic cartilage (chondrosarcoma) present; rhabdomyosarcoma foci possible.
3963.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Heterologous mesenchymal elements may occur in the dedifferentiated tumor. This image shows neoplastic cartilage (chondrosarcoma); foci of rhabdomyosarcoma also may occur

3956.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Rhabdoid and plasmacytoid cytomorphology present.
3956.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Rhabdoid and plasmacytoid cytomorphology can be seen in this example

3954.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. Cells may have clear cytoplasm. Formerly termed leiomyoblastoma.
3954.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, epithelioid. The cells sometimes have clear cytoplasm. This pattern was formerly known as leiomyoblastoma

3960.caption: Intramuscular hemangioma, cavernous variant with large thin-walled vessels.
3960.original_caption: Intramuscular hemangioma. The cavernous variant has large thin-walled vessels

3962.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma, low-grade. Pleomorphic spindle cells in fibrous stroma. Resembles fibromatosis/fibrosarcoma (β-catenin negative).
3962.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma with low-grade dedifferentiation. Mildly pleomorphic spindle cells are dispersed in fi brous stroma. This may resemble fi bromatosis (but b -catenin is negative) or low-grade fi brosarcoma

3959.caption: Angiomatosis of soft tissue. Capillary vessel clusters proliferate in/adjacent to thickened vein walls. Increased adipose tissue may be present.
3959.original_caption: Angiomatosis of soft tissue. Clusters of capillary vessels may proliferate within and adjacent to irregularly thickened walls of veins. A component of increased adipose tissue may be present

3957.caption: Angiomatosis of soft tissue: proliferations of well-formed medium-caliber vessels crossing anatomic planes, infiltrating subcutaneous fat, deep fasciae, and skeletal muscle.
3957.original_caption: Angiomatosis of soft tissue. Proliferations of well-formed vessels, usually of medium caliber, that cross anatomic tissue planes are termed angiomatosis . In this example, the lesion extensively in fi ltrates subcutaneous fat, deep fasciae, and skeletal muscle

3955.caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Small intestinal GISTs show skeinoid fibers: eosinophilic collagen deposits, PAS+ (diastase resistant). Ultrastructurally, tangled collagen fibrils resembling wool skeins.
3955.original_caption: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor. Amorphous eosinophilic collagen deposits, known as skeinoid fi bers, are seen in some small intestinal GISTs. They stain positively with PAS (diastase resistant), and ultrastructurally they are composed of tangles of collagen fi brils resembling a ball (skein) of wool

3967.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Multinucleated tumor cells, frequent mitoses (atypical forms), inflammation, necrosis.
3967.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fi brous histiocytoma). The cellular composition includes multinucleated tumor cells. There are frequent mitoses, including atypical forms, and in fl ammation and necrosis are additional common features

3964.caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. Some cases show meningothelial-like whorls of spindle cells around vessels, with metaplastic bone nearby. Cells positive for MDM2, CDK4, claudin-1, EMA, similar to perineurial cells.
3964.original_caption: Dedifferentiated liposarcoma. A few cases show meningothelial-like whorls of spindle cells around a blood vessel, often with metaplastic bone in the vicinity. The nature of these cells is unclear; immunohistochemical study is positive for MDM2 and CDK4 and also for claudin-1 and epithelial membrane antigen, as in perineurial cells

3972.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma. Tapered spindle cells with nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia.
3972.original_caption: Myxo fi brosarcoma. Tapered spindle cells show variable nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia

3968.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Tumor has pleomorphic polygonal/spindle cells in fascicular/storiform/random patterns. Term "malignant fibrous histiocytoma" is misnomer; cells are fibroblastic/myo fibroblastic.
3968.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (malignant fi brous histiocytoma). This tumor is composed of pleomorphic polygonal and spindle cells arranged in a fascicular, storiform, or random pattern. The term malignant fi brous histiocytoma , although widely established, is recognized as a misnomer; the cells are fi broblastic and myo fi broblastic

3969.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma. Myxoid foci merge with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma areas.
3969.original_caption: Myxo fi brosarcoma. The myxoid foci merge with areas of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma

3970.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma. Epithelioid variant: polygonal cells, prominent nucleoli, myxoid stroma.
3970.original_caption: Myxo fi brosarcoma. The rare epithelioid variant shows polygonal cells with prominent nucleoli in myxoid stroma

3965.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Osteoclast-like giant cells show uniform small nuclei vs tumor giant cells (lower right) with irregular chromatin. Osteoclastic cell (center) phagocytosing tumor cell nucleus.
3965.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell malignant fi brous histiocytoma). The nonneoplastic osteoclast-like giant cells have numerous uniform small nuclei and differ from tumor giant cells ( lower right ) that have enlarged nuclei with irregular chromatin. One of the osteoclastic cells ( center ) appears to be phagocytosing a tumor cell nucleus

3973.caption: Cellular angiofibroma: uniform cells, bland slender nuclei, mast cells present. Spindle cells CD34+, desmin-. Resembles spindle cell lipoma; both share 13q14 deletion, RB1 loss.
3973.original_caption: Cellular angio fi broma. The cells are uniform with bland slender nuclei. Mast cells are seen. The lesional spindle cells generally are immunoreactive for CD34 and negative for desmin. There are resemblances to spindle cell lipoma, and both entities have similar genetic features, with deletion at 13q14 and loss of RB1 gene

3966.caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell malignant fibrous histiocytoma). Features resemble usual undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma plus osteoclast-like giant cell foci.
3966.original_caption: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with giant cells (giant cell malignant fi brous histiocytoma). This tumor has features similar to those of the usual undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with the addition of foci of osteoclast-like giant cells

3977.caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Stellate/spindle cells in collagenous stroma.
3977.original_caption: Fibroma of the tendon sheath. Stellate and spindle cells are sparsely distributed in a collagenous stroma

3980.caption: Synovial sarcoma: biphasic type with mucin-secreting glands in spindle cell stroma, lacking nuclear pleomorphism
3980.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. The classic biphasic synovial sarcoma has mucin-secreting glands dispersed within cellular spindle cell stroma that lacks nuclear pleomorphism

3978.caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath: circumscribed lesion, digits, multinodular. Peripheral slit-like vessels, hypocellular area adjacent to cellular focus.
3978.original_caption: Fibroma of the tendon sheath. This is a circumscribed lesion mainly involving digits that may be multinodular. Peripheral slit-like blood vessels are present, and a hypocellular area is seen adjacent to a more cellular focus

3976.caption: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Cellular area resembles nodular fasciitis, seen in early stages. t(2;11)(q31-32;q12) rearrangement, similar to desmoplastic fibroblastoma.
3976.original_caption: Fibroma of the tendon sheath. The more cellular area resembles nodular fasciitis and is seen more typically in earlier stages. A t(2;11)(q31-32;q12) rearrangement has been described similar to that seen in desmoplastic fi broblastoma

3975.caption: Fibromatosis colli. Fibrous tissue infiltrates sternomastoid muscle fibers. Late stage shows hypocellular fibrosis. Tumor in newborns, may follow trauma, self-limiting, often regresses. β-catenin IHC negative.
3975.original_caption: Fibromatosis colli. Cellular fi brous tissue in fi ltrates fi bers of the sternomastoid muscle. This image shows a late stage of the disease with hypocellular fi brosis. The tumor occurs in newborns, sometimes follows trauma, is self-limiting, and often regresses. Immunohistochemistry for b -catenin is negative in nuclei

3982.caption: Synovial sarcoma. Many show hemangiopericytomatous pattern.
3982.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. Many examples have a prominent hemangiopericytomatous pattern

3974.caption: Superficial cervicovaginal myofibroblastoma. Rare subepithelial cervical/vaginal lesion with spindle/stellate cells in myxoid stroma. Deeper areas more cellular/fascicular with collagen bundles. Immunoreactive for desmin/CD34, less for SMA.
3974.original_caption: Super fi cial cervicovaginal myo fi broblastoma. This rare subepithelial cervical or vaginal lesion has spindle and stellate cells in a myxoid stroma. Deeper parts of the lesion are more cellular and fascicular, with admixed collagen bundles. The cells are immunoreactive for desmin and CD34 and less frequently for smooth muscle actin

3971.caption: Myxofibrosarcoma, formerly myxoid malignant fibrous histiocytoma, is an extremity tumor in older adults. Forms multinodular unencapsulated subcutis mass, may invade deep soft tissue. Frequently recurs as higher-grade (grade progression) and metastasizes. Worse prognosis with deeper/higher-grade tumors.
3971.original_caption: Myxo fi brosarcoma. This tumor, lower grades of which equate to the formerly termed myxoid malignant fi brous histiocytoma, is typically a tumor of the extremities in older adults. It forms a multinodular unencapsulated mass, most often in the subcutis, although it may extend through deep fascia and involve deep soft tissue. Myxo fi brosarcoma frequently recurs, often as a higher-grade tumor (a phenomenon known as grade progression), and may also metastasize. The prognosis is worse in deeper tumors and those of higher histologic grade

3981.caption: Synovial sarcoma, monophasic spindle cell variant: uniform short spindle cells, dark nuclei, minimal cytoplasm, scant stroma with mast cells.
3981.original_caption: Synovial sarcoma. The monophasic spindle cell variant is made up of closely packed fascicles of uniform short spindle cells with darkly staining nuclei and minimal cytoplasm. The stroma is minimal but contains numerous mast cells

3979.caption: Primary pulmonary myxoid sarcoma: lung parenchyma/endobronchial tumor. Uniform spindle/epithelioid cells in myxoid stroma. t(2;22)(q33;q12) EWSR1-CREB1 fusion (shared with clear cell sarcoma/angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma). No specific immunophenotype. Low-grade malignancy
3979.original_caption: Primary pulmonary myxoid sarcoma. This is a recently described entity that occurs in the lung parenchyma or endobronchially. Cords or nests of uniform spindle or epithelioid cells are arranged in a myxoid stroma. This tumor is characterized by t(2;22)(q33;q12) rearrangement with EWSR1 - CREB1 gene fusion, a feature also found in some clear cell sarcomas and angiomatoid fi brous histiocytomas. There is no speci fi c immunophenotype. The tumor is of low-grade malignancy, and a few cases have metastasized

3984.caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. Cells show pleomorphic nuclei, mitotic activity, amphophilic cytoplasm.
3984.original_caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. The cells have mildly pleomorphic nuclei with mitotic activity and abundant amphophilic cytoplasm

3989.caption: Synovial chondromatosis. Large joints (knee, hip, elbow, shoulder, TMJ). Hyaline cartilage nodules form under synovium, may detach as loose bodies.
3989.original_caption: Synovial chondromatosis. This occurs in large joints, especially the knee, hip, elbow, and shoulder and also the temporomandibular joint. Variably sized nodules of hyaline cartilage form beneath attenuated synovium. These may break off and form loose bodies in the joint

3988.caption: Synovial chondromatosis: well-differentiated cartilage, minimal atypia, possible binucleated cells, nuclear pleomorphism, calcification/ossification. Rare myxoid chondrosarcoma association.
3988.original_caption: Synovial chondromatosis. The cartilage is well differentiated and mostly lacks cytologic atypia, although binucleated cells and mild nuclear pleomorphism may be seen. Calci fi cation and ossi fi cation also may occur. Rarely, myxoid chondrosarcoma may arise in synovial chondromatosis

3983.caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma, initially termed fibroma-like epithelioid sarcoma variant, later epithelioid sarcoma-like hemangioendothelioma. Multifocal tumor affecting skin/deep soft tissue, mainly extremities. Microscopy shows plump spindle cell cords/fascicles. Prone to local recurrence, rarely metastasizes vs typical epithelioid sarcoma.
3983.original_caption: Pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. This entity was fi rst described as a fi broma-like variant of epithelioid sarcoma, subsequently as epithelioid sarcoma-like hemangioendothelioma, and most recently as pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma. It often is seen as a multifocal tumor involving skin and deep soft tissue, mainly of the extremities. Cords or fascicles of plump spindle cells may be identi fi ed microscopically. This tumor is prone to local recurrence but less likely to metastasize than the usual epithelioid sarcoma

3987.caption: Well-differentiated chondrosarcoma with atypical cells in chondroid matrix. May represent soft tissue extension from primary bone tumor or heterologous component of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, MPNST, or carcinosarcoma (müllerian/renal/bladder origin).
3987.original_caption: Well-differentiated chondrosarcoma. Atypical cells are seen within a chondroid matrix. This represents soft tissue extension from a primary bone chondrosarcoma but also may occur as a heterologous component of dedifferentiated liposarcoma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, or carcinosarcoma, including those of müllerian, renal, or urinary bladder origin

3986.caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma. Lobules with spindle cells, slit-like lumina. CD34/CD31/FLI1/D2-40+, GLUT1-. Vacuolated epithelioid cells, hyaline globules, hemosiderin, microthrombi.
3986.original_caption: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma. The lobules contain fascicles of short spindle cells with slit-like lumina. Capillary endothelial cells are positive for CD34, CD31, FLI1, and D2-40 and negative for GLUT1. Other features include small nests or glomeruloid clusters of vacuolated epithelioid endothelial cells, some with hyaline globules or hemosiderin, and microthrombi

3990.caption: Malignant solitary fibrous tumor: cellular spindle cell sarcoma, fascicular architecture, mitotic activity, variable CD34 immunoreactivity.
3990.original_caption: Malignant solitary fi brous tumor. This is a cellular spindle cell sarcoma with fascicular architecture and mitotic activity. CD34 immunoreactivity may be retained or lost

3985.caption: Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma: dermal/subcutaneous lesion in children/adults, intravascular growth with lymphatic endothelial immunophenotype. May have adjacent lymphangiomas/lymphatic vessel clusters. Previously termed malignant endovascular papillary angioendothelioma of childhood, but recent cases show no recurrence/metastasis.
3985.original_caption: Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma. This is a dermal or subcutaneous lesion of children or adults, with intravascular growth of cells that have a lymphatic endothelial immunophenotype. Some have adjacent lymphangiomas or clusters of lymphatic vessels. The earlier terminology was malignant endovascular papillary angioendothelioma of childhood , but in a more recent series, reported cases did not recur or metastasize

3993.caption: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. Fasciitis-like pattern with loose whorls of cells in inflamed myxoid stroma.
3993.original_caption: In fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor. A fasciitis-like picture, with loose whorls of cells in in fl amed and myxoid stroma, is another characteristic pattern that may be seen focally

3991.caption: Solitary fibrous tumor with giant cells (giant cell angiofibroma). Variant has cells with multiple dark nuclei, may line pseudovascular spaces. No prognostic significance.
3991.original_caption: Solitary fi brous tumor with giant cells (giant cell angio fi broma). This variant has few or many cells with multiple darkly staining nuclei, which sometimes line pseudovascular spaces. The feature is of no prognostic signi fi cance

3992.caption: Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor, mainly in abdomen/viscera of children/young adults. Composed of uniform spindle cells expressing smooth muscle actin, mixed with inflammatory cells (plasma cells predominant).
3992.original_caption: In fl ammatory myo fi broblastic tumor. This tumor occurs predominantly in the abdomen or viscera in children or young adults. It is composed of fascicles of relatively uniform spindle cells that express smooth muscle actin, with an admixture of in fl ammatory cells in which plasma cells predominate

3996.caption: Chondroid lipoma: benign tumor with adipose/chondroid differentiation. Circumscribed, common in extremity subcutaneous tissue, more frequent in females. Vacuolated cell clusters in mature adipose tissue.
3996.original_caption: Chondroid lipoma. This is a benign tumor with features of both adipose and chondroid differentiation. It is a circumscribed lesion that is most common in subcutaneous tissue of the extremities and occurs more frequently in females. Clusters of vacuolated cells are seen within mature adipose tissue

3994.caption: Chondroid lipoma: vacuolated cells form nests with uniform nuclei, S-100+. Features t(11;16)(q13;p12-13) rearrangement causing C11orf95-MKL2 fusion oncogene.
3994.original_caption: Chondroid lipoma. The vacuolated cells form nests and have uniform nuclei with well-de fi ned cell membranes. The cells are S-100 protein–positive. Chondroid lipoma is characterized by a t(11;16) (q13;p12-13) chromosomal rearrangement, resulting in C11orf95MKL2 fusion oncogene

3995.caption: Lipoblastoma. Myxoid areas merge into differentiated adipose tissue. Older lesions have mature fat, lobular architecture persists. 8q11–13 rearrangements affect PLAG1 gene.
3995.original_caption: Lipoblastoma. The myxoid areas merge into foci of differentiated adipose tissue. Older lesions consist mostly of mature fat, although the lobular architecture persists. Genetically, there are 8q11–13 rearrangements affecting the PLAG1 gene

4000.caption: Ewing sarcoma with Homer-Wright rosettes in tumor cell sheets.
4000.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. Some examples have Homer-Wright rosettes, seen here as paler areas dispersed within the sheets of tumor cells

3998.caption: Ewing sarcoma. Rosettes formed by tumor cells surrounding fibrillary cores, no central lumen.
3998.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. The rosettes are formed by tumor cells surrounding fi brillary cores that have no central lumen

4002.caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. Proliferating vessel clusters in dermis. Ulceration may cause edema/inflammation, resembling pyogenic granuloma.
4002.original_caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. Clusters of proliferating vessels are distributed within the dermis. Ulceration may result in edema and in fl ammation, giving the lesion the appearance of pyogenic granuloma

4001.caption: Ewing sarcoma: aggressive neoplasm with patternless sheets of uniform dark-staining cells, minimal intercellular reticulin; similar appearance across sites.
4001.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. This is an aggressive neoplasm composed of patternless sheets of uniform darkly staining cells with no or minimal intercellular reticulin. The appearances are similar regardless of site

3999.caption: Ewing sarcoma: rounded nuclei, vesicular/speckled chromatin, scanty cytoplasm, frequent mitoses
3999.original_caption: Ewing sarcoma. The cells have rounded nuclei with vesicular or speckled chromatin, scanty cytoplasm, and frequent mitoses

3997.caption: Lipoblastoma,常见于婴幼儿，偶见于青年。多部位发病，呈分叶状，含胚胎脂肪样组织、血管黏液梭形细胞区及脂肪母样细胞。随时间分化成熟。
3997.original_caption: Lipoblastoma. Lipoblastoma most commonly occurs in infancy and childhood but rarely may be seen in young adults. A variety of sites may be affected. It is a lobulated tumor that resembles embryonic fat, with vascular myxoid spindle cell areas with lipoblast-like cells. The tumor differentiates or matures over time

4007.caption: Fibroepithelial polyp. Multinucleated cells at superficial lesion margin.
4007.original_caption: Fibroepithelial polyp. Multinucleated cells typically are present at the super fi cial margin of the lesion

4003.caption: Cavernous hemangioma: ill-defined dermal cluster of thin-walled vascular channels with recent thrombus.
4003.original_caption: Cavernous hemangioma. This is an ill-de fi ned dermal cluster of thin-walled vascular channels, some of which contain recent thrombus

4005.caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. Intravascular extension may occur, including with preexisting benign vascular lesion/malformation.
4005.original_caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. Intravascular extension sometimes is seen, including in association with a preexisting benign vascular lesion or malformation

4004.caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. Lesion occurs on digits/mucosae, may follow trauma or recur with satellites. Distinct lobular architecture: capillaries proliferate around larger vessel. Endothelial cells lack multilayering/atypia.
4004.original_caption: Lobular capillary hemangioma. This lesion commonly arises on the digits and mucosae. It sometimes may appear following minor trauma, and it may recur with satellite lesions. The lobular architecture is distinctive. Proliferating capillaries are arranged around a largercaliber vessel. Endothelial cells lack multilayering and atypia

4006.caption: Angiomyofibroblastoma. Circumscribed lesion beneath vulvar epithelium, most common site; also in vagina, paratesticular, inguinal in males.
4006.original_caption: Angiomyo fi broblastoma. This is a circumscribed lesion, seen here beneath the epithelium of the vulva, which is the most common site, although it also has been described in the vagina and in paratesticular and inguinal locations in males

4012.caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma). S-100+ Schwann cells in myxoid stroma. EMA+ perineurial cells at lobule periphery.
4012.original_caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma). The lesion contains S-100 protein–positive Schwann cells in myxoid stroma. EMA-positive perineurial cells are sometimes identi fi able at the periphery of the lobule

4014.caption: Palisaded myofibroblastoma. Amianthoid fibers, thickened collagen bundles, distinctive tumor feature.
4014.original_caption: Palisaded myo fi broblastoma. Amianthoid fi bers, which are irregular formations of thickened collagen bundles, are a distinctive feature of this tumor

4008.caption: Fibroepithelial polyp, pseudosarcomatous variant. Atypical/multinucleated cells scattered. Normal/atypical mitoses possible.
4008.original_caption: Fibroepithelial polyp, cellular pseudosarcomatous variant. Cells with atypical or multinucleated cells are scattered throughout the lesion. Normal and atypical mitoses may be present

4016.caption: Lipoma with myxoid change, seen in typical lipomas. Differs from myxoid liposarcomas with plexiform vascular pattern and lipoblasts.
4016.original_caption: Lipoma with myxoid change. This stromal change sometimes is seen in otherwise typical lipomas. They differ from myxoid liposarcomas, which have a plexiform vascular pattern and contain lipoblasts in various stages of differentiation

4011.caption: Plexiform neurofibroma, pathognomonic for NF-1, shows expanded nerve trunks with interstitial myxoid material and increased cellularity. Enlarged nerves fold complexly, with gradual transition to MPNST.
4011.original_caption: Plexiform neuro fi broma. This lesion is pathognomonic of NF-1 and includes nerve trunks that are expanded by increased interstitial myxoid material as well as increased cells. The enlarged nerves fold into a complex pattern. There often is a continuous range of appearances within a lesion, with gradually increasing cellularity and transition to MPNST

4015.caption: Palisaded myofibroblastoma. Uniform, slightly wavy nuclei. Interstitial erythrocyte extravasation, resembles Kaposi sarcoma. Cells express SMA, lack endothelial markers and HHV8.
4015.original_caption: Palisaded myo fi broblastoma. The cells have uniform, slightly wavy nuclei, and there is interstitial extravasation of erythrocytes, imparting a resemblance to Kaposi sarcoma. However, the cells express SMA and lack endothelial cell markers and HHV8

4009.caption: Fibroepithelial polyp of lower female genital tract. Cellular polypoid lesion with fibromyxoid stroma, hyperplastic squamous epithelium. Lesional cells express desmin, not myogenin. Occurs in vagina, vulva, cervix; may appear during pregnancy.
4009.original_caption: Fibroepithelial polyp of lower female genital tract. A moderately cellular polypoid lesion with fi bromyxoid stroma is covered by hyperplastic squamous epithelium. The lesional cells often express desmin but not myogenin. These polyps occur in the vagina and sometimes the vulva or cervix and may appear during pregnancy

4017.caption: Fibrolipoma. Collagenous bands divide tumor into lobules with prominent fibrosis.
4017.original_caption: Fibrolipoma. Fibrosis often is prominent as collagenous bands divide the tumor into lobules

4019.caption: Lipoma with bone. Heterologous benign mesenchymal elements like bone, cartilage, or smooth muscle (myolipoma). No atypia.
4019.original_caption: Lipoma with bone. Heterologous benign mesenchymal elements such as bone, cartilage, or smooth muscle (myolipoma) may occur. No atypical features are seen

4013.caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma). Schwann cells show spindled, vacuolated, epithelioid morphology with multinucleated cells and syncytial-like clusters.
4013.original_caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma). The Schwann cells have a spindled, vacuolated, or epithelioid morphology, including multinucleated cells and syncytial-like clusters

4010.caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma), preferred term over cellular neurothekeoma. Affects young adults, mainly extremities/hands. Circumscribed multinodular tumor with S-100+ Schwann cells (spindled/vacuolated/epithelioid), multinucleated cells, syncytial clusters. May have EMA+ perine
4010.original_caption: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma (neurothekeoma). The term neurothekeoma has been applied both to this tumor of the nerve sheath type and to cellular neurothekeoma, a fi brohistiocytic lesion that does not show evidence of nerve sheath differentiation. For this reason, the term nerve sheath myxoma is preferred. It is a lesion of young adults that predominates in the extremities, especially the hands, and is uncommon in the head and neck or trunk. The tumor is circumscribed with a multinodular architecture and comprises S-100 protein–positive Schwann cells with spindled, vacuolated, or epithelioid morphology, including multinucleated cells and syncytial-like clusters. EMApositive perineurial cells are sometimes identi fi able at the periphery of the lobule

4018.caption: Lipoma with extramedullary hemopoiesis. Consider hematologic disease like myelofibrosis. Fatty tumors with hemopoietic component termed extra-adrenal myelolipoma.
4018.original_caption: Lipoma with extramedullary hemopoiesis. This is an occasional fi nding, but the possibility of hematologic disease, such as myelo fi brosis, should be considered. Fatty tumors with a prominent hemopoietic component have been termed extra-adrenal myelolipoma

4022.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma with prominent myxoid change.
4022.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. This is a rare example showing prominent myxoid change

4020.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma: bland cells with indistinct margins, may mimic reactive/granulomatous lesion.
4020.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. The cells may look very bland and have indistinct cell margins. This sarcoma may be mistaken for a reactive or granulomatous lesion

4023.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. Lesional cells border necrotic zone, mildly pleomorphic, abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
4023.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. The lesional cells, here seen bordering the necrotic zone, are mildly pleomorphic with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm

4025.caption: Reticulohistiocytoma. Histiocytes show ground-glass cytoplasm. Multinucleated cells with peripheral nuclei. Inflammatory infiltrate: eosinophils, mast cells.
4025.original_caption: Reticulohistiocytoma. The histiocytes have fi nely granular (ground-glass) cytoplasm. The multinucleated cells have mainly peripheral nuclei, and the in fl ammatory in fi ltrate includes eosinophils and mast cells

4024.caption: Reticulohistiocytoma: solitary/multiple dermal nodules in adults. Multicentric form may show fever, weight loss, polyarthritis. Histiocyte infiltrate with multinucleated cells and inflammation.
4024.original_caption: Reticulohistiocytoma. Mainly occurring in adults, this is a solitary or multiple dermal nodular lesion. Multicentric reticulohistiocytosis may present accompanied by fever, weight loss, and polyarthritis. There is a sheet-like in fi ltrate of histiocytes, including multinucleated cells, with in fl ammatory cells

4021.caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. Diffuse cytokeratin positivity distinguishes from cytokeratin-negative granuloma annulare/nonneoplastic lesions. Positive markers: epithelial membrane antigen, CD50% cases. Most INI-1 negative due to 22q loss.
4021.original_caption: Epithelioid sarcoma. Diffuse cytokeratin positivity is a feature. This allows distinction from granuloma annulare and other nonneoplastic lesions that are cytokeratin negative. Other positive markers include epithelial membrane antigen and CD34 in about half the cases. Most epithelioid sarcomas are INI-1 negative in relation to loss of 22q chromosomal material

4028.caption: Benign cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma). Symmetrical dermal lesion, epidermal hyperplasia, moderately demarcated deep aspect.
4028.original_caption: Benign cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma (dermato fi broma). This low-magni fi cation view shows a symmetrical cellular dermal lesion. There is overlying epidermal hyperplasia, and the deep aspect is moderately demarcated

4026.caption: Xanthoma: lipidized histiocytes in skin/soft tissue/tendons, uniform cells with vacuolated cytoplasm, may have giant cells, hemosiderin, cholesterol clefts, occurs with/without hyperlipidemia.
4026.original_caption: Xanthoma. Collections of lipidized histiocytes termed xanthomas may arise in skin or super fi cial soft tissue but also may involve tendon sheaths. The cells are uniform and have clear or fi nely vacuolated cytoplasm. They sometimes are associated with multinucleated giant cells, hemosiderin, and cholesterol clefts. Xanthomas may arise in patients with or without hyperlipidemia

4027.caption: Plexiform xanthoma. Xanthomatous nodules in dermis/superficial subcutis, unencapsulated. Common near knee/elbow joints.
4027.original_caption: Plexiform xanthoma. Nodules of xanthomatous tissue are dispersed in the dermis and super fi cial subcutis. The lesion is not encapsulated and usually appears near the knee or elbow joints

4029.caption: Benign cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma). Thick peripheral collagen bundles infiltrated by lesional cells.
4029.original_caption: Benign cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma (dermato fi broma). Typically, thick peripheral collagen bundles in fi ltrated by lesional cells may be seen

4032.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. Pleomorphic nuclei, indiscernible cytoplasm.
4032.original_caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. The cells have pleomorphic nuclei and indiscernible cytoplasm

4030.caption: Cellular cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma). Extends into subcutaneous fat septa. More common in males, may recur if incompletely excised. Rare lung metastasis.
4030.original_caption: Cellular cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma (dermato fi broma). Lesional tissue extends radially into interlobular septa in subcutaneous fat. This is more common in males and may recur, especially if not completely excised. Rarely, metastasis occurs, including to the lung

4033.caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Infiltrate of small lymphocytes, mixed B-cell and T-cell, characteristic of this neoplasm.
4033.original_caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. An intimate in fi ltrate of small lymphocytes, which are a mixture of B-cell and T-cell types, is characteristic of this neoplasm

4031.caption: Benign cutaneous fibrous histiocytoma (dermatofibroma). Lesional cells have scanty cytoplasm, ovoid nuclei (folded/wrinkled/reniform). May contain Touton giant cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages (foamy/siderophages), hemorrhage, fibrosis. Histologic variants exist (e.g., clear cell) but behaviorally similar.
4031.original_caption: Benign cutaneous fi brous histiocytoma (dermato fi broma). The lesional cells have scanty cytoplasm and short ovoid nuclei that sometimes appear folded, wrinkled, or reniform. Appearances may be modi fi ed by the variable presence of Touton-type giant cells (with a peripheral “wreath” of nuclei); lymphocytes; plasma cells; macrophages, including foamy cells and siderophages; and hemorrhage and fi brosis. Predominance of one element and variation in cytoplasmic appearance, such as clear cell change, have allowed identi fi cation of numerous histologic types, which are, however, not behaviorally separable

4034.caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Tumors involve lymphoid/soft tissue (oral cavity, pharynx, neck, axillae, breast, lung, mediastinum, stomach, colon, mesentery). May arise from hyaline-vascular Castleman disease. Shows whorls/sheets of uniform cells with scattered lymphocytes.
4034.original_caption: Follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. Tumors of follicular dendritic cells involve lymphoid tissue but also may arise in soft tissue sites, including the oral cavity and pharynx, neck, axillae, breast, lung, mediastinum, stomach, colon, and mesentery. Some develop on a background of hyaline-vascular–type Castleman disease, including cases with hyperplasia and dysplasia of the dendritic cells. The tumor illustrated here has typical whorls and sheets of relatively uniform cells, with a sprinkling of admixed lymphocytes

4038.caption: Paraganglioma: neuroendocrine tumor, adrenal medulla (pheochromocytoma) or extraadrenal sites (carotid body, Zuckerkandl organ). Cells in nests with sinusoidal vascular pattern.
4038.original_caption: Paraganglioma. This is a neuroendocrine tumor that may arise in the adrenal medulla (as a pheochromocytoma), and in extraadrenal locations; it often is related to normal paraganglia, such as the carotid body or the organ of Zuckerkandl. The cells often are arranged in nests with a sinusoidal vascular pattern

4035.caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. S-100+ neoplastic cells. HMB45/Melan-A usually negative in spindled melanoma. Junctional activity often absent. May mimic malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (neurotropic, Schwann-like features).
4035.original_caption: Desmoplastic melanoma. Diffuse immunoreactivity for S-100 protein highlights the neoplastic cells. Melanocytic markers such as HMB45 and Melan-A usually are not detectable in spindled melanoma. Junctional activity is not always present in the overlying epidermis. This tumor may be indistinguishable from the super fi cial malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, especially because both also may be neurotropic and melanoma can show ultrastructural features of Schwann cell differentiation

4037.caption: Ectomesenchymoma: rare childhood tumor in head/neck, soft tissue, genitourinary tract. Contains ganglioneuroblastomatous and mesenchymal (often rhabdomyosarcoma, spindled/round cell) components. Ganglion cell present (center).
4037.original_caption: Ectomesenchymoma. This very rare childhood tumor arises in the head and neck, soft tissue, or genitourinary tract and has both ganglioneuroblastomatous and mesenchymal components. The latter component is most commonly rhabdomyosarcoma with spindled or small round cell morphology. Note the ganglion cell ( center )

4044.caption: Reticular schwannoma. Anastomosing cell files in myxoid stroma. Rare variant, mainly visceral, especially GI tract.
4044.original_caption: Reticular schwannoma. Anastomosing fi les of cells in myxoid stroma characterize this rare variant. It occurs mainly in visceral locations, especially in the gastrointestinal tract

4036.caption: Melanotic neuroectodermal tumor of infancy. Nests of small cells in fibrous stroma: neuroblastic (neural markers) and pigmented cytokeratin+ epithelial cells in gland-like structures. Rapidly growing, mainly head/neck in 1st year. 10-15% recur, few metastasize.
4036.original_caption: Melanotic neuroectodermal tumor of infancy. Characteristic are nests of small cells in a fi brous stroma. The cells are neuroblastic (expressing neural markers) or pigmented, cytokeratin-positive epithelial cells in gland-like structures. The two cell types may be admixed. This is a rapidly growing tumor, mainly in the head and neck in the fi rst year of life. About 10–15 % recur, but few metastasize

4048.original_caption: Scattered vascular spaces in a less cellular area of solitary fibrous tumor

4049.caption: Cellular solitary fibrous tumor w/ dense ovoid tumor cells
4049.original_caption: Cellular solitary fibrous tumor with a dense population of ovoid tumor cells

4047.caption: Granular cell tumor infiltrates irregularly into subcutaneous fat.
4047.original_caption: Granular cell tumor. The tumor infi ltrates irregularly into subcutaneous fat

4042.caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. Nests with rounded cells, central cohesion loss. Eosinophilic cytoplasm, multinucleated wreath-like cells. Tumor cells immunoreactive: cytoplasmic desmin, nuclear myogenin.
4042.original_caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. The nests contain rounded cells with central lack of cohesion. Some cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm, and multinucleated wreath-like cells are seen. The tumor cells are immunoreactive for desmin in cytoplasm and myogenin in nuclei

4050.caption: Granular cell tumor with overlying skin reactive changes (pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia)
4050.original_caption: Granular cell tumor with reactive changes in the overlying skin epithelium (pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia)

4039.caption: Ganglioneuromatosis: ganglion cells, Schwann cells infiltrate ileum mucosa/submucosa. Rare intestinal disease linked to MEN IIb, occasionally NF1.
4039.original_caption: Ganglioneuromatosis. Numerous ganglion cells and increased Schwann cells in fi ltrate the mucosa and submucosa of the ileum. This is a rare disease of the large or small intestine associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type IIb, and occasionally with neuro fi bromatosis type 1

4046.caption: Granular cell tumor in tongue, subepithelial lesion. Overlying squamous epithelium shows pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia, common with granular cell tumor.
4046.original_caption: Granular cell tumor. This is a lesion in the tongue that fi lls the subepithelial tissue. The overlying squamous epithelium shows pseudoepitheliomatousa hyperplasia, a frequent association with granular cell tumor

4040.caption: Spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, pediatric type. Rounded rhabdomyoblasts among spindle cells, resembling smooth muscle. Immunoreactive for desmin and myogenin. Occurs in paratesticular/head-neck regions, better prognosis than embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.
4040.original_caption: Spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, pediatric type. Large rounded rhabdomyoblasts are scattered among relatively uniform spindle cells with evident cytoplasm. There is a morphologic resemblance to smooth muscle, but the cells are immunoreactive for desmin and myogenin. This tumor type occurs in the paratesticular region or the head and neck in childhood or adolescents and carries a better prognosis than the usual embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma

4045.caption: Epithelioid schwannoma. Clusters of polygonal cells with adjacent spindle cell component. Atypical features (prominent nucleoli, mitotic activity) warrant further sampling to exclude malignant epithelioid schwannoma.
4045.original_caption: Epithelioid schwannoma. The lesion displays clusters and fi les of polygonal cells. There is an adjacent spindle cell component. Atypical features, such as prominent nucleoli or mitotic activity, should prompt further sampling to exclude malignant epithelioid schwannoma

4041.caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: tumor cell nests separated by fibrous bands, mainly in children/adolescents. 75% have t(1;13) PAX7-FOXO1 or t(2;13) PAX3-FOXO1. PAX7 may indicate better prognosis. Rare PAX3 rearrangements.
4041.original_caption: Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma. Nests of tumor cells are separated by variably cellular broad fi brous bands. This occurs in a variety of sites, mainly in children and adolescents. About 75 % of alveolar rhabdomyosarcomas have one of two translocations involving related genes: t(1;13)(p36;q14) with PAX7 - FOXO1 fusion or t(2;13)(q35;q14) with PAX3 - FOXO1 fusion. Those with PAX7 rearrangement have a better prognosis in some studies but not all. A small number of cases have rearrangements of PAX3 with other partner genes

4043.caption: Spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, adult type: high-grade fascicular spindle cell tumor, may show focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. Often requires desmin/myogenin staining for diagnosis. Differs from juvenile type, favors head/neck region.
4043.original_caption: Spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma, adult type. This is a highgrade fascicular spindle cell tumor that sometimes displays focal rhabdomyoblastic differentiation. However, many cases lack distinguishing features and require immunohistochemical staining for desmin and myogenin to establish the diagnosis. This tumor differs from the juvenile type of spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma and favors the head and neck region
